abstract: The Thirty-second Massachusetts Regiment arrived yesterday afternoon, per the Amboy route, and proceeded to the Battery. It was not known whether the command could be got off last night, but in all probability it will not leave until to-day. This regiment represents seven Massachusetts regiments consolidated with it, and numbers 830 men and officers, having served in the Third Brigade, First Division, Fifth Corps. The following is a complete list of the officers:

abstract: Coroner BARRETT has concluded the inquest upon the body of the unknown man who was found drowned in Newtown Creek, on Thursday night, by Sergt. SLOATE, of the Forty-sixth Precinct. No information as to his identity was elicited. The jury rendered a verdict of "Found drowned," having no evidence as to whether he committed suicide or not; although it is probable that he did, as the water was not deep enough for an accidental drowning, and there were no indications whatever of foul play.
lead_paragraph: Coroner BARRETT has concluded the inquest upon the body of the unknown man who was found drowned in Newtown Creek, on Thursday night, by Sergt. SLOATE, of the Forty-sixth Precinct. abstract: To-day Messrs. BROWN, DEVOE & KNAPP, the contractors for cleaning the streets of this city for ten years, at $500,000 per annum, commence operations. These gentlemen have no very heavy accumulations of filth to remove. The streets at the present time are cleaner, probably than they have been for a year or more. The very worst portions of the city, with few exceptions, are reported to be comparatively free from dirt to-day. City Inspector BOOLE has doubtless been making an effort to leave the streets in a tolerably cleanly condition to his successors. Last year $800,000 were expended in street cleaning, of which amount Mr. BOOLE claims that $150,000 were disbursed in removing the filth accumulated during the pendency of the Hecker injunction. Wages, horse feed, &c., are, however, now lower than they were then, and are still falling, so that the amount which the contractors are to receive may be considered as ample remuneration for the work to be done.

abstract: By resolution adopted by both Houses of the Legislature at Albany, prior to the adjournment, the Governor was requested to preside at a presentation of the flags of New-York regiments that might have returned home at that time. Gov. FENTON cordially acceded to the request, and on Tuesday next there will be an intermingling of flags and a reunion of their defenders that is not likely to be seen again. As it is impossible that representative officers of all the regiments who fought under these flags can be present, an excellent officer, and withal, well-chosen representative, in the person of Maj.-Gen. BUTTERFIELD, will be there on the occasion, who will no doubt do his devoir as a speaker as creditably and honorably as he did his devoir when meeting the enemies of the Union on the battle-field. The flags of some eighty regiments will be presented. It is almost certain that Gen. GRANT will be there; Gen. HOOKER is also expected, and Gens. SLOCUM and PECK have been invited, with many other officers of note. Officers and honorable members will be the guests of the Governor, who purposes to run them to Saratoga, where the day will be grandly closed by festivities commemorative not only of Independence Day, but of the capture of Vicksburgh by Unconditional U.S. GRANT.

abstract: Gen. ROSECRANS was serenaded at Llewellyn Park, Orange Mountain, N.J., on Thursday evening. The occasion was the departure of Gen. ROSECRANS for Nevada, where he goes on a visiting tour, having received a furlough of six months from the War Department. The serenade was accompanied by a brilliant soiree, given by the General's host, WM. HEGEMAN, Esq., and was highly successful throughout. Gen. ROSECRANS made a short speech, expressing his gratitude for the delicate compliment tendered him by the residents of Llewellyn Park.

abstract: Volunteer Committee; Report of
lead_paragraph: -- The array of figures presented in the interesting report of the Volunteer Committee is too formidable to be grasped in a cursory survey. But one or two salient facts may be noticed. The city and county contributed to the national army 116,382 men. Of these, 53,544 were raised without any bounty. The average of the terms of service was nearly two years and a quarter; and the average cost per man for those who received bounties, hand-money, and expenses of equipment, and Family Relief Fund was $463 80. The bounties amounted in all to $9,317,612; the premiums to $552,715. The expenses converted with the payment of bounties appear to be excessive -- $724,064 -- but, perhaps, all this outlay may have been necessary in keeping the Enlistment Bureau in operation. The expenses not connected with bounties reached the gross sum of $6,918,281; making the grand total expenditure no less than $17,512,673. A portion of this has been reimbursed from the National Treasury and by the State; and a claim is held for settlement, which, with the actual repayments, according to the report, will reduce the net outlay by the city and county, to $14,577,214. Whether the expenditure has been characterized by discretion and economy, it would be impossible to gather from the bald tubular statements before us. But this much is apparent, that no community in this or any other country ever taxed itself voluntarily in support of a national war with the same ungrudging liberality.

abstract: Representation and Negro Suffrage
lead_paragraph: Emancipation, by making an end of the three-fifths slave basis of the constitution, increases the representation of the South in the Federal Congress and the Electoral College thirteen votes, taking the last census and apportionment as the standards. One of the arguments most strongly urged by the advocates of immediate and universal freedmen suffrage, is that without this regulation, a vote in the South will have twice the political power of a vote in the North. While, under slavery, the Southern vote, cast by the white man, carried three-fifths more power than a northern vote, it would now, they say, carry five-fifths more. It is contended that the only way to prevent this is to dilute the power of each individual vote by converting the freedmen into voters.

abstract: Returning Reason in
lead_paragraph: The government has just been able to conclude two large purchases of coal by contract -- the one for the navy and the other for the army -- at the respective prices of $5 21 and $5 34 per ton. This is a hopeful sign for consumers generally. There is no reason why the retail price should be much higher than this. But it will be higher, doubtless, especially toward the Fall, when the consumption becomes greater. Prudent housekeepers, who can afford it, should look ahead a few months in securing their Winter supplies. They can now buy at about one-half what they had to pay five months ago. A word to the wise.

abstract: Lecture on Russian-America
lead_paragraph: Last evening, the distinguished savan, Prof. W.P. BLAKE, of California, read a very interesting paper before the Travelers' Club of this city, at their splendid suite of Club-rooms, No. 1 West Fourteenth-street. The subject of the Professor's lecture was a description of his explorations in Russian America, and some account of his views and opinions relating to the past section of territory known as Russian America.

abstract: METROPOLITAN POLICE MATTERS. -- Capt. FRANK C. SPEIGHT, a veteran policeman of twenty years' standing, having received leave of absence, will sail this morning for Europe, to be absent about two months. Capt. SPEIGHT bears a graceful letter of introduction from Superintendent KENNEDY to Inspector TANNER, of London...Commissioner MCMURRAY will strive to pay the members of the force their salary for the expired month of June on the 3d of July, if possible, so that the men can have the money for use on the 4th. To do this, twenty-nine days are to be counted, instead of thirty, as it is necessary to obtain certificates, that the men have performed the labor for which they are to be paid. In the first week of August, the extra day is to be allowed. Since the 1st of April, the department has experienced much difficulty in getting money with which to pay the men. Until recently, the Comptroller has obtained the funds for several months previous to October on scrip to be paid from taxes collected in October and November. This year capitalists have been unwilling to advance money on this scrip, as they can get a higher rate of interest on government securities. By direction of the Secretary of State, Treasurer MCMURRAY deposited the funds of the department in the Shoe and Leather Bank, and on the 1st of April Mr. MCMURRAY applied to that institution for a loan of $175,000 on the Comptroller's scrip, for the salary of the force. The bank refused to make the advance, and the department applied to several moneyed institutions without success. Mr. MOSES TAYLOR, President of the City Bank, was then applied to, and he advanced the sum required.

abstract: City Inspector's Annual Tour of the Streets
snippet: City Inspector's Annual Tour of the Streets
lead_paragraph: The City Inspector and several gentlemen connected with his department, accompanied by the representatives of the press, yesterday made their annual tour of the city to inspect the condition of the streets, so far as relates to their cleanliness. The party first visited the eastern side of the city, passing through Frankfort, Dover, Forsyth, Water, Rutgers, Baxter, Pitt, Broome, Mulberry, Bleecker, the Bowery, and First and Second avenues, and thence passed to the west side for the purpose of inspecting the swill-milk establishments and the abattoirs in Thirty-ninth-street. The route taken included the very worst portions of the city, so far as cleanliness is concerned, and where the rate of mortality ranges the highest. Dover-street, one of the first visited, was found to be quite as clean as Broadway is at the present time, notwithstanding the fact that the inhabitants are principally poor people. From Dover-street the party passed into Water-street, with its low groggeries and dance-houses, sailors' boarding-houses and junk shops. This street, from the constant traffic passing through it, is in very bad condition. The holes worn in the pavement allow the accumulation of stagnant water; but this can hardly be laid to the account of the City Inspector. Water and filth will accumulate in these holes in defiance of all efforts to keep the streets clean. From Water-street a visit was paid to Roosevelt-street, Oliver, Market, Gouverneur and Grand streets. The pavement in the last-named street is also in bad condition, and small pools of stagnant water were occasionally to be met with. Pitt-street was one of the dirtiest streets visited, but it is only fair to say that the filth appeared to be principally garbage, which had been thrown out very recently, and was not in a state of decomposition. Baxter-street was somewhat similar. The upper part of First and Second-avenues is occupied by the large iron firms, who appear to think that they have a prescriptive right to that portion of the streets in front of their premises. It is almost needless to say that, in front of these establishments, there were mounds of earth and ashes which render the streets in parts almost impassable. Those who place these obtructions there ought to be compelled to remove them forthwith. The western part of the city was next visited. A passing gl[???]ce was afforded at the swill-milk establishments, and at the bone and fat-boiling establishments in Abattoir-place, leading from Thirty-ninth-street. The gutters in Abattoir-place are filled with green stagnant water, and the fumes from the establishments are sufficient to sicken anyone coming within a mile of them. Fortunately, this neighborhood is not thickly populated; but will it be believed that similar establishments exist in Elizabeth-street, surrounded by crowded tenement-houses? In this street is a fat-boiling house, belonging to one of the wealthiest firms in the city, the fumes from which establishment are sufficient to nauseate the strongest stomach. The City Inspector has repeatedly called the attention of the Mayor and the Common Council to these nuisances, having no power whatever to remove them himself; but, from some cause or other, no action has ever been taken in the matter.

abstract: Released on Parole
lead_paragraph: -By order of Gen. DIX, Mr. OSBON, the naval reporter, who was imprisoned on a charge of giving information to the enemy, was yesterday morning paroled until the verdict of the court-martial is promulgated in general orders from Washington. It is understood that the verdict acquits Mr. OSBON of all the charges brought against him by the government, and that Gen. DIX has approved the finding of the court. Mr. OSBON has been deprived of his liberty since the 2d of July last. His health has suffered considerably during his incarceration.

abstract: RUNAWAY ACCIDENT. -- Yesterday noon, as Dr. OGLE, a veterinary surgeon of New-York, was riding up Montgomery-street, Jersey City, his horses took fright and dashed off at a furious rate. Just above Washington-street the light wagon came in contact with a dray, was partially demolished and Dr. OGLE was pitched out head first upon the pavement, and sustained a scalp wound. He was conveyed to a drugstore and the wound dressed. His injuries were not very serious.

abstract: Perspiring fellow-sufferer, we mean sweating citizen, was hot yesterday? We imagine a faint response, the last gasp of exhausted breath, which almost shapes the answer "Yes." Was it hot? Let the thermometer and the soda fountains answer. But...
lead_paragraph: Perspiring fellow-sufferer, we mean sweating citizen, was it hot yesterday? We imagine a faint response, the last gasp of exhausted breath, which almost shapes the answer "Yes." Was it hot? Let the thermometer and the soda fountains answer. But of what avail and of what profit is your thermometrical measurement? Does not science tell us -- and is not science infallible -- that the thermometer on a railway train, going fifty miles an hour, marks exactly the same figure as its fellow sweltering in the stationhouse? Of course; and you, reader, who gasp across the hot pavement at the foot of Whitehall-street, and think the shade of the ferry-house a great relief, are just as hot when spreading yourself on the bow of the Staten Island ferry-boat and cutting the waves at the rate of twenty miles an hour, as you were while searching for your dime in the crowd at the ticket gate. Of course, you think you are cool, but you are not -- or you ought not to be, for the thermometer says exactly the contrary.

abstract: BOARD OF FIRE COMMISSIONERS -- REMOVAL OF BELLRINGERS. -- A meeting of the Board of Fire Commissioners (E.D.) look place last evening at Firemen's Hall. The principal business transacted was the removal of two bellringers, THOMAS KIRKMAN and THOMAS AMES, both cripples, and the selection of two stalwart young men to fill their places. KIRKMAN, about eighteen months since, was fearfully burned while in the discharge of his duty at the old Bell Tower, which caught fire while he was arranging his lights. His injuries, although severe, have not prevented him from the performance of his duties faithfully since his recovery. The minority of the board express an intention of resigning, in consequence of what they characterize the heartless action of the majority in this matter. The facts in connection with this affair are stated as follows: A short time since there was an election for Clerk of the Board, (salary $500,) and the then incumbent found a majority of one against his reelection. (The board consists of five members.) A bargain, it is asserted, was then entered into with one of the majority, who agreed to vote for the reelection of the old clerk, (a man named DONEVAN,) provided the bell-ringers were removed and friends of his put in their places. The bargain was consummated, it is alleged, last night.

abstract: its Sufferings and its Glory
lead_paragraph: Henceforth, when we speak of the Army of the Potomac, it will be as of a thing of the past. Its immediate commander, Gen. MEADE, has issued a farewell order, in which he announces that, by command of the President, that army has ceased to exist. Its work is done, its record is closed, and now only its traditions and its history remain.

abstract: Trial of
lead_paragraph: Another scientific and interesting test has been given this week, under the auspices of Rear-Admiral GREGORY, showing the terribly destructive power of an implement of war which American genius has evolved during the rebellion -- the various specimens of percussion and submarine shells which have been extensively used in blowing up vessels, removing harbor and river obstructions, and adapted to torpedo-steamers, &c. -- the design and invention of Chief-Engineer WOOD, United States Navy. The torpedoes were placed on board of the United States torpedo-steamer Naubuc, which sailed from the Navy-yard on Tuesday, and anchored below Governor's Island, where the tests were made, in the presence of the following distinguished gentlemen: Rear-Admiral Gregory; A.A. Low, Esq., President of the Chamber of Commerce; Capt Bythssa, of H.B.M. Navy; Capt. Kichkin, Engineer in the Russian Imperial Fleet; Capt. Mordier, of the French navy; Commodore Ringgold, Capt. Warden, Chief Engineer Wood, the inventor, and others. Shells were exploded at the depth of 15 feet, and one from the bow, in the usual shape of a buoyant percussion shell, containing a charge of 60 pounds, which raised a large column of water, submarine shells, &c. This torpedo was exploded about one-quarter of a mile from the vessel, near Governor's Island, with terrible effect. The tests were most gratifying and successful, there being no failure in any case, the time occupied being but a very few minutes, dearly demonstrating the efficiency and destructive power of these torpedoes. One of the most accomplished men in the British Navy, Capt. BYTHESSA, said there could be no doubtof their efficiency.

abstract: Eckford vs. Newark
lead_paragraph: The first match this season between these clubs took place yesterday afternoon, on the Union Bull Grounds, Williamsburgh, quite a numerous concourse of spectators being present, among them a fair delegation of the lady friends of the Eckfords. The Newark Club had out their best team, with the exception of their catcher, and the Eckfords were strongly represented, although they were minus the services of JOSH SNYDER, a fine batsman and active fielder. The Eckford nine opened play with some very lively batting, something quite in their old style, while their fielding was excellent after the first inning, in which they had not their in-field as well placed as in the succeeding innings. The Newark party did not get well into their work until after the fifth inning, when the nine began to display the ability they evidently possess, their opponents having but little to boast of in regard to superior play, either in batting or fielding, as the score shows, for though in the first five innings the disparity in the score did not speak favorably for the Newarkers, in the last four innings the score showed a marked degree of improvement, the Eckfords only obtaining four runs. Several fine fly catches were made on both sides, but the best were taken by the Eckfords. The umpire kept the players well up to the mark in the observance of the rules, and the consequence was a fairly-played game. We give the score below:

abstract: On Thursday night patrolmen JOHN CROWN, LEWIS P. WATEHMAN, EVERETT B. DELANOY, JAMES CLINTON, JOHN QUINN, and EBENEZER LIDGATE, of the Eighth, Fifteenth, and Twenty-ninth Precincts, apprehended nine street-walkers, who, on appearing before Justice DODGE, yesterday morning, described themselves thus: "MINNIE MCGUIRE, of the town, 19 years of age, a native of Boston; KATE POLLOCK, dressmaker, 23 years of age, a native of Vermont; ANN WELCH, servant, a native of Ireland, 23 years of age; FLORA KEEP, 20 years of age, waiter in a concert saloon, a native of Ireland; EVA ELLIOTT, actress, 24 years of age, a native of London; KATE SHERWOOD, of the town, aged 22 years, a native of New-York; CATHARINE ELDER, of the town, 32 years of age, a native of Piedmont; AUGUSTA WENDOVER, 40 years of age, a native of Ireland; and ANN KELLY, a native of Ireland, aged 25 years." Several of the prisoners candidly admitted that they followed no useful occupation, and one said that she dwelt with her sister, in Sixth-avenue, and that her family were aware of her conduct in walking the public streets at night These arrests are the result of several raids which were undertaken by the police on Thursday night. The raids were abortive, because of the many like efforts which the police have recently made, particularly in the down-town-districte, and partially, perhaps, because the men who were sent out to capture street-walkers were those whose monthly day off came round yesterday.Men who were entitled to sleep from 6 P.M. until midnight on Thursday night, and who at that hour were required to go to post duty until 6 yesterday morning, then to go to court with their prisoners if any, or to their beds or elsewhere if they had no prisoners, were sent out in civilian attire to make prisoners of persons who, not recognizing them would not report them for neglect of duty. The only wonder is that they took a solitary offender. If the police authorities really wish to cleanse the city and fill Balskwell's Island, they have only to make a raid with officers in uniform in Broadway between East Houston and Broome street between 1 and 2 o'clock in the morning.

abstract: DEPARTMENT. -- Judge LEONARD, yesterday, delivered an opinion at Special Term of the Supreme Court, adverse to Messrs. GILES and JEREMIAH, who claim to be Commissioners of the Croton Board, under appointment of the Mayor and Common Council, and in favor of Messrs. STEPHENS and DARRAGH, the former incumbents. This decision of Judge LEONARD is not final, and the case will probably be taken on appeal to the General Term. It is sincerely to be hoped that a definite settlement of the difficulty will not be long delayed. As the case now stands the affairs of the Croton Department are at a dead lock. Its business includes a vast amount of detail that is inseparable from the comfort and health of the city. While the confusion continues all grading and paving of streets must cease; all guttering and draining be neglected; the sewerage take care of itself, and the network of water pipes be left to the tender mercies of corrosion and rust. Besides all this, the mechanics and laborers employed by the department are put to sad straits for want of their wages, and this last is not the least of the unfortunate state of the case.
lead_paragraph: DEPARTMENT. -- Judge LEONARD, yesterday, delivered an opinion at Special Term of the Supreme Court, adverse to Messrs. GILES and JEREMIAH, who claim to be Commissioners of the Croton Board, under appointment of the Mayor and Common Council, and in favor of Messrs. STEPHENS and DARRAGH, the former incumbents. This decision of Judge LEONARD is not final, and the case will probably be taken on appeal to the General Term. It is sincerely to be hoped that a definite settlement of the difficulty will not be long delayed. As the case now stands the affairs of the Croton Department are at a dead lock. Its business includes a vast amount of detail that is inseparable from the comfort and health of the city. While the confusion continues all grading and paving of streets must cease; all guttering and draining be neglected; the sewerage take care of itself, and the network of water pipes be left to the tender mercies of corrosion and rust. Besides all this, the mechanics and laborers employed by the department are put to sad straits for want of their wages, and this last is not the least of the unfortunate state of the case.

abstract: Admits that Slavery is Dead; in Favor of Free Labor
snippet: Admits that Slavery is Dead; in Favor of Free Labor
lead_paragraph: Gov. BRAMLETTE evidently does not belong to the Mallory school of fossils. He has his eyes open, and instead of butting his brains out against the solid facts of the day, he recognizes them, and governs himself accordingly. He very plainly tells the people of Kentucky that slavery is dead, and recommends that they at once proceed to install free labor in its place. This is sound sense. He does not stop to mourn over the dear departed, nor to quarrel with the manner of the taking off, but goes cheerfully to work to "bury his dead out of his sight," stow away the emblems of mourning, and urge his people to take their proper place in the ranks of the regenerated States. The Governor was more than kind to "the institution" during its mortal illness; but now that all is over, he presents a conspicuous example of common sense as well as loyalty -- an example that the bats, of whom Mr. MALLORY is such an excellent specimen, would do well to follow. It should also be noted that the sometime head and front of rebellion in Kentucky, Gov. BERIAH MAGOFFIN, has come out emphatically for free labor; he, too, has taken a deliberate look at the defunct institution, and counts it past doctoring -- its eyes are set. MAGOFFIN was one of the loudest and most active of the pro-slavery zealots, and did, perhaps, more than any other Kentuckian to drive that State into the secession conspiracy. The failure was from no fault of his, for he worked with almost superhuman energy to achieve success. When such high priests in the Southern ranks come over to the side of freedom and loyalty, we may reasonably look for an early stampede of their so long deluded followers.

abstract: Their Satisfactory Aspect
lead_paragraph: The steady rise of our bonds in the European market, and the enlarged demand that has recently sprung up for them there, is an evidence of the satisfactory relations of European goverments with our own. It was feared, for a time, that the Mexican enlistments in this city, fictitious though they were known to be here, might lead to remonstrances on the part of France, and our credit was in consequence for a short time unfavorably affected: but the speedy and complete collapse of the entire movement, and the prompt action of the Government in preventing the sailing of a suspicious vessel from San Francisco, quickly restored confidence abroad.

abstract: We call the attention of concert-goers to the complimentary concert to be given this evening, for the benefit of a deserving soldier, Mr. J.W. GOUGLER, who was wounded at the battle of Honey Hill, Ga. Mrs. MOZART, Messrs S.B. MILLS, GEO. W. MORGAN, and JULES G. LOMBARD are among the artists who have volunteered their services for the occasion. The character of the performers and the object of the concert should insure a good house, even in this sweltering weather. Mr. GOUGLER has just published a new song, entitled the "Deserted Rebel Mansion," the merits of which are in keeping with the rest of his productions. He will open the concert himself.

abstract: Morgue to be Established in New-York
snippet: Morgue to be Established in New-York
lead_paragraph: We are glad to notice that the matter of establishing aproper receptacle for the remains of the unknown dead is at last receiving the attention of the authorities. The subject was yesterday under consideration by the Board of Supervisors, and also by the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections. The necessity for such an establishment has long been felt. Last year, the records of the coroner's office showed that no less than three hundred interments of unknown people had been made at Potter's Field. This is an appalling and a shameful fact Scarcely a day passes that we do not report some unfortunate "found drowned," and the publicity thus given by the journals to such events, has been the sole opportunity afforded the friends of missing persons for gaining information. A small and very inconvenient dead-house at Bellevue Hospital has been hitherto the only place of temporary deposit for those dead taken from the rivers and out of the streets, and often it has been absolutely necessary to remove remains from this over-crowded receptacle before a reasonable time had elapsed to claim or recognize them.

abstract: On the 22d ultimo Charles SCHWEIGER, a boarder at JOHN ROHN's saloon, at No. 95 East Fourth-street, was stung under the right eye by a large fly, which flew from the carcass of a bullock in his slaughter-house, in First-avenue. The wound being intensely painful, SCHWEIGER went home, and, his face swelling, arnica was applied, but without affording relief. The sufferer lay in torture until Thursday night, and then died, as a jury say, of "poisoning from the bite of a fly." The deceased, who was a native of Germany, was 40 years of age.

abstract: Kirkland, Hon. C. P., on the War
snippet: Kirkland, Hon. C. P., on the War
lead_paragraph: Hon. C.P. KIRKLAND has just published in a pamphlet of twenty pages, an elaborate and able discussion of the treatment to be extended to rebels individually, and also the mode of restoring the rebel States to the Union. It is marked by very full legal knowledge, and by a clear application of legal principles to the several branches of the topics discussed. Mr. KIRKLAND deems it important to carry into full effect the law of treason, in the cases of the leading agents of the rebellion, and that confiscation and disfranchisement should be inflicted as just penalties upon large numbers who acted with them. Concerning the other branch of the subject, Mr. KIRKLAND maintains that the rebel States have never been out of the Union, and that the constitutional rights of the States must be maintained inviolate. He holds that the National Government has no control over the question of negro suffrage, and that this matter may be safely left to the future population of the rebel states.

abstract: The members of this healthy and hearty society gave their annual "Pic-nic and Summer Night's Festival" at Lion Park, on Thursday last. Lion Park is located on One Hundred and Tenth-street, between Eighth and Tenth avenues. It is approached most, readily from the first-named thoroughfare, where the care are always to be found. Mr. PAUL FALK has recently become the lessee of the park and its surroundings. He has constructed an open-air concert hall of huge dimensions and elegant design. There is nothing like it in America. Here, then, twice a week, concerts are given under the direction of Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, and here, too, all the first-class German festivals take place. It would be difficult to imagine a more delicious spot. Occupying very high ground it possesses the great advantage of being always cool. At night-time, when it is lighted up with innumerable gas-lamps, the spectacle is almost fairy-like. This was especially the case on Thursday last, when, in addition to Mr. FALK's preparations, the members of the Arion Society exerted themselves to make their festival and the place in which it occurred beautiful. The hall and grounds were decorated with variegated lamps, arbors, evergreens, &c. The exercises commenced early in the afternoon, and terminated late the next morning. They included a grand vocal and instrumental concert, under the direction of Mr. THEODORE THOMAS; a series of comic processions -- satirizing the political and social events of the day; a fine display of fireworks, and lastly, but not leastly, a grand ball. The best of temper prevailed. Nothing indeed could have been more orderly or enjoyable. The fun was kept up, as we have before remarked, unflinchingly until decent business hours on Friday; the Eighth-avenue cars running all night for the accommodation of the visitors.

abstract: -The preparations for the celebration of the Fourth have nearly been completed in this Diserict, and the exercises will be of a magnificience and character never heretofore attempted by the staid citizens of the Burgh. At daylight a salute of thirty-six guns will be fired, followed by the ringing of bells. At 10:30 A.M., a meeting of citizens will take place in the chapel of the Ross-street Church. The following gentlemen will deliver addresses: Rev. E.S. Porter, D.D., Richard H. Huntly, Esq., Rev. E.W. Bliss, Rev. C.S. Pomeroy, Rev. A.H. Partridge, Rev. Charles H. Payne, Rev. J.T. Wilson. At 4:30 P.M., exercises under the direction of the Citizens' Committee, of which Hon. WM. WALL is chairman, will take place at the First Presbyterian Church, corner of South Fourth and Sixth streets. D.L. NORTHRUP, Esq., will read the Declaration of Independence, and Rev. E.S. CANFIELD will deliver the oration. The Churches of St. Vincent de Paul and St. Mary will celebrate the day by a pic-nic. In the evening every householder is invited to illuminate. The Germans of the Sixteenth Ward, it is understood, will have a grand procession and put lie meeting in Dutchtown, in which some thirty societies will take part.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, GOTLEIB SCHTETZER, a youth of sixteen, accidentally shot himself in the left thigh while playing with a pistol in his room, at No. 105 1/2 Lewis-street. He was taken to the New-York Hospital. Dr. JOHNSON thinks that the wound must prove mortal....RICHARD DONOVAN, a child of five years, lost a foot yesterday afternoon, having been run over near Eldridge-street by car No. 5 of the East Broadway and Canal-street line. The little sufferer was taken to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: The Eighth Vermont Veteran Volunteers arrived in this city on Friday evening, and left immediately for Burlington. The Eighth was mustered into the service at Brattleboro, Vt., for three years, from June 1, 1861, becoming a veteran organization in the Winter 1863. The regiment was mustered out near Washington June 28, 1865, and is to be discharged and paid off at Burlington, Vt. Until the Summer of 1864 the regiment served in the Department of the Gulf, and was in all of the leading battles under Gen. BANKS, viz: Bisland, Colton, Pleasant Hill, Port Hudson.
lead_paragraph: The Eighth Vermont Veteran Volunteers arrived in this city on Friday evening, and left immediately for Burlington. The Eighth was mustered into the service at Brattleboro, Vt., for three years, from June 1, 1861, becoming a veteran organization in the Winter 1863. abstract: -Among the paroled rebel soldiers who came up on the steamer Lady Gay on Tuesday, was a man a little over seven and a half feet in heighth. He started out with the Missouri troops at the commencement of the war, and stuck to them until the "dog was dead" and never received a scratch. Soon after he was mustered into the rebel service the regiment to which he belonged appeared before the Colonel on dress parade, and the colonel, who prided himself on the fine appearance and good size of his men, cast his eyes slong the line, with a smile of self-satisfaction until they rested on the towering form of the tall Missourian, when he knit his brows, and called out in fiercely thunder tones, "Get off that stump, you impertinent scoundrel, or I'll order you under arrest." The soldiers looked at each other, wondering what the Colonel meant, but no one moved. Finding his authority treated with disrespect he fairly boiled with rage, and advancing to the big soldier, he exclaimed, "What in the devil are you standing on?" The soldier respectfully replied. "On my feet, Colonel." The Colonel was completely taken back, as he surveyed this tall specimen of humanity from head to foot in blank amazement; he mumbled an apology for his rude remarks and hastened away, leaving his men convulsed with laughter. "Get off that stump" became a by-word with the Missouri rebels, and it will no doubt live as long as the long Missourian, -- Cairo Democrat.

abstract: About two months ago a young girl of pleasing looks and address arrived in Cleveland from New-York. At first she obtained a position as a waitress in a hotel, and afterward took charge of the cigar stand at the Varieties, a concert saloon of that name in Cleveland. There her good looks and winning ways obtained her numerous customers, and she drove a thriving business. In many cases her fascinated patrons refused to take any change, and thus "Miss ADDIE" for that was her name -- throve apace in her own right, and managed to pick up any amount of pin money. ADDIE's admirers, from the first, were numerous; but eventually they beseiged her in droves, so that often the cigar stand would prove more profitable than the stage itself. She was an accomplished coquette, and thus had a smile for each and every one of the crazy crew at her feet. Her smiles were by no means confined to the young, for gray hairs were found worshipping at her shrine as often as the fair locks of youth. Among those who wooed her were old bachelors, Young America, and men of family and widowers, and brainless fops, and boys whose chins had not even made the acquaintance of down. And the attentions to which she was treated were by no means confined to the wordy class. No, indeed; substantials in abundance fell to her lot. Old Mr. So-and-so gave her a now silk dress, and "old batch" So-and-so presented her with several dozen pairs of pocket-handkerchiefs, and fast Mr. So-and-so sent her two pairs of silk gaiters and a few pairs of Alexander's best, while Master So-and-so gave her an order for a new bonnet. Then, too, scarcely a day passed that she was not taken out to ride behind a pair offset nags, with all the usual accessories of ice cream, strawberries and cream, Roman punch, &c. Thus things west on -- from the time of her appearance at the Varieties -- in this roseate way, until a few days ago, when the astounding discovery was made that "Miss Addle" was a man! Of course, the manager and her crowd of admirers were both astounded and inclined to doubt their senses; but in spite of all, it turned out that she was not a woman, but that he was a man. The young man stated that, for fourteen years, he had worn the garb of a woman, in which guise his fair and pleasing looks had materially assisted him. In fact he looks as much like a woman when in male attire as when dressed in bonnet and gown. In New-York he played the part of a "pretty waiter girl" at a Broadway Varieties, remaining there till waiter girls were, "crushed," when he went to Cleveland. Since the discovery of his ruse, he has gone upon the stage, and appears each evening at the Varieties in "part first."

abstract: On the afternoon of Tuesday, ADELBERT STONE, a student of the Yale Scientific School, was drowned while bathihg in the Connecticut River, at Haddam. He, with some eighteen or nineteen students, were at Haddam, in company with Professors DANA and BRUSH, engaged in making geological examinations. Several of the students went in bathing, among whom was STONE. Two of them swam across the river, and, upon returning, met young STONE near the middle of the river, also attempting to cross. They passed him, when, as they neared shore, some of their friends motioned them back, but not understanding their signs they kept on until they reached shore, when they found that the young man STONE was seen to go down. They immediately returned to the spot, but could not discover any signs of him. Efforts were instantly made to recover his body, which had proved at last advices unsuccessful, although it was thought that they would yet result in finding the remains. It was thought that the deceased had been taken with a cramp and immediately sank, Young STONE is from Cleveland, Ohio, where his parents, who are people of considerable wealth, reside. He was about 21 years of age, an only son, and a young man highly respected and esteemed by his teachers and classmates. -- New-Haven Journal, June 29.

abstract: EIGHTH WARD SCHOOL MATTERS. The Board of Education, having promised the Eighth Ward a new school edifice, to take the place of the Clark-street Grammar School (No. 38,) the Trustees of that ward met on Friday evening present, Messrs. JOHN R.  RUSSELL, MATTHIAS CLARKE, THOMAS T. EVERETT, Dr.  JOHN AIKEN, Jr., and Dr. FRANCIS FLEET to consider the subject of an available and appropriate site.
lead_paragraph: EIGHTH WARD SCHOOL MATTERS. -- The Board of Education, having promised the Eighth Ward a new school edifice, to take the place of the Clark-street Grammar School (No. 38,) the Trustees of that ward met on Friday evening -- present, Messrs. JOHN R. RUSSELL, MATTHIAS CLARKE, THOMAS T. EVERETT, Dr. JOHN AIKEN, Jr., and Dr. FRANCIS FLEET -- to consider the subject of an available and appropriate site. Two sites are offered, namely: One known as the King-street Church property, where the trustees may secure a lot 100x100 feet, costing about $50,000: the other on Macdougal-street, looking down King-street -- lot 125x100 feet -- to cost about the same sum. A committee was appointed to ascertain precisely what terms can be made with the owners of this property, and to report at the next meeting of the Board of Education. The Eighth Ward Trustees contemplate the erection of one of the largest and finest school houses in the city. This new building is to take the place of the old Clark-street Grammar School, (No. 38,) an edifice that has been twenty years in use, and Dr. J. ELIAS WHITEHEAD, a graduate of the Eighth Ward schools, who has been principal of the school from the day of its foundation, is to have the principalship of the new school. It is proposed to consolidate the colored schools of the Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Wards, and to put the pupils therein under the roof of the old Clark-street edifice, thus giving colored pupils better and more commodious quarters than they now enjoy. The school authorities contemplate a change in the evening schools, whereby all girls shall be sent to one school and all boys to another.

abstract: C.C. CLAY has been taken sick; his imprisonment is evidently telling on his health. Dr. BANCROFT attends him. The doctor is doing all he can to restore the prisoner's health. He is suffering from no particular disease, but is laboring under general physical prosrtation or debility.

abstract: One of the four officers of the City Hall Police that had been assigned the duty of street-car inspection,reports that between the 4th of March and the 30th of June, the City Railroad Companies on the east side would have paid the city $202.850 in fines it they had been mulcted in $50 for every car that was run wihout license. If the other three car inspectors each found as many unlicensed cars running on the west side, the total bill which Capt. BRACKETT's men have run up against the city railroads, and which the city authorities may collect if they are so disposed, is nearly a $1,000,000 within four months.

abstract: Dry Dock car No. 5,432 and car No. [???] of the Bleecker-street line, passed Tryon-row [???] precisely 8 yesterday morning, both having aboard the usual morning and evening load of 5,678 passengers. The Dry Dock driver was about a length ahead. Seeing this, the Bleecker-street man whipped up and gained on the Dry Dock vehicle, and when the two passed the Tammany Hall crossing they were abreast; but the betting was on the Dry Dock man, the bystanders evidently imagining that he had loitered merely to give his horses rest, for he now spurred up, and when half-way down Park-row was at least a length ahead, and evidently would have won the race had not several apple-women, two or three drays and a dozen or more Express reporters fallen under the wheels and retarded the car a moment. That moment was fatal; it gave the Bleecker-street car the race in one minute and four-and-a-quarter records. We will thank Capt. BRACKETT, of the City Hall Police, to keep Park-row clear of pedestrians hereafter, so that there may be no impediment to the races.

abstract: Nurses; Order of Merit Suggested for; Order of Merit for Army Nurses Suggested
snippet: Nurses; Order of Merit Suggested for; Order of Merit for Army Nurses Suggested
lead_paragraph: Amid the reminiscences of the war now closed, the noble conduct of those women whose Christian deeds shed light on many a dark scene of suffering and death, will ever be conspicuous. It is not too much to say that thousands of our returning soldiers owe to them life itself. How many a couch has been cheered by their influence, how the passage of many a brave spirit has been calmed by their presence, we know. The bravery of these army nurses, their self-denying, long-suffering devotion to their country and her defenders, will never be forgotten. Every one of them a worthy compeer of FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE, shall they be less honored? Upon her breast was placed a jeweled badge by the hand of her Queen. Let the nation decorate those Queens of Mercy and Patriotism, who left luxurious homes and loving friends on the noblest errands of humanity the world exer saw.
headline: {'main': 'An Order of Merit for our Patriotic Women.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Order of Merit for our Patriotic Women.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as the train of cars on the Hudson River Railroad that left Peekskill at 3 P.M., was approaching Elvington near Sing Sing, the engineer discovered that the switch had not been turned, and although every effort was made to stop the cars it was found to be impossible, and in a few seconds afterwards the engine, tender and baggage and smoking cars were thrown from the track and fell into the river.
lead_paragraph: About 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as the train of cars on the Hudson River Railroad that left Peekskill at 3 P.M., was approaching Elvington near Sing Sing, the engineer discovered that the switch had not been turned, and although every effort was made to stop the cars it was found to be impossible, and in a few seconds afterwards the engine, tender and baggage and smoking cars were thrown from the track and fell into the river.

abstract: Some of the citizens of Richmond have taken the trouble to address President JOHNSON a petition asking that he will revoke the twenty thousand dollar clause of his amnesty proclamation, and a number of bankers doing business in the former rebel capital indorse the application, urging that business is paralyzed by the fear lest the property of those to whom an unconditional pardon is not extended may yet be confiscated. All concerned in this movement might employ their time to much better purpose. Let these thin-skinned gentlemen, who are fortunate enough to be possessed of more than $20,000, prefer their petitions for pardon to President JOHNSON according to the forms he has prescribed. All of them who deserve it will receive full absolution for past offences, in just about the length of time that it will take to get an answer to their unnecessary petition. Then business will revive rapidly enough.

abstract: Brackett and Briggs Horse Cruelty Case
snippet: Brackett and Briggs Horse Cruelty Case
lead_paragraph: About two weeks ago, Mr. EDWARD BRACKETT, of this city, mode a wager of $1,000 that his horse Lyon would trot from this city to Portland in one day -- that is, between the hours of sunrise and sunset. The animal is a black gelding, large and thin in flesh, weighs come ten hundred, stands sixteen hands high, is a little over ten years of age, and was raised in Maine. Since the race was arranged, it has excited a good deal of speculation among horse men in this city and vicinity, and considerable money has been wagered on the result, those well acquainted with the endurance of the animal being perfectly willing to invest their stamps in his favor. The horse was to go to harness, and it was expressly stipulated that he should travel the old stage road to the Forest City, the distance being computed to be about 116 miles. The attempt to drive a horse this distance in a single day, over a rough road, is, we believe, unprecedented, although several noted matches against time are fresh in our memory. Two or more horses in this country have accomplished the feat of trotting 20 miles in one hour, and a few years since a man undertook to drive a horse 100 miles in 10 hours, on one of the Long Island racing courses. The animal went some 98 or 99 miles well inside of time, but fell dead on the track with the feat so nearly accomplished. Mr. BRACKETT's horse had some minutes more than 15 hours to do the 116 miles, and previous to starting the odds were that the feat would be accomplished. Lyon was put in training ton days ago, and up to the day of the race easily did his exercise of Sixty miles per day.
headline: {'main': 'ATROCIOUS CRUELTY.; A Horse to Trot from Boston to Portland in One Day The Animal Dies Near the End of his Journey.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ATROCIOUS CRUELTY.; A Horse to Trot from Boston to Portland in One Day The Animal Dies Near the End of his Journey.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Not Come to Pass
lead_paragraph: The Boston Journal says: The black gelding Lion, Mr. BRACKETT's, driven on a wager that he would reach Portland between sunrise and sunset, 116 miles, an average of 7 miles an hour, was in sulky, FRANK BRIGGS in the chair. Mr. SHERBURNE SOMERBY, of Portsmouth, accompanied with another team, and Mr. CHAS. KIMBALL and a friend in a wagon with Wilton Maid, a sorrel mare, 850 pounds, as far as Portsmouth. The animal reached Portsmouth at 10:45, an average of nine miles an hour. Here he was sponged and refreshed and started again at noon. The poor animal was within six miles of Portland, with an hour and a quarter of time left, when he suddenly showed signs of great exhaustion, fell and died. This horse has been several times lately driven as much as 75 miles a day, merely for exercise, and it is thought that with an half hour's rest this side of Portland he might have gone through in time. He was worth several hundred dollars. There were, beside the original bet of $1000, many subordinate bets, pending in different quarters. The horse was 14 years old. We hope a similar cruel feat will not soon be attempted.

abstract: It has been decided by the vote of a large majority of the members of the Commercial Association doing business at the Produce Exchange to suspend all regular transactions in flour, grain, provisions, &c., at the Exchange on Monday next, July 3. This action, together with the resolutions of the Stock Boards, and all other financial and commercial centres to adjourn from Saturday afternoon, July 1, to Wednesday, July 5, will make Monday a holiday, as far as concerns wholesale trade down town. The Custom-house, Sub-Treasury and other United States offices, as also the banks and private banking-houses will, of necessity, be open on Monday, as it has not been made a legal holiday.

abstract: Crop Prospects, General View of
lead_paragraph: We have already reproduced enough from our exchanges to show that everywhere throughout our loyal land the husbandman will be greeted with the most generous harvest; and even in portions of that part of the republic so recently devasted by the war against treason and barbarism, there are indications of encouraging crops.Were we to call the roll of the States and inquire as to the crops, we should receive the same reply.

abstract: Cincinnati, Desperate Attempt on Conklin Bros. Bank
snippet: Cincinnati, Desperate Attempt on Conklin Bros. Bank
lead_paragraph: DAY. -- The Cincinnati Gazette, of Wednesday, says: "About noon, yesterday, two men entered the banking establishment of CONKLIN BROS. & CO., on the upper side of Third-street, near Main, and while one remained at the counter the other approached Mr. J.B. CONKLIN, one of the proprietors, who sat writing at a table on one side of the room, and inquired the price of gold. Mr. CONKLIN, who was the only one left in the office, his partners and clerks having gone to dinner, replied that he could not tell until his brother returned. At this instant the man, drawing a slung-shot, struck a heavy blow at the banker, who had turned once more to his writing; but the latter, throwing up his arm, warded off the blow from his head, and shouting for help, seized the office seal beside him, and struck at his assailant with all his might.

abstract: Colored People: Meeting on 4th July
lead_paragraph: It is reported that a good deal of excitement was aroused lately in Columbia, S.C., in reference to a mass meeting of the colored people of that vicinity. The meeting was only to make arrangements for a proper celebration of the approaching Fourth of July, and certainly if any one has a right to celebrate the day which gave to the world the immortal enunciation of the fundamental principle of the right of all men to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, the colored men of the South have it, if they only choose to exercise it.

abstract: -- The correspondent of one of the Boston papers writes from this city: "A cousin of JEFF. DAVIS has been in the city preparing for his trial. CHARLES O'CONOR is to have the lead of the defence. It is said he enters into it with great gusto, and intends to make it the leading forensic effort of his life. Sub rosa, quite a number of the prominent members of the bar are engaged on "points" which are to enter into the defence, two of which are these: First, That DAVIS owed allegiance to his State; her laws, her processes and commands must be obeyed; and if a collision exists between the State and General Government individuals cannot be punished -- it must be settled by the authorities. Second, That the Federal Government, by proclamations, by laws, by exchange of prisoners, &c., have recognized, over and over again, the rebels as belligerents, which entitles all the rebel government to the rights of belligerents."

abstract: Street-Cleaning Contractors' Card on Wages, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The contractors for cleaning the streets, Messrs. BROWN, DEVOE and KNAPP, commenced work with a small force yesterday morning. They do not anticipate any trouble in regard to obtaining laborers, not-withstanding the strike of the street-sweepers. They state that if unable to engage the requisite number of horses and carts they will purchase them, the government sales of horses affording them great facilities for so doing. Machinery, which is now employed in sweeping Broadway and Fifth-avenue, will gradually be introduced into the smaller streets. The contractors expert to employ between eight hundred and nine hundred laborers when their arrangements are perfected.

abstract: A short time ago a large quantity of alcohol and whisky, (valued, at nearly a million of dollars), was shipped from the factory at Peoria, Ill., to some dealers in this city, with a view, it was thought, of evading the revenue tax. The agent of the government at Peoria telegraphed to Collector SHOOK that the spirits were en route to New-York by the Erie Railroad.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Elm Park, Eighty-sixth-street and Eighth-avenue, was thronged by a happy crowd of "hoop-skirt hands" belonging to the manufactory of VICTOR FREUND. There could not have been less than two thousand persons present, and the day and evening were spent as pleasure-seekers usually do spend them. Dancing was a great feature in the programme, and the spacious platform was thronged by the votaries of Terpsichore, who whirled in the dizzy waltz and otherwise disported in the intricacies of cotillions, polkas and schottisches, to the great wonder of the spectators, who, remainining quiet, could scarcely keep cool. Mr. LOUIS M. COHEN, floor-manager, and Dodworth's Band exerted themselves to please those ambitious ones who wanted to dance, and evidently succeeded. A great deal of fun was observable among the various groups, and several amusing games were carried out. Messrs. THEODORE KOHN and JOHN FIELD, reception committee, were also indefatigable. Altogether the pic-nic was a success, and no rowdyism permitted, there being an adequate police force upon the ground.

abstract: -A morning paper has been expending its energies of late in trying to prove that JEFF. DAVIS was not taken disguised in his wife's apparel. On Friday it argued that the story was a fiction because it was destitute of proof, stale as a joke, and finally because it would not be very discreditable to DAVIS if it were true. This is very like the man who, when sued for damages by a neighbor, who charged that his dog had bitten him, urged as his defence, first, that his dog was a good-natured animal, and had never been known to bite; second, that he had lost all his teeth and could not have bitten the plaintiff, and third that he had no dog.
lead_paragraph: -A morning paper has been expending its energies of late in trying to prove that JEFF. DAVIS was not taken disguised in his wife's apparel. abstract: Any one who will look over the stock list and compare prices with what they were some nine months ago, will readily discover that immense sums of money have been lost. Some few, who early realized on their oil company shares, and at that time apparently made large fortunes, are well off if they put their oil profits into real estate, or the more substantial stock securities; but there were comparatively few of this character. Quite a number realized largely, but unfortunately, the great majority forgot the old saying, that the same individual is rarely, if ever, twice struck by lightning, or twice draws a capital prize in a lottery. They, too, generally put their first profits in again, grasping for a still larger return. The result is, they hold thousands of acres of barren lands, some few wells, irregular in their produce of oil, and a very considerable number producing no oil at all. The formation of companies and the traffic in shares are things of the past. Companies are now occasionally started, but there are no purchasers of shares. The business is utterly used up, Millions on millions of dollars as represented in paper shares of companies are swept from existence, and will never be heard of more in any tangible shape. The lands remain on which these corporations were formed, and whatever of value they possessed as oil producing territory is still in the earth, but the difficulty of reaching it, and the uncertainty of its amount when reached, re[???]s that capitalists have learned to measure by more practical tests than come from a lively imagination. The poetry of patro[???]m is last following the "[???] n[???]s." the "merino sheep." and "tulip" [???]s of other years. Not that we would be understood denying that there is oil in the earth in several parts of the country, or that it is of much value. It is of large value, and will pay w[???]l to produce it at reasonable prices for the land under which it is supposed to lie. By industry and the skillful use of machinery, a judicious boring for oil may be contained at a fairly remunerative business on the average. Like other pursuits, it will be attended with the usual vicissitudes and irregularities in results. Some, by steaks of good fortune, or by greater skill and economy, may realize fortunes, while others less skill[???] or less provident will lose. But whatever profit is realized in the business henceforth is to come from actual values. The sales of printed certificates at prices doubling at almost every turn, in many instances on erroneous, not to say designedly false, representations, have beggared many honest people, with little profit resulting to those who, in glowing circulars, set the tempting bait before them; for what the gamble gained them in one transaction they lost in another, so that there is little advantage, perhaps, from all that has been lost, beyond the fuller development of the trade years earlier than would have been the case, had not enterprise and speculation been so largely directed to it. The oil product is large, as the following comparison of production and average price of oil at the wells during each of the last four years shows:

abstract: We here present a list of all the complaints which were made before the commissioners, on Wednesday, with the record of every officer who appeared as defendant. The general reader will observe that the commissioners' decision is given in only a few cases; but their probable action may readily be guessed when we say that they ordinarily impose a fine of one day's pay by way of enforcing discipline, when it is shown that an officer has been guilty of a trivial offence, and that they number up the days in the ratio of the heinousness of the offence until they reach ten; but if an offender has wilfully committed a wrong requiring more than ten days' fine, they invite him to resign. It may be observed that the commissioners have gone first into one of their most cleanly station-houses to ascertain whether the new sanitrry rule is enforced, requiring policemen who have been sweltering several hours in the streets to change their linen on retiring. This is a necessary rule, which the commissioners have established for the benefit of the force. Yesterday's list of complaints is as follows:

abstract: Independence day will be celebrated in this city in a manner far surpassing any demonstration of the kind that has been witnessed here. The Common Council, determined not to be straitened for want of funds, have appropriated $20,000 for the purpose, nearly three times as much as has been heretofore expended by them in doing honor to the day. Our citizens naturally expect that for this large sum there shall be a display throwing all previous ones into the shade.

abstract: Surrender of
lead_paragraph: Gen. S.B. BUCKNER, who enjoyed the doubtful distinction of making the first surrender of a large army to the forces of the Union, namely, that of Fort Donelson, on the 16th day of February, 1862, to Brig.-Gen. U.S. GRANT, had also the additional celebrity of making the last surrender of a main army, during the war, to the same U.S. GRANT, this time Lieutenant-General, through the latter's efficient subordinate, Major-Gen. CANBY. The terms of this final surrender were arranged by BUCKNER at New-Orleans, on the 26th day of May.

abstract: From the hour of LEE's surrender it became apparent that we should have no guerrilla warfare in any of the disloyal States, from Virginia to Texas. The prompt, wise and careful posting of troops by government throughout the South, though once a necessary precaution, was seen to be no longer required. Our gallant troopers -- within a week of the capture of JEFF. DAVIS -- would have had to hunt, as for a needle in a haystack, to discover one rebel, in arms, of those hundred thousands who, last mid-Winter, defied the National authority. Musquitos will be the most blood-thirsty opponents our men henceforth will encounter, and "Johnny Rebs" will now be for all time a thing of story.

abstract: -A writer describing this military establishment observes: "During my visit I learned that since the war began over three thousand cannon have been manufactured here for our government -- the Parrott gun exclusively -- varying from those of the minium calibre to 300-pounders. These guns have done duty in our forts, on our gunboats, and in our grandly-moving armies, so sublimely sweeping through the hostile Southern States. One of these 300-pounders weighs twenty-six thousand pounds, or thirteen tons. One was being cast as I visited the place. It was a sight worth traveling hundreds of miles to see. These guns are submitted to the severest tests before turned over for service. The precipitate banks of Crow Nest are the target of the experimental trial, the distance fired being two thousand yards. Two huge bared spots, with deep indentures in the rocks, attest the accuracy of the range and force of the firing. At all hours of the day for the past four years the firing of these guns have awakened fearful echoes among these environing heights, oftentimes sounding like the roar of a terrible battle."

abstract: Fish and Fisheries
lead_paragraph: Fishing is an ancient and honorable occupation; an occupation from whose ranks some of the disciples of old were chosen to "preach the gospel to every creature;" on occupation whose followers since that period down to the days of the good, old, genial pious IZAAK WALTON, have been men of great moral character, of patience and watchfulness; have been men that disappointments never conquer; men of virtue and humility; and these truths the page of history has ofttimes recorded, and the melodies of music warbled to the world from the dim centuries of the present period. Have not the fishermen of "beauteous Naples" been made historically and operatically eminent?

abstract: We have no prevailing sickness in Charleston at the present time, and the indications are that we shall escape the yellow fever and other epidemic diseases this season. It is true, the weather is uncomfortably warm, and people feel languid, but so long as we escape contagious diseases, we have no reason to complain.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C., Saturday, June 24, 1865.

abstract: A correspondent writes that a rector of Wiltshire had an interview with CONSTANCE KENT. She was sitting at a table busily writing, and with several books open before her. She was dressed in mourning. She shook hands with the rector, and seemed perfectly self-possessed, hard and cold in her manner. On the rector asking her if she really believed in the power of a priest to grant absolution, she replied, "I do not feel sure that my sin is forgiven, for no one on this side of the grave can feel sure of that, not even the great apostle himself, for he said. Lest I am a castaway." On being asked on what she built her hopes of salvation, she said, "On Christ, and Christ alone." She seems ready to lie on the bed she has made without a murmur for herself or the expression of a regret. It is said that her friends have secured Mr. COLERIDGE, Q.C., as leading counsel to defend her, and that the point raised will be a special kind of insanity, or monomania, and that she is under the influence of hallucination in confessing that she was guilty of the murder.

abstract: Schutzen Corps left for Bremen
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the steamers Matlaman and Chicopee sailed from the dock of the Bremen Steamship Company, at Hoboken, and rushed forth into the river laden with a dense mass of perspiring humanity, green-clad riflemen and good wishes generally. The occasion of this very general exodus from New-York heat and dust was the sailing of a deputation of skilled marksmen from the New-York Schutzen Corps, delegated to represent the sharpshooting fraternity at the second grand Bremen rifle march. The New-York organization, it will be remembered. distinguished itself in the early part of June last, when the three days' festivities in Jones' Wood pretty conclusively demonstrated that there were good marksmen enough in the number to represent worthily the tolerably large fraternity of riflemen. The rapid manner in which the Schutzen Corps heartlessly demolished a large double headed Austrian eagle that had been erected as a target, was proof sufficient that they would have a fair chance at winning some of the laurels destined to grace the brows of the best marksmen. The Bremen Festival will commence on Sunday, July 16, and will come to a close on Sunday, July 23. None will be allowed to compete for the several minor prizes but members of the German Sharpshooters' Union and individual guests. These last, even, will be excluded from the competition for the two principal prizes. Upon the grounds will be erected a ball-room, an immense dining-room and a telegraph office. A daily journal will be published from the 13th inst. to the 24th, giving all information relative to the progress of the match. Dancing and instrumental concerts, by the band of the Hanoverian Hussars, will be features of the daily exercises. Riflemen from all parts of the world will be present, including this, the delegation from New-York, and representatives from St. Louis, Louisville and Milwaukee.

abstract: Revenue Case: The additional 50 per cent. duty
snippet: Revenue Case: The additional 50 per cent. duty
lead_paragraph: We give this morning an interesting decision in the United States Circuit Court, arising out of the resolution passed by Congress in April, 1864, increasing duties fifty per cent. for a short time. The resolution was passed on the 29th of April. On the evening of that day a quantity of teas arrived in this port by the ship Hamilla Mitchell, and on the next day the importers applied to enter them for consumption. During the early part of that day goods were allowed to be entered at the old rates, but when these importers applied to make entry of the teas, it had become officially known, and the Collector refused to allow their entry except on payment of the additional fifty per cent. The importers declined to pay, withdrew their entry under protest, and a day or two after entered their goods for warehouse.

abstract: Decline at Albany
lead_paragraph: -- We observe that the Albany market has experienced a heavy decline. Beef has fallen off nearly 1 1/2 cents a pound, and mutton the same. The Argus says, that butchers can afford to sell their best cuts at 20 cents. The wholesale top price is 8 1/2 cents. The New-York public will probably think it worth while to note these figures.

abstract: The maimed soldiers at Central Park Hospital will have a good time to-morrow. Col. COLYER has provided 15 omnibusses to take 150 of them and their medical officers on an early drive through Central Park, if permission of the Commissioners can be obtained, down to Madison-square in time to witness the military parade of the First Division N.Y.S.M. After the parade they will be taken to the City Assembly Rooms, whom a festival will be prepared in their honor. Rev. Dr. ADAMS will deliver an address; ROBERTSON's full band and the Union Glee Club furnish some fine music; and the Ladies of Rose Hill Relief Association will provide some ice-cream and fruit. They will be taken back to their quarters in the cool of the evening. Admission for the festival can only be obtained by tickets from Col. COLYER, No. 50 Howard-street.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths last week was 148, of which 40 were adults and 108 under 2 years of age. The principle causes were: Cholera infantum, 37; consumption, 15; convulsions, 9; inflammation of the brain, marasmus and dropsy, 6 each; debility, 5; inflammation of the lungs, typhoid fever and diarrhea, 4 each; scarlet fever and hooping-cough, 3 each; croup, diphtheria and small pox, 2 each; puerperal fever and cholera morbus, 1 each. Under one year of age, 68. Natives of the United States, 128, Ireland 7, Germany 6, England 5, Scotland 2.

abstract: On Abuse of Fire Department
lead_paragraph: The Board of Engineers and Foremen of the old (volunteer) Fire Department had a most important meeting Friday night, as will be seen by the detailed report given elsewhere. The question was as to whether they would disband at once or not, but it was finally decided to hold on until the 1st of August, by which time, we hope, the new commission will have got things in working order. There is not a very pleasant feeling in the old department on account of the causeless abuse and slanders of certain public journals; but we urge upon the old firemen the wisdom of doing their duty to the very last. They cannot afford to give way to their resentment to the peril of the property of the city that always treated them kindly. -- World.

abstract: EIGHTH WARD SCHOOL MATTERS. -- The Board of Education, having promised the Eighth Ward a new school edifice, to take the place of the Clark-street Grammar School (No. 38,) the Trustees of that ward met on Friday evening -- present, Messrs. JOHN R. RUSSELL, MATTHIAS CLARKE, THOMAS T. EVERETT, Dr. JOHN AIKEN, Jr., and Dr. FRANCIS FLEET -- to consider the subject of an available and appropriate site. Two sites are offered, namely: One known as the King-street church property, where the trustees may secure a lot 100x100 feet, costing about $50,000: the other on Macdougal-street, looking down King-street -lot 125x100 feet -- to cost about the same sum. A committee was appointed to ascertain precisely what terms can be made with the owners of this property, and to report at the next meeting of the Board of Education. The Eighth Ward Trustees contemplate the erection of the of the largest and finest school houses in the city. This new building is to take the place of the old Clark-street Grammar School, (No. 38,) an edifice that has been twenty years in use, and Dr. J. ELIAS WHITEHEAD, a graduate of the Eighth Ward schools, who has been principal of the school from the day of its foundation, is to have the principalship of the new school. It is proposed to consolidate the colored schools of the Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Wards, and to put the pupils therein under the roof of the old Clark-street edifice, thus giving colored pupils better and more commodious quarters than they now enjoy. The school authorities contemplate a change in the evening schools, whereby all girls shall be sent to one school and all boys to another.

abstract: Atlantic Cable; The Progress of
lead_paragraph: Our advices concerning the Atlantic telegraph are hopeful. The indications are that we will not have long to wait before the success or failure of the enterprise shall be determined. The last foot of the 7,000 tons of cable, which is to find a lodgment on the ocean bed, at a depth varying from 1,500 to 2,500 fathoms, was coiled on board the Great Eastern on the 22d ult. As early as Thursday or Friday of this week the mammoth ship is announced to leave for Valentia, on the Irish coast, where the massive shore end of the cable will have preceded her, and be ready for attachment to the main line, at a distance of twenty-five miles from the land.

abstract: the Prison at, Described
lead_paragraph: Let no one who has never visited this busy place imagine that he knows anything about it. For our part, we confess our total ignorance hitherto. We had heard of its stone walls, its lonely cells, its whitewashed corridors, its stone quarry and its shower-bath, but we were unprepared for a, township in extent, a concourse vast and numerous of population, business operations of great magnitude, discipline so rigid, punishments so terrible, possibilities for good or evil so fearful in their range, unlimited in extent and irresponsible, vested in weak human nature.

abstract: Ecclesiastical Question Not Settled
lead_paragraph: By last night's European mail, it appears that the question of ecclesiastical appointments, so long pending between the Papal Court and the King of Italy, has not yet been settled. The King refuses to have ecclesiastics appointed to the vacant Sees, who do not subscribe to the oath of allegiance. The Pope will not consent to require such an oath from the ecclesiastical nominees, and thus the matter stands --practically where it was a year ago.

abstract: Mrs. Grundy, New Comic Periodical; Nast's, Thomas, Frontispiece to Mrs. Grundy
snippet: Mrs. Grundy, New Comic Periodical; Nast's, Thomas, Frontispiece to Mrs. Grundy
lead_paragraph: We have the first number of a new comic weekly under the above title. If the enterprise is intended to furnish new proofs of the genius of Mr. THOMAS NAST, that intention is fully realized. The title-page, whether as a specimen of drawing, perspective, power of caricaturing is equal to the best efforts of JOHN LEECH or RICHARD DOYLE, whose works are as well known here as in Europe. But if wit, without unkindness, humor, without coarseness, criticism, without favoritism, be aimed at, number 2 of Mrs. Grundy must be a great improvement on number 1 before the object be reached. Dress reform is too trite a subject with which to fill a couple of columns. It may be well enough to acknowledge the existence of other languages than our own, but there was no need for Mrs. Grundy to be pedantic. There is too evident a personal feeling in the criticism Miss HOSMER, and the writer on art has surely an eye to some envied rival. Mrs. Grundy's title-page is a magnificent piece of art. If the promises of her preface were kept, nothing but praise could be accorded the entire specimen on our table.

abstract: Anniversary; Orators and their Texts
lead_paragraph: In all the popular orations which will be listened to by a million people to-morrow, we do not suppose there will be more than a half-dozen topics treated of. These will be such obvious but splendid themes as the advent of peace, the restoration of the Union, the abolition of slavery, and the prospective glories of our country. They furnish scope for the highest order of intellect and the grandest sweeps of oratorical genius. Some of them are altogether novel, and the others are now presented in entirely new aspects. The man who, in dealing with them, does not rise to spontaneous elequence, may rest assured that in the course of his life he will never have a more favorable opportunity to do so.

abstract: In answer to a reception address at, the Burnett House, Cincinnati, on Friday evening, Gen. SHERMAN stated this interesting fact: "It was here in this city, in this very hotel, through which I passed to reach this spot, that Gen. GRANT and myself met over a year since; and in that very room we laid down the maps and studied out the campaigns which ended this war. I had been away down in Mississippi attending to a little matter there, and when Gen. GRANT and myself ended our conference here, we separated, he to go to Richmond and I to Atlanta, and the result has been just as we planned it here in 1864."

abstract: Manhattan College Commencement
lead_paragraph: The second day's proceedings of the annual commencement at Manhattan College, took place last evening, and passed off to the entire satisfaction of the large audience present. As usual at this institution, the annual exercises were nothing more than an insight into the modus operandi of the system of education pursued there, the students being placed on a public platform and subjected to the closest questioning on the part of any gentleman in the audience. This system of public examination conduces to a spirit of diligence and zeal in the student, as he keenly feels the honor or disgrace resulting from success or failure on such an occasion.

abstract: Smith vs. Simeon Draper, Excess of Duties
snippet: Smith vs. Simeon Draper, Excess of Duties
lead_paragraph: William H. Smith et al. vs Simeon Draper. -- The plaintiffs, who are merchants of the City of New-York, bring this action against Simeon Draper, Collector of the Port, to recover the sum of $9,000, being the amount of an alleged excess of duties exacted by him of the plaintiffs upon an importation of teas by the ship Hamilla Mitchell.

lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Owasco, Lieutenant Commander T. ABBOTT, left Sabine Pass June 10, via Pensacola 22d, bound to Boston.
