abstract: Policeman BAKER, of the Seventh Ward, apprehended ROSE KELLY, for tendering at JOHN MCCABE's store, No. 19 Catharine-street, a spurious $10 note, purporting to have been uttered by the Girard Bank, of Philadelphia, and a spurious $5 on the Union Bank, of Troy, in payment for a cloak and shawl which she had purchased. Other counterfeits were found on the prisoner's person, as follows: Commercial Bank, of Glens Falls, $5; State Bank, of Newark, N.J., $5; Syracuse City Bank, $5. She was committed for examination.

abstract: Fiscal Year, Close of; Gold Surplus
snippet: Fiscal Year, Close of; Gold Surplus
lead_paragraph: The Fiscal Year 1865 closed on Friday last, June 30. The figures for the port of New-York will be found in our Money column. The estimates for the other ports are of easy approximation, from the Customs of the first three-quarters of the year. Altogether the actual consumption of foreign merchandise, owing to the extravagant price of gold last Summer and Fall, is found to be about eighty millions in gold value, less than the previous year, while the Customs in gold derived from this moderate consumption, are only seventeen millions less than in 1861. The duties now average 44 1/2 per cent. upon the invoice or appraised value of the goods entered for consumption. This rate, on a consumption of about $194,000,000, gives a customs revenue in gold of $86,000,000. Last year the duties averaged 37 1/2 per cent., and gave $103,000,000 on a consumption of about $275,000,000.

abstract: Hudson River, Train Off Track--Two Killed, >amp;c.
snippet: Hudson River, Train Off Track--Two Killed, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday last, a passenger train on the Hudson River railroad, which had started from Peekskill at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, arrived at Irvington half an hour later and was thrown off the track by the displacing of a switch, the accident resulting in the immediate death of one of the passengers and the severe wounding of eight or ten others. With the characteristic reticence which is always displayed by the employes of such companies as have been implicated in such disasters, no definite and official details could be obtained beyond the varying statements of a few of the witnesses of the accident, and the unreliable news collected by hearsay. It is positive, however, that the manifold duties devolving upon the switchman had called him elsewhere, and his absence (the switch having been displaced) was the cause of the destruction of human life.

abstract: British Subsidies to
lead_paragraph: We have to-day, by the European mail, the text of the agreement entered into between the British Government and the Canadian delegates. The official statement does not differ materially from the verbal report brought hither a few days ago by the delegates. In one item of the agreement, the colonists have struck even a better bargain than they could have anticipated. The purchase-money of the Hudson Bay Company, which will probably reach the sum of ten or twelve million dollars, is to be guaranteed by the Home Government, as well as the loans necessary for building the fortifications. All the forts are to be supplied with their armament, absolutely at the expense of the British War Office. And the Lords of the Admiralty have come under a promise to supply, when occasion shall call for it, a naval armament on the lakes. This implies that the Provincial canals are to be enlarged to admit the passage of larger craft than can use them now. And we dare say, it implies also that the money necessary for these canal improvements may, at the proper time, be borrowed under an Imperial guarantee.

abstract: The Fourth will be celebrated year in a manner worthy of the occasion. Twelve months ago the country was engaged in a devastating war, the end of which no man could foresee. This year the recurrence of the nation's birthday finds us in a condition of peace. The country can therefore afford to indulge in a display which last year would have seemed out of place. In this city, the preparations for the celebration of the day exceed those made on any previous ococcasion. The Common Council have appropriated the sum of $20,000 for the purpose. Whether the whole amount is to be expended in fireworks and music the public have yet to learn, but certainly a very large quantity of both could be supplied for hair the money. Not content, however, with celebrating one day, they recommend our citiztens in the published programme to observe the 3d also as a birthday. It is quite probable, in view of the fact that the Stock and Produce Exchanges will be closed to-day, that very little business of any kind will be transacted until Wednesday morning.

abstract: Col. JAMES MEINELL, whose death was announced in our columns yesterday, was a native of Kent, England, and came to the United States in 1798, when he was but twelve years old. He entered into business very early and prosecuted it with great energy and success, being in the days of GIDEON LEE and his cotemporaries, one of the best known dealers in "the Swamp," and speedily accumulating a handsome fortune, which he invested very largely in real estate in the neighborhood of Fortieth-street and Seventh-avenue, which was then quite out of town. He retired from business in 1830, and has since that time devoted himself mainly to the care of his real estate here, and to the active and laborious supervision of his large farm at Jerusalem South, on Long Island. He was very fond of out-door employment, and greatly strengthened his naturally robust and powerful frame by occupations so congenial to his taste. His Winters were usually spent in town, but, in spite of the society of many old and warmly attached friends, his Winter residence always became somewhat irksome to him, and he usually took advantage of the earliest promise of Spring to escape to his country farm. While working there one day last week, he received a severe blow on his thumb, to which, at the time, with characteristic endurance, he paid but little attention. Symptoms of lock-jaw, however, manifested themselves soon after he came to town, a day or two after the accident, and in spite of the most skillful medical care, he died on Sunday. He was a man of large and robust frame, of strong intellect, of great integrity, and eminently just in his business relations. He has a son, a Lieutenant in the Fifth Artillery, of the Regular Army, who went through some of the heaviest battles of the war with gallantry and credit, and was himself a firm and energetic supporter of the government throughout the contest. He leaves quite a large family and a very large circle of friends to mourn his loss.

abstract: To-day the whole people may rejoice; rejoice that the glory of the nation is manifest anew; that from sedition, privy conspiracy and rebellion the country has been delivered; rejoice that out of her great trouble and sorrow she comes hopeful and trusting; and that, while security and peace are once more hers, she can stretch forth her hands before the world, saying, I have let the oppressed go free!

abstract: -- CHARLES R. O'GRESS, a child of 15 months, was accidentally shot, and almost instantly killed, at about 8 o'clock last evening, while in his mother's lap, at No. 28 Lewis-street. Many boys were discharging their pistols in the neighborhood at the time, and the police were, consequently, unable to ascertain who fired the fatal bullet.

abstract: A middle-aged woman, name not known, was found dead in a rear room of the liquor-store of JOHN BURNS in Smith-street, corner of Fourth-place, on Sunday morning. She came to the place on Saturday night, and being plied with whisky became crazy drunk. The proprietor permitted her to retrain in the back room until morning, when, on opening the store, he found her dead. Coroner LYNCH will investigate the circumstances on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A middle-aged woman, name not known, was found dead in a rear room of the liquor-store of JOHN BURNS in Smith-street, corner of Fourth-place, on Sunday morning. abstract: Atlantic Telegraph; High Charges of
lead_paragraph: By the China we have the tariff under which the Atlantic Telegraph Company propose to go into business. The rates are high enough to please the stockholders -- doubtless. They are probably high enough even to satisfy the purposes and subserve the interests of general stock operators in New-York. A pound sterling a word -- nothing less than twenty words counted -- to and from Great Britain; a guinea a word to the Continent of Europe; and twenty-five shillings sterling a word to connecting points in Asia and Africa ought to pay if the line works at all. The Company being sensible that their tariff is framed to suit the purses of a select circle of patrons, apologize for it, on the ground that they only want a select circle of patrons. Just so. But we doubt, whether the circle is not made a fraction too select by this remarkable scale, to give public satisfaction. At the rate at which the electricians reckon their ability to transmit messages -- which is eight words per minute, the line can be made to transmit four million words a year. It takes but little reckoning to sum up what this would bring in the way of revenue. At one pound sterling a word, the directors, by their own admissions, must calculate on an income of $20,000,000. That is, they reckon on getting back about four times the amount of the principal in twelve months.

abstract: During the last two weeks, about 1,000 army wagons, drawn by mules, have passed through the neighboring town of Washington, in several trains, all of which parked over night outside of the town. Some very enterprising citizens concluded to avail themselves of the opportunity thus afforded to procure a few mules for their own use. Accordingly, some eighteen or twenty were obtained by various persons in the borough and vicinity, some taking more and some less. Just how they were procured, we are unable to say; but we will presume they were purchased from some unauthorised person. During the early part of this week some of the government officials having missed their mules after leaving town, and suspecting all was not right, returned and made search, finding upward of a dozen snugly haltered up and properly taken care of in various places in the town and vicinity. The persons in whose possession they were found, not being able to show that they had obtained them in the regular way, had of course to give them up and lose whatever money they paid to the drivers from whom they purchased, knowing that they had no authority to sell them. -- Pittsburgh Chronicle, June 28.

abstract: -- Between 10 and 11 o'clock a fire, of an unknown origin, occurred in Mrs. SARAH SCHOFIELD's boardidg-house, at No. 226 Varick-street. It was speedily extinguished, with loss not exceeding $200 to household furniture, and $100 to the building. The property is fully insured in the St. Nicholas office....At about 6 o'clock fire was discovered in the garret of the tenement dwelling at No. 238 Second-street, occupied by a number of German families. The flames extended to the roof of No. 240, but were there checked. The damage, which is estimated at $1,500, is covered by insurance in the Astor office ....The roof of No. 31 Roosevelt-street, took fire at about 10 o'clock from fireworks.... At about 9 o'clock, about $100 loss was sustained from fire on the second floor of No. 512 East Sixteenth-street....KATE FRANKFORD, a child about 5 years of age, was run over by a butcher's cart, near her parents dwelling, at No. 170 Broome-street....ABRAHAM ISHUR accidently shot himself in the left arm, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital by Policeman KENNEDY.

abstract: The city to-day will in some respects resemble a field of battle. Even last night, the firing of crackers and pistols was such as to bring to mind the crackling of musketry, that might be heard any night along the lines in front of Petersburgh, while our army was lying there. lead_paragraph: The city to-day will in some respects resemble a field of battle. Even last night, the firing of crackers and pistols was such as to bring to mind the crackling of musketry, that might be heard any night along the lines in front of Petersburgh, while our army was lying there. Louder than the smaller explosives, the noise of a gun would occasionally resound along the streets, resembling in a striking degree the cannon-shot which used to be fired every now and then over into the rebel works by our soldiers, and which was heard high above the musketry. To-day all this kind of thing will be vastly increased.

abstract: Gen. GRANT has accepted the invitation of Gov. FENTON to be present at Albany to-day, and participate in the celebration, one feature of which will be the formal surrender to the custody of the State of a large number of battle-flags from returned regiments. Gen. GRANT is expected to reach the city at 5 o'clock this morning, and, after a hasty breakfast at the Astor House, ho will take a special train on the Harlem Railroad at 5:45 o'clock A.M. It is believed that he will leave Albany on his return to Washington at 6 o'clock in the evening, foregoing the expected visit to Saratoga.

lead_paragraph: The Montgomery and West Point Railroad is in running order from Chehaw to West Point on the upper section, and from Chehaw to Girard on the lower. Trains occasionally arrive at Girard, but the bridge being burned, there is no means of crossing over to Columbus. There is not running stock sufficient on the road to enable the company to run daily trains yet to both West Point and Girard. We learn from the Montgomery Mail, that a tri-weekly line of four-horse coaches has been put upon the line between that city and Chehaw. The coaches leave Montgomery on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 3 o'clock P.M., and arrive at Chehaw the next morning. The Macon Telegraph says that the work on the State Railroad was expected to be finished so far as to allow the construction trains to go through from Chattanooga to Atlanta by the end of last week. On Thursday last the construction train reached Ackworth. The whole bed of the road has been cleared off and repaired, and the ties are all ready. The Chattahoochee bridge has also well progressed toward completion. The officers in charge express the utmost confidence that they will be able to establish regular passenger trains by the first or fourth of July.

lead_paragraph: The loss by the incendiary fire, on Sunday night, in Messrs. WESTS, BRADLEY & CARY's duplex elliptic hoop-skirt warehouse, at Nos. 79 and 81 Reade-street, ending through to Nos. 97 and 99 Chambers-street, is estimated at $50,000. Messrs, WESTS, BRADLEY & CARY, who are the heaviest losers, expect to resume operations within a fortnight, only the fifth stoy of their manufactory having been destroyed. Their stock on the second, third and fourth floors of the building has been considerably damaged by water, as has also the stock owned by Messrs. DIBBLEE, WORK & MOORE, on the first floor; but as the latter firm regard their losses and insurances as a private matter merely, and decline to make any statement to either the Fire Marshal or the reporters, we are unable to esmate the loss on the first floor with any degree of accuracy. The building, which is owned by N.P. HOSSACK, Esq., and insured for $60,000, can hardly be repaired for $5,000. The insurances are as follows:

abstract: Yesterday morning some of the soldiers belonging to the Irish Brigade, mainly men of the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts, became involved in a dispute with some of the Naval Brigade, regarding a trifling matter relating to the war. Being outside of the barrack inclosure, and out of reach of their officers' influence, the argument had full scope, until it became so exciting that words became insufficient for the purpose of settling the mooted point. Blows, and pretty heavy ones at that, were resorted to. The result of the fracas was that several of the disputants were successively "chawed up," and the original question is as open for discussion as before. During the progress of the fight bayonets were drown and sundry kinves flourished in the early sunlight. The policemen on duty at the Battery were manful in their efforts to quell the battle, disarming several of the combatants, at no small risk to themselves. The disturbance was finally quieted by the officers of the brigade. A platoon of police from the Tenth Precinct, under the command of a sergeant, patrolled the Battery during the day, allowing none to go near the barrack gate, but those on business. As usual, bad rum was the cause of the whole disturbance.

abstract: Securities; Fluctuations in Europe
lead_paragraph: Within the last three days of the week ending the 24th of June, there appears, by the China's news, received last night, to have been a rise of three, and a fall of four per cent. in five-twenties in the London market. Up to Friday, according to Messrs. BARINGS' circular, the rise was steady. The last report received here was up to Wednesday, the 21st, when the highest quotation was 71 3/4. Within forty-eight hours of the date of that report the price appears to have culminated at 74 1/2, and thence declined until at the close of Saturday the quotation is reported as low as 70 3/4.

abstract: PRESIDENT JOHNSON'S HEALTH.  At 9 o'clock this evening the President's health was somewhat improved. He will keep his chamber, and, by the advice of his physician, Surgeon-General BARNES, he will not resume the consideration of official matters for three or four days.

abstract: The celebration of the Fourth may be said to have commenced yesterday. Wall-street and the lower part of the city generally were deserted. The public schools were adjourned at noon, and the youthful of both sexes were permitted to run home and lay in their stock of torpedoes and fireworks. Business men appeared to look on the day as a sort of "blue Monday," and confined their transactions to purchases of "crackers" and similar combustibles. At 8 P.M. the chimes of Trinity rang forth through deserted Wall-street, a prelude to the programme which ushers in to-day.

abstract: -- While the Atlantic Telegraph Company propose charging $100 for a message of twenty words, the Russo-American Overland Telegraph Company propose to send messages of twenty-five words between London and New-York, via Berlin, St. Petersburgh, &c., for $40. We shall need the sound competition of half a dozen lines to bring the prices within the bounds of reason. When a message of twenty or twenty-five words can be sent to Europe for $5, we shall have got to something like a fair basis for honest commerce. Meanwhile, it may occur to most people that none of the lines are as yet in operation.

abstract: New-York Irish Brigade, Return, Officers and Record
snippet: New-York Irish Brigade, Return, Officers and Record
lead_paragraph: The famous and long-tried Irish Brigade, under the command of Brevet Brig.-Gen. ROBERT NUGENT, arrived early yesterday morning, remaining all of yesterday and last night at the Battery, preparatory to taking part in the grand celebration of to-day. This brigade consists of four regiments, viz: The Sixty-third, Sixty-ninth, and Eighty-eighth New-York, and twenty-eighth Massachusett Regiment, from Boston. The brigade has an extensive and gallant record, having shared in the glory of every engagement fought by the army of the Potomac, since its organization, from the siege of Yorktown and the Peninsula campaign, under MCCLELLAN, through all the different campaigns of HOOKER, BURNSIDE, MEADE and GRANT, down to the final surrender of the army of northern Virginia, under LEE, at Appomattox Hollow, Va., April 9, 1865. The following comprises the complete roster of the officers of the New-York regiments in the brigade, the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts having left for home yesterday:

abstract: The Sixty-third, Sixty-ninth and Eighty-eighth New-York: Regiments, composing, with the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment, the famous Irish Brigade, arrived in this city yesterday, and will remain over until to-morrow to take part in the grand celebration of the Fourth to-day. The Sixth, Tenth, Seventy-third and Fifty-ninth New-York Regiments went to Hart's Island yesterday, so they cannot be present in the military pageant to-day. The First and Sec
lead_paragraph: The Sixty-third, Sixty-ninth and Eighty-eighth New-York: Regiments, composing, with the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment, the famous Irish Brigade, arrived in this city yesterday, and will remain over until to-morrow to take part in the grand celebration of the Fourth to-day. The Sixth, Tenth, Seventy-third and Fifty-ninth New-York Regiments went to Hart's Island yesterday, so they cannot be present in the military pageant to-day. The First and Second Massachusetts Cavalry, the Fifth Rhode Island Heavy Artillery, and several detachments of discharged soldiers, passed through yesterday for their respective States. The Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment also started for Boston yesterday morning, where a grand reception awaits them.

abstract: -- A Murfreesboro (Tennessee) correspondent of the Milwaukee Wisconsin relates the following: "Among the former magnates and late leaders of the rebellion, who have returned to eat their leek, is Gen. GIDEON J. PILLOW. I visited him last week at his mansion, five miles from Columbia. The splendid estate on which his mansion is built is leased out by the government to an enterprising Yankee. The family of the General have, however, been allowed to use the house and adjoining grounds. The place is an elegant one, like some English country seat. After leaving the pike to enter the carriage-way upon the grounds, you ride a considerable distance through a most beautiful grove and lawn before you get a glimpse of the residence. Gen. PILLOW greeted us very affably, and is quite communicative, indeed exceedingly talkative. He appears about fifty years of age -- had on a gray coat, which I judged to be his uniform, stripped of its insignia and gilt buttons -- not by any means a man of imposing exterior, but would pass for an intelligent and genial farmer of the old school.
lead_paragraph: -- A Murfreesboro (Tennessee) correspondent of the Milwaukee Wisconsin relates the following: "Among the former magnates and late leaders of the rebellion, who have returned to eat their leek, is Gen. GIDEON J. PILLOW. I visited him last week at his mansion, five miles from Columbia. The splendid estate on which his mansion is built is leased out by the government to an enterprising Yankee. The family of the General have, however, been allowed to use the house and adjoining grounds. The place is an elegant one, like some English country seat. After leaving the pike to enter the carriage-way upon the grounds, you ride a considerable distance through a most beautiful grove and lawn before you get a glimpse of the residence. Gen. PILLOW greeted us very affably, and is quite communicative, indeed exceedingly talkative. He appears about fifty years of age -- had on a gray coat, which I judged to be his uniform, stripped of its insignia and gilt buttons -- not by any means a man of imposing exterior, but would pass for an intelligent and genial farmer of the old school.

abstract: A very touching instance of devotion took place yesterday morning at No. 34 Willoughby-street, Brooklyn. The person residing there, Mr. WILLIAM J. MORRIS, has a little son, JOHNNY, aged about sixteen months. During the past year the little fellow has been almost constantly in the company of a little girl named KATY ROSE, about six years old. On this occasion they were together in the privy attached to the place, when the seat gave way and the little boy was plunged into the filth below. Screaming out an alarm to the other inmates, KATY, undaunted, jumped in after him. Fortunately she struck a barrel, and standing on it attempted to rescue her little playmate who had already sunk chin-deep in the mire. Her strength was insufficient, and her repeated efforts but made his case more desperate. The screams of the girl attracted the attention of Mrs. MORRIS, who ran to the spot. Throwing a rope to the child she told her to fasten it to herself, and she would pull her up. But the little friend faithful to the last stuck to her little companion and endeavored to tie the rope about him. Other help soon arrived, and an old gentleman, whose name we could not learn, went down into the pit and saved both. The sublime heroism and faithful adherence of this little girl deserves the recognition of every lover of humanity, and for her sake we are pleased to record the entire safety and certain recovery of the little boy.
lead_paragraph: A very touching instance of devotion took place yesterday morning at No. 34 Willoughby-street, Brooklyn. The person residing there, Mr. WILLIAM J. MORRIS, has a little son, JOHNNY, aged about sixteen months. During the past year the little fellow has been almost constantly in the company of a little girl named KATY ROSE, about six years old. On this occasion they were together in the privy attached to the place, when the seat gave way and the little boy was plunged into the filth below. Screaming out an alarm to the other inmates, KATY, undaunted, jumped in after him. Fortunately she struck a barrel, and standing on it attempted to rescue her little playmate who had already sunk chin-deep in the mire. Her strength was insufficient, and her repeated efforts but made his case more desperate. The screams of the girl attracted the attention of Mrs. MORRIS, who ran to the spot. Throwing a rope to the child she told her to fasten it to herself, and she would pull her up. But the little friend faithful to the last stuck to her little companion and endeavored to tie the rope about him. Other help soon arrived, and an old gentleman, whose name we could not learn, went down into the pit and saved both. The sublime heroism and faithful adherence of this little girl deserves the recognition of every lover of humanity, and for her sake we are pleased to record the entire safety and certain recovery of the little boy.

abstract: EPISCOPAL ORDINATION. The annual ordination by Bishop POTTER of candidates for holy orders, who are members of the graduating class in the General Theological Seminary, took place Sunday morning at the Wainwright Memorial Church, Hammondstreet. The services were conducted by Rev. EDWIN...
lead_paragraph: EPISCOPAL ORDINATION. -- The annual ordination by Bishop POTTER of candidates for holy orders, who are members of the graduating class in the General Theological Seminary, took place Sunday morning at the Wainwright Memorial Church, Hammondstreet. The services were conducted by Rev. EDWIN COOK, rector, Rev. Drs. PAYNE, JOHNSON and GOLDSBOROUGH and the Bishop. Thirteen students and candidates were admitted to the Order of Deacons, as follows: Thomas McKee Brown, B.A., H. Warren Fay, R.A., Alfred Goldsborough, Samuel B. Leyon, Flavel Scott Mines, Brockholst Morgan, A.K.C, John Wm. Payne, M.A., Richard B. Post, Jr., Daniel Crane Roberts, Caleb Theophilus Ward, A.B., William C. Winslow, A.B., Messrs. Dealey and Austice of the diocese, but not of the seminary, were admitted to the Order of Deacons.

abstract: Mary Brady and Margaret Brady vs. Sigismund Lasar. -- This was an action of trespass, brought by the plaintiffs against the defendant, an Assistant Assessor of Internal Revenue. abstract: Major-Gen. SHERMAN arrived at Lancaster on Saturday, June 24. He was received at the depot by several thousands of his friends and neighbors and escorted to his residence by a large number of returned veterans, under command of Col. J. STAFFORD, of the One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Ohio Regiment, preceded by a brass band and followed by hundreds of enthusiastic citizens, anxious to greet the General. Over the gate at his residence the ladies had erected a beautiful arch, with the following inscriptions; "Atlanta is ours, and fairly won," and "Welcome, thrice welcome home."

abstract: CONTINUED EXCITEMENT AMONG THE FIREMEN  SPECIAL MEETING OF THE BOARD OF REPRESENTATIVES. lead_paragraph: CONTINUED EXCITEMENT AMONG THE FIREMEN -- SPECIAL MEETING OF THE BOARD OF REPRESENTATIVES. -- The excitement growing out of the recent action of the Eastern District Fire Commissioners, in removing the two crippled bell-ringers and disbanding eight companies is assuming white heat. Yesterday, Engine No. 8 threw out a banner with the inscription, "Apartments to let -- Inquire of Jack Perry" -- meaning JOHN H. PERRY, one of the Fire Commissioners. Last night a special meeting of the Board of Representatives was held at Firemen's Hall, HENRY M. DIXON, President, in the chair. A communication was presented from the Fire Commissioners, notifying the board of their action in disbanding the companies heretofore published. On motion of Mr. SHIELDS, Hose No. 8, the board refused to receive the communication. A committee of five was then appointed to wait upon Mayor WOOD to protest against the action of the commissioners in removing KIRKMAN and AMES, the crippled bell-ringers. The following gentlemen comprise the committee; -- James Stack, Engine No. 1; Charles P. Dower, Engine No. 13: George Bond, Engine No. 6; Michael Shields, Hose No. 8, Wm. Johnson, Hose No. 9. Mr. JOHN GACONY, Secretary of the Board, then moved that a committee, consisting of one from each company, be appointed to draw up resolutions expressing the sense of the department regarding the action of the commissioners on the disbandment question. This motion elicited a warm and interesting discussion, in the course of which Mr. JOHNSON, of Hose No. 9, stated that when he asked a certain commissioner to vote for the opponent of DONEVAN, he was told that if he did so, his company would be disbanded, and his company was disbanded. Mr. DIXON, the President, left his chair, and spoke at length on partisan feeling injuring the department, but the committee was finally unanimously appointed. The nominees of the commission who appeared before Mayor WOOD for confirmation as bell-ringers have not received his indorsement, and he told one of them that he thought he was better calculated for a prize fighter than a bell-ringer. The board adjourned, after an acrimonious debate.

abstract: The steamship China arrived off Cape Race yesterday, bringing four days' later news from Europe. The political advices are meagre and unimportant. The Atlantic Telegraph Company have revised their very moderate rates, and will charge five dollars a word on messages for England. The rates for other parts of Europe are even higher. In excuse for this enormous increase, the directors of the company allege that otherwise the line would be incumbered with messages. They promise to lay a new cable and reduce their rates, if the present attempt should prove successful. Five-Twenties have experienced sudden fluctuations. They rose to 73 3/4, but subsequently fell to 70 3/4, in consequence of the Persia's news. The Emperor NAPOLEON and his cousin are still unreconciled. VICTOR EMANUEL and the Pope find they can't agree, and negotiations have been interrupted.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources, many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Detective Officer RICHARD FIELD, of the Fifth Ward, reached town at 8 o'clock last evening, having in custody the negro WM.H. CALHOUN, the murderer of Dr. WM. MURPHY, of No. 372 Canal-street. CALHOUN, who is scarcely darker than a native West Indian, is an athletic and well-formed negro, of about 45 years of age. On the day of the homicide, he had indulged in deep potations; indeed, he had hardly drawn a sober breath from the time of his liberation from the Jefferson Market Prison, where he had been incarcerated for fighting with his wife -- a white woman -- only a week previous. Befogged with gin, he resented a remark which Dr. MURPHY addressed to him, and a clench followed, resulting in a mortal thrust of a butcher knife, penetrating Dr. MURPHY's neck. CALHOUN fled, and Patrolman LENZ took the wounded man to the New-York Hospital, where he died four days thereafter, on the 28th ult. An inquest was held by Coroner GOVER, and the jury rendered a verdict against CALHOUN, and thereupon the Coroner gave Capt. PETTY a warrant for the arrest of the murderer. The negro's whereabouts were unknown until Friday last, when Capt. PETTY ascertained that immediately after the stabbing, he had taken passage in the steamer Metropolis, for Newport, and that there he had engaged as waiter on board the new steamer Newport. Officer FIELD was sent at once to capture him. He reached Newport at about 4 o'clock on Sunday morning, and on going aboard the new steamer, learned that CALHOUN was asleep in the "glory hole," or forecastle. He was called thence, ironed, taken to Newport jail, and there hold until yesterday forenoon, when Officer FIELD embarked with him for this city. The prisoner was held in the Fifth Ward Police-station last night, and is to be delivered to Coroner GOVER this morning. CALHOUN's wife is now in prison for drunkenness. He is a native of Baltimore, and was formerly employed as waiter at the Metropolitan Hotel.

abstract: Various Articles on Celebration of
lead_paragraph: The people of the Southern States will enjoy a new experience, or rather the renewal of an old experience to-day. For the first time since this date in 1860, the Fourth of July will be celebrated in every capital and in every large city of the South. During the existence of the rebellion, the national anniversary was treated with contempt; but with the renewal of the Union it will be everywhere celebrated. It will be not merely our soldiers in the South who will celebrate the day; but there is the best reason for believing that the Southern people generally will give expression to their joy over the return of peaceful and happy times. The Fourth will, moreover, on this occasion be celebrated throughout the South by a class who never before could celebrate it -- we refer to the four millions of blacks who were lately slaves. We have heard in half a dozen States of their making great preparations for the festivities; and even in the capital of South Carolina, the negroes are to have a great jubilee.

abstract: Markets; Good News from
lead_paragraph: We are glad to learn by our reports from the Live Stock Markets, held yesterday, that there was a decided fall in the price of stock. The better grades of cattle sold at prices equivalent to 14c.a16c. per pound for the dressed weight of the fore quarters -- the lowest whole-sale prices reported for this grade of cattle since March, 1864, or fifteen months ago. Common and poorer grades sold yesterday at from 12c. down to 9c. net weight. The receipts of beef cattle at all the city markets for the past week were 5,414 head, against a weekly average for all of last year of 5,136; while the bad weather and the agitation of the subject have greatly diminished the demand. The butchers at the yards claimed that they are giving their customers the full benefit of the decline, and even more. We hope all our readers see and feel (in their purses) that this is the case.

abstract: Annual Tax Lists
lead_paragraph: -- The Commissioners of Taxes yesterday presented their annual estimate to the Board of Supervisors. From this exhibit, we learn that the aggregate value of real and personal estate owned in the City and County of New-York for 1865 is $608,784,355, against $634,615,890 for 1864; leaving a net deficit of $25,831,535. In the item of real estate, the exhibit shows an increase over last year of $16,712,199, and the falling off is solely in personal estate, being no less than, $46,410,598. The explanation of the decrease is found in the fact that at the term of the United States Supreme Court, held at Washington last December, a decision was rendered against the legality of local taxation of United States securities. As much of the capital of our banks of issue consists of government stocks, the city and county are precluded from levying a tax upon it.

abstract: Independence Day, Celebration of
lead_paragraph: The observance of the National Anniversary was characterized everywhere throughout the country by a sober heartiness and earnest enthusiasm, in perfect keeping with the peculiarities of the occasion. The public fully appreciated the moral grandeur of the festival. The all-pervasive sentiment, finding its expression in public utterances and private merrymakings, was profound gratitude at the happy issue of the terrible ordeal through which the nation has just passed victoriously. This feeling of gratitude, though dominant, was tempered, nevertheless, by the saddened memories which must cling for long, long years to the epoch of the rebellion. There was devout joy at the salvation of the country, redeemed from the dark stigma of slavery, and established on surer and better foundations as the land of a free people, whose right to self-government has been vindicated before the world, and whose success finds a response of thankfulness in the hearts of the down-trodden and oppressed among all peoples. There were also the sorrowful remembrances of homes made desolate, families bereft, broad lands devastated, and great cities laid waste by fratricidal strife. No wonder, then, that the day was fraught with conflicting emotions, and was not the less fruitful of sober thoughtfulness than exhuberant patriotism.
headline: {'main': 'THE CELEBRATION OF INDEPENDENCE DAY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CELEBRATION OF INDEPENDENCE DAY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Fourth of July 1865 was destined to be memorable. For the first time since the original Fourth, the honored occasion whose "day we celebrate," the flag of the United States floated in peace over a nation of freemen, and turning their backs full upon the past four years, the people thanked God that no ear was deafened on this Independence Day by the report of hostile cannon, no heart made sad by the shock of battle. Intuition revealed to us all that heaven and earth would combine to render this anniversary pleasant and enjoyable; every body felt confident of a glorious day and a brilliant celebration. All over the land, North and South, East and West, festive bands of patriots, mammoth assemblages of citizens made the blue vault echo with their shouts of gladness, in whose composition no voice of discord, nor wail of bitterness was found.

lead_paragraph: At daybreak a salute of thirty-six guns was fired in the Nineteenth Ward, and immediately afterward the bells of the district were put in motion. The Forty-seventh Regiment, Col. MESSEROLE, preceded by its famous drum corps, soon filled the street on its line of march to Bedford-avenue, with an enthusiastic crowd. In the Thirteenth Ward many rasidences presented attractions for passers-by, in the numerous devices exhibited from their balconies. The residence of Senator STRONG presented a fine appearance. In the Fourteenth Ward there was not much external display, but the patriotic fervor of the rising generation there was most unmistakably exhibited. The residence of Hon S.T. MADDOX, Coroner BASSETT, and others, attracted attention.

abstract: The great event at Saratoga Springs on the Fourth was a reunion meeting of the officers of the "Army of the Tennessee," which came off at the Messrs. LELAND's Union Hotel, where a dinner was partaken of, the affair winding up by a ball in the new and beautiful opera-house, just completed. At the dinner were present Gens. SCHOFIELD, WALLACE, SICKLES, KILPATRICK, DEVIN, KAUTZ and ROBINSON, and quite a number of officers of lesser rank. Toasts appropriate to the occasion were drank, and short, pertinent speeches were made in response. Col. HILLYER presided. The ball was graced by the presence of a large number of ladies from the different hotels, and many distinguished military men and civilians were present. The whole affair passed off pleasantly and agreeably.

abstract: At Whitestone, L.I., yesterday, a lad named [???]ARROW was pouring powder from a flask, when a little falling upon some burning punk near by, the whole exploded, instantly killing the lad, without leaving any mark on the body except apparently a concussion upon the breast. abstract: on Power of Government over Southern States
snippet: on Power of Government over Southern States
lead_paragraph: The last number of Harper's Weekly insists that the Federal Government may rightfully impose upon the Southern States any requirement which it may deem essential to the public safety, as a condition of their again fulfilling their duties and enjoying their rights as members of the Union. If the Federal Government were, as it soon may be, in the hands of the Democratic party, we think Harper's would change its opinion. If Congress and the President were to say to the Southern States --you must disfranchise every loyal man in your borders and return every negro to slavery, as a condition of readmission, Harper's Weekly would deny their right to impose any such conditions, even if they did "deem them necessary to the public safety." The hypothesis is, perhaps, an extreme one; but it tests the principle involved. The government has not the right to make its ideas of the "public safety," the sole and exclusive guide of its action in dealing with the Southern States. It is bound, in this as in everything else, by the Constitution of the United States. That instrument provides for the "public safety" -- and the government is bound by its provisions.
headline: {'main': 'The Government and the South The Constitution.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Government and the South The Constitution.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Memphis Argus says the city was startled on the morning of June 25 by the report that Col. JOHN R. MCCLANAHAN, one of the editors of the Memphis Appeal, had been killed by falling from a window of the Yazoo House. About 5 o'clock in the morning the form of a man was discovered lying in the alley behind the hotel. Upon examination it was discovered to be that of Col. MCCLANAHAN, who, although horribly mangled and weltering in blood, was still alive. Both arms and both legs were broken, the latter near the knees. His chin was badly crushed, and he was otherwise sadly bruised. When discovered consciousness had been restored, and the sufferer, in the intensity of his agony, begged the attending surgeon to kill him, and thus put an end to his sufferings.

abstract: Hotel, London, Immense New, and Prices
snippet: Hotel, London, Immense New, and Prices
lead_paragraph: -- In a quarter of London quite as fashionable as Madison-square is for New-York, a company of noblemen and gentlemen have erected a hotel at an expense of $1,500,000. The building is splendid, alike as to its dimensions, its style, its decorations and its furnishing. Every improvement suggested by our American hotel system, as well as by the best Paris hotels, has been introduced. The building is perfectly fire-proof; but as an extra precaution against all sort of risks, water is so abundantly supplied from an artesian well, to tanks distributed throughout the building, that anything in the shape of a fire could be quenched almost in an instant.

abstract: It is in keeping with the times, at least on this side of the Atlantic, that the Ocean Telegraph Company should propose to start their business by a charge of $5 a word for messages between New-York and London. The directors cannot be ignorant of the all-prevailing desire here, to maintain the prices of things generally at the old gold rates. And they evidently intend to profit by that feature in our present economic and social condition. But are they not calculating on too much profuseness? The public can judge of the rates at which the company think the American people are prepared to pay for intelligence, when it is known that one column of British telegrams in the NEW-YORK TIMES will cost us exactly $9,000. The same amount of matter sent from the Pacific coast, 3,500 miles distant, would cost $819.

abstract: Iron-clads, British and French Exhibition of
snippet: Iron-clads, British and French Exhibition of
lead_paragraph: It is tolerably certain that the coming international iron-clad show of England and France -- which is to consist of a "promenade all round" the coasts of the two countries, and a review by the chief dignitaries of their governments -- is designed quite as much for effect on this side of the Atlantic as on the other. It is more than tolerably certain that whatever the effect intended, the actual one, so far as we are concerned, will be neither that of wonder, fear nor envy. There will be magnificence, doubtless, in all the adjuncts of scenery and pageant; but we very much question whether we, onlookers, from this side, eyeing the ceremonies askance and at a distance, will find anything very novel or very useful therein, for the benefit of our own naval architecture.

abstract: WASHINGTON AND NEW-YORK. -- In Washington there is a fall in house rents since April last of from 25 to 30 per cent. Houses that were held, three months ago, at $900, now go begging for tenants at $700. This satisfactory state of things is due chiefly to the large number of discharged employes from the public departments, the reduction of the military force in and around the city, and the consequent resignation of officers. Before the Fall season opens it is believed that the decline in rents at the National Capital will reach from forty to fifty per cent. We can hope for no such good fortune in New-York. One might almost count on his ten fingers all the decent dwellings in progress of erection between Union Square and Spuyten Duyvil Creek. There may be a partial emigration to the South when the cool weather arrives. But there will be no emigration, we fear, sufficient to give any sensible relief to the anxious crowd of intending housekeepers, or to the multitude already housed at exorbitant and intolerable rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON AND NEW-YORK. -- In Washington there is a fall in house rents since April last of from 25 to 30 per cent. Houses that were held, three months ago, at $900, now go begging for tenants at $700. This satisfactory state of things is due chiefly to the large number of discharged employes from the public departments, the reduction of the military force in and around the city, and the consequent resignation of officers. Before the Fall season opens it is believed that the decline in rents at the National Capital will reach from forty to fifty per cent. We can hope for no such good fortune in New-York. One might almost count on his ten fingers all the decent dwellings in progress of erection between Union Square and Spuyten Duyvil Creek. There may be a partial emigration to the South when the cool weather arrives. But there will be no emigration, we fear, sufficient to give any sensible relief to the anxious crowd of intending housekeepers, or to the multitude already housed at exorbitant and intolerable rates.

abstract: The heavy fall in the price of meat, which we recorded in our last, involves a lesson for both buyers and sellers. The weather was intensely hot, it is true, but that was not the reason why the Washington Market butchers sat idle, and finally had to throw away what they could not sell at five or six cents a pound. The public would not buy, and will not. The price must come much lower before they will. Meanwhile the drovers have, by their extreme folly, given a great impetus to the jerked or infiltrated beef enterprise, and will soon find that, for the sake of a temporary excess of profit, they have raised up a permanent and effective competitor in the supplying of meat.

abstract: The Park was visited on the Fourth by some thirty or forty thousand persons, most of whom were on foot, there being a marked absence of carriages and equestrians. Dodworth's Band occupied the pagoda, and about 3 1/2 P.M. commenced the concert, which was listened to by an immense audience. Another set of musicians occupied a boat on the lake, from which they gave forth inspiriting strains. No crackers, torpedoes or pistol-firing being allowed, the Park was as quiet as on any other day, the visitors congratulating themselves that there was at least one place in the city free from the smell of gunpowder and the noise of torpedoes. The assemblage was a most quiet and orderly one, not a single disturbance of any kind taking place.

abstract: Wooster-street, Music Printers; $16,000
lead_paragraph: Between 5 and 6 o'clock this morning a large four-story brick building in the rear of No. 18 Wooster-street was found to be on fire, and the flames had gained such headway that it was manifestly impossible to save the building, and the firemen confined their efforts to the saving of adjoining property. Paper, stock and presses, belonging to Messrs. LAWSON & FERGUSON, music printers, on the upper floors of the building, were destroyed to the value of $10,000. The firm are insured in the St. Mark's and Park offices. A stock of paper and music belonging to Messrs. WILLIAM HALL & SONS, was damaged to the amount of $2,000, and insured for $1,500 in the Brevoort Insurance Company. A like stock, belonging to Mr. E.T. FIRTH, was damaged to the extent of $500; also a like stock, the property of Mr. W.A. POND, was damaged to the amount of $1,500; Mr. POND has $2,090 insurance in the Lenox office. The building, which is owned by Mr. FERGUSON, was damaged to the extent of $1,500, and is fully insured in the Arctic office. Mrs. MARY O'DONNELL's boarding-house, at No. 18 Wooster-street, was slightly damaged by water. Mrs. O'DONNELL has $1,000 insurance in the Arctic office. Mr. HERMAN BRINKHORST's house, No. 23 Greene-street, was also damaged slightly by water. Mr. B. has $4,000 insurance in the Battle office. The fire originated from a rocket which entered the building early last evening.

abstract: Visit to West Point on July 4; Speech July 4, at Albany; Speech on Receiving Flags of State Regiments; Oration, 4th of July, at Albany
snippet: Visit to West Point on July 4; Speech July 4, at Albany; Speech on Receiving Flags of State Regiments; Oration, 4th of July, at Albany
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT's visit to Albany was the occasion at a hearty display of enthusiasm on the part of the citizens, and the celebration of the eighty-ninth anniversary of our national independence in the State capital, was rendered interesting and memorable by the presence of the Lieutenant-General and nearly all the leading Generals of the Army of the Potomac and some of those from the Western armies. During the day about two hundred battle-rent and weather-stained banners, belonging to New-York regiments, were formally presented to the Governor by Gen. BUTTERFIELD. We present a [???]ll account of the proceedings:

abstract: The soldiers of the New England Rooms desire to thank the liberal proprietors of several of the hotels of this city, including the Astor House, the Stevens House, the Howard, National, Delmonico's, the Metropolitan, the Washington and others, for plentiful donations of delicacies, donated by them to Mrs. RUSSELL, the Matron, for their benefit. Also to several dealers in fireworks for donations. The "Cripple Brigade" at the rooms, as well as many convalescents sojourning there, were thus enabled to outwardly testify their joy at the return of that peace to our country for which they are now suffering.

abstract: A weekly journal bearing this title, and which has been advertised for some time in the columns of the TIMES, made its first appearance yesterday. It is a handsome quarto sheet of 32 pages, printed on the very best paper, in a clear bold type, and contains, besides a summary of notable events, twenty-six essays of different merit on a variety of political, literary and art subjects. It is published at No. 130 Nassau-street, by Mr. JOSEPH H. RICHARDS, and Thursday is its publication day.

lead_paragraph: In accordance with the finding and sentence of the Military Commission, which have been approved by President JOHNSON, DAVID E. HERROLD, LEWIS PAYNE, Mrs. MARY E. SURRATT and GEORGE A. ATZEROTH, convicted of having conspired against the life of the late President LINCOLN, are to be hung to-day by the proper military authorities. The death warrants were yesterday read to the prisoners. Mrs. SURRATT was much affected, and pleaded for a few days' respite in which to prepare for death.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Mill, John Stuart, Reply to Charge of Irreligion
snippet: Mill, John Stuart, Reply to Charge of Irreligion
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN STUART MILL is the Liberal candidate for the representation of Westminster in the British House of Commons. He is stoutly opposed by the Tories, and supported very indifferently by friends of the Palmerston ministry. The pharisaical brawlers of the London Record and London Morning Advertiser have now taken up the cry against him on account of his alleged Atheism. To this Mr. MILL replies in a published letter received by the China's mail last night. On the general subject of catechising a candidate as to his religious opinions, Mr. MILL says -- and his words are worth quoting:

abstract: The Emperor is still at Puebla, where the climate, as well as the people, seem to be better adapted to his health and taste. Indeed, there has been considerable talk as to removing the Imperial residence and making Puebla the capital. Mexico is not as loyal as it might be; it is not as clean as it might be, and its people are really backward as far as improvements are concerned.

abstract: At about 6 o'clock last evening, a fire occurred from the spontaneous combustion of a can of phosphorus, in the yard in the rear of Mr. JEFFERSON J. BECKWITH's drug-store, at No. 252 Greenwich-street. The flames having been extinguished, with damage not exceeding $100, the firemen attached to Hook and Ladder Company No. 15 and Hose No. 49, then stationed at the intersection of Warren and Greenwich streets, engaged each other in a fierce but not sanguinary encounter, with brickbats, trumpets and wrenches, and for five minutes, or until the police entered upon the scene, there was promise of serious results. The police being on the ground in heavy force -- detachments having been sent to the fire from the First, Second, Fifth, Sixth and Eighth Wards -- the riot was speedily quelled, and RICHARD SCULLY, THOMAS LOFTUS, PETER BURNS and JOHN RYAN, firemen, were apprehended and committed to the cells in Capt. GREER's police-station, in Chambers street, near West Broadway.

abstract: Assassins; the Verdict Against
lead_paragraph: The justice of the verdict in the case of the conspirators if the 14th of April is such as to command the approval of the whole country, and what is of high importance in this instance -- of history. Of the eight culprits, who were under trial before the Military Commission, four (HERROLD, ATZEROTH, PAYNE and Mrs. SURRAT) are condemned to death, the sentence to be carried into execution this day under military authority; and of the remaining four, three (O'LAUGHLIN, ARNOLD and MUDD,) are condemned to hard labor for life in the penitentiary, while SPANGLER, is to be confined for six years. There will doubtless be some who, at first view, will consider the sentence, upon the four persons last-named, altogether too lenient. Their complicity in the great crime of the age was proven beyond all question, and the sentiment of inexorable justice would seem to demand the highest penalty upon every one who had any share in it. But the simple fact that the verdict as a whole, and in each of its parts, was pronounced by a board of high military officers, who patiently gathered and collated all the facts, weighed all the evidence, and listened to all the arguments of counsel on both sides, -- who had ample time for deliberation, and who appreciated their great responsibility; and the additional fact that the finding of the commission has been approved in all its parts by the President, will modify any such opinion that might hastly be formed, and will tend to convince every one that substantial justice has been the result of the trial, even though it has been tempered with mercy.
headline: {'main': 'The Verdict Against the Assassins.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Verdict Against the Assassins.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Illinois, Central, Prices in
lead_paragraph: In a populous district of Central Illinois, before the war broke out, potatoes were to be had for 12 1/2 cents a bushel, chickens 10 cents apiece, eggs 5 cents a dozen, butter 6 cents, beef from 4 to 6 cents, mutton from 4 to 5 cents. Potatoes are now sold in the same district at $1 50 per bushel, chickens at 40 cents apiece, eggs 25 cents a dozen, butter 40 cents, beef 20 to 25 cents, and mutton 15 to 20 cents. Some allowance, doubtless, has to be made in this comparison for the growth of the marketing town, and the consequent increase in the number of consumers at the market. But when allowance is made for such increase, the fact that the price of potatoes is to-day twelve-fold what it was five years ago, in a fine agricultural district, is not a healthy sign. The great fear with reflecting people is, that war prices may become chronic with us. There can be no reason for this as applies to articles of home growth and home production. We are paying now in New-York from 25 to 30 per cent. more than the London consumer for scores of housekeeping articles that, are grown at our doors, while they are imported into London from the continent. The people will only submit to this for a time.
headline: {'main': 'BEFORE AND AFTER THE WAR', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BEFORE AND AFTER THE WAR', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board assembled at 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, the President, Mr. JAMES M.McLEAN, in the chair. After the reading and correction of the errors in the printed report of the Board's proceedings on the 21st of June, and the presentation of several communications, the Board considered the expediency of authorizing the school Trustees of the Ninth Ward to expend $300 in making alterations to Primary School building No. 18, in Waverley-place; the nomination...
lead_paragraph: The Board assembled at 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, the President, Mr. JAMES M. MCLEAN, in the chair. After the reading and correction of the errors in the printed report of the Board's proceedings on the 21st of June, and the presentation of several communications, the Board considered the expediency of authorizing the School Trustees of the Ninth Ward to expend $300 in making alterations to Primary School building No. 18, in Waverley-place; the nomination of Mr. OLIVER KEYSER as Principal of Grammar School No. 10; the application of the Seventh Ward School Trustees for an additional appropriation of $3,000; the recommendation of Superintendent S.S. RANDALL that THOMAS E. CODY, in the First Ward, be removed, and a letter was read from Mr. LEWIS W. ANNAN, asking the Board charitably to reinstate him as Principal of Ward School No. 20, in the First Ward, and pledging himself to resign without two months if the Board comply with his request. Mr. ANNAN's communication was laid on the table.

abstract: Exclusive Policy on Emigration
lead_paragraph: In North Carolina some of the best men of the State are engaged in maturing plans to facilitate eud eucourage immigration from the North. A land agency, for that purpose, has already been established in Raleigh. Our Charleston correspondent has informed us that a similar movement is on foot in South Carolina. But in Virginia, on the other hand, the land-owners are combining to keep out Northern immigration, by agreements to make no sales to men from the North. This spirit not only exists among the old Secessionists, but seems to infect a portion at least of the so-called loyal people of the State. Gov. PEIRPOINT's legislature refused to incorporate a company which had been formed to buy and sell unemployed land, for the furtherance of immigration from the North, although the Governor himself had recommended the measure in strong terms. The broad ground was taken in the debate that it was not desirable that Yankees should settle in the Old Dominion.

abstract: A BLIND MAN RUN OVER. -- Yesterday forenoon, as "Uncle BILLY, the blind newsman," junction of Newark-avenue and Montgomery-street, was crossing the street near his place, he was knocked down and run over by a horse and loaded cart. He was taken to a drug-store where it was found that he had received several severe flesh wounds about his arms and head, but no bones were broken. Dr. FEENEY dressed the wounds, after which he was conveyed to his home. The driver is not blamed, as his horse was unmanageable at the time.

lead_paragraph: The evidence against HERROLD of having assisted BOOTH in the assassination, and aided him to escape, was clear. As early as February last he was found to have been in confidential relations with the assassin, and was proved to have been present on; several occasions at secret meetings with BOOTH, ATZEROTH and others of the conspirators. Once he was at Mrs. SURRATT's in company with them. He called with SURRATT and ATZEROTH at the tavern in Surrattsville, and left the two carbines and ammunition which were taken away from the tavern by him and BOOTH on the night of the assassination. During their flight he acknowledged to WILLIE JETT and other rebel soldiers that he and BOOTH were the assassins of Mr. LINCOLN, and he was captured in the barn with BOOTH. There can be no doubt whatever of his guilt. His personal appearance during the trial was described as first of a boy of nineteen, dressed in a faded hire suit, in height about five feet four inches, dusky black, neglected hair, lively, dark hazel eyes, slight tuffs of [???]rd along the chin and jaws and faintly surrounding the mouth, rather round face, full but not prominent nose, full lips, foolish, weak, confiding countenance indicating but little intelligence, and not the fain[???]est tra[???]e of ferocity. HERROLD seemed to live but in the smile of BOOTH, following him devotedly in his flight, and sharing his privations, perils and capture.

abstract: Grundy, Dr. R. C.; Dayton, Ohio; Bolles, Enoch, Sen., Newark, N. J.
snippet: Grundy, Dr. R. C.; Dayton, Ohio; Bolles, Enoch, Sen., Newark, N. J.
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. R.C. GRUNDY, D.D., died in Dayton, Ohio, June 26. The Gazette gives this sketch of his life: "The life of Dr. GRUNDY was one of great activity in the ministry, to which he dedicated himself at an early age. He was a native of Kentucky and a graduate of Princeton Theological Seminary. His first settlement as a pastor, we believe -- at least it occurred early in his ministerial career -- was at Maysville, Kentucky. There he labored zealously and effectively for many years, until, because of the decline of the city, the field became too contracted for his acknowledged abilities, and he was prevailed upon to accept a call from the Second Presbyterian Church at Memphis, Tenn. There he labored until the rebellion broke up the relations between himself and his church. He refused to relinquish his attachment for the Union, and this fact, although he took no active part against the rebel cause -- which, of course, he could not do while within the rebel lines, and surrounded by rebel bayonets -- caused him to be driven from his church. Be remained at Memphis, however, preaching most of the time in a public hall, without compensation, until that city was occupied by the Union forces. Soon thereafter he was called to the pulpit of the Central Presbyterian Church of this city, and at the same time he received a call from Chilicothe. He finally accepted the former, and about three years ago he was installed as pastor of that church, where he has since labored earnestly and successfully."

lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK VS. BROOKLYN -- THE EXCELSIORS AND KNICKERBOCKERS IN THE FIELD ONCE MORE. -- These two clubs of Brooklyn and New-York, the members of which are mainly from the mercantile community, Wall-street being duly represented in both organizations, meet every season in a series of friendly contests on their respective grounds, which, for true enjoyable recreation are not surpassed by any meetings on the ball-field during the season. Yesterday afternoon the first of these games for 1865 took place at Hoboken, it being the first time either club had appeared in a match game this year, and the meeting proved to be, if anything, more agreeable than any of the previous matches.

abstract: William Taylor, a returned soldier was charged with inflicting a very serious assault on Philip Houpt, the porter of a German hotel. Witness said -- I am porter of a hotel at No. 106 Grand-street; on the 30th of June the prisoner threw a stone and hit me here. (There was a very severe gash over the eye.) I came out of the house, and as soon as I came out on the sidewalk he hit me with the stone; I had no difficulty with the man; I never saw the man before, and I don't know whether he was drunk or sober.

abstract: Exorbitant Price of
lead_paragraph: We alluded the other day to the price of milk, and the meeting of milkmen in July last year to fix that price. The reasons then adduced were fair, and so acknowledged to be by the public. Not only was gold at 250, but there had been a terrible drouth, burning up everything green on the face of the earth. Now, however, all the causes for high prices have disappeared, and it is quite time that the price be reduced to the old rate, six cents a quart. The price paid to farmers by even first-class dealers, is, we understand, five cents per quart for the pure article. There is hardly any of this sold by retail pure, but on the contrary from 20 to 40 per cent. of water and salt is added according to the conscience of the dealer. Of course there are ways of detecting the adulteration, no less than there are methods of forcing down the price. We would counsel the milk trade to lose no time in the matter, since we are daily urged to print letters advocating total abstinence. We do not to-day say to our readers go without milk; but such advice must follow a further continuance of the present price.
headline: {'main': 'THE EXORBITANT PRICE OF MILK.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE EXORBITANT PRICE OF MILK.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the 26th ult. a thief entered Mr. PETER J. MASGIN's jewelry-shop, at No. 78 West Houston-street, and robbed it, during his momentary absence, of four valuable gold watches which hung on his repairing rack near the window. A little girl who sat at the threshold of No. 77, opposite, witnessed the theft, and guided by her minute description of the thief, Detective Officers BENNETT and VAUGHAN apprehended one AUGUSTUS BACON, yesterday, and he was identified. He stated, when on examination before Justice DODGE, that he was in Hartford at the time of the robbery. BACON was committed for trial.

lead_paragraph: It is now about ten years since the first installment of this work appeared in England. It was entirely unheralded by fame of any kind, without even a preface or introduction to explain the plan of the author. By its own merits the book made its way, and succeeding volumes only deepened the general conviction that an acute and powerful mind, rich in the acquired learning of the subject, was engaged in the investigation of a path, already beaten by the tracks of many inquirers, but still open to fresh and startling developments from the critical acumen of the nineteenth century. The principal characteristics of Mr. FROUDE's history are the independence of his views and the accuracy of his narrative of facts. His researches are confined, on principle, to the original authorities now for the first time, in many cases, rendered accessible through the increasing liberality that no longer condemns to dust and worms the records and archives that contain the true history of the past. The space of time included in these volumes is brief in duration, extending from 1528, the year when the divorce of HENRY VIII, from his wife CATHARINE was broached, to 1536, when the execution of ANNA BOLEYN concluded what may be called the first act of the Reformation; that great drama, the turning point of mediaeval and modern history, involving interests that still shake the solid foundations of the social world. Mr. FROUDE's reading of the character of HENRY VIII, is a new one, and startling from this very originality. It is, however, so fortified in every step, by contemporary documents and authentic testimony, that an ordinary reader is forced to acquiesce in many of his conclusions; and it is an undoubted fact that the rehabilitation of "Bluff King Hal" has made rapid progress since his cause was undertaken by an advocate of Mr. FROUDE's ability. A glowing and hearty sympathy with the nascent spirit of Protestantism and its martyrs, lends a charm to these volumes. The story of these "first Paladins of the Reformation" has never before been told in such weighty words. The connection of English, history with the transactions of the continental kingdoms, is another point brought out with great freshness and originality in this history. The condition of the people, the effect of monastic establishments, and their bearing on society, and many other subjects overlooked by prior historians, can only be studied in Mr. FROUDE's book. Two more volumes (to be issued this Fall) will complete the reign of HENRY VIII.

abstract: On Thursday, the 29th ult., at a pic-nic in Cremorne Gardens, whither, it appears, the East Houstonstreet gang of thieves and murderes went on a foraging expedition, a fight occurred between MORTIMORE MAGUIRE, son of the landlord of the Red House, Harlem, and another person, and MAGUIRE was severely beaten.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the 29th ult., at a pic-nic in Cremorne Gardens, whither, it appears, the East Houston-street gang of thieves and murderes went on a foraging expedition, a fight occurred between MORTIMORE MAGUIRE, son of the landlord of the Red House, Harlem, and another person, and MAGUIRE was severely beaten. The police interfering, the fight was stopped, and the festivities went on until late in the evening, when the party dissolved and the thieves returned by rail to the city, and the fight was resumed, with what result does not appear, since the gang, who filled the car, to the exclusion of decent people, have sealed their lips lest they be implicated in the tragedy, and sent back to Sing Sing to serve the State again. Reaching their favorite haunts, they again fought, and MAGUIRE received mortal internal injuries. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and there he died on Monday last; but Coroner GOVER, unable to secure with [???], postponed the inquest until yesterday, and then took the following and other depositions:

abstract: TRIAL OF FIRE ENGINES. The capacity of the steam fire engines of the Western District was tested yesterday afternoon, in Raymond-street, near the corner of Willoughby-street, direction of Chief-En gineer CUNNINGHAM. Several thousand spectators were present, among them two of the New-York Fire Commissioners and several Brooklyn Aldermen, all of whom seemed to take a lively interest in the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: TRIAL OF FIRE ENGINES. -- The capacity of the steam fire engines of the Western District was tested yesterday afternoon, in Raymond-street, near the corner of Willoughby-street, direction of Chief-En gineer CUNNINGHAM. Several thousand spectators were present, among them two of the New-York Fire Commissioners and several Brooklyn Aldermen, all of whom seemed to take a lively interest in the proceedings. The steamers present were Nos. 7, 9, 14 and 17, together with hand-engine No. 21. Steamer No. 2, for some unexplained cause, was not on hand. Each engine had full complements of men, who did their duty with a will. The operations commenced shortly after 2 o'clock P.M. by raising steam. No. 7 got up steam in four minutes; No. 9 in three and a half minutes; No. 14 in three minutes, and No. 17 in four and three-quarter minutes. No. 7 started in four minutes; No. 9 in six minutes; No. 14 in seven and three-quarter minutes, and No. 17 in five and three-quarter minutes. The result of the playing was as follows:

abstract: Messrs. WILLIAM and MAROUS SAMUEL's hair net manufactory at No. 138 Canal-street was entered by burglars, on the night of April 28, and $700 worth of silks, thread and ready-made nets were stolen. No clue to the thieves was obtained until Wednesday, when Policeman LYON, of the Tenth Ward, found twenty-five nets in MORRIS SILLECK's fancy goods store at No. 231 William-street. SILLECK was thereupon arrested, and Justice SHANDLEY held him in $1,000 bail....WM. ALSCHWEE, of No. 155 Eldridge-street, appeared against ELIZABETH TAYLOR, and astonished Justice SHANDLEY by swearing that the girl robbed him in a den in East Houston-street. The accused, who is a native of Ireland and lives at No. 172 Elizabeth-street, was committed....Yesterday morning, JAMES HAYDEN, of No. 7 Leonard-street, fell asleep in a cart in Ninth-street, near Third-avenue, and one JOHN STEWART stole his wallet. Policeman SMITH, of the Seventeenth Ward, witnessed the transaction, and pursed STEWART to Eleventh-street and Avenue-D, where the fugitive was captured. STEWART was committed.

abstract: Card on United Service ??? >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday Mr. AARON L. REED, a merchant, of No. 83 John-street, entered a complaint against JOSEPH SHEPHERD, of Charleston, S.C., alleging that on the 30th ult. SHEPHERD called on him, and said that he was a son of B.A. SHEPHERD, of Houston, Texas, with whom the complainant is well acquainted, and asked for a loan of $50, till his father's arrival in this city in the course of a few days. Mr. REED advanced the money, but subsequently learned that the accused was not a son of B.A. SHEPHERD as represented, but that his name was SAMUEL B. WEBBER. Mr. WM. P. MCGOWAN, formerly of Houston, Texas, who is now stopping at the New-York Hotel, testified that he had known WEBBER for the last five years. Officer STILLWELL arrested the accused, and the latter charged MCGOWAN with having been in the rebel army. MCGOWAN acknowledged that he had been a Captain in the Southern army, and said that WEBBER was a private in his company, but deserted and came North. Justice DOWLING committed WEBBER for trial.

abstract: Firemen's Fights; Must be Stopped
lead_paragraph: Our reporters give an account of another incipient riot got up by firemen and runners last evening. For a time the brawl went on with great violence, and the rival factions or companies enjoyed the pleasure of trying to kill each other without let or hindrance, because -- and here is the fact of main importance -- "the Chief Engineer and his assistants had completely lost control of the men," and their efforts to stop the disgraceful row were simply laughed at. In a short time, however, a squad of policemen came down the street at double-quick, and the fighting firemen left, at a little more than double-quick.

abstract: Maximilian on Education
lead_paragraph: MAXIMILIAN, it will be seen by our Havana letter, has given new cause of offence to the retrrogade party in Mexico by his communication to the Minister of Public Instruction on the subject of popular education. The Emperor takes the radical ground that education must not only be open to all, but that, with respect to elementary education, it must be free of charge while attendance is made compulsory. As to religious education, he leaves that entirely with the priests, considering that "the less the State meddles in religious matters, the more faithful it is to its mission." This, it must be confessed, is advanced ground for an Austrian Prince to occupy. And looking to the positive disregard of the ecclesiastical party which is shown in the issue of this State paper alone, we can hardly wonder that the Prince's agent at Rome has left the Vatican under the severe displeasure of the Pope. Stranger things have happened than that the Liberalists of Mexico should seek for a constitutional government under MAXIMILIAN. Much depends upon his power to withstand the influence of the hierarchy.
headline: {'main': 'MAXIMILIAN ON EDUCATION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'MAXIMILIAN ON EDUCATION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Ninety-first Veteran New-York Regiment numbering 676 men and officers, under the command of Brevet Brig.-Gen. J. TARBELL, arrived yesterday noon, from Washington by the New-Jersey route. Landing at the foot of Cortlandt-street, they proceeded up town to the rooms of the State Agency corner of Centre and Grand-streets, where all needful accommodations and refreshments were afforded them. The regiment subsequently left by chartered steamer for Albany, where they will be mustered out.
