abstract: FIRES AND FIREMEN's FIGHT. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning a stock belonging to the Board of Publication of the Dutch Reformed Church, on the first floor of No. 103 Fulton-street, corner of William, was seriously damaged by fire and water. The origin of the fire does not appear....On Wednesday evening a car load of hay, of the value of $700, was consumed at the intersection of Fourth-avenue and One Hundred and First-street, having taken fire from sparks from a locomotive. Subsequent to the fire a fight occurred between THOMAS KENNEDY, foreman of Fire Engine Company No. 49, and JOHN O'DONNELL, of Fourth-avenue near Eighty-fifth-street; foreman of Hose Company No. 48, and the former struck the latter on the head with his speaking-trumpet, injuring him severely. KENNEDY fled and was pursued, but not captured, by the Harlem Police, and O'DONNELL was taken home.

abstract: Microscopical Society Organized
lead_paragraph: -- A number of scientific gentlemen met at No. 72 Varick-street, last Tuesday afternoon, and organized the New-York Microscopical Society, by electing A.A. STARR, Esq., the well-known microscopist, President, and Prof. HENDRICKSON, of the Grand-street School, Secretary. The society will hold its next regular meeting at the same place, on the last Wednesday of this month, at 8 o'clock P.M.

abstract: -- A YOUNG LADY KILLED BY A STROKE OF LIGHTNING. -- A correspondent of the Hartford Post writes from Collinsville, Ct.: On Sunday morning, about four o'clock, a severe thunder shower passed over this section. The house of Dr. B.A. KASSON was struck by lightning, and his daughter, JOSEPHINE KASSON, aged twenty-three years, was instantly killed. Her sister, two years older, was sleeping with her, and although severely burned and injured, will probably recover. The father hastened to the relief of his daughter DORA, who was in great distress, and after getting her easier reached over to the back side of the bed, putting his hand on the shoulder of JOSEPHINE to waken her, saying, "Come, your sister is hurt," and was horror-struck on finding her dead. He immediately placed the body on the kitchen floor before an open door, and commenced the application of cold water, hoping to resuscitate the body, but all his efforts were fruitless. While attempting to restore the daughter to life, the lightning struck again in the door-yard, passing down a tulip tree, tearing off fragments and scattering them over the ground, and temporarily stunning the Doctor by the explosion. There were only Dr. K. and his two daughters in the house at the time, Hundreds of people were visiting the scene of the disaster during the day. There was no lightning rod on the house, and it is difficult to tell where the fluid first hit the house; its track is visible in various places on the corners and angles of the main house and L part. From appearances, the electric current branched off in different directions. One branch went down the corner where the girls slept, and when opposite the bed, passed inside, striking the young lady near the ear, then down the back to the hips, and then passed to the sister. The skin was lacerated on both of them. One branch of the fluid passed down the tin conductor to the bottom, then tore off some boards, passed through under the stone step, plowed two small furrows in the earth, leaving two holes where it disappeared. This makes not less than five times that lightning has struck buildings within a few years in that neighborhood.

abstract: Gen. SHERMAN is here, and cordially welcomed by the city and the citizens. A citizens' banquet, costing over $4,000, is given him to-night. Of the four hundred or more banqueters fifty will be invited and the rest will pay $10 or more apiece. He was publicly received to-day by Mr. GUTHRIE, and happily responded. The point Gen. SHERMAN made, as I understood him, was the supremacy of the government and the permanency of the Union.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: Reported Cession of Sonora
lead_paragraph: We have news direct from Vera Cruz to-day, as late as the 28th of June. The story is revived of the intended cession of Sonora and other Pacific States to France. The Emperor MAXIMILIAN, so it is alleged, is about to issue a decree mortgaging all the vast mining property of these States to the French Government as security for the debt incurred in the regeneration of Mexico. There is no authority given for the story. Repeated denials, official and semi-official, have been given to similar statements on previous occasions. And, before giving credit to the report in its present shape, it is perhaps well to wait for the issue of the promised decree.

abstract: One of the Democratic General Committees, of which Mr. E.J. LOWBER is Chairman, adopted an address at their recent meeting, in which the policy of President JOHNSON, as thus far divulged, was indorsed. Another General Committee, called the Regulars, held a meeting on Thursday night, at which the Chairman, JAMES DEVAUCNE, resigned, and Col. CALVIN E. PRATT was elected in his place.

abstract: A false alarm of fire, at about 9 o'clock last evening, brought out the firemen of the Fifth District; and several fire companies having met in Canal-street, near the Bowery, an attempt was made to create a riot. The police of the Sixth Ward, anticipating difficulty, were promptly on the ground, and on the first blow, they stepped in, and scattered the crowd. No arrests were made. Multitudes of citizens tarried in the Bowery, near Canal and Grand streets, until a late hour in the evening, evidently expecting to witness the promised riot among firemen, but they were disappointed.

abstract: From the records of the Court of Special Sessions, it appears that during the six months ending June 30, 1864, nine hundred and nine offenders were tried. During the corresponding period of this year, one thousand and forty-seven here placed on trial, being an increase of one hundred and thirty-eight. Of these cases tried during the six months ending July 1, 600 were cases of larceny, and 415 of assault and battery.
lead_paragraph: From the records of the Court of Special Sessions, it appears that during the six months ending June 30, 1864, nine hundred and nine offenders were tried. During the corresponding period of this year, one thousand and forty-seven here placed on trial, being an increase of one hundred and thirty-eight. Of these cases tried during the six months ending July 1, 600 were cases of larceny, and 415 of assault and battery. Of these offenders 687 were males, and 360 females, 819 were convicted, and 228 were turned out of court with a Scotch verdict, "Not proven." The greatest number of assaults and battery cases occur in the warm weather. Thus 43 persons are charged with these offences in February, while in June there are 107. Of the 173 tried in January, only 22 were acquitted, while in sultry June there were 55. In the cold weather more females fight than men.

abstract: The corner-stone of the church of the Fortieth-street Presbyterian Church, near Lexington-avenue, was laid on Thursday afternoon with appropriate ceremonies. The pastor, Rev. C.E. HART, read an historical sketch of the enterprise, and addresses were made by Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL and Mr. KELLOGG. The corner-stone was laid by B.B. ATTERBURY, Esq. The church will be free from debt, all the money needed for its erection being already subscribed. The chapel will be 44 feet front by 99 feet in depth, of two stories, containing a fine audience-room, lecture-room, Sunday school and infant school rooms, &c.

abstract: Memorials; Monumental Art
lead_paragraph: Numerous distinct movements are progressing in different ports of the country, looking to the erection of monuments to the late President LINCOLN, designed to commemorate alike the wonderful era in which he lived, and the popular appreciation of his public life and service. Among the pending propositions is one for a monument over the honored grave at Springfield, Ill. Another is talked of in this metropolis; and California proposes to excel all other sections in lavish expenditure for a splendid monumental pile upon the Pacific shore.

abstract: The Kings County Circuit Court is finishing up the business of June. The next regular term will be held in October. The July term of the Brooklyn City Court will be commenced on Monday, the 10th inst., when the first twenty causes on the calendar will be taken up. Issues of fact before a jury, will be tried the second week, and all other issues the fourth week. Notes of issue for the September term should be filed on or before Saturday, Aug. 26.

abstract: Mlle. MORENSI, the favorite vocalist, residing in Brooklyn, is to take her departure for Europe to-day in the steamship Virginia, with the intention of remaining absent for one year. She is to proceed to Milan, Italy, where she will devote herself to the study of operatic music and the cultivation of her voice. The friends of the lady have presented her the handsome sum of $1,500 in gold.

abstract: Mr. WILLIAM S. KEEPS, of No 226 West Twenty-fourth-street, made oath that recently while riding in the Central Park with one JOHN H. MCKIBBEN, that person took his gold watch and declined to restore the same; that the two rode down the avenues to the Bowery, the deponent repeatedly demanding his watch and MCKIBBEN repeatedly making evasive replies; that when far down the Bowery deponent left the carriage and entered a shop to make a purchase; that MCKIBBEN remained in the carriage saying that he would take care of the horse until deponent's return, and that on completing his purchase and seeking MCKIBBEN and the horse and carriage they were nowhere to be found. Mr. KEEPS thereupon entered complaint at the Sixteenth Precinct Police-station, and after diligent search Policeman JAMES KRUNAN found MCKIBBEN at the Dupont House, on the northeast corner of Hudson and Laight streets, and took him into custody. The prisoner, who is a person of superior address, was committed for examination.

abstract: -- J. MORAN and JAMES J. HAYES were tried in this court yesterday on the charge of stealing three horses from the stable of Alderman BLISS in Greenpoint, on the night of the 24th of May last. The accused were found in possession of the animals, on their way to the ferry. The horses, valued at about $2,000, were identified shortly after the arrest of the accused, who were convicted and remanded for sentence ....JOHN MEINKES was arraigned for robbery, in having stolen from the room of Mrs. MATILDA WITTENBURG, in the 17th Ward, on the 1st of July, 1864, the sum of $900 in greenbacks, which amount had been placed in her keeping by her husband and brother, who had enlisted. A verdict of guilty was rendered by the jury....JAMES MYERS was convicted of committing a feloneous assault with a knife upon M.J. BURNS, of No. 152 Second-street. He explained, in extenuation, that he had mistaken BURNS for another man with whom he had a difficulty. The prisoners were remanded for sentence.

abstract: the Fluctuations in
lead_paragraph: It is of high importance to the government and the public, to the national finances and the general popular economies, that the price of gold should approximate as nearly as possible to par -- (we use the current phraseology.) While at its present rate, or at any great valuation above the issues of legal national currency based on public credit, there is with every day's expenditure a large and unnecessary addition made to the public debt; for our current expenditures and aggregate permanent indebtedness are greater by just so much as the purchasing power of currency is less than that of gold. If, in the future, we pay our debt in coin, we shall have to disburse as many gold dollars as we run in debt paper dollars; and should the principal of our debt become a permanency, the burden of the annual interest upon it (the greater part ultimately payable in coin) will, of course, be proportioned to its magnitude, which is increased in the ratio of the depreciation of government paper. The question affects the entire community, also, in their daily ordinary affairs; for it is impossible to have a stable, definite and satisfactory regulation of the prices of the necessaries of life, and the prices of labor, while the purchasing power of the legal currency, as compared with that of coin, is liable to such perturbations and irregularities as we have been and are still suffering from.

abstract: -- The offshoot of the old firm of TICKNOR & FIELDS appears on Broadway under the sign of B.H. TICKNOR. Its location is at No. 823, hitherto occupied by WALTER LOW, who has disposed of his stock books, stationery, &c., &c., to the above-named gentleman, and commends him to the public. Mr. TICKNOR has had thorough experience in the business, having been an efficient member of the veteran Boston publishing house with which his name is identified.

abstract: Assassins; Execution of the
lead_paragraph: No par of the duty assigned to the Military Commission, at whose hands the assassins received the award of justice, was performed with more satisfaction to the public than that which provided for summary dispatch in carrying the sentence of the Court into effect. The last of the black and horrible record is given to-day. The execution of the four principal criminals was demanded by every consideration of justice, of policy, of public and private security. It had to be gone through with in some fashion; and it was fortunate that it was in hands where needless delays were avoided, and where the arm of the law's executor could not be arrested for an hour beyond that designated for the final close of the tragedy.

abstract: In the management of our Internal Revenue Department hundreds and thousands of officers are charged with delicate duties whose performance demands not only quickness, business aptitude and professional familiarity with accounts, but a sound judgment, a calm head and a love of equity. This is a wide range, and it would be strange indeed if the former head of the department, or the illustrious Chief-Justice of the United States, had been so fortunate as to select only competent and desirable men for the thousands of positions at their command. At all events very many men were appointed whose fitness for office amounted to nil, and whose resignations have been cheerfully received by the responsible head of the department. Among those who have held on from the first there are many degrees of excellence; some have been faithful if not accurate, others diligent and prompt if not always effective, others have displayed great executive ability, and have been advanced from posts of comparative obscurity to those of wider range and graver responsibility -- while one of the collectors originally appointed, Mr. WM. ORTON, of the Sixth Collection District, has so fully and ably discharged his duties, and evinced such signal knowledge of the infinite ramifications and bewilderments of the law, that the Secretary has been pleased to place him at the head of the bureau, and to locate him in the fever hole of the country, Washington City.

abstract: The wills of the following named persons have just been admitted to probate namely: Archibald Gracie, George Derr, James L. Montgomery, Henry Stevens, William Roberts, Ann Graham and Martha Codwise. None of these wills, excepting the two last named, contain bequests of any interest to the public. The will of Ann Graham bequeaths the sum of $500 to the American Bible Society; $560 to the Leake and Watts Orphan House; $500 to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America; $500 to the Trustees of the Board of Domestic Mission of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America; $250 to the Society for the Relief of Aged and Respectable Indigent Females; $250 to St. Lukes Home in Hudson-street; and $250 to the Colored Home for Aged Indigent People of Color.

abstract: The Staten Island ferryboat Northfield, while on her 9 o'clock trip from New-York, and when about a mile below Governor's Island, ran into the steamer Joseph Belknap, also bound down the bay, while endeavoring to cross the Northfield's bow. The Belknap had her port wheel-house, with the guard and rail carried away, and wheel somewhat damaged. The Northfield did not receive any damage.

abstract: The following named cavalry officers, specially called for by Maj.-Gen. SHERIDAN, will leave to-day in the steamship Guiding Star for New-Orleans, where they will report for duty: Brevet Maj.-Gen. A. Gibbs, Brig.-Gen. Charles L. Fitzhugh, Capt. J.H. Mahnkin, A.A.G.; Capt. A.M. Halberstadt, A.D.C.; Capt. William Shephard, A.D.C., Lieut. J.C. Wiggins, Signal Officer. The above named officers have been under the command of Gen. SHERIDAN, throughout all of the Lard fought battles of the last year and found themselves worthy of his confidence. Hence he desires them with him now.

abstract: Yesterday, at the billiard-room of CHARLES J. CHYLER, was made the largest run of billiards ever recorded. It was played by Mr. FREDERICK G. BRITTON, a fine amateur player of this city. He commenced a friendly game with another gentleman, and, after making a run of thirty-five points, got the two red balls in the corner, and made the unprecedented number of seven thousand seven hundred and fifteen points. The largest run heretofore recorded was six thousand one hundred and fifty points. It was made by a gentleman in Louisville, Ky., a few weeks ago. The run made yesterday by Mr. BRITTON was upon a full carom table, and occupied four hours and twenty-five minutes. The balls were out of their position, in the corner, six times during the play, but, by the expert manipulation of the player, were brought back. There was not a "foul" stroke made in the run, and the counting only ceased by the balls becoming " froze." This remarkable run shows extraordinary nerve and the utmost delicacy of touch in striking the balls. -- Cleveland Herald.

The run made yesterday by Mr. BRITTON was upon a full carom table, and occupied four hours and twenty-five minutes. lead_paragraph: The grave of the mother of our late President is located in Spencer County, Indiana, near the little village of Gentryville, embowered amid the majestic forest trees of the country. There is neither headstone nor monument to denote the sacred spot, and the place where the remains lie buried is an unfrequented locality, or comparatively so. A short time before his death, Mr. LINCOLN wrote a letter, expressing his intention to visit the grave this Summer, and cause a suitable monument to be erected; and in this letter (to an old friend) he expressed the regret that the business cares of life had so long compelled him to postpone this duty.

abstract: -- Three professional bounty-jumpers made their escape this week from the fourth-story window of the barracks corner of Elm and Broome streets, by tearing their blankets up and making ropes of them. One of them, named YOUNG, had been sentenced to ten years' hard labor on the Dry Tortugas; another, one WARD, had been sentenced to two years in the Clinton State Prison, and the third, one WARNER, to one year in another prison.

abstract: Outbreak with and Stirring up of Strife
snippet: Outbreak with and Stirring up of Strife
lead_paragraph: -- An evening cotemporary having reached the conclusion that a casus belli is "an event but too probable in the complicated relations and still unsettled questions" between the United States and Great Britain, proceeds to illustrate the numberless grievances of a minor kind, of which we have reason to complain, and which will tend to embitter the coming struggle. These minor grievances include what some nameless writer said, two years ago, about the Southern Confederacy in the Journal of Mental Science; what another nameless writer said more recently in the Tory Quarterly Review; and what still another said in Blackwood's (Tory) Magazine. As a specimen of what we ought to treasure up in view of the coming war, we are reminded that one of these Tory writers recently informed the British public that "the deciduous cypress is a native of the Confederate States of America.!" This was bad enough, no doubt. It showed that the British Tory writer recognized the spurious Confederacy -- a very malicious act on his part certainly. But does it not occur to the New-York journalist, that when he condescends to go into a revival of such rubbish as this -- rubbish uttered in nine cases out of ten by nameless, brainless, and utterly irresponsible individuals -- that he is making more both of them and their stuff than they are worth? We don't think it need aggravate our people, beyond all power of self-control, even if some scientific bummer, writing for a British periodical, did declare the deciduous cypress to be a Confederate plant. It only showed that he was thinking more of the history of the rebellion, than of natural history, when he wrote.

abstract: -- A meeting of the board was held on Thursday evening at Firemen's Hall, for the purpose of settling up all unfinished business. Mr. PLATT presided. It was decided to present the banner of the Department and also the monument in Firemen's Hall to Exempt Engine Company. The Marshall House fia -fire bucket of the Cumberland, and other military trophies of the Department have already been presented to the Bureau of Military Statistics in Albany. Mr. PLATT returned thanks for the courtesy he had received from the board during the last five years, and reminding the members that the board had no longer a legal existence, the meeting, on motion, adjourned sine die.

lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Press characterizes it as a "stupendous delusion to expect Congress and the Executive to do that for the uneducated freedmen of the South, which the independent States of the North have failed or refused to do for the better trained and more experienced free colored men in their section." In the main, we believe this is true. Still it is evident that negro suffrage in the Southern States is pressed upon public favor by many considerations which do not affect it at the North.

abstract: -- The inconveniencies of the English railway-car are amusingly illustrated by a fact which has just come to light in the course of a Parliamentary inquiry. It was stated that no officer or employe of a railway will occupy a compartment with a female, unless other passengers are present, for fear of being accused of assault, or some other misdemeanor. Accusations of this sort have become so frequent of late, that gentlemen of character and experience, when traveling in an English car, prefer almost any company to that of an interesting but unprotected female.
lead_paragraph: -- The inconveniencies of the English railway-car are amusingly illustrated by a fact which has just come to light in the course of a Parliamentary inquiry. abstract: Distress of
lead_paragraph: -There is a wider field now open in this city for the operations of the benevolent and philanthropic than was ever before presented. Thousands of widows and orphans, whose natural protectors have fallen in the war, are imploring for relief. The fund from which the county has supplied a pittance to this much-to-be commiserated class is completely exhausted, and it is estimated that not less than ten thousand helpless women and children are now without any means of support whatever, except such as is derived from public charity. The number of beggars in our streets, many of them children of tender years, has greatly increased within the last few months. The Five Points House of Industry, and similar institutions, are filled to repletion. Our citizens should consider the fact that these widows and orphans have a claim upon them which cannot be disregarded. The lives of their natural protectors have been sacrificed in the defence of the country, and they can rightfully demand something in return. They ask but food and shelter or the means whereby they may obtain them. Some action should be taken, and that speedily, to relieve their necessities, or we shall no longer be able to boast of our unstinted charities. Millions of dollars have been raised to relieve the wants of sick and disabled soldiers; a few thousands would be sufficient to save their families from starvation.

abstract: On the 1st inst. a gang of burglars entered Messrs. JOHN PULLMAN & CO.'s warehouse, at No. 321 Broadway, and stole $800 worth of muslins. These goods were taken to No. 2 Rivington-street, and there repacked, after which they were sent by express to BERNARD SPRINZE, of No. 437 Grand-street, and by him held for a sale. SPRINZE was arrested yesterday by Detective Officers COYLE and TIEMANN, and held for examination by Justice DOWLING.

abstract: THE TROUBLES IN THE E.D. FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- The agitation in the Fire Department, arising from the recent action of the commissioners in the matter of the bell-ringers and disbanding of certain companies, still continues, with no prospect of a speedy abatement. Last night a committee, consisting of one member from each company, assembled at Firemen's Hall, by direction of the Board of Representatives, with a view to harmonize existing troubles with the commissioners. After considerable fencing by the leaders of the clashing factions, the committee adjourned without marking out any line of future proceeding.

abstract: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- Mr. COLVILLE could hardly fulfil his intentions with regard to this establishment during the brief engagement of Mr. and Mrs. HENRY WATKINS. These artists were pleasant enough in a small way, but a small way was not at that time required. A few years ago it would have been regarded as absurd to play a melodrama in the dog days. Light, effervescent pieces, such as the WATKINS' affect with ordinary success, were the vogue. Now we take our horrors hot After all, it is easier to thrill than to laugh. To the man who has been pulling through a sweltering day, it is agreeable for a short period to hold his breath. Acting on this hint, Mr. COLVILLE has now engaged Miss KATE REIGNOLDS, and simultaneously produced the spectrality called the "Angel of Midnight." Both the lady and the work are known in New-York; the former having played several engagements at BURTON's, and the latter having been produced at the Museum. The lady is an excellent actress. Her education was received in a good school, and she has not forgotten its precepts in the vicissitudes of many country towns. The opportunities afforded in the present play, are to a great extent pantomimic. No one need doubt that who posses the theatre, and notices the many reductive portraits which render its entrance so attractive. This, however, is unimportant. Pantomime demands experience more than any other form of art, and Miss REIGNOLD's pantomime is exceedingly good. Such language too as falls to her part, is uttered with feeling and expression. We question if there is another actress in the city who could play the Angel of Death so quietly and yet so powerfully.

abstract: Funeral and Corporation Job
lead_paragraph: -Some weeks ago a resolution went through the Common Council to print 25,000 copies of a report of the official proceedings in this city on the occasion of the funeral of President LINCOLN. The resolution was broad and indefinite enough to have comprehended the history of man from Eden to Tammany Hall, and it would have been entirely feasible to have made such "report" one or fifty volumes, one hundred or one hundred thousand pages. The Mayor very promptly vetoed the "job," on the ground that, instead of furnishing the public with a historical memoir, the Aldermen intended to lay out a large amount of public money on "piles of printed lumber, never to be read, seldom consulted, and destined eventually for the paper-mill." But did the members give it up so? Not a bit. The veto having laid over the designated time, was squelched by the Aldermen a few days ago. The resolution is now before the Councilmen; at first they were going to rush it through at railroad speed, but some twinges of conscience impelled them to pause, and the matter has gone to a committee -- a course which usually indicates either that the subject is to be burked outright, strangled by a refusal to report, or "arranged" by proper conference with persons supposed to be interested. We cannot, of course, predict the fate of this grand paper-spoiling job; but there can be little doubt that it is to go through, and that the lumber-rooms in the attic of the City Hall will in time be filled with such useless stuff as that forgotten report of the Obsequies of HENRY CLAY -- (when the funeral pall was divided by the City Hall soldiery and made into coats for their friends) -- of which many thousands of copies were got rid of by the fire on the occasion of the Atlantic Cable celebration. To be sure, the newspapers have long ago given to the people everything worth knowing concerning the late President's obsequies from the White House to the grave, and most people would consider an attempt, at this late day, to make money out of our great misfortune, a matter of bad taste, to say the least; but it seems that a job is to be perfected, and neither Mayor's vetoes nor respect for public opinion are likely to interfere. So we go.

abstract: On Thursday evening private JOHN R. JONES, of Company D, Fifth New-York Heavy Artillery, who had been waiting in town to get his pay from the government, was found sick in Canal-street. He was taken thence to Bellevue Hospital, but expired before reaching that institution. He leaves a wife and several children in Southern Maryland. Mr. SWIFT, a lawyer, of No. 200 Broadway, has charge of the collection of the soldier's money.

abstract: Trade in Charleston has assumed wonderful proportions for this season of the year. The railroads are being rapidly opened, and in a short time we shall doubtless see the streets filled with drays ladon with cotton, rice and other products, and the wharves completely barricaded with merchandise. We are all looking forward to a busy season next Fall.

abstract: Dr. SHEPHARD, the original Turkish-bath man, having made a fortune and enlarged his boundaries several times, is about doing so some more, prior to which he proposes visiting the old country, where he will examine the baths of the Orientals, the laving places of the Musselmanic dignitaries, and thence return to his native shore, to impart health and perspiratory satisfaction to his friends and countrymen.

abstract: On the 4th inst. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at Mrs. LOUISA R. HULL's, No. 322 West Thirty-sixth-street, over the remains of LUCY M. FOOT, a maid of 37, who died at Mrs. HULL's on the 3d, of consumption. Miss FOOT, who was a sewing-woman, had been quite ill nearly a year, and having exhausted her means, she went to Bellevue Hospital about three months ago, but was taken thence and given a home by Mrs. HULL. Subsequent to the inquest, ascertaining that Miss FOOT's mother lived in Boston, Coroner WILDEY telegraphed to her, and received from the Boston office the reply that "hereafter all telegrams must be prepaid, or they cannot be relieved." The mother came to this city, and went to see her daughter's remains at Mrs. HULL's; but, ascertaining that there were no effects, she posted back to Massachusetts, leaving her daughter to be buried in Potter's Field. This, however, Mrs. HULL would not permit; and, interesting herself, she induced Mr. JONES STOLTS, of No. 237 Bowery, undertaker, to supply a coffin, and Mr. J.T. YOUNG to furnish a hearse, and the attaches of the Coroner's office made up a purse to cover the expense of opening a grave, and buried the deceased at Union Hill Cemetery yesterday afternoon.

abstract: Commencement
lead_paragraph: -- Commencement exercises at Dartmouth begin Sunday, July 16, with the Baccalaureate by President SMITH. Prize speaking, Monday evening, July 17, Tuesday, class-day exercises. Address before Theological Society, by Rev. EZRA ADAMS, D.D., of Philadelphia. Wednesday, July 19, address before the Phi Beta Kappa Society, by Prof. ALPHENS CROSBY, of Salem, Mass., poem by WILLIAM A.C. CONVERSE, of Toledo, Ohio. Afternoon, address before the United Literary Societies, by Hon. ALEXANDER H. BULLOCK, of Worcester, Mass., and a poem by JOHN G. SAXE. Evening, concert in the College Church by the Boston Germania Band. Thursday, July 20, commencement exercises. Preceding these at 8 o'clock A.M., the Alumni meeting will be held in the College Chapel. A large attendance of the Alumni is expected, and it is particularly desired that those who have taken part in the war for the Union should be present.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen was called for 2 o'clock this afternoon, but a quorum was not present. It is understood that the subjectto be considered was a preamble and resolution to the effect that as the contractors for cleaning the streets have failed to perform their duty, the Mayor be requested to convene the Board of Health immediately for the purpose of having the dirt and garbage removed from the streets forthwith.

abstract: Dispatches given elsewhere this morning, informus of the fate of the parties tried before the military court at Washington, for complicity in the assassination plot which resulted in the foul murder of President LINCOLN. Four of the parties -- HARROLD, the companion of BOOTH; PAYNE, the man who attempted the murder of Mr. SEWARD; ATZEROTH, who undertook the murder of President JOHNSON, but lost heart and bolted, and who was mixed up with the whole conspiracy, and Mrs. SURRATT, whose house was the headquarters of the plotters, and who would almost seem to have been the leading spirit of the conspiracy, are sentenced to death, and are to be executed to-day. The others -- Dr. MUDD, O'LAUGHLIN and ARNOLD, are sentenced to imprisonment for life. SPANGLER the stage carpenter, who assisted BOOTH in his escape, is sentenced to six years' imprisonment. The evidence upon which these sentences are based was, it is generally admitted, most conclusive -- so much so that in at least one case, the lawyer for the accused attempted no other defence than an argument that his Southern fanaticism convinced the wretch that he was doing right. Indeed, the chief argument for the defence in all the cases was a denial of the jurisdiction of the court. The fate of the condemned will excite little sympathy in any respectable community in any part of the world. Those unenviable natures that could rejoice at the fate of President LINCOLN and mourn the death of BOOTH as a martyr and a hero, win, no doubt, grieve for the miscreants just condemned at Washington. But among right-minded people, there can be out one opinion as to the justness of the punishment which has overtaken BOOTH's accomplices.

The others -- Dr. MUDD, O'LAUGHLIN and ARNOLD, are sentenced to imprisonment for life. SPANGLER the stage carpenter, who assisted BOOTH in his escape, is sentenced to six years' imprisonment. The evidence upon which these sentences are based was, it is generally admitted, most conclusive -- so much so that in at least one case, the lawyer for the accused attempted no other defence than an argument that his Southern fanaticism convinced the wretch that he was doing right. Indeed, the chief argument for the defence in all the cases was a denial of the jurisdiction of the court. The fate of the condemned will excite little sympathy in any respectable community in any part of the world. Those unenviable natures that could rejoice at the fate of President LINCOLN and mourn the death of BOOTH as a martyr and a hero, win, no doubt, grieve for the miscreants just condemned at Washington. But among right-minded people, there can be out one opinion as to the justness of the punishment which has overtaken BOOTH's accomplices.

abstract: Tribune Correspondent. Author of Croton Dam Plot
snippet: Tribune Correspondent. Author of Croton Dam Plot
lead_paragraph: -- Evidence is produced in the Toronto (Canada) papers to show that CONOVER, the confidential correspondent of the Tribune, was the author of the project to destroy the Croton Aqueduct. We publish CONOVER's proposition on the subject, as it was submitted to JACOB THOMPSON in detailfor that worthy's approval. This CONOVER is a healthy sort of correspondent to have about a daily newspaper. A few more like him would make a morning paper lively.

abstract: Hardship to Prisoners
lead_paragraph: There are three places of detention in this city for persons awaiting trial at the Courts of General or Special Sessions, viz., the Tombs, Jefferson Market and Essex Market Prisons. At each of these jails the authorities suffer an individual, termed a "runner," to act as the medium of communication between the prisoners and their friends outside the cells. In this business the "runner" has a monopoly. He fixes his own rates of compensation, consults his own convenience as to the time of executing his commissions, and is responsible only to his own conscience for the faithful performance of the duties of his calling.

abstract: Anthony L. Gescheid was charged with assaulting Frederick Bergold, in the wine saloon No. 49 Bowery. Complainant said: In the last week of the month of April, I believe the 27th, I drank four glasses of wine, in this house of Mr. Bruckbower; I met this gentleman bore, (the prisoner,) and he talked about Lincoln and Booth two hours, and he said what Booth had done was right; then I said he had no right to talk so, and I said his uncle was a poor man, and he said he would have satisfaction, and he had a big ring on his finger, and he said he would have satisfaction, and he hauled off and gave me a big kick on the eye; he struck me twice.

abstract: -- The New-Bedford Mercury slates that the [???]te EDWARD M. ROBINSON left $10,000 to the town of South Kingston, R.I., where he spent his early years; $10,000 to Mr. BARLING, his confidential clerk; $10,000 to ABNER, H. DAVIS, formerly of New-Bedford, and for many years in the employ of the deceased, and $1,000 to WILLIAM E. WATSON, of New-Bedford, a clerk. The principal portion of his property is left to his daughter, an only child, $1,000,000 in fee, and the balance, probably more than $1,500,000, in trust. The executors are Mr. EDWARD D. MANDELL, of New-Bedford, and Messrs. BARLING and DAVIS, of New-York.

abstract: -- About a year ago, Miss Dr. MARY E. WALKER, it will be remembered, was captured in front of Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON's army, in Tennessee, and sent to Richmond. After being incarcerated for a considerable period in Castle Thunder, she was released, much to the gratification of those who do not believe in the imprisonment of females except upon very aggravated charges. Since then we have heard nothing of her until we saw her yesterday upon Broad-street, clad in a blue coat with military buttons, and a very long skirt, a pair of nicely-fitting blue pants (not like the dandies now wear,) and gaiters, which fitted so as to display a pretty foot. As she passed the Powhatan Hotel she was followed by a number of colored school boys and girls, and by the time she reached Seventh-street, her retinue in number would have done no discredit to a lieutenant-general. Ladies congregated upon the corners, and men and boys stopped along the sidewalk to comment upon the novel appearance of a lady in uniform. At the corner of Sixth and Broad streets, as she turned to go through the market, she was stopped by the provost-guard, who asked her by what authority she appeared upon the streets in the garb in which she was attired. She replied, "By what authority do you make the inquiry?" Guard -- "By order of the Provost-Marshal." "Then give him my compliments and tell him I will call upon him." She then moved off as if nothing had occurred. Dr. WALKER, we learn, has been South in search of her brother, who belonged to the army, and was fortunate enough to find him. -- Richmond Bulletin, June 28.

abstract: Steel Furnaces, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The first named of these interests is in a very depressed condition, and complaints about insufficient protection are loud and incessant. The East River Steel Works, which lately employed one hundred men, are now running only two days in the week, with an average of about ten men. The medium quality of cast-steel has been reduced from twenty-two to eleven cents per pound, from which government taxation in various shapes takes off nearly two cents. Three large steel-making establishments, in or near this city, have been closed for the present, namely, the Montauk Steel Works at Mott Haven, the National Steel Works in Forty-second-street, and the New-York Steel Works on Staten Island. At least three hundred men have thus been thrown idle. The steel men complain the more about this depression, inasmuch as they did not previously advance prices with the upward movement in gold. Thus, while by the rise of exchange, English file steel was selling for thirty-five cents, the American article was selling for twenty-one cents per pound. It is now offered at fourteen cents. By the revised tariff, the rate of duty on steel was fixed at $45 per ton, in gold, but of this it is estimated that $32 per ton, in currency, are paid back in taxes, which are piled on the top of one another. An early and thorough revision of our whole system of taxation in imperatively called for.

abstract: London Star on British Party Politics
snippet: London Star on British Party Politics
lead_paragraph: There appears to be a tacit understanding between the Whig and Tory leaders in England, that so long as Lord PALMERSTON feels that he is physically able to hold the position of Premier and leader of the Commons, there shall be no serious effort made to disturb him. The Tories have to keep up their party discipline. The Carleton Club has to do its duty by Church and State in any, and under all emergencies. In view of the approaching General Election, the party has to press into the field as many candidates as it possibly can, even in constituencies where the most moderate kind of Whigism prevails, and where moderate Whigs run no risk of being defeated by radicals. All of this must be done in view of the contingency of Lord PALMERSTON's being compelled to submit to the rapidly growing infirmities of age. In that event, it is important that Lord DERBY should have a strong Conservative phalanx of supporters at his back. But it is at the same time perfectly consistent with all this, that an understanding should exist whereby the venerable Premier should be allowed to hold his place as long as his physical strength will permit.

abstract: Notwithstanding the vigilance with which the police watch the dwellings of citizens who are absent, the burglars now and then contrive to enter these houses; but they have not, thus far this season, completed a single burglary therein. They usually undertake these jobs by daylight. On Friday afternoon a citizen discovered two young burglars in Mr. A.W. LOWERRE's dwelling, at No. 123 West Thirteenth-street, and Sergeant SMITH and patrolmen WASHBURNE, LOONEY and BURKE, having been summoned, entered the house to capture the thieves; but they fled up through the scuttle to the roof of another house, nearly half a block distant, which they entered, also through the scuttle, having forced the same with a jimmy. The officers pursued the fellows to the cellar of this house, (Mr. WM.L. SKIDMORE's,) and thence to the coal-hole, where the capture was made, not, however, without a severe fight with the burglars. The prisoners, on being taken before Justice DODGE, rendered their names as EDWARD COSTELLO and JOHN DAVIS, and stated their age as 17 and 23 years respectively. They were committed for trial. Both of the houses which they entered were vacant, the families having gone in the country for the Summer. The burglars had a complete set of tools for housebreaking, and in Mr. LOWERRE's parlors and basement they had broken opon the safe, taken up all the carpets, and packed and made ready for removal upward of $5,000 worth of wearing apparel, household furniture and trinkets.

abstract: Brace, C. L. Change in European Opinion of U. S.
snippet: Brace, C. L. Change in European Opinion of U. S.
lead_paragraph: Before writing on the especial topics of my investigations in England I desire to say a few words on a subject which may already be old with you in America. I mean the remarkable change of feeling and opinion here toward the Union cause. For weeks I have been meeting a great number of people of all possible classes and conditions, and I have as yet met but one person who showed any prejudice or hostility against America. There were always probably far more in our favor than ever appeared in the press or the expressions of the public men.

abstract: 4th of July Speech at Warren, Ohio
snippet: 4th of July Speech at Warren, Ohio
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: I congratulate you on the happy auspices under which we meet this day, to celebrate our national holiday Never before since the birth of our country have we had the same cause to exalt the 4th day of July, as we have this day. Never before did the truths of the declaration of American Independence stand out in which living light as they do this day. We have often before celebrated the 4th day of July by such scenes as these -- by popular assemblies, by orations and songs, by rockets and bonfires, by all the manifestations of joy. Foreigners, and especially our English neighbors, have ridiculed the exaggeration of national pride shown by us on the Fourth of July; but now all your joy, your pride, your boasting, cannot express the feeling of exultation with which, by the judgment of all mankind, we may this day celebrate our national holiday.

abstract: Reason for Surrender
lead_paragraph: The parting addresses of the late ConfederateGenerals to the main armies decidedly differed materially upon the reason why the rebel cause broke through. LEE declared it was in consequence of the "overwhelming numbers and resources" of the Union forces. JOHNSTON summed it up in "the disaster in Virginia, the capture by the enemy of all our workshops for the preparation of amunitionand repairing of arms, the impossibility of recruiting our little army, opposed to more than ten times its number, or of supplying it, except by robbing our own citizens." TAYLOR seems to have kept silence on the matter. KIRBY SMITH said the last ditch was evacuated by the rebels themselves. "I reached this place (Houston) to find the Texas troops disbanded, and hastening to their homes. They had forsaken their colors and commanders." And he thereupon claimed that but for this conduct, "God would yet give us the victory." Per contra, BUCKNER, commanding a part of KIRBY SMITH's troops, said they have "won the admiration of the civilized world." MAGRUDER agreed with BUCKNER. JEFF. THOMPSON, however, bluntly said:

abstract: Madawaska, S. S., Launch of
lead_paragraph: The United States screw steamer Madawaska, 17 guns, was launched yesterday at 9:33 A.M., at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Long before that hour the buildings, wharves and avenues in the vicinity of the splendid man-of-war, were crowded with ladies and gentlemen, naval officers of high rank and sub-officers, in all numbering not less than 10,000 souls. Although it was expected the launch would take place according to the announcement, between 8 1/2 and 9 1/2 o'clock, yet the wind and the high water rendered it advisable to wait, as it was feared the vessel would swing around too suddenly in the stream. At the appointed hour, as the last prop was being removed, the accomplished and youthful daughter of the designer and builder of the craft, Miss DELANO, supported by six maids of honor, dressed in white, and waving the Star Spangled Banner, advanced to the bow of the vessel, and as the craft gave the first perceptible motion toward the water, the bottle of champagne was broken across the bows, and the vessel duly christened by the name she now bears. She glided so gracefully into the water that there was not so much as a splash heard. Loud huzzas followed for the red, white and blue, and it was the universal opinion that there never was a more successful and beautiful launch.

abstract: Those strong safe chambers, designed for the secure custody of valuables of every known description, and of which an extended notice was published some time since in the TIMES, are now in full tide of successful operation. The vaults are rapidly filling with an immense store of plate and personal valuables, including bonds, wills, deeds, notes, drafts, counting-house ledgers, and even valuable descriptions of ladies' wearing apparel, such as laces, silks and jewels. The ventilation of these safe chambers is perfect. Since our former visit nearly all the spaces allotted for safes have been occupied, so that the vaults will soon be full.

abstract: Yesterday being hot and dusty, it was natural for those having leisure time to take the cars and go to the Park, to lounge the afternoon hours away beneath the shade of the wide-spreading trees on the Mall, and listen to the felicitous music provided by HARVEY DODWORTH. AS the burning sun descended to his rest, and the passing breezes became cooler and fresher, the crowds hovering around the Lake visibly augmented in their numbers, and became more active in their movements. The day in the Park was a delicious one, the great heat being sensibly and gratefully tempered by the free zephyrs playing hide and seek amid the basky retreats of the Ramble, and the other lovely vistas of the Park. The freshly sprinkled drives and walks gave renewed elasticity to the step, and the velvet sward of the level lawns, for the time free to the feet of all, was thronged by a happy crowd of children and their guardians.

abstract: New-York 127th Regiment, Formal Reception to
lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Regiment of New-York, familiarly known as the "Monitor Regiment," and of whose arrival a brief notice appeared in yesterday's TIMES, was given a formal, yet hearty welcome by the friends of the regiment, at the armory of the Seventh Regiment. Good speeches, a splendid dinner and fine singing and music comprised the interesting exercises of the day, which were as may be supposed, a perfect success.

abstract: THE WHITE MOUNTAINS AND LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG. A trip to the mountains and lake is as delightful an excursion as can be taken at this season. Passengers can leave the city by the New-Haven steamboat at 3:15 P.M., lodge at Springfield and arrive at the mountains the following evening; or, by rail, they can leave the New-Haven depot at Twenty-seventh-street at 12:15 P.M., sleeping at White River Junction and arriving at their destination the following afternoon.
lead_paragraph: THE WHITE MOUNTAINS AND LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG. -- A trip to the mountains and lake is as delightful an excursion as can be taken at this season. Passengers can leave the city by the New-Haven steamboat at 3:15 P.M., lodge at Springfield and arrive at the mountains the following evening; or, by rail, they can leave the New-Haven depot at Twenty-seventh-street at 12:15 P.M., sleeping at White River Junction and arriving at their destination the following afternoon. This route is shorter than any other by sixty miles, and affords travelers a view of the lovely scenery of the Connecticut Valley. Lake Memphremagog is on the borders of Canada, and thence Montreal and other points can be reached in a few hours. These routes were very popular last Summer, and will undoubtedly be equally so this.

abstract: Mr. GEORGE S. TURNBULL, of Boston, employed THOMAS BARTON, hackman, to drive him from University-place and Thirteenth-street to Pier No. 28, North River, on Friday evening, and on reaching the pier was required to pay $2. Understanding nine shillings to be the legal fare, he appealed to Policeman KANNEALLY, and that officer informed him that his impression was correct; but the hackman insisted that Mr. TURNBULL should pay $2, and he did so under protest, and, causing the arrest of the driver, went with him to the City Hall. The hackman, who had acted under the orders of his employers, Messrs. RYERSON & BROWN, thought that he had violated no law, his being a special hack, and as such exempt from the restrictions which the corporation ordinances place upon ordinary hacks. To test the question, Mr. TURNBULL consented, at the request of Capt. BRACKETT, to wait over to yesterday and enter complaint before the Mayor, and that official, yesterday morning, ruled that BARTON had no right to charge more than nine shillings; but as he had not intended to defraud Mr. TURNBULL, the Mayor imposed no fine, and merely required the hackman to return the seven shillings overcharge. Capt. BRACKETT desires special hackmen to note this decision and hereafter keep out of difficulty.
lead_paragraph: Mr. GEORGE S. TURNBULL, of Boston, employed THOMAS BARTON, hackman, to drive him from University-place and Thirteenth-street to Pier No. 28, North River, on Friday evening, and on reaching the pier was required to pay $2. Understanding nine shillings to be the legal fare, he appealed to Policeman KANNEALLY, and that officer informed him that his impression was correct; but the hackman insisted that Mr. TURNBULL should pay $2, and he did so under protest, and, causing the arrest of the driver, went with him to the City Hall. The hackman, who had acted under the orders of his employers, Messrs. RYERSON & BROWN, thought that he had violated no law, his being a special hack, and as such exempt from the restrictions which the corporation ordinances place upon ordinary hacks. To test the question, Mr. TURNBULL consented, at the request of Capt. BRACKETT, to wait over to yesterday and enter complaint before the Mayor, and that official, yesterday morning, ruled that BARTON had no right to charge more than nine shillings; but as he had not intended to defraud Mr. TURNBULL, the Mayor imposed no fine, and merely required the hackman to return the seven shillings overcharge. Capt. BRACKETT desires special hackmen to note this decision and hereafter keep out of difficulty.
headline: {'main': "The Mayor's Office.; CAPT. BRACKETT OBTAINS A DECISION CONCERNING SPECIAL HACKMEN.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Mayor's Office.; CAPT. BRACKETT OBTAINS A DECISION CONCERNING SPECIAL HACKMEN.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There were no returning regiments arriving yesterday, and none are expected to-day. To-morrow several regiments are likely to come from down the coast and Washington. The One Hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York Regiment was the recipient of a formal reception at the hands of its numerous city friends. A fine collation was spread in the armory of the Seventh Regiment, and speeches were made and songs sung. The One Hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York is a crack organization, and comes home in a most creditable manner.

abstract: City Railroads; Night Cars on
lead_paragraph: We trust the City Railroad Companies that run cars at very late or very early hours, will take in good part a hint which we offer, as the result of long experience in night travel. The conductors and the drivers of night cars ought to be men of great physical strength, and courageous, prompt and decided men to boot. It is no fault of the companies that rowdies, in greater or smaller force, get on to the platform, or into the inside of nearly every late car. If they do not often commit very flagrant outrages, they shout and swear, and smoke too often, we are compelled to say, without any regard to the timid remonstrances of the conductor. If the conductor is physically a feeble person, the annoyances are indulged in with a liberty proportioned thereto. A stout resolute conductor, as several we have in our eye may be described, finds it easy enough to make the "roughs" at least pay some regard to decency. And it is just such conductors we desire to see employed on every night car. The company would be themselves the gainers, if they had to pay extra for renumeration for a class of special service men at night.

abstract: A dispatch to the Chicago Journal, dated Cairo, July 6, states that the rebel gunboat Missouri, from Red River, was towed to Mound City the night previous by the Brown and Gen. Price. The Missouri was brought to the mouth of Red River by the rebel crew, consisting of seventeen seamen and two officers, who surrendered themselves and were paroled by the commander at that point. The Missouri is the last of the rebel gunboats in the Red River. Her hull is very much decayed. When delivered at the mouth of Red River she was in a sinking condition, and on her way up required half of the Brown's steam to keep nor pumped out. Her machinery, however, is good, and was working on the way up. Her sides are heavily plated with railroad iron, and she has three guns that were taken from the Indianola -- one nine and one eleven-inch, and one 30-pounder. She has a large amount of ammunition. The Mary L., also a rebel gunboat, came down at the same time, and, with the rebel ram Tennessee, lies at the mouth of the Red River.

abstract: Excise Duties, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Before resuming a review of our Metropolitan industry it may be as well to notice here the effect upon it of the excise system devised by Congress. Of course, a tax rising from three to six per cent. upon new work, and two or three per cent. upon repairs cannot fail to enhance prices. In the very nature of things a tax of six per cent. laid upon manufactures at the fountain-head, is equivalent to eight or ten per cent. before they reach the consumer. The tax paid is so much capital invested, if not directly in work or materials, yet indirectly it has to be applied, in order that the business may he carried on. Interest, risk and profits must be calculated upon the sums thus paid out, precisely as if paid for wages or raw materials. But this is not all. It happens that the law has been so construed that scarcely a commodity reaches the consumer without being taxed more than once -- in some fabrics, indeed, the collector levies thrice a 6 per cent. rate before they pass into the retailer's hands, making the aggregate equivalent to 25 or 30 per cent. Let us take a few examples: Cotton pays two cents per pound in the raw state. A manufacturer spins it into yarn, on which 6 per cent. is assessed. He sells the yarn to a weaver, who works it up into table-covers, bed-spreads or common muslins, whereupon the tax-gatherer calls again and demands 6 per cent. more. From the weaver's hands it may pass into those of the printer or dyer, who will be called on to contribute a third 6 per cent., in addition to the original levy of two cents. It would he stating a truism rather than a truth to say that these exactions are exceedingly oppressive; that their counterpart is not to he found in any other country professing to be civilized and enlightened. They are part of those burdens voluntarily assumed by the people to pay the bill of costs of a most expensive war, while it was being waged. But nothing save inexorable necessity should plead for their retention in their present shape a day longer than they can be essentially modified.

abstract: Five-Twenties, the
lead_paragraph: The news from Europe to-day, indicates that the Five-Twenties have partially recovered from the fall they had on the 23d and 24th of last month, on the receipt in the London market of American advices by the Persia. The latest London quotations we had by the China was 70 3/4. On the 22d, the highest figure reached was 74 1/2. Our news by the Belgian to-day, is to the 30th, at which date the quotation was 72. Our surmise, therefore, that the fall was a small stock-jobbing trick operated upon private advices relative to Mr. SEWARD's acknowledgment of the British withdrawal of rebel belligerent rights, will turn out, in all probability, to be correct. Mr. SEWARD, it will be remembered, in making the announcement of the withdrawal of belligerent recognition by France, said, addressing the Secretary of the Navy:

abstract: Magazines for July
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine (New-York: HARPER & BROTHERS) commences its July number with some vivid experiences of "Prison Life" in the South, by Capt. B.L. CALEB, who was captured in the Virginia Wilderness, and transferred to various Southern prisons, until exchanged in December last. He corroborates, to the fullest extent, the truth of the reported ill-treatment designedly inflicted on our men. Mr. ABBOTT's "Heroic Deeds" relates the history of the remarkable railroad raid in Georgia, undertaken by twenty-four young men of Gen. MITCHELL's command, illustrated by a fine portrait of that heroic and noble-minded man. "Garden Philosophy" is a pleasant paper, suited to the season, by Rev. S. OSGOOD. Mr. NOAH BROOKS communicates "Personal Recollections of ABRAHAM LINCOLN," and Dr. SPRAGUE's "Annals of the American Pulpit" is made the text for an amusing gathering of personal anecdotes relating to the Unitarian clergy, by Rev. S. J. PRIME. "Armadale" and "Our Mutual Friend" pursue their wonted course. The mysteries of WILKIE COLLINS' story thickens at every step; DICKENS' tale shows symptoms of winding up, with a possibility of tragic incidents looming ahead. The whole number is varied in its contents and highly readable.

abstract: -- A newsboy, named VIRGIL RANDOLPH, and living in Middletown, Del., met with a terrible death on the 23d ult. While the train was in motion, he was pushed from the platform of the baggage car by some person who was in haste to enter the eating saloon. He fell upon the track, the wheels passing over his lower extremities, crushing him into a shapeless mass up to his hips. He lived a few hours, and died without a groan or murmur.
lead_paragraph: -- A newsboy, named VIRGIL RANDOLPH, and living in Middletown, Del., met with a terrible death on the 23d ult. abstract: Amnesty Proclamation and Appeals of Wealthy; Secessionists
snippet: Amnesty Proclamation and Appeals of Wealthy; Secessionists
lead_paragraph: The President, it will be seen by the Washington dispatches to-day, is strongly importuned to modify that portion of his Amnesty Proclamation which denies the benefit of a general pardon to Southern residents, worth over twenty thousand dollars, who took part voluntarily in the late rebellion. The arguments in support of the Virginia petitioners in the immediate case before the Executive are specious enough; and in some special instances they may be sustained perhaps on strong and indisputable ground. But these strong and well-supported cases are just such as the special pardoning power held by the President can with proper effect be applied to, while the spurious cases -- such as Mr. JOHNSON refers to when he speaks of the Southern residents that have made money by war contracts, &c. -- get their proper award under the Amnesty Proclamation as it now stands.

abstract: Cotton, Speculation in
lead_paragraph: By the Belgian's news this morning it will be seen that the Manchester cotton speculators have arrived at the conclusion that two million bales is the utmost amount of cotton likely to be got out of the South, and that this will not be speedily obtained. Possibly these farseeing dealers will discover before long that they are under-estimating the amount by a considerable reckoning, and that their speculations on that basis will hardly pay. The release of internal as well as external trade throughout the South, under the Presidents last proclamation, will spoil not a few cotton speculations at home and abroad. And Manchester need not be in too great a hurry to settle the rates for the raw stuff until we see what there is of it. It will take far less time to show this than our foreign factory friends can well appreciate.

abstract: The Belgian, at Father Point, and the City of Baltimore, at this port, bring advices from Europe to the 30th ult. The Berlin correspondent of the Times says, that the American Ministers in Germany are instructed to obtain treaties, or, at any rate, binding promises, that German emigrants who have collected in the United States, before acquitting themselves of military service in Germany, shall not be held responsible for the emission and conscripted after return. At a meeting of the Cotton Supplies Association at Manchester, the speakers generally looked upon two million bales as the maximum to be expected from the South, with but little probability of speedily obtaining it. Parliament was to be dissolved July 6. Public business was virtually completed. The House of Lords, on motion of the Earl of DERBY, rejected by a majority of twenty-one the bill passed by the the House of Commons to modify the oaths required of Catholic members of Parliament. Electioneering for Parliament was growing warmer. The Great Eastern safely anchored at the Nore on the evening of the 24th ult., where she was to remain until about July 8. The shipment of coals and stores and other preparations were busily progressing. Marshal CANROBERT has been appointed commander of the Army of Paris. The Italian Government, had rejected the terms proposed by the Pope for the settlement of the question of Bishops. The negotiations were broken off. United States Five-Twenties had reached 72 in the London market.

abstract: We learn that the fire which destroyed the Sussex Herald office, at Newton, yesterday morning, involved a loss of from $7,000 to $8,000, on which there was an insurance of $5,000. The fire broke out about 3 o'clock in the morning, and the proprietors barely saved their books -- losing, however, all their files, records and valuable papers. The loss on the building, the main portion of which was saved, was probably $3,500, insured for $4,000. The building belonged to Mr. A.J. HILL. The proprietors of the Herald will go on immediately, refurnishing the office, and issuing the paper next week as usual, if it shall be found possible to do so.

abstract: Albany, Veazie, Saloon Keeper, House of $11,000
snippet: Albany, Veazie, Saloon Keeper, House of $11,000
lead_paragraph: -- The Albany Argus of the 6th has the following: EDWARD A. VEAZIE, saloon-keeper, met with a heavy loss on the Fourth. He boards with his sister, at No. 6 Dallius-street, and in the bureau of his room, which is on the third floor of his house, he had $11,000 in United States 7-30s. It was deposited in a mahogany box, and he had counted it on the morning of the Fourth. The house was left alone about an hour and a half in the evening, during the exhibition of the fireworks. When the inmates returned the house was found locked all right, and there was no evidence that a thief had been there. Yesterday morning the bureau drawer was found locked, the mahogany box was locked, a valuable diamond ring remained undisturbed, and the envelope that contained the money was there, but all else was gone. Mr. VEAZIE says that no one -- not even the family -- knew ho was possessed of the money, except Cashier WILLIAMS. Three of the bonds were of the denomination of $1,000 each, numbered respectively 48,879, 57,345 and 82,546. The remainder were of $500 each, numbered from 157,173 to 157,188, inclusive.

abstract: Nearly all the Southern soldiers from all the armies of the Confederacy, and from the prisoner camps of the North, have now got back to their homes in the various States from which they originally came. They will undoubtedly have tales to tell of their exploits during the four-years struggle; but they will also carry in their own persons and in their reminiscences proofs of the greatness of the Union, of the power of the government, of the valor of the North, and of the fact that they were, beaten, broken, and hopelessly crushed in their struggle: that the cause for which they fought was irretrievably ruined, and that the Union is established in immovable stability. The old Meas, as well as the old institutions of the Smith will thus be uprooted, and a better crop of things and thoughts will be planted.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all the Southern soldiers from all the armies of the Confederacy, and from the prisoner camps of the North, have now got back to their homes in the various States from which they originally came. abstract: Presentation. -- During the progress of the third act of "Eustache Baudine," at BARNUM's Museum, on Srturday evening, Mr. HENRY CUNNINGHAM, who was performing the part of Captain Henry De Brissac, was startled by a voice from one of the private boxes, which said, " CUNNINGHAM, a word with you." Mr. CUNNINGHAM stepped to the front of the stage near the box, and was addressed by Mr. H.B. ROOME, who held in his hand a magnificent gold watch, value $300. Mr. ROOME said, "Mr. CUNNINGHAM, a few of your mends, who nave ever admired you as a gentle man and an artist, have deputed me to present you with a small token of their esteem. I am proud, Sir, to be selected as the medium on this occasion. Take it, Sir, and wherever you go, when on look at the hour, remember that at the same moment your friends are thinking of you. Accept it, Sir, with our best wishes for your future welfare.

abstract: Opera House Erected
lead_paragraph: The long-needed desideratum at Saratoga, of a first-class place of amusement, is achieved, thanks to the enterprising liberality of the brothers LELAND -- the men of many hotels and the proprietors of that mammoth establishment at the Springs, "Union Hall." Yielding to the solicitations of this most fashionable of watering-places -- who, accustomed to the luxuries of opera, concert and first-class dramatic amusements in the Empire City, and who naturally weary of dancing, flirtation and small-talk, seek to be amused in place of amusing themselves -- the LELANDS, last season, determined to erect an opera-house in the spacious grounds attached to Union Hall, and in connection with it -- although it has another frontage on the street running parallel, for the convenience of other visitors -- and the theatre is now un fait accompli.

abstract: Mr. GEORGE S. TURNBULL, of Boston, employed THOMAS BARTON, hackman, to drive him from University-place and Thirteenth-street to Pier No. 28, North River, on Friday evening, and on reaching the pier was required to pay $2. Understanding nine shillings to be the legal fare, he appealed to Policeman KANNEALLY, and that officer informed him that his impression was correct; but the hackman insisted that Mr. TURNBULL should pay $2, and he did so under protest, and, causing the arrest of the driver, went with him to the City Hall. The hackman, who had acted under the orders of his employers, Messrs. RYERSON & BROWN, thought that he had violated no law, his being a special hack, and as such exempt from the restrictions which the corporation ordinances place upon ordinary hacks. To test the question, Mr. TURNBULL, consented, at the request of Capt. BRACKETT, to wait over to Saturday and enter complaint before the Mayor, and that official, on Saturday morning, ruled that BARTON had no right to charge more than nine shillings; but as he had not intended to defraud Mr. TURNBULL, the Mayor imposed no fine, and merely required the hackman to return the seven shillings overcharge. Capt. BRACKETT desires special hackmen to note this decision and hereafter keep out of difficulty.

abstract: There were no returning regiments arriving either yesterday or Saturday. To-day several regiments are likely to come from down the coast and Washington. Saturday afternoon, the One Hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York Regiment was the recipient of a formal, reception at the hands of its numerous city friends. A fine collation was spread in the armory of the Seventh Regiment, and speeches were made and songs sung! The One hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York is a crack organization, and comes home in a most creditable manner.

abstract: The To[???]s contains a complete description of the Taureau, a steam ram built on a new system, and lately launched at Toulon. The Taureau presents a fo[???]ridable appearance, due more to its from than to its size. The impression produced is that of an impregnable fortress; it is neither pretty nor light, and its beauty consists in its formidable appearance. The construction was commenced in 1863, and it was Admiral BOUET-WILLAUMEZ, at that time Maritime Prefect of Toulon, who, by permission of the Minister of Marine, prepared the plan of an iron-plated steam ram for the defence of the seaports. Its utility was incontestible, and it became more so after the attacks on Charleston and Fort Fisher. The Taureau draws so little water that she may be concealed close to the shore while waiting for an enemy to enter the harbor, or she may take a position in shallow water where it will be impossible to follow her. Her prow terminates in a point, and this point is armed with a kind of massive bronze cone, which serves as her spur. It is with this spur that this heavy ram, driven at a speed of twelve to fourteen knots an hour, by machinery of 500-horse power, can strike and split a ship. The Taureau is, moreover, supplied with two screws, which enable her to turn in a very small space, and with the greatest facility. She can consequently in a moment present her front to an enemy, whatever her position. Let it be supposed that an iron-plated frigate has forced the entrance to the port of Toulon, and is attacked by the ram. The latter can turn in a small space at a speed of twelve knots an hour, while the frigate, moving at that speed, must describe a circle of 600 yards in diameter. Under these disadvantageous circumstances it will be difficult for the frigate to avoid the shock of the ram. The latter can further avail herself of one large gun which she carries. Her facility of evolution will enable her to place herself in any position. She may, for example, attack the frigate by approaching her stern, and thus avoid her broadside. This large gun -- the only one the Taureau carries -- weighs twenty tons. This ram is intended not only to do buttle in the harbor and defend its entrance, but likewise to pursue a ship when she has been driven out of it. Her powerful artillery will enable her to attack an enemy on her arrival and pursue her in her flight at such a distance that it will be impossible for a frigate to return her fire. In a word, the new ram, with her formidable spur and her heavy gun, is a very terrible instrument of war, and no less efficient for defence. The Taureau has but one deck, which is plated with iron from one end to the other. The sides of the hull are likewise plated with iron the full length, from three feet under the water line to the deck. The deck and the sides form, as it were, an iron box, safe from any shot that may be fired at it. It is in this iron box that the machinery is placed, and the entire crew during an action, except those in the tower. The deck of the Taureau is covered over its entire length with a cylindrical ball-proof dome. The surface of the dome is so inclined that it is impossible to walk on it; it will consequently be impossible to capture it by boarding.
lead_paragraph: The To[???]s contains a complete description of the Taureau, a steam ram built on a new system, and lately launched at Toulon. The Taureau presents a fo[???]ridable appearance, due more to its from than to its size. The impression produced is that of an impregnable fortress; it is neither pretty nor light, and its beauty consists in its formidable appearance. The construction was commenced in 1863, and it was Admiral BOUET-WILLAUMEZ, at that time Maritime Prefect of Toulon, who, by permission of the Minister of Marine, prepared the plan of an iron-plated steam ram for the defence of the seaports. Its utility was incontestible, and it became more so after the attacks on Charleston and Fort Fisher. The Taureau draws so little water that she may be concealed close to the shore while waiting for an enemy to enter the harbor, or she may take a position in shallow water where it will be impossible to follow her. Her prow terminates in a point, and this point is armed with a kind of massive bronze cone, which serves as her spur. It is with this spur that this heavy ram, driven at a speed of twelve to fourteen knots an hour, by machinery of 500-horse power, can strike and split a ship. The Taureau is, moreover, supplied with two screws, which enable her to turn in a very small space, and with the greatest facility. She can consequently in a moment present her front to an enemy, whatever her position. Let it be supposed that an iron-plated frigate has forced the entrance to the port of Toulon, and is attacked by the ram. The latter can turn in a small space at a speed of twelve knots an hour, while the frigate, moving at that speed, must describe a circle of 600 yards in diameter. Under these disadvantageous circumstances it will be difficult for the frigate to avoid the shock of the ram. The latter can further avail herself of one large gun which she carries. Her facility of evolution will enable her to place herself in any position. She may, for example, attack the frigate by approaching her stern, and thus avoid her broadside. This large gun -- the only one the Taureau carries -- weighs twenty tons. This ram is intended not only to do buttle in the harbor and defend its entrance, but likewise to pursue a ship when she has been driven out of it. Her powerful artillery will enable her to attack an enemy on her arrival and pursue her in her flight at such a distance that it will be impossible for a frigate to return her fire. In a word, the new ram, with her formidable spur and her heavy gun, is a very terrible instrument of war, and no less efficient for defence. The Taureau has but one deck, which is plated with iron from one end to the other. The sides of the hull are likewise plated with iron the full length, from three feet under the water line to the deck. The deck and the sides form, as it were, an iron box, safe from any shot that may be fired at it. It is in this iron box that the machinery is placed, and the entire crew during an action, except those in the tower. The deck of the Taureau is covered over its entire length with a cylindrical ball-proof dome. The surface of the dome is so inclined that it is impossible to walk on it; it will consequently be impossible to capture it by boarding.

abstract: On Saturday last the Union Club of Morrisania, paid a visit to the Eureka Club, of Newark, and had a contest with them on the new ball grounds on Ferry and Adams Streets, Newark, near the Market-street depot, the result of which was the signal success of the Eureka's who played finely throughout, both at the bat and in the field. Both clubs were strongly represented, and the result is such as to make the chances of success this season, very promising for the Eurekas, as the Unions play a very strong game, and have won three of the four previous games they had played.
