abstract: AN ADROIT BURGLAR. -- The house of Mr. J.T. MCQUIRK, No. 43 Clermont-avenue, was feloniously entered on the afternoon of the 4th inst, and robbed of a watch and other articles, valued at $600. The man who perpetrated the robbery was suspected, and, as it was believed that he had gone to Philadelphia, a detective was sent after him. On the 6th inst., the same fellow, as believed, again entered the house, and stole between $300 and $400 worth of property, the officer at the same time looking for him in Philadelphia. He has not yet been arrested.

abstract: THE FIREMEN's IMBROGLIO. -- The property-holders of the Eastern District are interesting themselves with what they consider the outrages of the three Fire Commissioners. In the Seventeenth Ward, when many of the streets are without wider, the only engine in the place (No. 11) has been disbanded, and the property-owners are very much concerned at the defenceless state of their property in consequence. The only hook and ladder company in the Fifteenth, Sixteenth and Eighteenth Wards, (Americus. No. 2.) has also been disbanded. A remonstrance against this action has been signed by Alderman TAYLOR and other influential gentlemen. Judge PHILLIPS, of New-York, has been employed to bring the matter before the Board of Appeals. It is stated by the rival faction that the Donovan faction, who are in the ascendant, disbanded these companies to perpetuate their ascendancy.

abstract: On the 4th inst. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at Mrs. LOUISA R. HULL's, No. 322 West Thirtysixth-street, over the remains of LUCY M. FOOT, a maid of 37, who died at Mrs. HULL's on the 3d, of consumpiion.
lead_paragraph: On the 4th inst. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at Mrs. LOUISA R. HULL's, No. 322 West Thirty-sixth-street, over the remains of LUCY M. FOOT, a maid of 37, who died at Mrs. HULL's on the 3d, of consumpiion. Miss FOOT, who was a sewing-woman, had been quite ill nearly a year, and having exhausted her means, she went to Bellevue Hospital about three months ago, but was taken thence and given a home by Mrs. HULL. Subsequent to the inquest, ascertaining that Miss FOOT's mother lived in Boston, Coroner WILDEY telegraphed to her, and received from the Boston office the reply that "hereafter all telegrams must be prepaid, or they cannot be received." The mother came to this city, and went to see her daughter's remains at Mrs. HULL's; but, ascertaining that there were no effects, she posted back to Massachusetts, leaving her daughter to be buried in Potter's Field. This, however, Mrs. HULL would not permit; and, interesting herself, she induced Mr. JONES STOLTS, of No. 237 Bowery, undertaker, to supply a coffin, and Mr. J.T. YOUNG to furnish a hearse, and the attaches of the Coroner's office made up a purse to cover the expense of opening a grave, and buried the deceased at Union Hill Cemetery on Saturday afternoon.

abstract: Mr. B.S. abstract: The grape crop, every year growing more important, appears, especially in the western part of the State, to be very promising this season. In Hancock County it is estimated that the yield of wine will amount to nearly 1,000,000 gallons, against 250,000 last year, when the crop was almost an entire failure. Grape culture in that county is becoming very general, almost every farmer in that section having a vineyard. The varieties cultivated are the Catawba, the Delaware, (which produces a quality of wine much like the Forsterriesling, one of the best brands of Rhein wine,) and Norton's Seedling, which produces a wine similar to Port. The profits to the producer amount to from $2 to $3 per gallon.

abstract: The Berlin correspondent of the London Times says: "The American Ministers in Germany have been instructed to obtain treaties, or at any rate binding promises, to the effect that German emigrants who have settled in the United States before acquitting themselves of the duty of military service at home, shall not be held responsible for the omission and conscripted after their return home. Collisions of this sort have been rather frequent of late, and, as a rule, decided according to the circumstances of the case. The demand now raised is one exceedingly unpalatable to the governments concerned, not only because it tends to curtail that most precious and valuble among the rights of the crown -- the right to so many years of the subject's life, and, maybe, to his blood -- but also because it would be another and most effective incentive to emigration, were it accorded."

abstract: Notwithstanding the vigilance with which the police watch the dwellings of citizens who are absent, the burglars now and then contrive to enter these houses; but they have not, thus far this season, completed a single burglary therein. They usually undertake these jobs by daylight.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the vigilance with which the police watch the dwellings of citizens who are absent, the burglars now and then contrive to enter these houses; but they have not, thus far this season, completed a single burglary therein. They usually undertake these jobs by daylight. On Friday afternoon a citizen discovered two young burglars in Mr. A.W. LOWERRE's dwelling, at No. 123 West Thirteenth-street, and Sergeant SMITH and patrolmen WASHBURNE, LOONEY and BURKE, having been summoned, entered the house to capture the thieves; but they fled up through the scuttle to the roof of another house, nearly half a block distant, which they entered, also through the scuttle, having forced the same with a jimmy. The officers pursued the fellows to the cellar of this house, (Mr. WM.L. SKIDMORE's,) and thence to the coal-hole, where the capture was made, not, however, without a severe fight with the burglars. The prisoners, on being taken before Justice DODGE, rendered their names as EDWARD COSTELLO and JOHN DAVIS, and stated their age as 17 and 23 years respectively. They were committed for trial. Both of the houses which they entered were vacant, the families having gone in the country for the Summer. The burglars had a complete set of tools for housebreaking, and in Mr. LOWERRE's parlors and basement they had broken open the safe, taken up all the carpets, and packed and made ready for removal upward of $5,000 worth of wearing apparel, household furniture and trinkets.

abstract: The New-Haven Palladium says: "SAMUEL SLY, the deluded old man, and the murderer of JUSTUS MATTHEWS, of whose plan to starve himself to death we gave a full account in our issue of Friday evening last, died the same afternoon. He persisted in refusing all food and drink until death. His end was peaceful, and he retained his perceptions of all that was going on around him to the last; retaining to the last also his impressions that he was the prophet Elijah."

abstract: The new play of "Arrah-na-Pogue," by Messrs. DION BOUCICAULT and E.H. HOUSE, will be brought out at Niblo's Garden to-night. Few plays have created a greater sensation in the theatrical world. We may safely anticipate for it a hearty public acceptance, for its popularity [in England is unquestionable. Mr. WHEATLEY has exhausted the resources of his establishment in its production, and the cast is singularly strong, introducing two new artists, Mr. J.H. GLENNY and Miss JOSEPHINE ORTON, and restoring to the stage that capital actor of small parts, Mr. CHARLES PETERS, who, it will be remembered, was severely hurt a few months since.

abstract: The measure which passed the British House of Commons, a few days ago, to release Roman Catholics from an obnoxious test oath, has been summarily rejected by the House of Lords. The majority reached the respectable number of twenty-one, and on this occasion the champion of the Crown and the Established Church was Lord DERBY himself. The reigning dynasty, the constitution and its appendages generally, are thus safe a few years longer, for every Catholic who takes an official oath is still obliged to swear to what he doesn't believe.

abstract: The correspondent of the Epoque (says the Paris correspondent of the London Star) announces the opening of the Closerie des Lilaos, and describes the dancing there as characterized by more frantic vehemence than is to be seen even at one of the winter...
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the Epoque (says the Paris correspondent of the London Star) announces the opening of the Closerie des Lilaos, and describes the dancing there as characterized by more frantic vehemence than is to be seen even at one of the winter bals de l'Opera. Mabille, or the Chateau des Fleurs, are, according to his account, bals d'ambassade, or prefectorial entertainments, when compared to the Closerie. It is chiefly frequented by the students ofthe Quartier Latin and their proteges. That the homeless young student should spend his unoccupied evenings in such frightful orgies is to be deplored, but there can be but one feeling of disgust and reprobation for the women of rank and high position who consider it "the thing" to visit such scenes pour sencanailler, as they express it -- a new term which will be vainly sought in the pages of the Academy dictionary. One hears of ambassadresses and clever women too, whose intellectual powers are of no mean order, leading a party of the most aristocratic members of Paris society to St. Germain for the purpose of spending a day in the woods, and of having a dejeuner at the celebrated resturant. There, by their perfect imitation of the dress and manners of the Anonymas of another world, they attract a mob under the windows where they are breakfasting. The mob, mistaking them for those they so faithfully copy, assail them with shouts of derision and a storm of epithets not usually applicable to their class. To propitiate the angry crowd, a fair princess appears on the balcony, and sings Theresa's well-known canzonette, "Rien n'est sacr-r-e, pour un sapeur-r-r," so perfectly mimicking that personage's intonation and gestures that the song is rapturously encored. What is the result, even to these leaders of fashion in their own exclusive circle? They are known by nicknames from which any delicately-minded woman would shrink, such as canaillette, chopinette, dindonette, and many others, which, as they have appeared in an article of one of the reviews of the day, I betray no confidence in repeating, the names all bearing personally on the fair and youthful marquises and comlesses, on whom they are bestowed. The husband of a lady holding a high position in society was lately absent on business connected with his court. To pass the time of his absence a course of dancing was arranged, and in the ambassador's salons might be seen twice a week, the peculiar spectacle of the young aristocracy of the day learning the celebrated cancan, under the able tuition of a serene highness. But your probable remark is, "These things have nothing to do with English visitors to Paris. That they have is precisely the cause of my alluding to them, and I take the opportunity of once more protesting against the practice which is gradually spreading to English ladies of the highest respectability, and even rank, allowing their curiosity so far to conquer their sense of propriety as to visit these public places of entertainment. I was present lately at the Eldorado, when, in consequence of THERESA's refusal to sing, a scene took place such as at once attracted crowds of police to the spot. To my infinite disgust I heard the remarks of some French gentlemen present on the fact of the number of English young ladies brought there by their parents, and I could but admit the criticisms made on the circumstance to be perfectly justified. As long as the delightful Concert Musard is open in the Champs Elysees, no excuse exists for lovers of music in the open seeking elsewhere that recreation.

abstract: Empire vs. Atlantic, at Bedford; Manhattan vs. Satellite
snippet: Empire vs. Atlantic, at Bedford; Manhattan vs. Satellite
lead_paragraph: A very interesting match took place between the second nines of these Clubs at Bedford yesterday, it being about as fine a display of batting as any made this season in the best games played. The Empires led in the first innings, but lost their vantage ground in the second. In the third innings, however, they again took the head and retained it up to the sixth innings, when the total stood 31 to 28 in favor of the Atlantics. In the last three innings the Atlantics scored 29 runs to 8 on the part of the Empires, finally coming in victorious by a score of 60 to 36. B. PIKE made the finest hit of the match, but Oliver led the score in run-getting on the Atlantic side. WILLIAMSON headed the list on the part of the Empires. The Atlantics made 11 fly-catches and the Empires no less than 17. The umpire efficiently discharged his duties, and the match was played in the most friendly spirit throughout.

abstract: At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, Mr. JOHN H. SILLICK, of No. 119 East Eighty-sixth-street, real estate agent and formerly a Methodist Clergyman, committed suicide by hanging with a small cord which he attached to a baluster in his dwelling. Mrs. SILLICK discovered the body almost immediately after the occurrence, and it was cut down, but life had fled. The deceased, who leaves a large but not helpless family, had recently suffered under a fever, and is supposed to have been laboring under temporary aberration. He was well known and highly esteemed in Yorkville.

abstract: OPERATIC. -- Mr. MAX MARETZEK has wasted no time in Europe. By the last steamer we hear that he has engaged the following artists: Soprani, Signora ANNA TICCONA, Signorina ELENA BOZZATTI; Tenori, Signor GUISEPPA CASSETTI, Signor CESARE CHIAVERINI; Baritoni, Signor ETTORE CORNUTI, Signor CHIAVACCI; Bassi, Signor ANTONUCCI, Signor ROVERE, and Signer PAPINI. Here are nine artists whose names, it must be confessed, are not greatly known to fame. This, however, is one of MARETZEK's merits. He seeks voices, not reputations.

abstract: Dangers of Antagonism
lead_paragraph: A Charleston (S.C.) correspondent of a Boston paper writes that "the worst sign here (in Charleston) is the growth of a bitter and hostile spirit between blacks and whites -- a gap opening between the races which, it would seem, may at some time result seriously." The blame for this state of things is attributed by some to the whites, by others to the negroes, by others to Boston busybodies, who have gone South and stirred up animosities of race.

abstract: The work of cleaning the streets progresses but slowly, and many of those in the most populous portions of the city are now in a filthy condition. Broadway and some of the other principal thoroughfares are swept regularly by machinery, and no fault can be found with them, but in the back streets, garbage and ashes are accumulating to an extent that will soon render necessary some decided action, if the public health and comfort are to be preserved. The contractors say that they cannot get men to work for them although they offer fair and remunerative wages, and that a combination has been formed to compel them to abrogate their contract. On the other hand, the street-sweepers announce that they are quite willing to come to terms so soon as the contractors offer them wages on which they can support themselves and families. In the meantime the city has to suffer.

abstract: Seven-Thirty Loan; Progress of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- The daily statements published concerning the Seven-thirty Loan show to what a large extent small investers continue to be interested in it. The exhibit for Saturday last, made yesterday, showed that on that single day, there were no less than 3,675 individual subscriptions; on the Friday previous, there were 3,850; and on other days the figures have been still higher. The whole population of the country is interested in the finances of the government.

The former wish a provisional government the latter object to it. Mr. COVODE, who was recently here, will report against WELLS.

abstract: Breckinridge, J. C., on Cruelty; A Sincere, rests with the South
snippet: Breckinridge, J. C., on Cruelty; A Sincere, rests with the South
lead_paragraph: There are few of us who have forgotten that famous, or rather that infamous address of JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, when, having safely skedaddled into the Confederate lines, he denounced President LINCOLN in bitter and almost beastly language, and detailed what things were not to be done while the gallant sons of Kentucky could "make that State sing to the music of their rifles."

abstract: Street-Cleaning Contracts, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Without being alarmists, and with no disposition toward fault-finding, we heartily concur with the Common Council in solemnly adjuring the Street Cleaning Commission to delay no longer such effective measures as shall remove at once the pestilence-breeding offal which now clogs most of our streets. The danger of further neglect is imminent and appallingly real. No human organism can be subjected long to such abominable stenches and poisonous miasm, as arise from the heaps of festering putridity in the thoroughfares reeking under the fervid rays of a mid-Summer sun, without, sooner or later, succumbing to its balefulness.

abstract: Building Organizations Wanted
lead_paragraph: A few days since we spoke in these columns of the dreadfull crowded condition of the City of New York, of the great want existing for houses in which respectable working people of limited incomes could reside; of the enormous height of rents; of the unhealthfulness, inconvenience and general wretchedness of the tenement houses in which half a million of our inhabitants live, and of our dismal prospects for the future in these regards. We showed that house-building had almost entirely stopped, while our population daily largely increased. As a partial remedy for this state of things, and as a profitable investment of capital, we suggested the establishment of building companies, in which capitalists should combine, for the purpose of erecting blocks of houses where small families could live economically, and yet enjoy comfort, cleanliness and health.

abstract: The Board of Engineers and Firemen of the Volunteer Fire Department hold a meeting at Firemen's Hall last evening. A communication was received from the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners, stating that they are not prepared to grant an honorable discharge to all the members of the volunteer department on the 1st of August next. A vote was then taken on the question of adhering to the resolution to disband on the 10th of July, when twenty-four companies voted in the affirmative and fifty-seven in the negative. The Secretary of the board, Mr. DAVIDSON, tendered his resignation, and the board then adjourned. The commissioners of the paid department met yesterday and ordered the houses of Engine Companies Nos. 18 and 25 to be locked up, the members having been guilty of disorderly conduct.

abstract: Affidavits of Bounty Jumpers Against
lead_paragraph: -- In reference to complaints published yesterday concerning the operations of Col. BAKER in regard to bounty-jumpers in this city, we publish in another column an affidavit from MICHAEL MANAHAN, contradicting utterly the statements previously made. The affidavit completely relieves Mr. M.C. STANLEY from the injurious inferences which might be drawn from the previous publication. It is only fair, in regard to all these and similar cases, to suspend any definite opinion until the facts shall be made public. The preliminary statements all come from persons who are themselves seriously implicated, and who very naturally endeavor to throw upon others the responsibility that belongs to themselves.

abstract: New-York Eighth Collection District
lead_paragraph: The several districts thus far developed in the columns of the TIMES have disclosed each its peculiarity. In one there are no incomes of any account in another the manufacturing interest leads the van in another the warehouse business demands the greater portion of the officials' time, and in the district of which we write to-day we find the income lisswollen to enormous proportions, its numerical exten being wonderfully great, and the revenue derived from this source for the benefit of the government approaching the fabulous.

abstract: -- A story is afloat that a reporter for a New-York daily paper was recently fleeced of $50 by some sharpers on a North River boat. The tale is ridiculous. There is no real reporter in New-York who is not up to all the tricks of the sporting fraternity, while must of them hold five aces and throw double sevens, when there is anything to win; there is not one who could possibly be induced to handle a card or a faro-chip -- not a bit of it, they are too smart; and lastly, where is the reporter who has fifty dollars to be fleeced of? And echo triumphantly answers -- nowhere -- nary a where -- not any. The story is provincial gammon.
lead_paragraph: -- A story is afloat that a reporter for a New-York daily paper was recently fleeced of $50 by some sharpers on a North River boat. The tale is ridiculous. abstract: CITY MORTALITY. -- From the City Inspector's report, it appears that 554 deaths occurred in this city during the past week -- 78 men, 66 women, 213 boys and 197 girls -- being an increase of 43, as compared with the mortality of the previous week, and a decrease of 7 as compared with that of the corresponding week of last year. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 45; marasmus, 84; convulsions, 60; cholera infantum, 155; cholera morbus, 2; diarrhoea, 27; dysentery, 16; scarlet fever, [???]; typhus, 14; inflammation of the lungs, 26; measles, 6; small-pox, 3. The deaths from cholera infantum during the previous week numbered 94.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: We must remember that it is an entirely new thing under the sun -- this, of a race of negroes four millions in number, living in a state of political and personal freedom, and under a constitutional government. In Africa, the savagery of the negro race has been from time immemorial, and has been all but universal On this continent, in those of the anarchical Spanish-American States where slavery has been abolished, the negroes do not exist under conditions at all analogous to those that have obtained in the South, and, moreover, the identity of race has been in great part lost by admixture with other races. The outside negroes, whose character, condition and history approximate nearest to those of the late slaves of the country, are the negroes of the British West India Islands. These, under the colonial government, enjoy personal freedom, with very limited political rights and franchises.

abstract: Sandwich Islands, Queen of, in London
snippet: Sandwich Islands, Queen of, in London
lead_paragraph: -- The blaze West-enders of the English capital are in danger of a new sensation. The Queen of the Sandwich Islands, widow of KAMEHAMEHA III., is already at Panama, on her way to London. She is a worthy successor of our own POCAHONTAS, and will doubtless make a stir in the sluggish blood of the ton. And, withal, she is said to be a lady of gentle manners and good education; not in the least anthropophagite in her tastes and in her style of dress observing the golden mean between the original Owyhee fashion, (a necklace and sandals,) and the incomprehensible multifariousness of the Court of St. Cloud. We trust that the barbarian Queen may have a good time; and also that such of our people as may meet her will remember that one of the earliest -- if not, the very first -- of governments to take positive ground with the Union in our late war, was that of which this lady was the Queen. It was no fault of hers, or of the King's, that their nation was small. Indeed, there was all the more merit in the act, since it could not be suspected of springing from hopes of personal gains.
headline: {'main': 'A NEW SENSATION', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A NEW SENSATION', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The only command that arrived yesterday was the Second Connecticut. Although several were telegraphed as on the road between this city and Baltimore, up to a late hour last night no signs of their appearance were visible. The troops from the coast, also expected yesterday, have not yet arrived. Now that there is a lull in the arrival of discharged soldiers, it is to be hoped that those already in the city will be at once paid off, to make room for the proper accomodation of fresh troops, almost hourly expected.

abstract: Great Neck, L. I., Attack on Allen's Hotel; Miss Boyd, Williamsburgh
snippet: Great Neck, L. I., Attack on Allen's Hotel; Miss Boyd, Williamsburgh
lead_paragraph: RUFFIANISM AT GREAT NECK, L.I. -- A few days since, a party of ruffians visited Great Neck, L.I., in a sloop, which hailed from New-York. After landing, they proceeded to the hotel kept by SAMUEL ALLEN, where they demanded refreshments. The proprietor informed them that there was a private party at the house, which prevented him from entertaining strangers. The roughs then proceeded to help themselves to whatever came in their way, and when remonstrated with by the party at the hotel, they commenced an indiscriminate onslaught on all present -- men, women and children. The furniture of the house was completely destroyed. The guests were beaten most unmercifully, and robbed. Mr. FRANK THOMAS, of Williamsburgh, with his family, was a guest at the place, and beside receiving severe bodily injuries himself, his daughter, a girl of four years, was kicked and maltreated otherwise in a ruthless manner. Mr. BENJAMIN JOHNSON was also among the injured. The rowdies, after becoming satisfied with their evil doings, managed to regain their sloop and escape.

abstract: Circular to K. G. C.'s
lead_paragraph: The time has arrived for performing a task Which I have purposely avoided for two years past, and which the circumstances of the case new so clearly justifies. In discharging this official duty I shall endeavor, with moderate language and charitable impulses, to address the reason of my countrymen, frusting the vindication of my own course to the searching scrutiny of time and the decisions of impar[???]al history. Conscious of having intentionally done so wrong, I have no other defence to make than to enunciate a few facts, which are susceptible of, and will be verified before the high tribunal of public intelligence. For my opinions I am responsible to God alone; for my acts I am amenable to my fellow-citizens through the proper legal chandels.

abstract: Of the third and final issue of the 7-30 Loan, the sales thus far have amounted to $105,330,050, making a weekly average of $13,166,256 for the eight weeks which have elapsed since the series was first formally opened to popular subscription, May 15. The actual sales in each week have been as follows: Week ending with May 20, $12,106,700; May 27, $9,733,600; June 3, $6,681,600; June 10, $12,806,000; June 17, 811,925,000; June 21, $15,922,700; July 1, $15,309,150; July 8, 20,818,500. The sales in the first six business days of the current month of July amounted to $24,723,700, or at the very liberal daily rate of $4,120,616; and the orders for the $50 and $100 notes of this loan in the same period. 18,075, making a daily average of 3,012. Less than $125,000,000 worth of the whole series remains to be disposed of. This unmarketed balance will doubtless be closed out before a month's interest shall have accrued on the notes, or by the time (Aug. 15) that the second half-yearly coupon on the first series shall have ma[???]ed. Of the first and second series liberal sales continue to be made at the Stock Boards and through the commission houses, (at 99 [???]@ 100, adding interest,) to buyers on foreign account, as well as for home investment. Saturday's steamers took out over $1,000,000 worth of the old issues, chiefly those of the second series, (June 15,) for Germany.

abstract: On Friday last HANNAH DOLE, daughter of a switch-tender, near Paterson, on the Erie Railway, went to conduct an aged man across a bridge which had no planking. Having crossed, the girl ran back to get a cane which the old man had dropped, and while she was recrossing the bridge a train struck and ran over her, severing her limbs. She was taken hither on the train and conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where she expired yesterday morning. She was 12 years of age.

abstract: Gotham vs. Mutual
lead_paragraph: GOTHAM vs. MUTUAL. -- The match between these clubs, played at Hoboken yesterday, resulted in the signal defeat of the former. It was anything but the fine game all expected to witness, the play on the Mutual side being confined mostly to the pitcher, catcher, and first-base player. In fact it was the old style of game in vogue in 1863, when there was a rage for swift pitching. The contrast between this game, and the one the Mutuals played with the Empires, in which medium-pace pitching was the rule on both sides, was very great. We hope to see swift pitching laid aside alter this. The following is the score:

abstract: Business Men of the South
lead_paragraph: --The Charleston Courier makes a very earnest appeal to Northern mercantile creditors in behalf of a policy of temporary leniency toward the business men of the South. Merchants in Charleston and elsewhere who were formerly extensively engaged in business express their determination to proceed North and settle old accounts as soon as they can make proper arrangements, and they very generally declare that in time they will be able to satisfy the holders of claims against them, provided they are not hampered with premature law processes in their efforts to get on their feet again. At present they stand amid the wreck of their former fortunes, but they are neither discouraged nor hopeless. They recognize the new order of things, and their new position and responsibilities, and with what they have been able to gather from the general wreck, are seeking once more to reestablish themselves in the various vocations and pursuits of life. What they require is confidence and support in their efforts, and time for the payment of their liabilities.

abstract: As with butter so with milk. Six cents a quart will give ample profits to the milkmen, even if they are less intimate with the pump. abstract: Acting Rear-Admiral S. P. LEE has reduced the Mississippi Squadron to the peace basis. Fifteen vessels are retained in the inland service of the government. The Tempest is to be the flagship, and the transport Gen. Lyon, towboats Samson and Brown, and tug Thistle are attached to her. The First Division of the squadron has been placed under command of Lieut.-Com. E. Y. McCAULEY, and consists of the Hastings, Abena and Kale.
lead_paragraph: Acting Rear-Admiral S.P. LEE has reduced the Mississippi Squadron to the peace basis. Fifteen vessels are retained in the inland service of the government. The Tempest is to be the flagship, and the transport Gen. Lyon, towboats Samson and Brown, and tug Thistle are attached to her. The First Division of the squadron has been placed under command of Lieut.-Com. E.Y. MCCAULEY, and consists of the Hastings, Abena and Kate. The district of the First Division embraces all above the Mississippi, from White River northward as far as naval operations extend. The Second Division, Lieut. T.T. CORNWELL commanding, extending from White River to Grand Gulf, is guarded by the Groesbeck; Sybil and Oriole. The Third Division is under Lieut.-Commander T.P. FOSTER, who patrols the river from Grand Gulf to New-Orleans with the Ibes, H. Hindman, Collier and Gamange. All the iron-clads, except the Tennessee and Missouri, and all mortar vessels below Memphis have been ordered to that city, and all the other superfluous vessels of the squadron are to be sent to Mound City to be put out of commission. The Gen. Bragg, Gen. Price and Little Rebel (all captured vessels) are, for the present, to be retained on blockade duty at the mouth of the Red River.

abstract: London Herald; a Lament for Slavery; Advice to on End of the War
snippet: London Herald; a Lament for Slavery; Advice to on End of the War
lead_paragraph: The Tery journals of England, which bolstered up the rebellion from beginning to end, finding it now dead upon their hands, are occupied with pronouncing over the corpse their panegyrics and funeral sermons. Never was insurrection so noble and heroic, and never cause so sanctified. The London Herald, in its issue of the 26th, piously comes as chief mourner to weep over the tomb of the extinct but blessed institution of slavery, which, as it bewails, "is to be thus violently and suddenly terminated." It says:

abstract: Sheriff MERRIAM, of Keokuk County, came up on the Western train yesterday, with a man named W.J. ALLEN in custody, who was arrested on a charge of killing his wife at Sigourney last Tuesday. When charged with the crime Allen denied his guilt, and said it was done by two strange men while he was working in the field. Circumstantial evidence was strong against him, however, and he was arrested and taken before the magistrate, who bound him over for $10,000 to appear at the next term of the district court, which, being unable to pay, he was started off to jail at Oskaloosa -- there being none at Sigourney -under charge of the Sheriff. They had hardly gone over eight miles ere they were overtaken by a large number of the citizens of Sigourney, who demanded the prisoner, swearing they would hang him on the spot. The Sheriff gave them to understand that he would shoot the first one who laid hands on the prisoner. After considerable parley, the mob consented to disperse if ALLEN was taken to a stronger jail than the one at Oskaloosa, fears being entertained that he would escape. The Sheriff promised to take him to the Muscatine County jail, when the crowd seemed satisfied.

abstract: We learn that Collector DRAPER, yesterday, paid into the Treasury $4,200,000 in gold, being the proceeds of recent sales of cotton and other seized or abandoned property. The money arising from these sales is no longer a special fund, but goes into the general treasury account; and persons having demands for property of the kinds specified, seized or destroyed by the government, will have to prosecute their cases before the Court of Claims, and, if successful, wait for special appropriations by Congress to do them justice.

abstract: -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, last evening, at the Fifteenth Ward police-station, over the body of SAMUEL HOLZ, of No. 18 Sixth-street, a youth of 13 years, who, while attempting to ride on the front platform of car No. 59, of the Fourth-avenue line, was drawn under the wheels and instantly killed -- the wheels passing over his head and cutting off the top of the skull. The jury exonerated both conductor and driver.

abstract: The people of South Carolina are rejoiced that at length they were favored with a Provisional Governor. The impression prevailed to a considerable extent that the government had decided to let this State remain out in the cold, but now all will admit that President JOHNSON is by no means disposed to withhold civil government from this State any longer than such a course would be for the best interests of the people.

abstract: An herb doctor named ANCHEAS EVELAIN, residing in Graham-avenue, near Johnson-street, Eastern District, yesterday made two attempts to commit suicide. He was first observed by Officer REED, of the Forty-sixth Precinct, attempting to dash out his brains against a fence. The officer took charge of him, and, while on their way to the station-house, EVELAIN made another attempt at self-destruction by strangulation. The man is evidently insane, and will be sent to the asylum by Judge WALTER.

abstract: -- We judge by reading our Texas files that some of the people of that State are quite unaware of certain things that have been settled by the war. This arises from the fact that they have seen and known so little of the war and its results. It is a fact, however, which they will have to learn, that the Southern Confederacy was not negotiated out of existence, but was crushed out of existence; that the Union is now established by military power; that its establishment has changed for a time, at least, their relations to the government; that it has made treason a crime has annihilated their treasonable State government and all its appendages, having forever abolished slavery and all its relations, has squelched the doctrine of State sovereignty, and has relegated the regulation of their public affairs, for the time being, to the military authorities. Their leaders very wisely determined to surrender, and the soldiers of the State very discreetly determined to make for their homes, as soon as they learned the immense force that the Lieutenant-General had dispatched for their State under SHERIDAN; but this does not alter the fact that loyal conduct on their part is now necessary, and that a submission to the conditions imposed by the conqueror is imperative. Let the people of Texas remember all this, and especially that slavery in their State is abolished, and they will yet become a great people.

abstract: New-York, Ryan, a Soldier, Garroted in Market-street
snippet: New-York, Ryan, a Soldier, Garroted in Market-street
lead_paragraph: The morning and evening newspapers, the police, and, for aught we know, the telegraph, have recently teemed with sensation tales of an abduction which was supposed to have occurred in Henry-street on the night of the 5th instant; and during all this time, it appears, the heroine of the drama has been rusticating, near the city, with a new-made husband, languishing in the honeymoon and hugely enjoying the sudden immortality which the newspapers had thrust upon her, but not dreaming that the youngsters with whom she was last seen lay, ill at ease, in the uninviting cells of Essex Market Prison. The story is, briefly, as follows: On the evening of the 5th, Miss SARAH E. BOYD, then a marriageable daughter of Mr. JAMES BOYD, of No. 97 Henry-street, went out with JOHN PARE, a boarder at her father's house, and in the Broadway Theatre they met JOHN and THOMAS ARMSTRONG, brothers, with whom the young couple were mutually friendly, and between the second and third acts, THOMAS ARMSTRONG took the young woman out, as PARE and JOHN ARMSTRONG supposed, to an ice-creamery. But the roguish twain eschewed the ices and went straightway to the dwelling of a worthy clergyman and were made one flesh. Then, not caring to see the "old folks," they toted off to Tottenville, and thence to the seaside, where they tarried until yesterday morning. Mr. BOYD, meantime, had caused the arrest of young PARE and JOHN ARMSTRONG, and Justice SHANDLEY had committed them to answer for abduction. The prisoners were released yesterday afternoon, and it may be presumed that Mr. and Mrs. THOMAS ARMSTRONG "stood treat " last evening.

abstract: -- The United States Mail steamship Lodona will leave pier No. 21 North River, on Wednesday, the 19th inst, at 3 P.M., and will hereafter make regular trips to that port. Freight and passengers are taken at reduced rates. The agents are Messrs. HEINEKEN & PALMORE, No. 115 Broadway. A regular semi-weekly steamer for Norfolk, City Point and Richmond is dispatched by the same firm, offering a fine opportunity to excursionists. The company are now building two elegant side-wheel steamers for the Richmond trade, which will be ready in about two months.

abstract: The Board of Commissioners of Metropolitan Police have transferred Capt. WADDY, of the Forty-ninth, or East New-York Precinct, has been transferred to the Forty-fourth, and Capt. LEICH, or the Fiftieth, has been sent to the Forty-ninth. These changes had become necessary because of serious differences between Captains, Sergeants and Patrolmen in the Forty-fourth Precinct.

abstract: Squatter Sovereignty (Up-town Shanties)
lead_paragraph: The poverty, wretchedness and crime of New-York is by no means confined to the over-crowded tenement-houses, under-ground dens and seething alleys, recently described in the columns of the TIMES. In another quarter of the metropolis, close to that magnificent Park, which is the pride of our citizens, the wonder and envy of our visitors from provincial towns -- in a quarter which is destined to become the finest built and most fashionable part of our city --there are a dozen or more collections of shanty-settlements, which shelter the vilest, most degraded and most turbulent population that over disturbed the peace of a city. In one police precinct alone (the Nineteenth) there are, it is estimated, not fewer than eight hundred shanties or cabins, each one containing from one to six prolific families, with their household duds, and cows, goats, pigs, geese and goslings, hens and chickens, in number limited only by the lack of accommodations. Ten thousand is supposed to be a low estimate of the population of these settlements, including, of course, the children.

abstract: Trade Convention
lead_paragraph: The convention now in session at Detroit will be best judged of by the result of its deliberations. But it is not anticipating these deliberations, nor the issues which may arise out of these deliberations, if we say that this Commercial Convention is, in some respects, the most remarkable extra-constitutional assembly of our time.

abstract: Monitor Building in England; Capt. Coles; Coles, Capt., on Turret Ships
snippet: Monitor Building in England; Capt. Coles; Coles, Capt., on Turret Ships
lead_paragraph: Another of those periodical letters with which Capt. COWPER COLES favors the world at pretty regular intervals, through the columns of the London Times, has just appeared. Our readers will remember that Capt. COLES has become famous in England by having advocated a plan of constructing vessels which the Admiralty did not accept, and which caused him, therefore, to be continually puffed by the opposition journals and magazines as an ill-used patriot. This breeze of popularity has been constantly fanned by the Captain's own letters, which appear from time to time in the public prints. It was the advent of the American monitors, however, which plucked Capt. COLES from oblivion, almost by the hair of his head. The great and memorable Parliamentary panic which ensued on the iron-clad battle of the Monitor and Merrimac brought out Capt. COLES, who instantly claimed to be the inventor of the "cupola" system of iron-clads. It is, of course, perfectly well known that he was not the inventor, but the American excitement served to bring him into a notoriety he has always since enjoyed. Perhaps it is in gratitude for this favor that he now drops his term "cupola" for the American word turret, and that the article in question is headed "Turret Ships." The material thing itself he long ago borrowed from us -- dropping the wretched "cupola," fit only for guns of very low calibre, and taking up the American cylindrical turret -- and it was proper the name should follow.
headline: {'main': 'Monitor-Building in England Capt. Coles and His Cupola System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Monitor-Building in England Capt. Coles and His Cupola System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The New-Jersey Schutzen Corps were to have commenced their annual festival yesterday, but owing to the unfavorable state of the weather it was postponed until to-day, when they will proceed to Guttenberg to shoot for prizes. In the evening they will have a supper and ball at Otto Cottage Garden, in Hoboken. On Wednesday the corps will reassemble at the Garden, when the prizes will be distributed, to be followed by such pastimes as ladies' prize shooting, bag running, climbing greased poles, &c., to conclude with a moonlight festival.

abstract: On Friday evening last private PATRICK LEE went into CHARLES and ANNA WILSON's brothel, in Canal-street, and was there so handsomely entertained by one LIZZIE JONES that he resolved to tarry there, and finish his celebration of the army's return. The keepers of the den plied him with brothel "wine," of course, and kept him in a generous mood until he had given the female JONES $30 and several new dresses, and on Saturday morning, as he began to talk of going to his abo[???]e, at No. 333 West Forty-second-street, the gang filled him with their most villainous gin, and during the stupor that ensued robbed him of a watch and $165 in money. Awakening on Sunday, and being unable to recover his Treasury notes, he entered complaint at the Fifth Ward Police-station, and Capt. PETTY and Officers TAYLOR and RICHARD FIELD took CHARLES and ANNA WILSON into custody, but were unable to find LEE's money. The prisoners were committed for examination.

abstract: New-York, Boyd, W., and Wife, Garroted in Charlton-street
snippet: New-York, Boyd, W., and Wife, Garroted in Charlton-street
lead_paragraph: Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAM BOYD, of No. 86 Charlton-street, were garroted, at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, near their own dwelling, but not robbed, Policeman SCHMIDT having appeared before the robbers had completed their work. The officer pursued the outlaws, and captured one JOHN ALLEN, a young butcher. On the way to the Twenty-eight Precinct Police Station the prisoner escaped, but was subsequently rearrested by Patrolman ROWLAND, and taken to court, and Mr. BOYD, who is a marketman, and had started for Washington Market at the time of the attack, appeared and identified him. Justice DODGE declined to accept bail, and sent ALLEN to the Court of General Sessions for trial.

abstract: -- According to announcement, TIFFANY relighted the immense eagle in front of his Broadway warehouse, last evening, to the gratification of a vast multitude of citizens who assembled to witness the display. The night being of pitchy darkness, and there being no breeze to affect the gas-jets, the illumination was a complete success. The piece has been previously described as an American shield in red, with thirteen stare in white fires, beneath which is flung a wreath, bearing, in deep red, white and blue, the single word "Peace," the whole surmounted by an American eagle, whose expanded wings cover a space of about fifty feet. Under the wings fall two immense stars, in which are the letters U.S.

abstract: Butter still stands at nearly double the price it ought. The stock is very large. In the interior great stores are accumulating for high prices -- let them. Every family ought to shut down on butter forthwith, and realize to dealers that a great danger is before them unless they at once exercise moderation. Let the Anti-Butter Clubs begin to organize. As surely as Providence has given us green crops in vast abundance, so will the butter merchants and producers find that the gifts of Providence are not for them alone.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. A reckless bachelor, in blue satin waistcoat and red neck-tie, stands no chance in such a piece as "Still Waters Run Deep." The play, in its purpose and effect, is a glorification of dull husbands. John Mildway, the hero, wades quietly on the stilts of prudence to heights which fiery indiscretion in vain attempts to scale.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- A reckless bachelor, in blue satin waistcoat and red neck-tie, stands no chance in such a piece as "Still Waters Run Deep." The play, in its purpose and effect, is a glorification of dull husbands. John Mildway, the hero, wades quietly on the stilts of prudence to heights which fiery indiscretion in vain attempts to scale. At first it is a little tiresome to find this worthy devoting himself to green paint, and regarding that inadequate artistic effort as a moral virtue. Then, too, the ostentation with which he goes to Manchester, without kissing his very pretty wife, is apt to breed a feeling of contempt. If Captain Hawksley were not such "an unaccountable scoundrel," he would certainly, at this period of the evening, win the sympathies of the audience, if not of Mrs. Mildmay. But his unconquerable desire to "bilk" every one deprives his other actions of gallantry, and we are not sorry when John comes down upon him with an overwhelming amount of common sense and other legal documents, and so brings him to shame and a dungeon. The lesson of the play is highly important, in a humanitarian point of view. It is, that a man is seldom so great a fool as he looks.

abstract: Numerous cases of overcharging by hackmen have lately occurred; strangers being, in nearly all cases, the victims. Yesterday, on Pier No. 28, North River, (Fall River line,) a gentleman appealed to Officer KENNALLEY, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, to know the hack fare from his hotel to the pier. The officer calculated the fare and told him $2, at the same time asking him how much the driver demanded. The gentleman stated $4. The officer told him he ought not to give him one cent; but the gentleman insisted on giving him the legal charge, which the driver accepted, and doubtless considered himself lucky to get off without being arrested for overcharging. The gentleman stated that he had recently read a case in the TIMES of overcharge by a hackman who had brought parties down to the same pier, and this led him to make the inquiry of the officer.

abstract: Garroters and the Law
lead_paragraph: -It is earnestly to be hoped that prompt and exemplary justice will be administered upon the ruffians who are now in custody for the crime of garroting citizens in the public streets. The revival of this practice of late is cause of great alarm to quiet people; and so boldly and openly has it been done in some instances that it seems really dangerous for a citizen to be abroad in the greater part of the city after nightfall. In two instances it has even been done in daylight, and the case that occurred in Union-square, a few mornings since, equals in audacity anything in the records of highway robbery. We believe that death has not resulted to the victims of any of the recent cases of garroting, but that is purely accidental or Providential, for we heard of one instance in which the victim, when his throat was assailed, fell back and split his skull.
headline: {'main': 'THE GARROTERS AND THE LAW', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE GARROTERS AND THE LAW', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: - The examination of the seven young men charged with a diabolical outrage on the person of Mrs. ROSA ALLEN, a woman 63 years of age, was resumed yesterday before Judge WALTER. The testimony of the injured woman was first taken. She stated that after she had been foully dealt with, and while in a fainting condition, she heard one of the accused (UNDERSTILLER) say to ANTON FRANK, another of the accused: "You killed her," meaning the witness. After this she became unconscious of what transpired, remembering only that the was taken to the Forty-sixth-Precinct Station-house and cared for. Mrs. ALLEN also testified that when the party first attacked her she was walking up the road, and that they lifted her over the fence. When in the field the prisoner FRANK struck her violently with a bottle, which blow caused her to fall to the ground; he then kicked her, and tore out her pocket containing about one dollar in postal currency. Officer REED, who arrested the accused, deposed to their presence at the scene of the outrage. The testimony for the defence did not affect materially the facts as stated. Case adjourned till Friday.

abstract: So many efforts are made to befog the meat question by interested parties that a word for the bewildered is necessary from time to time. For instance, beef on Monday rose one cent a pound at the Drovers' Yards, and the reason assigned was that there was a short supply. Of course, there was in New-York, but there was a heavy supply kept back at Albany, seemingly to force that rise of one cent. At Albany the price was lower by half a cent. Of the New-York supply 4,075 head (to which must be added the cattle left over last week, during which 5,514 head arrived,) not all are sold. And this process is and and has been adopted all along.
lead_paragraph: So many efforts are made to befog the meat question by interested parties that a word for the bewildered is necessary from time to time. abstract: ARREST OF A SKILLFUL COUNTERFEITER SEIZURE OF MONEY, DIES,  Yesterday Detectives ELDER and McCORD, THOMAS SAMPSON, of the Sub-Treasury Department, and Deputy-Marshall YOUNG, arrested JERRY COWSDEN, an experienced counterfeiter, at Guttenberg, N.J., while in the act of printing counterfeit 50 cent fractional currency.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A SKILLFUL COUNTERFEITER -- SEIZURE OF MONEY, DIES, &c. -- Yesterday Detectives ELDER and MCCORD, THOMAS SAMPSON, of the Sub-Treasury Department, and Deputy-Marshall YOUNG, arrested JERRY COWSDEN, an experienced counterfeiter, at Guttenberg, N.J., while in the act of printing counterfeit 50 cent fractional currency. On searching the premises the officers found over $3,000 in finished and unfinished counterfeit currency. The finished notes are excellent imitations of the genuine. It is said that COWSDEN has sold large amounts of the counterfeits for fifty cents on the dollar. The officers also seized the plates, presses, engraver's tools, and other apparatus used by COWSDEN, which were brought to this city. The prisoner was locked up for examination.

abstract: ALMOST A TRAGEDY. -- On Tuesday night, an engineer in one of the government transports arrived from New-Orleans, and reached his home in the Fourteenth Ward at a late hour. After effecting an entrance he observed that there was somebody in the house whose presence his wife sought to conceal. In this she failed, however, as in a few minutes a well-known city official appeared at the head of the stairs, not exactly in full dress. The husband immediately recognized the intruder, and ran for his revolver in an adjoining room; but the official was too quick for his vengeance, as he leaped through a lower window and escaped, leaving, however, a certain part of his apparel, which the injured husband says his has no wish to retain.

abstract: African Civilization Society Report
lead_paragraph: From the report of the "African Civilization Society" of its sixth annual meeting, held in this city on the 31st of May last, just published, we learn that the receipts of the society from all sources, since its organization, have been, in 1864, $5,484 64; in 1863, $7,608 64; in 1862, $1,128; and in 1861, $557. The expenditures last year footed up $5,434 64; and of this sum, $3,780 94 was paid for salaries and labor. The Treasurer reports only $50 on hand.

abstract: Brophy; a New Witness
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that a man of the name of BROPHY has just turned up in Washington, who knows a great deal about the Presidential assassins and conspirators, and who is especially crammed with evidence proving the innocency of Mrs. SURRATT. Would it not be well for the authorities to have this BROPHY, who knows so much, taken into custody, to be held as a witness in case JEFF. DAVIS be tried before a military commission for complicity in the assassination? As BROPHY knows so much about Mrs. SURRATT's innocency, he ought to be able to tell who is guilty.

abstract: -- Chancing to look into the ponderous volume which professes to be the "City Inspector's Report for 1864," we found once again the same old song by that immense genius, the Registrar of Records. This pleasant writer and rare mathematician has been for many years engaged in the cheerful work of showing that the annual mortality of any last year is about ten per cent. less than for the immediately preceding year. According to his refreshing logic, backed by figures, too, the number of deaths decreases nearly in inverse ratio to the increase of population. For instance, if 27,000 died in 1854 out of a population of 500,000, and only 25,645 in 1864, out of a million, the ratio is: 1854, 4 1-2 per cent.; 1864, 2 1-3 per cent. Decrease in ten years, over two per cent. Therefore, by the time we have a population equal to that of London, we shall have no deaths at all, unless those who wish to go to glory emigrate to the insalubrious hills of Weehawken. Science is a great thing; figures won't lie; the Registrar of Records is a "peculiar institution" -- long may he flourish and figure.
lead_paragraph: -- Chancing to look into the ponderous volume which professes to be the "City Inspector's Report for 1864," we found once again the same old song by that immense genius, the Registrar of Records. This pleasant writer and rare mathematician has been for many years engaged in the cheerful work of showing that the annual mortality of any last year is about ten per cent. less than for the immediately preceding year. According to his refreshing logic, backed by figures, too, the number of deaths decreases nearly in inverse ratio to the increase of population. For instance, if 27,000 died in 1854 out of a population of 500,000, and only 25,645 in 1864, out of a million, the ratio is: 1854, 4 1-2 per cent.; 1864, 2 1-3 per cent. Decrease in ten years, over two per cent. Therefore, by the time we have a population equal to that of London, we shall have no deaths at all, unless those who wish to go to glory emigrate to the insalubrious hills of Weehawken. Science is a great thing; figures won't lie; the Registrar of Records is a "peculiar institution" -- long may he flourish and figure.

abstract: -The Army and Navy Official Gazette, the publication of which the recently suspended by the War Department, should not be confounded with the Army and Navy Journal, which is now left alone in its special sphere of journalism. The Official Gazette was intended only as a temporary means of communicating official orders and information to the staff corps and departments. The Army and Navy Journal embraces the whole range of military journalism, and is designed to be the permanent representative of our army and navy.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, yesterday, before Justice BARNARD, a motion was made in the case of TILLINGHAST vs. THURLOW WEED, W.C. LITTLE, J. PARSONS et al., to make a preliminary injunction perpetual. A temporary injunction was granted a few days since, by a Judge of the above-named court, whereby the defendants, as printers of law books, were enjoined from issuing the second volume of a work known as Tillinghast & Shearman's Practice. After able arguments upon either side, Justice BARNARD decided that the preliminary injunction must be dissolved, with costs to the defendants.

abstract: The Union Convention of Sussex County, New-Jersey, which met at Newton on Monday, appointed a full delegation to the State Convention to be held at Trenton on the 20th inst. Gen. KILPATRICK, who is a citizen of the county, was present, and was appointed one of the delegates. He made a glowing Union speech, denouncing the disloyal conduct of the New-Jersey Democratic leaders, and pledging himself to stump the State if he could get leave of absence from the field. The General expects to be present at the State Convention.

abstract: James, Edwin; Complaint of Statement in Manchester Guardian
snippet: James, Edwin; Complaint of Statement in Manchester Guardian
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Mr. EDWIN JAMES, the well-known English lawyer, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY, at the fourth District Police Court, and directed his attention to two libels which had appeared in the Manchester (England) Guardian, and which had been copied into other English papers, arising out of a case which had been before Justice CONNOLLY for judicial investigation. Mr. JAMES said that one of the libels referred to himself, and that the other was an attack upon the Judge. After reading the articles, Judge CONNOLLY said that they were scandalous and untrue, and were gross misrepresentations of what had occurred in his court. On the complaint of HENRY WILSON against HENRY HAYWOOD (obtaining money under false pretences) he had fully investigated the case, and there was not the slightest imputation upon the conduct of Mr. JAMES or his firm; on the contrary he had acted honorably throughout the whole transaction. Upon the other charge against HAYWARD, (sending a threatening letter for the purpose of extorting money,) the Judge said that after a very careful examination of the evidence, he had decided to commit HAYWARD for trial.
headline: {'main': 'Fourth District Police Court Before Justice Connolly.; LIBELS AGAINST EDWIN JAMES IN FOREIGN JOURNALS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Fourth District Police Court Before Justice Connolly.; LIBELS AGAINST EDWIN JAMES IN FOREIGN JOURNALS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Messrs. BROWN & SPAULDING, jewelers, have on exhibition at No. 570 Broadway, some beautiful charms for watch-chains, made from the wood of the tree under which Gen. LEE stood when agreeing to Gen. GRANT's terms of surrender on the [???]th of April last. These charms are in united with fine gold, and represent safes, canteens, k[???]ks, &c. The tree, which stood near Appomattox Court-house, is no longer to be found, it having been turn up root and branch, and the wood divided among such of the soldiers as desired to have it. Messrs. BROWN & SPAULDING are now engaged in manufacturing a brooch and ear-rings from the same wood for presentation to Mrs. Gen. GRANT.

abstract: Surratt, Mrs.; Unwise Action of her Friends
snippet: Surratt, Mrs.; Unwise Action of her Friends
lead_paragraph: -- The friends of the late MARY E. SURRATT are resorting to ill-judged action in endeavoring to prove her innocence. Her trial was conducted with extraordinary patience, and the proofs of her guilt entirely justified the conclusion arrived at. Disloyal persons may endeavor to lead to an opposite conclusion, but they will not succeed in that endeavor. She has paid the penalty of her crime, and the wisest thing is for all who were upon terms of friendship with her to let her name be as far forgotten as the magnitude of that crime will allow.

abstract: Railway Racing Over
lead_paragraph: Between the western end of the Erie Railroad tunnel, at the Palisades, and the bridge over the Passaic at Newark, is a stretch of five or six miles of salt meadow, level as a floor and tenanted by nobody in particular except musquitoes, many of whom weigh from two ounces to half a pound. Over this meadow run, or rather lie, two railroad tracks -- the Morris and Essex -- emerging from the tunnel, and the New-Jersey, coming from the deep cut below Hudson City. These tracks for three or four miles run side by side, not more than ten feet apart -- both are double. Over each road pass about forty trains per day, so that cars are pretty thick. Both roads seem to be as well managed as roads generally are, and very few accidents occur. But we set out to mention a little scheme just entered into for the diversion of their passengers, by way of keeping them awake in these sleepy afternoons. It is this.; When Morris and Essex gets a sight of New-Jersey around the spur of the hill west of the tunnel, be puts on steam so as to get up about sixty miles an hour; if course New-Jersey is not to be bluffed, and he jerks open the throttle-valve and spins along all he knows how; now the firemen cram in the fuel, and the safety-valve hisses spitefully; a little pause at Hackensack Bridge, over we go at slow pace, and then comes the fun. The trains rapidly near each other, and now are side by side; passengers can almost shake hands; the cars sway to and fro, the steam hisses, the whistles scream, women get nervous, men become anxious, the speed is fearful; when, to pile up the agony, down the return track plunge two other trains engaged in the same lively business -- racing across the meadows. For an instant the four trains are all in a heap, confusion and bewilderment overcome the helpless passengers, and the more nervous begin to faint or scream for help. We have been there, and although pretty well hardened with many thousand miles of railroad travel, we are still not ashamed to say that we think racing of trains that run not more than three or four yards apart is much more exciting than enjoyable. One may get into Newark or New-York live minutes sooner, perhaps, in consequence of this headlong speed; but if a wheel should break or a rail give way, when four such trains are passing, a hundred persons might be killed. Suppose we take a little more time over the meadows; and particularly suppose that each engineer runs by his own tables, and lets the other chap paddle his canoe on the same principle.

abstract: JOHN HENRY, who is said to be a young burglar, was arrested early yesterday morning, by Officer MOSBACK, of the Eighteenth Precinct, while coming out of the shoe-store of THOS. MCGRATH, NO. 213 East Nineteenth-street, with two pairs of boots in his hands, which he had stolen, having forced open the door of the store. While taking the prisoner to the station-house, the officer was struck a powerful blow on the head. HENRY then attempted to escape, but was compelled to submit after a brief struggle, and was locked up. A loaded revolver and skeleton key were found in his possession. Justice DODGE committed the accused for trial, without bail.

abstract: The funeral ceremonies over the remains of this well-known lawyer and politician took place yesterday morning, in the presence of a large congregation, comprising among its members numerous lay and legal friends of the deceased, at St. John's Church. The school children of the Fifth Ward, in whose welfare Mr. TILLOU had always exhibited a lively interest, manifested their respect to his memory by forming in procession, and, headed by the school officers, marched to the church, for the purpose of taking a parting look at the remains of their friend. The corpse was brought into the edifice at 10 o'clock, when the lid was removed, and those who desired to view it were gratified. The services were conducted by Drs. Dix, Weston, Ogelsby and Young, assisted by Rev. Mr. Fitzgerald, Rev. Mr. Ellis and Rev. Mr. Cookson, at the conclusion of which the lid was replaced, the coffin removed to the hearse in attendance, and the cortege, numbering some sixteen carriages, journeyed to Greenwood Cemetery, where the deceased was interred with appropriate ceremonies. At the time of his death Mr. TILLOU was 69 years of age.

abstract: Yesterday, Mr. MILES CRAGIN, residing at Susquehanna Depot, Susquehanna County, Penn., entered a complaint before Justice HOGAN, at the Tombs, against DANIEL HOGAN, living at No. 504 Canal-street, charging him with grand larceny. The complainant alleges that on Tuesday night he went to sleep on a stoop in Canal-street. On awaking he missed four deeds for certain houses and tracts of land in Susquehannah County, Penn., and Broome County, in this State, made out in his name, and valued at $15,000, which were stolen while he was asleep. Soon after he awoke, the complainant alleges that HOGAN told him that if he (CRAGIN) would pay him a certain sum, he would get him all his papers. The complainant gave HOGAN $2, and the latter entered a house near by and soon returned with one of the deeds. The three others have not been recovered. Officer GUNSON, of the Fifth Precinct, arrested HOGAN, and he was subsequently taken to court. The accused denied stealing the deeds, and said that he saw a boy take a package from CRAGIN's pockett, pursued him and took one from him, returned it to CRAGIN, and claimed $2 for the service, which was given to him. HOGAN was detained for examination.

abstract: View of South American Republics; Gen. Sickles' Views of
snippet: View of South American Republics; Gen. Sickles' Views of
lead_paragraph: During an interesting interview with Major-Gen. SICKLES, since his return from South America, we were particularly edified by his description of the fatal operation of the doctrine of State rights, as developed under the inspiration of the Cal[???]oun school of politicians and applied in the several South American Republics. Our own people may gather admonition and instruction from their experience. According to their theory, the relation of the Federal Government to the States is one of entire neutrality. Take the Republic of Colombia: If a revolution or insurrection occurs in any State, the Federal Government cannot interfere, either by a military or a civil authority. When a revolution has effected a change in the government, it is obligatory upon the Federal Government to recognize whatever State authority exists de facto in consequence of such revolution. The Senators in Congress are called Senator Plenipotentiaries from the various districts they represent. These Senators, when a revolution takes place before their terms of office expire, retain their positions for the time for which they were elected -- because they are deemed the representatives of the sovereignty, and not of the successful party for the time being. Their ideas as to the tenure of office are equally striking. The presiding officer of the Senate, corresponding with our Vice President of the republic, is elected once a month! The Speaker of the House is chosen for the same term. The Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court holds his office for a single term of court. Suffrage is universal, including negroes. Emancipation has produced great changes in the social and political status of the blacks. They are eligible to all employments or professions, civil or military. Black doctors attend white patients; black lawyers have white clients, and argue cases before white judges, and white lawyers argue cases before black judges, one of whom presided last year as Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of the Republic. He is both learned and accomplished. Several officers of distinction and high rank in MOSQUERA's revolution, which terminated year before last, were blacks who commanded white and black troops brigaded together. The Indian race is similarly embodied together with the blacks, and are soon holding seats in both branches of Congress, and in the different State Legislatures. The facility with which revolution is inaugurated and ended, was illustrated on the 5th of the March last in Panama. Between dinner and tea the government of the State was changed. A battalion of regular troops s[???]ioned there as the conservators of order, were induced to take part in the movement for a new government by some of the residents, who were dissatisfied with the existing administration. They "sounded" the Colonel to know what he thought, but finding that he was opposed to the scheme, they quietly imprisoned him, together with several of the other commanding officers who concurred in his objections. [???] themselves under the [???] of those who were [???]y to their cause, they deposed the State au[???] [???] [???]n [???]ted as Governor a well-known [???] [???], JIL COLUNGE, [???] [???]ly [???]. [???] as "Hall Columbia." COLUNGE is [???] [???]ed, and has made a marked improvement [???] condition of affairs s[???] is election. He would not be el[???] [???] any [???]e in this country, [???] a n[???]. The deposed Governor, being a [???]r of Congress elect, and having [???]nju[???] the as[???] of a United States ship-of-war for a [???] [???] his personal [???]ty was [???] in da[???], presented to [???] [???] [???] State, [???] [???] [???] the Federal Government. Thus being the [???] [???] in [???] revolution [???] [???] presented by Federal troops, he [???] that, as he had been [???] from power by Federal troops, he should be reinstated in the same manner. This novel question was gravely considered at the Capital, but it was finally decided that as the troops acted without orders and in defiance of the authority of their officers, and as the rule of constitutional law in the government was imperative, that the Federal Government could in no case interfere with the order of things in any State, the de facto government of JIL COLUNGE must be recognized!! Gen. SICKLES entertained COLUNGE on board his vessel, the Huntscille, and found him a most agreeable gentleman. He is popular with the people. The inhabitants looked upon our struggle with amazement. They at first regarded the endeavors of the National Government to put down insurrection in a dozen States, by the aid of Federal troops, as entirely inconsistent with the republican theory; and this view for a time made the Liberal party of South America unfriendly to our cause. The "Conservator" party, which was anti-republican, was, of course, against us. Our only friends there, for a long period, were a few enlightened men, who, by residence and observation in our country, had obtained some correct views of our system. Chief among these was that gitted statesman, the President of Columbia, MURILLO. As our struggle proceeded, and the great ideas upon which it was based were better understood in South America, as well as in Europe, a wholesome change of sentiment was observed. Its progress cannot be better illustrated than by the scenes in Bogota when the news reached there of the surrender of LEE and his army and the final triumph of the Union arms. The President ordered his artillery to the Grand Plaza, and a national salute was fired in honor of our triumph. A regiment of infantry ran up the American flag and saluted it. Congress adjourned, and most of its members, together with the Cabinet ministers, made visits of congratulation to the American Minister, Mr. BURTON, and to Gen. SICKLES, who was temporarily sojourning there. In the evening many houses were illuminated; bands of music were sent by the Secretary of War to the residences of our representatives, and played our national airs to an admiring crowd of many thousands assembled in the streets; thus giving to this Spanish city, far away in the Andes, the appearance of a town in the United States.

abstract: - Three matches between DUDLEY KAVANAGH and the great French player, Monsieur CARME, have been finally arranged. They are, first, a French game of 250 points, with French balls, on a second size Phelan & Collender table; a four-ball carom game of 1,500 points, without the push shot, with same sized balls and table, and a regular four-ball American carom game, with regular sized balls and table; and each of these is to be played for $1,000 a side. The first of these games will be played on Thursday, Oct. 5, in this city, and the others will follow at intervals of thirty days.

abstract: As early as 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and in spite of the threatening appearance of the weather, the persons interested in this large sale began to assemble at the Navy-yard, some to discuss the merits of the vessels, and others to inspect them. A large number of speculators were present, but the sequel will prove that they found little, if any, employment for their funds, as all of the vessels were evidently purchased for service in the employ of the parties who purchased them.

abstract: Resolute, of Brooklyn, vs. Empire, of New-York
snippet: Resolute, of Brooklyn, vs. Empire, of New-York
lead_paragraph: RESOLUTE OF BROOKLYN VS. EMPIRE OF NEW-YORK. -- The first match between these clubs took place yesterday afternoon on the Union Ball ground, Brooklyn, E.D., and despite the fact that the rain fell during the first five innings of the game quite a large crowd were present to witness the game, the majority standing out in the rain for an hour or more. Neither club appeared on the field in their full strength, the Empires being minus three of their nine and the Resolutes four; but both clubs had good substitutes to represent the absentees. The Resolutes led in the first innings, but the close of the fourth saw their opponents in the van by a score of 12 to 3. The Resolutes, however, pulled up handsomely afterward, the close of the eighth inning leaving the total 24 to 24. In the last innings, which was quite an exciting period of the game, the Empires scored 5 runs to their opponents 2, thus winning by the total score of 29 to 26. This is the best score the Resolutes have made this season, and it was a creditable result. The following is the score:

abstract: The New-York and New-Haven Railroads Company vs. Robert Schuyler and others. An injunction herein was personally served. The decree expressly modifies these orders in the manner therein setforth. This is in effect a continuation of those orders in the modified form. The judgement not extending but limiting
lead_paragraph: The New-York and New-Haven Railroads Company vs. Robert Schuyler and others. -- An injunction herein was personally served. The decree expressly modifies these orders in the manner therein set forth. This is in effect a continuation of those orders in the modified form. The judgement not extending but limiting the operation of the orders, the party must be presumed to have notice of the injunction in the judgment. He had personal notice of the injunction in the orders, and before taking the step in question he must have taken measures to ascertain whether that injunction order had been vacated or superseded; and in taking such measures, he must have come across the judgment, and by that he would have seen that the injunction orders were continued in a modified form.
