abstract: The contractors for cleaning the streets commenced work in earnest yesterday. In the Eighteenth Ward, at an early hour, about a dozen carts made their appearance, and the ashes and garbage, which have been accumulating for many day's past, were removed. Quite a strong police force had been detailed to protect the laborers, and two or three disturbances occurred during the day.
lead_paragraph: The contractors for cleaning the streets commenced work in earnest yesterday. In the Eighteenth Ward, at an early hour, about a dozen carts made their appearance, and the ashes and garbage, which have been accumulating for many day's past, were removed. Quite a strong police force had been detailed to protect the laborers, and two or three disturbances occurred during the day. A couple of carmen, while at work in Broome-street, were attacked by the "strikers," and one of the men was seriously beaten. The police were soon on hand, and the "strikers" drew off their forces. Later in the day, an attack was made on the men cleaning the streets of the Thirteenth Ward. The police repaired to the asasistance of the workmen, and arrested Peter Canfield, Thomas Fay, James Lynch, Edward Jones, Thomas Pender and Patrick McCullum. It is charged that MCCULLUM struck JOB DREW, a dirt carman, with a cart rung, seriously injuring him. Justice SHANDLEY held all the prisoners but JAMES and PENDER to bail. The two latter were discharged. Officer LYON found a number of men on the corner of Broome and Ludlow streets, and believing they intended to make an assault on the men engaged in cleaning the streets, ordered them away, when PATRICK SMITH refused to go. The officer arrested SMITH and took him before Justice SHANDLEY, who discharged him with a reprimand. An assault was also made on the workmen in the Seventeenth Ward, during which several men were seriously injured.

abstract: The St. Petersburgh correspondent of the Independence Beige gives on interesting account of the causes that led to the condemnation and banishment to Siberia of three Russian gentlemen lately. The prisoners were named SERNO-SOLOVIEVITCH, VETOCH[???] and WEADIMIROFF, and were all connected, in various subordinate positions, with the government. Their [???] was complicity in the revolutionary attempts of Russian political refugees in London. It seems that a certain M. KELSEIFF, who had quitted Russia, not in consequence of any political trouble, but because he was discontented with the existing order of things, went to London, and took an active part in the revolutionary propaganda of M. HERTZEN. He started a paper there addressed specially to Russians disaffected toward both the government and the ecclesiastical authorities of the empire. With a view of organizing the spread of his doctrines, M. KELSIEFF visited Russia under an assumed name, and with a Turkish passport. While there, it seems, M. SOLOVIEVITCH and his fellow-prisoners gave him shelter and protection. On his return to London he [???]e[???] to organize a plan for obtaining the [???]e of the religious dissenters among the revolutionary party in Austria. With this view a certain young man, named NITCHIPORENKO, was sent as the envoy of the dissentient Russian sectaries to [???]-[???]za, where the Metropolitan of the Austrian dissenters resided. An act of imprudence on his part ruined all the plans af his employers. Tobacco, it seems, is abhorred by the Austrian sectaries, and they call it "the devil's herb." Yet NITCHIPORENKO was foolish enough to smoke in the presence of the Metropolitan himself. This so offended the Austrian sectaries that, instead of uniting with their "Russian brethren," they handed over the imprudent smoker to the government authorities, who in their turn delivered him up to Russia. To save himself, NITCHIPORENKO betrayed the whole plot, and among other things, told how KELSIEFF had been protected by SOLOVIEVITCH and his two friends. The trial of these gentlemen has extended over a space of about three years, and they ware sentenced on the 17th to perpetual banishment to Siberia, with the loss of all civil and political rights. Even this is a commutation of their original sentence, under which they were condemned to hard labor for the first twelve years of their exile. A British subject, named VENI, or BENI, is also implicated in this affair. His offence is that he knew KELSEIFF was in Russia, and did not denounce him to the police. He is to be imprisoned three months, and then be sent out of Russia, where he has long resided and distinguished himself as a journalist.

abstract: Atlantic Telegraph; Exclusive Proceedings of Directors; Press, the
snippet: Atlantic Telegraph; Exclusive Proceedings of Directors; Press, the
lead_paragraph: It is announced in the journals received yesterday by the Persia that the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company have determined to allow no one on board the Great Eastern during the laying of the cable, except the persons in the company's employ. The object apparently aimed at in this decision is to prevent any "unauthorized" account of the work of laying the cable from being given to the public. No representative of the press is to be permitted on board; but a gentleman engaged, paid and controlled by the Directors, is to take notes on the passage and draw up a report, which, after being revised and approved by the proprietors of the telegraph, is to be given to the public.
headline: {'main': 'The Atlantic Telegraph A Bad Beginning.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Atlantic Telegraph A Bad Beginning.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- At the fight which took place near Blue Mills, Mo., in September, 1861, the Union forces, Third Iowa Volunteers, were accompanied by one piece of artillery, a 6-pound gun, belonging to SCHWART's battery. The piece came early interaction, and so terrible was the fire upon it, that it was compelled to fall back, with the loss of many killed and wounded. The shifting of the scene of strife threw the ground upon which the gun had stood, again into our possession, when a member of the battery, named SCHELLING, was found standing with a rammer in his hand unconscious of anything going on around him. He was brought off the field, immovable as a statue. When he arrived in this city he was still unconscious. An examination indicated no wound, no concussion or compression. The pupils of the eyes were natural -- the position of the body would remain as placed. He neither ate nor drank, except by artificial means, He Showed no signs of sleep save by his breathing. He died on the seventeenth day after the battle. He was said to have been an Austrian and an old soldier. Dr. THORNE, who was in charge of the general hospital here at the time, and from whom we obtained the particular, is of the opinion that SCHELLING died from mere fright. -- St. Louis News.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. BOUCICAULT'S spectacular drama of "Arrah-na-pogue," of which we have heard so much, was produced here last evening, and received with favor, warming once or twice into enthusiasm, by an audience that was crowded in every part of the house. The drama is constructed with all Mr.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- BOUCICAULT's spectacular drama of "Arrah-na-pogue," of which we have heard so much, was produced here last evening, and received with favor, warming once or twice into enthusiasm, by an audience that was crowded in every part of the house. The drama is constructed with all Mr. BOUCICAULT's well-known skill, and the dialogue represents that gentleman's and Mr. HOUSE's ability in the use of words. The story of the piece is is by no means intricate, but we lack time, writing at midnight, to even faintly sketch it. In the main, it is the old Irish legend of the peasant protecting the rebellious and proscribed lord of the soil and nearly getting to the gallows for his pains. In the present case there is a complication, involving the simple love and troth of Arrak, the heroine. She offers the protection of her root to the McCeul and promises not to divulge the fact for three days. The presence of a stranger in her cottage is discovered by Michael Feeney, the informer and villain in of the peace, and on the day of her wedding to Shaun, the post, he divulges the secret, which leads to an uneasy rupture. The best "sensation" of the play is here. Shaun finds his bride overwhelmed with the suspicious of her neighbors, and the accusations of Feeney amounting almost to evidence of her guilt. To save her honor he deliberately asserts a falsehood, and says that he was the man who took shelter in the cottage. Hereby he becomes involved in a supposititious robbery which attaches to the real individual. It is impossible to follow the plot at greater length. It is framed effectively and affords abundant opportunities for stage manager, artist, machinist and carpenter. The difficulties in the way of production are so many that every allowance ought to be made for a first night. Fortunately, however, allowance was unnecessary. No contretemps occurred. The performance, nevertheless, terminated at a late hour.

abstract: Fire Department, Progress of Organization
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Fire Commissioners are energetically pushing forward the work of organization, but as yet the difficulties in the way are far from overcome. The one great obstacle so far encountered is the absolute want of funds with which to carry out the projected improvements entertained by the new board toward a complete reorganization. As soon, however, as the budget sent in by them to the Board of Supervisors is accepted and the moneys are forthcoming, the board will set about making the extensive alterations already laid out.

abstract: Inaugural Proclamation
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS OF THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI: The President of the United States, by virtue of the power vested in him by the Constitution of the United States, has been pleased to appoint the undersigned Provisional Governor of the State of Mississippi, "for the purpose of enabling the loyal people of said State to organize a State Government, whereby justice may be established, domestic tranquillity insured, and loyal citizens protected in all their rights of life, liberty and property;" and, to accomplish that object, has directed me, "at the earliest practicable period, to prescribe such rules and regulations as may be necessary and proper for convening a Convention of Delegates, to be chosen by that portion of the people of said State who are loyal to the United States, and no others, for the purpose of altering or amending the constitution thereof," so that the State may be able to resume its place in the Union. And being anxious to carry out the wishes of the President, and to restore the dominion of civil government as speedy as possible, I do hereby ordain and declare as follows, to wit.:

abstract: Transatlantic Express and Steamship Company
lead_paragraph: There are few of our readers who will not peruse with very great interest the report, which we publish in other columns to-day, of a partly organized new Atlantic Steamship Company. Aside from any interest in the proposed establishment of an American line for the Atlantic trade, and without being committed to the present scheme. it is safe for us to say that the subject is made peculiarly attractive in this instance by the splendid class of vessels (of Great Eastern proportions) it is intended to construct; by the novelty of their architecture, by the proposed innovations in the application of the propelling power, and by the approval which the scheme has elicited from such accomplished navigators as Capt. GADSDEN.

abstract: Miss AUGUSTA J. EVANS, of Mobile, author of Beulah, Macaria, etc., has been spending a few days in the city. Shut up for four years by the blockade she has enjoyed greatly the privileges of the metropolis, and has been the recipient of much attention from well-known litterateurs. During her stay Mr. F.B. CARPENTER has painted a portrait of her, which is pronounced by competent judges to be one of the best works ever from his easel.

lead_paragraph: A.W. Heye et al. vs. The Ship Cordillera. -- The libelants having agreed with the ship to take 350 tierces of lard to Liverpool, sent it alongside the ship in a lighter. abstract: Barnum's Museum Burned; Barnum's Museum destroyed and adjoining buildings
snippet: Barnum's Museum Burned; Barnum's Museum destroyed and adjoining buildings
lead_paragraph: The fire which yesterday destroyed BARNUM's American Museum, while greatly injuring and materially impoverishing its enterprising and public-spirited proprietor, did a damage to this and the adjacent communities, which neither time nor money can replace. Granting the innumerable sensations with which the intelligent public were disgusted and the innocent public deluded, and the ever patent humbuggery with which the adroit manager coddled and cajoled a credulous people, the Museum still deserved an honorable place in the front rank of the rare and curious collections of the world.

abstract: Fifth-avenue, Widening of
lead_paragraph: -- Every day's experience shows that within twenty, or even ten years from the present time, easy and safe access to the Central Park will demand a much wider avenue than the one now used for that purpose. It is no uncommon thing even now to see three lines of carriages, in the upper end of Fifth-avenue, going to and returning from the Central Park. The constantly increasing attractions of that magnificent resort, and the rapid increase in the population of the city, render it certain that within the time mentioned the number of vehicles that visit the Park daily will at least be doubled.

abstract: It is a pleasant thing to be a Lieutenant-General, particularly if honor and success have ever attended your footsteps. Gen. GRANT must find it so. Swords, money, houses, horses, cigars and suits of clothing are sent him from all parts of the country, and his autographical acknowledgments are regarded as ample compensation for the outlay. The last present brought to our notice is one of MERRIAM's last editions of WEBSTER's Unabridged, illustrated and gotten up in the sensational style of the superb press at Riverside, Cambridge. The book is on exhibition at the store of Messrs. HURD & HOUGHTON, in Broadway, where it attracts very general attention. The binding is a rich Le vantine Turkey morocco. The inside covers are highly finished in red, white and blue, and panel work of inlaid morocco ornamented with gold lines, thirty-six gold stars, a shield, an eagle, the national flag, and the insignia of the lieutenant-general's office, all in gold. In the centre of the inside cover is the inscription, "Lieut.-Gen. ULYSSES S. GRANT," and just above this name, in a diamond figure, is the motto: "I propose to move immediately on your works." Below, in another diamond figure, is that other motto: "I propose to fight it out on this line, if it takes all Summer."
lead_paragraph: It is a pleasant thing to be a Lieutenant-General, particularly if honor and success have ever attended your footsteps. Gen. GRANT must find it so. The last present brought to our notice is one of MERRIAM's last editions of WEBSTER's Unabridged, illustrated and gotten up in the sensational style of the superb press at Riverside, Cambridge. The book is on exhibition at the store of Messrs. HURD & HOUGHTON, in Broadway, where it attracts very general attention. The binding is a rich Le vantine Turkey morocco. The inside covers are highly finished in red, white and blue, and panel work of inlaid morocco ornamented with gold lines, thirty-six gold stars, a shield, an eagle, the national flag, and the insignia of the lieutenant-general's office, all in gold. In the centre of the inside cover is the inscription, "Lieut.-Gen. ULYSSES S. GRANT," and just above this name, in a diamond figure, is the motto: "I propose to move immediately on your works." Below, in another diamond figure, is that other motto: "I propose to fight it out on this line, if it takes all Summer."

abstract: Tory Journals on Confederate Valor
lead_paragraph: In the gallant sea-fight between the Kearsarge and the Alabama, when the latter was sent to the bottom, it will be remembered that nearly all the sympathy of our foreign friends was expended upon the crew of the ship that was whipped, and little praise was left for the gallant conquerors. Capt. SEMMES was instantly made a hero, a Confederate Nelson, and toasted, feted, banqueted, speechified, chaperoned and lionized ad libitum; while the modest Capt. WINSLOW was put quite in the lurch by the discomfited freebooter he had blown out of the water.

abstract: Probably no building in New-York was better known, inside and out, to our citizens than the ill-looking ungainly, rambling structure on the corner of Broadway and Ann-streets, known as the American Museum, where for more than twenty years Mr. BARNUM has furnished the public with a wonderful variety of amusements. The contents of the building, and the arrangement of the various departments, are elsewhere fully described. Here he has exhibited all the remarkable curiosities which money and enterprise could procure, or ingenuity invent. A model of Niagara Falls operated by a steam-engine; the Feejee mermaid, made up of the head and body of a monkey and the tail of a fish; the diorama of the removal of the remains of NAPOLEON I. from St. Helena to Paris; the Happy Family, the "What Is it?" the Lightning Calculator, the hippopotamus, whales, alligators, baby shows, dog shows, prize poultry, and ten thousand other objects of curiosity, formed at various times the objects of popular attraction, and achieved for Mr. BARNUM a success which probably exceeded even his most sanguine expectations.
lead_paragraph: Probably no building in New-York was better known, inside and out, to our citizens than the ill-looking ungainly, rambling structure on the corner of Broadway and Ann-streets, known as the American Museum, where for more than twenty years Mr. BARNUM has furnished the public with a wonderful variety of amusements. The contents of the building, and the arrangement of the various departments, are elsewhere fully described. Here he has exhibited all the remarkable curiosities which money and enterprise could procure, or ingenuity invent. abstract: The M.T. Brennan Chowder Club, composed of members of Hose Company No. 60. made their annual excursion on Tuesday last to Sheepshead Bay. The attendance was unusually large, about one hundred and twenty-five persons being present. The excursion was as much enjoyed as in former years, and after spending a most delight ful day, the company returned to the city, at an early hour in the evening. It has been resolved to continue the club, which has proved a source of much pleasure to its members.

abstract: Burning of
lead_paragraph: -- Our reporters give, in another part of this sheet, complete details of the destruction by fire of the American Museum and other valuable buildings. The loss of the large collection of curiosities by this fire, is of national importance. Of course a great deal can be restored with time and money, and for so much there need be no special regret; but there were a great many relics of the Revolution, of the War of 1812, and other peculiar curiosities connected with our national and personal history, which are gone forever.

abstract: Michigan, Commencement
lead_paragraph: This college may not be so well known as some of our older and Eastern Colleges, but it has a history and a growth, which give promise of a brilliant future. It is located in the quiet and beautiful village of the same name, easily accessible, and distinguished for the intelligent and Christian morality of its citizens. Its annual commencement and examination exercises occurred during the last week of June, and were of a highly intellectual and attractive character.

abstract: The society met for the last time this season a few evenings since, Mr. F.H. NORTON presiding, at the Society Library. The Incorporation Committee presented a final report, with accompanying documents and printed copy of the act of incorporation. The Committee on the Lincoln Memorial Medal presented a circular bearing a rough wood-cut design in bronze coloring of the proposal medal. The obverse bears a profile bust of the late President, surrounded by the words, "Salvator Patriae;" the reverse has the following inscription: "In Memory of the Lafe, Acts, and Death of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, born Feb. 12, 1809; Died April 15, 1865." Encircling this is a laurel wreath outwined with which is a narrow band bearing the words, "Pub. by the American N[???]smatic and Archaeological Society, New-York, 1865."

abstract: Gettysburgh and the NEW-YORK TIMES Correspondent
snippet: Gettysburgh and the NEW-YORK TIMES Correspondent
lead_paragraph: -- A small weekly newspaper, printed at Gettysburgh, Penn., a place rendered historic by the accident of a battle at its doors, contains a small personal assault upon the gentleman in charge of the Washington bureau of this paper, and who visited Gettysburgh on the occasion of the late celebration as the representative of the TIMES. For the sake of the reputation of the place, and in compliance with the wishes of the very best and most respectable people there, our correspondent passed by the disgraceful demonstrations personal to himself in silence; he was hospitably and courteously treated by the respectable portion of the population with whom he came in personal contact, and as the efforts of the few rowdies to do him personal violence utterly failed, there is no cause for giving the circumstances in detail, which would only add to a load of odium already too great for the people of the locality to bear -- for it so happens that the respectable people of a place always have to bear the blame of the derelictions of a few, and Gettysburgh is no exception to this rule. But it seldom happens that the conductors of the weekly village paper are so ignorant and dishonest as to incite mob violence upon a gentleman who happens to be visiting their village upon a national occasion. Perhaps a few more celebrations in that part of Pennsylvania may educate even such men into decency and comparative intelligence.

abstract: Yesterday morning the Third Vermont Regiment arrived at Battery Barracks, from Washington, via the Camden and Amboy route. The regiment landed at Pier No. 1 at about 10 o'clock, and remained at the Barracks until 3 P.M., when they took the Hudson River road for Albany, intending to proceed to Burlington, Vt., for final payment and discharge.

abstract: A MACHINIST TURNS DOCTOR AND LOSES HIS FIRST PATIENT. -- A child named WM. L. RYAN, whose parents reside in Eagle-street, near Liberty, Greenpoint, died on Monday last under circumstances which induced Coroner BARRETT to cause an investigation. A post-mortem examination was made by Drs. CREAMER and DONNER, and they yesterday submitted the result of that examination to the Coroner's jury. The evidence elicited showed that deceased had been suffering from cholera infantum, and that a man named JOHN W. ALEXANDER, a machinist by trade, undertook to prescribe medicines for its relief. The nostrums failed and the child died. The medical testimony went to show that the medicines, although harmless in many cases, were unfit for this. The jury rendered a verdict of death from perforation of the stomach, and also censured Mr. ALEXANDER for undertaking a business of which he knew nothing.... Coroner BARRETT also held an inquest last evening upon the body of an infant found in the vault of the premises rear of No. 107 Grand-street, E.D. No evidence was obtained in relation to it.

abstract: DE LA SALLE INSTITUTE. -- The closing exercises of the annual examination at this institution took place Wednesday evening, a good audience attending. The exercises consisted of declamations, examinations in Greek, Latin, mathematics and music. The students, mere boys, acquitted themselves very creditably, particularly in construing passages of the ancient languages, and in solving problems pertaining to the calculus and logarithmic series. The band, composed of members of the institute, made a fine display. At the close of the exercises, prizes were awarded to those having attained a prescribed degree of merit.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS. -- In this court, Wednesday, JOHN VRAGAN, a German, was tried for rape upon a little girl aged seven years, named FREDERICKA REINHART, residing in Twenty-seventh-street, near Fourth-avenue, Gowanus. The offence, as alleged, was perpetrated in defendant's store, near the residence of the child's parents, on the 27th of June last. The jury found the prisoner guilty of an attempt to commit rape, and sentence was deferred. ....THOMAS STEWART was tried for burglary and convicted. It appeared from the evidence that he entered the residence of Mr. FOOTE, No. 223 Clermont-avenue, and took up a number of valuable articles. The servant girl gave the alarm, and he was arrested. The jury returned a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was sentenced to State Prison for ten years.

abstract: Bright, John, on Parliamentary Reform
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRIGHT, whose name has so long been identified with the championship of the principles of democracy in England, and with the advocacy of liberty in all countries, has presented himself again at Birmingham as a candidate for reelection to Parliament. His address is eminently characteristic of the man. Regardless of rank or party, he expresses a hearty contempt of all "trimmers," and speaks in the following terms, in his address to his constituents, of the Punic faith of the Palmerston-Russell Administration on the question of reform:

abstract: Mr. Seward, Mr. Weed and the TIMES
snippet: Mr. Seward, Mr. Weed and the TIMES
lead_paragraph: Men out of place are generally more or less unhappy. Mr. MONTGOMERY BLAIR, formerly, to the great discontent of the country, Postmaster-General, is the most unhappy specimen of the race we have lately heard from. He lacks naturally the faculty of living in peace with the rest of mankind, and while in the Cabinet of President LINCOLN was perpetually at war with the rest of his associates. To such an extent had his quarrelsome propensities made him obnoxious to the general sentiment of the Union party, that his removal was imperatively demanded by large sections of that party as the sine qua non of supporting Mr. LINCOLN for reelection. And it was at him that the resolution of the Baltimore Convention, calling for a reconstruction of the Cabinet, was especially aimed.

abstract: Carlisle, Penn.; Gover's Paper Mills; $30,000
lead_paragraph: Gov. SHARKEY, of Mississippi, issued a proclamation on the 1st, in which he says: "The negroes are now free -- free by the fortunes of war, free by the proclamation, free by common consent, free practically as well as theoretically; and it is too late to raise questions as to the means by which they became so." He wishes the people to cordially unite in efforts to organize a State Government, and prepare themselves to live in prosperity and happiness in the changed condition of their domestic relations.

abstract: The ruins caused by the fire wore an air of extreme desolation yesterday. All day volumes of smoke ascended from the heated debris, and streams of water were kept continually playing upon them. Thousands of persons visited the locality, and a strong force of police was necessary to keep the crowd back and allow a passage for vehicles and pedestrians. The Knox building, at the corner of Fulton-street and Broadway, is still standing, and on its top is a lofty flagstaff, which looks as if the slightest gust of wind would send it down on the heads of the crowd below. The streets in the vicinity are still obstructed by rubbish, among which numbers of persons were hunting all day for relics of the great fire.

abstract: Free Academy Prize Speaking
lead_paragraph: Irving Hall was crowded in every part, last night, by a large and brilliant audience, assembled to hear the difierent prize compositions of both the Senior and Junior Classes of the New-York Free Academy, known usually as "Rigg's Prizes." The occasion was one of peculiar interest, and the proceedings of the evening passed off greatly to the gratification both of the students and their friends.

abstract: Odd Fellows Circular Declaring Unbroken Unity
snippet: Odd Fellows Circular Declaring Unbroken Unity
lead_paragraph: -- A circular has recently been issued by ISAAC M. VEITCH, of St. Louis, M.W.G. Sire of the Grand Lodge of U.S. Independent Order of Odd Fellows, declaring the unbroken unity of the Order throughout the United States. This high official further proclaims that any and every act or declaration to the contrary is null and void, and of no force or effect whatever. All Grand Lodges or Grand Encampments in the United States are invited to send representatives to the Grand Lodge of the United States which will convene in Baltimore, on the third Monday of September, 1865.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon JAMES MURPHY, of No. 33 Monroe-street, having quarreled with his wife, of whom he is jealous, threatened to "spoil her figure;" and shortly afterward, having been to a drug-store, he returned and threw vitriol into her eyes. He was arrested by Patrolman BUCKLEY and taken to the Fourth Ward Police-station, and there held, last night, by Capt. THORNE to await examination, and Mrs. MURPHY was taken to the Bellevue Hospital. Her eyes and face are very seriously disfigured.

abstract: Heston, Rev. Newton, of N. Y.
snippet: Heston, Rev. Newton, of N. Y.
lead_paragraph: SUDDEN DEHTH ON A CLERGYMAN. -- The Rev. NEWTON HESTON died suddenly at his residence on Thursday of apoplexy. The deceased was Pastor of the Suite-street Congregational Church, over which he presided for the past five years. He had been ill for some days, complaining very much of a singular feeling about the head and pains in the breast. He was walking in his room when he remarked to his wife that he felt strangely. She sprang to him and asked him a few questions when he sank in her arms and soon expired. Mr. HESTON was 40 years of age, and a native of Philadelphia. His remains will be taken to that city for interment on Monday next.

abstract: The Fifty-sixth Messachusetts Regiment, containing the remnants of the Twenty-first and Thirty-sixth Massachusetts Regiments, arrived yesterday afternoon and left by the Neptune line for Readville. The Fourth Vermont Regiment also arrived last evening, and are now remaining at the Battery Barracks. They will depart by special steamer for Albany this afternoon, en route for Burlington, Vt. The Seventeenth New-York is expected to arrive to-morrow, (Sunday.) The One hundred and Second New-York will, no doubt, also come in on Monday, and the Corcoran Legion, consisting of the Sixty-ninth National Guard, One Hundred and Fifty-fifth. OneHundred and Sixty-fourth and One Hundred and Seventieth New-York Volunteer Regiments will arrive on Tuesday. Great preparations are now being made for the reception of these several commands.

abstract: GOG. -- A trip to the mountains and lake is as delightful an excursion as can be taken at this season. Passengers can leave the city by the New-Haven steamboat at 3:15 P.M., lodge at Sprirngfield, and arrive at the mountains the following evening; or, by rail, they can leave the New-Haven depot at Twenty-seventh-street at 12:15 P.M., sleeping at White River Junction, and arriving at their destination the following afternoon. This route is shorter than any other by sixty miles, and affords travelers a view of the lovely scenery of the Connecticut Valley. Lake Memphrema[???]g is on the borders of Canada, and thence Montreal, and other points can be reached in a few hours. These r[???]s were very popular last Summer, and will undoubtedly be equally so this.

abstract: WILLIAM THOMSON was arraigned on a charge of having burglariously entered the premises of Mr. SOLOMON HERMAN, at No. 98 Seventh-street. When arrested, he was trying to escape from the house through the cellar. Thomson is said to be an old offender, having served a term of five years in the State Prison, on a charge of highway robbery. He was committed without bail.

abstract: The Fifty-sixth Massachusetts Veteran Regiment arrived in this city, yesterday afternoon, by the New-Jersey route, and marched down Broadway from Cortlandt-street to the Battery Barracks, being received with considerable applause by the crowds who were attracted from their contemplation of the smouldering ruins of the Museum by the music of the regimental band. The command comprises about 427 men and 22 officers, under command of Col. STEPHEN M. WELD. After dinner at the Barracks, the regiment started for Readville, Mass., taking passage by the Neptune Line, at 5 P.M.

abstract: Promotion of
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. CLIFFORD THOMSON, of this city, who, when the war broke out, was a capable and energetic reporter for the press, has just been commissioned by the President Major in the Fifth United States Colored troops. Major THOMSON, who is a brother of MORTIMER THOMSON, (Doesticks,) the well-known comic writer and lecturer, has served all through the war as an aid-de-camp on the staff of Major-Gen. PLEASONTON. His promotion has been nobly earned by hard service and numerous acts of gallant conduct in the field. His regiment is now stationed in Kentucky, but it is likely that he will be retained on Gen. PLEASONTON's staff.

abstract: --A statuette and a bust of Mr. LINCOLN, in bronze, both of which were manufactured in Paris, are now on exhibition at the establishment of Messrs. MAGUIN, GUEDON & Co., No. 2 Maiden-lane. The cast of the face in both works is admirable, as a striking and ex pressive likeness. In the statuette Mr. LINCOLN isrepresented holding in his left hand the Emancipation Proclamation, while his right hand retains the pen with which he has just affixed his name to the document. A long cloak or toga falls gracefully from the shoulders, without obscuring the figure in the least. Barring the pen, which seems out of place with the cloak, and a certain rigidity of pose, not characteristic of the late President when standing, the artist has achieved a success -- so much of a success that it may be hypocritical to refer to these minor faults. The bust in all respects is unexceptionable.

snippet: Gotham, of New-York, vs. Atlantic, of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: GOTHAM, OF NEW-YORK, VS. ATLANTIC, OF BROOKLYN. -- The first contest between these clubs this season took place yesterday afternoon at Hoboken, and attracted a numerous crowd of spectators, numbering at least 4,000, every seat on the platforms being occupied -- a large delegation of the fair sex being present in the seats recently erected by the Mutual Club, in the rear of the catcher's position. To the disappointment of all present, the champion nine of the Atlantic Club was not present, that noted member of it, C. SMITH, being an absentee. The Gothams, too, did not have GEORGE WRIGHT with them, as expected, and they therefore did not in consequence play with that effect they otherwise would have done.

abstract: Messrs. VALLANDIGHAM, PENDLETON, LONG, OLDS, and the others who recently met in Ohio as a Democratic State Convention, have just sent forth a challenge to anybody to discuss with them the question of slavery, they affirming it to be the proper condition for the negroes of the South. We have not yet heard of any Abolitionist proposing to take up the challenge, and we fear that the argument will all be on one side. We are perfectly willing that it should be.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. abstract: S.N.Y. -- Companies H and B are making arrangements for a grand excursion to Albany and Saratoga, which will probably take place during the first part of August. The affair will probably surpass anything of the kind ever gotten up by our city military. DODWORTH's full band will accompany [???], and rumor has it that Lieut. REMSEN APPLEBY, of B. company. (a member of the committee) has e[???]d I[???]and's Opera House for a grand hop. New-Yorkers at the Spring will rejoice to learn the truth of this; they can at least rely on a well-founded rumor and patiently await further announcement. The military of Albany will doubtless make preparations to receive those companies in a creditable manner. The committee appointed will report at a special meeting of the two companies at the Armory of B company, on next Tuesday evening.

abstract: Robert McIlroy, proprietor of a liquor store at No. 268 Avenue A, was placed on trial, charged with keeping a disorderly house at the above number. John Loonan, proprietor of a rival liquor saloon No. 269 Avenue A, directly opposite, was the complainant. He said: Previous to the 11th of July for about fifteen weeks there has been nothing there but a great deal of trouble daily, drinking and annoying the citizens; they are continually coming around and stabbing people. I swear it is a resort for tipplers; I have seen from twenty-two to twenty-four in there; I have seen not only reputed thieves in there, but I know them to be thieves, and to have been on the island and in the State Prison; I have never seen any women in there; there is no dancing there, but I have heard McIlroy play the fiddle there; there is quarreling and fighting continually from eleven and twelve to three o'clock in the morning. I swear it is a common nuisance to the neighborhood and the people passing by.

abstract: A large crowd of sweepers, formerly employed by the City Inspector, assembled round the Comptroller's office yesterday morning to receive their back pay. About six weeks' wages were due them, amounting in the aggregate to $126,930. The pay-rolls having been made out by the City Inspector, the men were rapidly paid off and departed.

abstract: The States of Missouri and Maryland have had about a year's experience of emancipation. The late slaves in both these States are behaving remarkably well in their new condition. There are no complaints about their idleness, indolence or worthlessness. On the contrary, we learn that they work industriously for wages, and that their services are in great demand, while they are also making progress in education and intelligence. It will be so in all the other Southern States, after a little time has been given for the establishment of things on the new basis.

abstract: One of the most interesting and successful of the literary exhibitions of the season took place, yesterday afternoon, at Ward School No. 33, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Ninth-avenue, Twentieth Ward. Under the skillful management of Miss CLARA M. EDMONDS, the accomplished principal of the grammar department of this school, it has attained rank among the best of the grammar schools in the city, both in respect to the numbers of the pupils and the thoroughness of its course of study. The exercises on this occasion celebrated the graduation of ten young ladies, who have fully completed the course of studies prescribed for our highest school for girls. The fact of their excellence was testified to by HENRY KIDDLE, Esq., the efficient Superintendent, who, in presenting their diplomas, stated that having examined the class thoroughly for a day and a half, he knew that each of the persons to whom he gave a diploma was fully entitled to it. It should be said to the credit of these young girls, seventeen years of age, that, beside taking their graduating diplomas, eight of the ten were found at the examination to be entitled to the highest grade of certificates as teachers.

abstract: Our German fellow-citizens are unrivaled in the success which crowns their efforts to make their social life happy and enjoyable. Unlike the native American, the naturalized German never forgets his childhood or youth; to him the pleasures of life, the innocent recreations of early days are as bright and as desirable now as ever. Their pic-nics, concerts, reunions, glee clubs and festal associations bear ample and continuous testimony to the fact of their hearty appreciation of the good in life, and their equal determination to hold fast all that is good as long as their Teutonic tabernacles remain this side the swelling flood.

abstract: Fifty-third-street, Totten's Carpenter Shop and Dwelling; Incendiary; Yorkville, Brown's Stables; Incendiary; South-street, Vine Hotel; Incendiary; West Forty-fourth-street, Ackerman's Coffee Factory and nine Buildings; $50,000
snippet: Fifty-third-street, Totten's Carpenter Shop and Dwelling; Incendiary; Yorkville, Brown's Stables; Incendiary; South-street, Vine Hotel; Incendiary; West Forty-fourth-street, Ackerman's Coffee Factory and nine Buildings; $50,000
lead_paragraph: While the great fire was raging, fire was discovered in the two-story wooden building numbered 317 West Forty-fourth-street, in Messrs. ACKERMAN & CO.'s coffee mills. This building was speedily consumed, and the flames extended to the frame building adjoining, numbered 319, occupied as a curled-hair factory by Mr. ANDREW BEISER & SON, which, in a very short time fell, and soon the two frame and brick buildings, numbered 321 and 323, occupied by Mr. HENRY BECK as a cabinet factory, were also destroyed, together with two frame and brick tenement houses in the rear, which had been occupied by twenty-five families. Taking an easterly direction, the fire entered the four-story wooden tenement-house numbered 315, and thence sped to the four-story tenant-houses numbered 313 and 311, and thence to Nos. 307 and 309, where the firemen gained mastery.

abstract: HEARTLESS SEDUCTION OF YOUNG WOMEN. --Yesterday afternoon Officer MOFARLAND, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, arrested JOHN PFEIFER, of No. 239 South Fourth-street, E.D., who is charged by Miss LOYD, residing in Lincoln-place, E.D., with accomplishing her ruin, under promise of marriage. PFEIFER, who is a married man, with a family, don't deny the young woman's allegation. He wooed her as a single man under an assumed name, and represented himself as the owner of a farm on the island. He is now locked up....A young and interesting girl, named KATE VAN HOUTEN, residing at No. 7 North Second-street, caused the arrest of EDWARD WROCKNER, a young man who succeeded in accomplishing her ruin under promise of marriage. The girl suspected his insincerity some time since, and applied for advice to Justice DAILEY, who issued a warrant for his arrest; but by dyeing his hair a jet black, (it was previously carrotty,) he managed to evade the officer until yesterday, when he was arrested and locked up.

abstract: Press; Amendment Needed
lead_paragraph: - From every city and State of the South we are now receiving regular files of daily or weekly journals. Fully a half of them are entirely new in all their characteristics, while the other half consist of the old papers, with their old names, but with new proprietors and principles. The bulk of them all are truly loyal, and accept the new order of things in all its fullness. There are no more earnest anti-slavery papers in all the country than those we get from New-Orleans, Mobile, Vicksburgh, Memphis and Nashville; and we can say nearly as much for those from the cities of the Atlantic States, as Savannah, Charleston, Wilmington, Raleigh and Norfolk. But we cannot speak so well for the daily papers issued at the late rebel capital, Richmond. They seem to be afflicted with the mollygrubs. They have not the hearty, vigorous, progressive, unconditionally loyal spirit that we find, for example, in those of Memphis. They are not only fault-finding and atrabilious, but often insolent and dictatorial. The strong hand of military power has had to interfere with two of them within a short time, and all of them need an amendment in their character. If they would serve the present and future interests of Virginia, let them learn to be manfully and grandly loyal.

abstract: The great fire which has destroyed so much property at the Fulton-Ann street angle of Broadway, gives an opportunity worthy the serious attention of those City Railroad Companies whose eastern terminus has long been an eyesore and inconvenience at that part of the city. The buildings destroyed leave a large space which might be appropriated to the erection of a spacious and convenient terminus with all the addenda of passenger's rooms, car-houses, &c, Such an undertaking might be made a profitable one by the erection of first-class offices for letting, and the public would at last be provided with shelter while waiting for cars, instead of having to wade through mud or over mountains of snow as heretofore, to say nothing of the risk of anhihilation by wheel or hoof. Will not the companies give this matter their attention?

abstract: Attacks on Government
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. F.P. BLAIR, Jr., has been making a speech in Kentucky, apropos of the election soon to come off there. It contains a good deal of very excellent advice on the subject of slavery, -- urging the people of Kentucky to ratify the constitutional amendment, and to make the best of the circumstances which surround them. But a large part of it, like that of his brother, MONTGOMERY BLAIR, in Maryland, is devoted to denunciation of members of the government at Washington, especially Mr. STANTON and Mr. HOLT. He goes a good deal out of his way, also, to assail Chief-Justice CHASE, whom he charges with having traversed the South to make votes for himself for President. The Blair family, now that slavery is abolished, is the most "peculiar institution" of this country.

abstract: New
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the newspapers are industriously collecting and printing all the criminal news from all parts of the country, and are attempting to make a great panic and sensation about the prodigious growth of crime. They get the largest stories, the wildest rumors, the most horrid details, and really succeed, we suppose, in making some people believe that we have now fallen upon what they call the "criminal era." But neither the records of this city, nor, so far as we can judge, any other large city, give countenance to the idea that there is any extra-ordinary prevalence of crime at this time. Our court and police reports do not by any means show it. The fact is that during the progress of the war, with its great battles and tremendous issues, the newspapers had no room for long and harrowing details of every case of violence, and a murder was then recorded in ten lines, which is now made to cover sensational columns.
headline: {'main': 'THE CRIMINAL ERA."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CRIMINAL ERA."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The New-York Museum Association, incorporated under the laws of the State, has just issued its prospectus. The proposed capital is $300,000, on which, says the prospectus, it is confidently expected that a profit of eighty per cent. per annum can be made. The building is to contain a collection of natural and artificial curiosities, a lecture-room, a gallery of paintings, a hall for the exhibition of new and useful inventions and machinery of all kinds in actual operation, and an historical department for the reception of national trophies. The management is to be under the direction of Mr. JOHN BANVARD, and the establishment is to be located in the vicinity of Madison or Union squares. The Treasurer is Mr. EDWARD K. GOODNOW, and the Directors are Messrs. Joseph Ayers, Henry R. Brown, Wm.K. Banvard, W.H. Goodnow and W.A. Lilliendahl.

abstract: Yale College is to do honor to those of her former pupils who have served the country in the present war, by a celebration on Wednesday, July 26, the day before commencement. An oration will be delivered by Rev. Dr. BUSHNELL, of Hartford, after which a dinner, with speeches and sentiments, will be provided. The "Roll of Honor," including those under-graduates who left the college after the war began, in order to serve the country, already numbers over 500 names. It is expected that a large representation will be present at the festival.

abstract: County Court-house, History and Progress
lead_paragraph: At the north end of the City Hall Park is a mysterious enclosure. A high board fence serves as the barrier behind which ordinary mortals must not go, beyond which are sounds of hammer and saw, and great numbers of full-grown voters, whose services are as secret as their pay is regular. One side of this fence has served for many years as a rival to the advertising columns of the newspapers. There, well educated people can read the most tempting promises of WALLACE, STUART, WOOD and BARNUM; the passer can learn where to buy the fragrant "Sozodont;" the infirm can ascertain the whereabouts of the nearest crutch factory or pill shop, and the stranger need go no further to find a cure for every ill. We have seen elderly men from the country pause in amazement in front of that lofty fence; we have seen thimble-riggers avail themselves of the unfeigned curiosity of their victims beneath its very shadow; we have seen itinerant boot-blacks cease for the moment in the practice of their vocation as the wheezing sounds from the inclosure burst out upon the silent Park. Small boys who avoided that corner after dark in years gone by, who tore numerous trowsers in their subsequent attempts to climb up and peep over, who regarded it in maturer years as a disgrace to the city, are now full-grown men, taxpayers in the county, who are much interested in the tearing down of the fence, and wonder each year if that "infernal job will ever be completed."
headline: {'main': 'THE COUNTY COURT HOUSE.; A Curious Bit of History---Its Origin, Progress and Prospects. Its Present Condition, Cost and Estimates. When it will be Done, and What the Taxpayers May Expect. AT THE PRESENT TIME. ARE NO DEFINITE PLANS. abstract: and Lee as Historians
lead_paragraph: The two leading Generals of the late war, GRANT and LEE, are now engaged in writing up the history of their respective campaigns. In both cases, we suppose, the histories will be almost purely military in their purposes, and hence not very popular in their character. LEE, however, will have some advantage over GRANT, in that his history will not be made in the form of an official report, and hence he can indulge in greater discursiveness of statement and greater freedom of style than is customary in official documents.

abstract: -- The government enterprise, to which we referred a few days ago, that of establishing a large depot for naval ordnance just below Jefferson Barracks, is being carried out with all practicable speed. The land to be occupied is part of the military reservation, and has been conveyed by the Secretary of War to the Navy Department for the purpose for which Capt. BABCOCK and his assistants are now applying it. As soon as the ground is properly marked and leveled for the buildings necessary for the depot, their erection will be commenced. They will comprise two large stone powder magazines, each about one hundred and fifty feet by fifty, a structure for general stores two hundred and fifty feet by sixty, and an immense shed, of capacity sufficient to cover 800 cannon with their carriages. These will be of all sizes, from the light boat howitzer to the ordnance of greatest calibre now in use on any of our Western gunboats. The depot is to remain permanently at the location named, and the cost of establishing it is already provided for in the appropriations for the Ordnance Bureau of the Navy that were voted at the last session of Congress. The Moose and two or three other gunboats have arrived since our last notice, and are discharging freights of naval material brought from the abandoned station at Mound City. All the gunboats that are ordered to be sold at Cairo in August will doubtless visit the new station and land their guns and the contents of their magazines. -- St. Louis Republican, July 11.

abstract: Ecclesiastical Affairs in
lead_paragraph: The recent attempts to restore amicable relations between the King of Italy and the Pope appear to have definitely failed. The vacillation which has so long distinguished the Councils of the Vatacan, in all matters embracing ecclesiastical policy, bas again been exhibited. A few weeks ago it was announced, almost with the weight of official authority, that His Holiness had consented that the incumbents of the bishoprics he desired to erect within the Kingdom of Italy should take the oath of allegiance to VICTOR EMANUEL and promise obedience to the laws of the State over which he rules. To the mere secular mind, this demand on the one side, and the consent on the other, would appear to be mere matters of form, to be quietly disposed of instanter. But matters seem to be arranged differently at Rome. The Papal authorities now desire to recede from so reasonable an engagement as that into which they are reported to have entered, and wish to be allowed to appoint their bishops in a foreign State without any stipulations. It is an endeavor in fact, to reenact in the Kingdom of Italy the course pursued in England some years ago, when the latter was coolly cut up into numerous archiepiscopal and Episcopal-Roman Catholic districts, and appointments were made to each. A few old women, of both sexes, took the matter dreadfully to heart, and Exeter Hall, for a few months, exuded high-power Protestantism from every brick of its pious walls; but the majority only laughed. This contemptuous tolerance did its natural work, and divested what was an encroachment of all power for harm. A great Protestant community like that of England could afford to take this course, but the position of VICTOR EMANUEL is one which must utterly forbid his permitting any such an arrangement within his dominions. He can tolerate no imperium in imperio. -- either he or the Church must succumb, and the experience of the past, on the nunnery and similar questions, can lead us up to a very safe insight as to which power will ultimately prevail. The King has the best of the game, and he not only knows it, but possesses the resolution to take the fullest advantage of his position. Even the stern resort to excommunication has been clearly thrown away upon this intractable sovereign, who will persist in thinking for himself. He judiciously resolves to have no part in any half measures. Aut Cesar, aut nullus. He must be sole, acknowledged, and undisputed head of his own State, or the dioceses shall remain vacant.

abstract: According to the Quebec Chronicle, the supply of gas in that city is rather niggardly, and it sets forth the needs of the city as follows: "With streets of the most irregular conformation and disposal, with narrow obstructed lanes leading down to the wharves and docks of the waterside, with rocky heights, precipices and declivities forming the boundaries of several of our wards, with wretched sidewalks which, even in the best of our thoroughfares, only serve as pitfalls, and with two-thirds of our streets in bad order, we certainly require all the benefit which can be afforded us during the night by means of gas-light."

abstract: -- One of the city dailies, and the one which affects the highest standard of abstract morality, mercy and justice, was never able to give a more commendable heading to the trial of the persons charged (and convicted) of compassing the assassination of the President, than "The Conspiracy." But its tender conscience is not so sensitive in the case of Miss HARRIS. In this trial it says, in large type, "Trial of the Woman HARRIS; Testimony of the Brother of the Murdered Man and of the Lady with whom the Murderess Boarded." It may be all right according to our neighbor's view of abstract justice; but is it quite fair to denounce a prisoner (and one who seems to have but few friends) as a murderess before the conclusion of the trial? Should the verdict be the other way, what will the woman HARRIS then be?

abstract: Broadway, No. 641, $9,000; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning an incendiary fire was discovered in the hall-way under the stairs leading to the second story of No. 74 Bleeeker-street, and before the firemen could gain mastery of the flames the upper floor and part of the second story were destroyed. Considerable damage was also done at No. 641 Broadway, adjoining. The losses and insurances are as follows: M.E.E. SHEPHARD, silver-plater, lost $800; insured for $500 by the Continental Company. Mr. CHRISTIAN FLOCKS, cigar-maker, $800, and insured in the Hanover office for $500. Messrs. J.M. GRENNELL & CO. lost $300, and are not insured. Mr. G.W. BURGHER lost $150, and has $200 insurance in the Kings County office. Mr. C.N. BROWN lost $200, and is not insured. Mr. A.E. DELOUEST, plumber, lost $200, and is insured for $1,500 in the Franklin office of Philadelphia. Mr. LEFFERTS, of No. 641 Broadway, estimates the loss on his stock of dry goods at $5,000; his insurance is $16,000, in the Atlantic, Corn Exchange, Columbia and Standard offices. Mr. ISAAC SOLOMON, jeweler, of No. 641 Broadway, lost about $500, and is insured for $10,000 in the Brevoort, Jersey City, Lafayette, Stuyvesant and Tradesmen's offices. The building, which was damaged to the extent of about $1,300, is fully insured.

abstract: -- Seven years have passed away, and Delhi still stands, but changed -- changed for the better in its moral, social and political aspects. The Delhi of 1865 is not the Delhi of 1857. When we beheld the change that has come over the old city, we, while we dropped a tear to the sad memory of our slaughtered friends, are ready to exclaim, "Thank God we had this mutiny, since it has irrevocably destroyed the Mohametan power in India, and raised that of Great Britain!" From a native city, sunk in unfathomable vice, it has now become an English station, with fine broad streets and numerous English houses; and when the railway will be completed, and all the proposed alterations and other public structures finished, Delhi will become one of the finest cities under the Punjab Government. The future traveler, as he passes through, will find it difficult to recognize the old Mogul capital. The Jumah Musjid resounds no more with the shrieking summons of the Muezzin, and the loud prayers of the faithful, as it did in days gone by. The lofty rooms, the arched corridors, are stamped with the image of death; gone are the worshippers; silent are the voices of the priests; and the Feringhee, who dared not once at a time to enter the threshold of the great Mosque, enters now carelessly and without fear. The marble halls, too, still exist, but gone are all their inner splendors; the throne is wanting, and the titular Emperor, the last of the Moguls, who used in his dotage to sit upon it, died the other day in exile. What was once the palace of an Emperor is now a barrack, and where once English Ambassadors came to ask for land or for permission to trade, English soldiers now live and make the domed roof echo to their songs and jests. To one pacing up and down this spacious hall of judgment, and reviewing things present and past, it seems a dream that such changes should ever have taken place. -- Bombay paper.

abstract: Prof. Liebig on
lead_paragraph: -- The waste of beef in making beef tea is enormous. 62,000 lbs. a year are used in one London hospital alone; and if any head of a household, where there has been long illness, will just sum up the addition to the Butcher's bill in the shape of beef tea meat, he will be able to form some notion of the quantity used, and (many of the doctors are beginning to tell us) more than half wasted, throughout the country. At the present price of meat this is a very serious matter. It is LIEBIG's theory that in beef tea, properly made, you get all the nutrive part of the beef, and leave nothing but a worthless mass of bouilli behind. The British Medical Journal, on the other hand, asserts that fibrine is absolutely insoluble in water, and that a dog fed on beef tea dies as soon as one who gets nothing but mere water. If this be true, LIEBIG is as great a romancer in his way as the cook who, when asked by his noble master what use he could find for some thirty hams for one dinner, replied, "I shall put them all into no bigger as my thumb." We believe the safest way for the patient is to drink up that red meaty sediment which the "purists" so generally strain out. The fact is, LIEBIG's pint of tea, made from a pound of beef, yields by evaporation less than half an ounce of solid matter; and though we cannot admit that this "represents the whole nutritive matter contained in the pint of fluid," (for do not gases feed us?) the result is certainly startling. The Medical Journal makes two suggestions -- first, cat the bouilli, which, of course, can only be done by a stomach capable of digesting boiled beet; next, use more wine and less, beef tea in fever cases and the like. Wine is seldom rejected by the feeblest stomach, and it contains all the elements of the blood -- alkalies, iron, albumen, traces of most of the acids; besides, wine by itself will support life for a very long time. We heartily agree with this latter suggestion. Wine, by all means, for sick poor as well as for sick rich. But how, if you please, are middling folks to get it? Where is the parson, for instance, to buy it for his poor and for himself? Madeira is not; port is not -- i. e., not within the means of ordinary people. The Chancellor of the Exchequer has, they say, given us cheap claret; but will he make his gift doubly precious by telling us where we may obtain it sound? -- Pall Mall Gazette.

abstract: Central Park and City Railways
lead_paragraph: -- It is everywhere accepted as a fact that the Central Park is an institution indispensable to the city. All classes of our population find within its limits healthful, elevating, humanizing enjoyment. It is the pride of the rich and the delight of the poor. Its music on Saturday afternoon is the event of the week to countless thousands who are released by the early closing of stores and factories for a few hours' recreation from toil and drudgery. In behalf of this large class we again implore the managers of the city railroads for proper accommodation. It is not far wrong to state that each company transports on Saturday afternoons to and from the Park at least six thousand extra passengers, thus adding the handsome sum of $360 to its ordinary receipts. For this liberal patronage there is no compensating return. The management of the railroads is apparently actuated by a sordid and niggardly spirit. The money is received, and the railroad people don't care a rap how many women and children are crushed and how much clothing dystroyed in their closely-packed, badly-ventilated cars. It is simply heartless on their part to compel visitors returning from the Park, fatigued by their afternoon's exercise, to stand upon the platforms of the vehicles and cling precariously to the abominable straps which dangle inside, all through the tiresome down-town journey. Will these rich monopolies ever show a disposition to do the fair thing?

abstract: -- The pretended report of an interview between Senator SUMNER and President JOHNSON, first put in circulation by the Cincinnati Enquirer, and afterward copied by the New-York Herald, the Springfield Republican and other papers, is obviously on its face an invention; whether to make mischief, or for the sake of amusement, it is difficult to say. The interview is reported to have taken place at the White House, and with reference to the proclamation for the reorganization of North Carolina. Now it is well known in Boston that Senator SUMNER has not been in Washington since President JOHNSON has been in the White House, or since the promulgation of the North Carolina proclamation. The whole story is, therefore, an impossibility. On inquiry, we learn that nothing has ever occurred at any previous time to furnish the least pretext for this story. Down to his leaving Washington in the month of May, Senator SUMNER had occasion to see the President frequently, and spoke with him on public questions, including, of course, the great question of reorganization, and of the colored suffrage. The conversation on both sides was always of the most friendly character. -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: Bequests of; Incomes in
lead_paragraph: -- SYLVIA ANN HOWLAND who died a short time since in New-Bedford, Mass., left an estate valued at two and a half millions. One million is bequeathed to public and private charities. The Mercury says: "The sum of $20,0000 is given to the Orphan's Home, and the further sum of $15,000, on the decease of three persons who are to receive the income during their lives. To the City of New-Bedford is given the sum of $100,000, to be expended under the direction of the City Government towards the introduction of pure water into the city and the encouragement of manufactures requiring steam power. To the City of New-Bedford is given a further sum of $100,000, to be invested by the City Government, and the income appropriated to the encouragement of liberal education here, and the enlargement of the free public library. To the trustees is given $50,000, to be invested by them, the income to be carefully divided among such aged and infirm females of this city as may need relief. The trustees under the will are GEO. HOWLAND, Jr., Dr. WM. A. GORDON and EDWARD D. MANDELL, to each of which is given the sum of $50,000, and to Dr. GORDON, as a mark of the testatrix's personal esteem for his worth, a further sum of $50,000, THOS. MANDELL is the sole executor of the will."

abstract: -- Not long since Gen. CANBY assumed to interfere with the civil action of the President and Secretary of the Treasury in their efforts to get cotton out from the then rebellious States. As soon as this was known, Gen. GRANT ordered CANBY not to interfere in a military point of view with the operation and execution of the trade regulations; in other words, not to do anything to prevent the getting out of cotton by any person having authority to do so. Gen. CANBY, for reasons best known to himself, not only ceased his unnecessary and unauthorized interference, but withdrew all military protection over cotton known to have belonged to the Confederate Government, but which had become the rightful property of the United States, leaving it to be seized by rebels or any other persons who chose to appropriate it to their own use.

abstract: -- Many people are apt to pay the butcher what he asks, from a kind of mistaken sympathy for that person. That is to say, because the butcher bewails his fate in being forced to charge so much. But whether he be sincere is a question. At all events the public have him alone to deal with, and it is he only through whom they can act. While therefore the provision merchant may profitably undertake the importation of South American jerked beef, the public will properly do its part by staying away from the butcher altogether.
lead_paragraph: -- Many people are apt to pay the butcher what he asks, from a kind of mistaken sympathy for that person. That is to say, because the butcher bewails his fate in being forced to charge so much. But whether he be sincere is a question. At all events the public have him alone to deal with, and it is he only through whom they can act. While therefore the provision merchant may profitably undertake the importation of South American jerked beef, the public will properly do its part by staying away from the butcher altogether.

abstract: She was penurious in small things, but her generosity could rise to circumstances. Her dower was an annuity from the estate of Mortonhall. She had a contempt for securities, and would trust no bank with her money, but kept all her bills and bank notes in a green silk bag, that hung on her toilet glass. On each side of the table stood a large white bowl, one of which contained her silver, the other her copper money, the latter always full to the brim, accessible to Peggy, her handmaid, or any other servant in the house, for the idea of any one stealing money never entered her brain. Indeed, she once sent a present to her niece, Mrs. Cuninghame, of a Â£50 note, wrapped up in a cabbage-leaf, and intrusted it to the care of a woman who was going with a basket of butter to the Edinburgh market. My friend, Mrs. Cuninghame, related to me this, and the following histories of her aunt. One day, in the course of conversation, she said to her niece: "Do ye ken, Margaret, that Mrs. Thomas B_____ is dead? I was gaun by the door this morning, and thought I wad just look in and speer for her. She was very near her end, but quite sensible, and expressed her gratitude to God for what He had done for her and her fatherless bairns. She said 'she was leaving a large young family with very small means, but she had that trust in Him that they would not be forsaken, and that He would provide for them.' Now, Margaret, ye'll tell Peggy to bring down the green silk bag that hangs on the corner of my looking-glass, and ye'll tak' twa thousand pounds out o' it, and gi'e it to Walter Fearier for behoof of these orphan bairns; it will fit out the laddies, and be something to the lassies. I want to make good the words, 'that God wad provide for them,' for what else was I sent that way this morning, but as a humble instrument in His hands?" Miss Trotter had a friendship for a certain Mrs. B_____, who had an only son, and he was looked on as a simpleton, but his relatives had interest to get him a situation as clerk in a bank, where he contrived to steal money to the extent of five hundred pounds. His peculations were discovered, and in some days he would have been hanged, but Miss Trotter hearing the report started instantly for Edinburgh, went to the bank and ascertained the truth. She at once laid down five hundred pounds, telling them, "Ye maun not only stop proceedings, but ye maun keep him in the bank in some capacity, however mean, till I find some other employment for him." Then she fitted the lad out, and sent him to London, where she had a friend to whom she wrote, offering another five hundred pounds to anyone who would procure him a situation abroad, in which he might gain an honest living, and never be trusted with money. After all this was settled, she went herself and communicated the facts to his mother. -- Mystifications, edited by Dr. J. Brown.

abstract: -- The Queen has annually been in the habit of giving a ball at Balmoral to her tenants and dependents, which is conducted on nearly the same principle as that of the dance at Beausejour -- no respect of persons, no difference between a Lord and his retainers. And what the Queen, surrounded by her court, does, that also many of the great houses throughout the country will do. I could name a country seat in Yorkshire where a dance, exactly like that at Beausejeaur, is arranged every fortnight, one of the ladies of the family, whenever she is at home, makes a point of bespeaking for a partner the fat coachman, who has been for ages about the house. She takes care to give him a good spin down the room, and has the pleasure of hearing him at the end of the dance pant out, "Oh -- yah -- Miss, but ye do make un swet so." Now a London audience would survey such a scene upon a stage with shuddering incredulity. What a Duke may do among his retainers, Jones and Brown are quite unable to do in their households. In their little castles there is not such a distance between master and servant that Jones can feel at ease in dancing with his housemaid, or Mrs. Brown can permit her waist to be encircled by the single-handed butler -- The Shilling Magazine.

abstract: New-York
lead_paragraph: The grand German Singing Festival, of whose noteworthy preparations the TIMES has thoroughly informed the public, is under full headway, and if we may judge of the result from the beginning the "fest" will prove most enjoyable. Yesterday the several subcommittees continued their arduous labors of preparation for the reception and entertainment of their non-resident friends and associates. Lists of housekeepers, whose hospitable doors were opened for the board and lodging of the expected delegates, were arranged, programmes of public and private entertainment were prepared, things good to eat and things fit to drink in generous quantities were laid carefully by in the headquarters' cellars, and the decorations of the Germania Assembly Rooms were completed. An addition of a large room has been made to the former capacious accommodations of this place, so that now one of the most convenient and eligible halls and suites of rooms for public entertainment in the city is here provided.

abstract: Mr. JULIUS PERRIDEANS, of No. 258 Third-avenue, made oath that on the 5th inst., AMEAL SANTONI, a French coffee-merchant, stabbed him in the right side of the body, inflicting a dangerous wound, which laid him up in Bellevue Hospital until yesterday, and that he gave Mr. SANTONI no provocation whatever. The accused, who is of the French Legion of Honor, and evidently a gentleman of good standing, was apprehended by Patrolman JOHN LA RUE, of the Eighteenth Ward, and Justice DODGE required him to find $1,000 bail.

abstract: North-street "roughs," between 17 and 20 years of age, were arrested by Officers JELLISON, CURRIER and HAM, of the First Station, last evening, upon a charge of committing a felonious assault upon ALICE BURNS, about 14 years of age, in the town of Weston, yesterday. The Bay State Association, of Boston, with their friends, including a large number of disreputable characters, visited the grove in Weston for their annual pic-nic. Among the party were those named above.

abstract: Fire Companies, Rebellious and Incendiarism
lead_paragraph: -- We are sorry to observe that Steam Fire Engine Companies Nos. 1 and 33 are reported as failing to attend the incendiary fire in Fifty-third-street on Friday. None will, it is hoped, more regret this conduct than the companies themselves, when they think seriously over the matter. Whatever their opinion of the recent change in the department, they have a duty to the public to perform, the neglect of which is fraught with the gravest consequences. The fact that the fire is reported as incendiary involves the character of these companies in a manner which they cannot fail to perceive. In refusing to combat the wicked designs of incendiaries, they, in effect, give them the most efficient aid in their power. Of course, the new department will be at work in due course; and those members of the old one, who oppose it by endangering the lives and property of their fellow-citizens, will, if not wise in time, make a record which themselves will not care to remember or to see remembered.

abstract: Brown, Gov., of Georgia, Exit
lead_paragraph: Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, has been universally regarded as one of the most impracticable and obstinate of State Bights men, but the address which he has just issued to the people, who have so long recognized him as their Chief Magistrate, shows pretty conclusively that his recent compulsory trip to the North has made him somewhat more tractable. He very frankly tells those whom he addresses that the people of the North do not raise any question about the policy of abolishing slavery -- that they regard it already as a thing of the past. He advises the Georgians to acquiesce in this decision, and adds that, as he does not mean to give any counsel which he is not willing to follow himself, he shall hereafter treat his own slaves as free, and give them part of the crop, with such other wages as may be agreed upon. This is sensible in Gov. BROWN, and he should receive full credit for his candor. There is one inconsistency, however, which his address reveals. While he advises the citizens of the State to take the amnesty oath, he states that he has not yet subscribed to it himself. As the doughty Governor has set so good an example with regard to his slaves, he certainly cannot refuse to furnish the people with another excellent precedent by taking the oath.

abstract: -- A young man has just been sentenced to imprisonment for six months by the police court of Lille for vagrancy, whose career of crime is one of the most extraordinary ever developed before a court of justice. PERNET was born in Paris twenty-four years since, and at the age of fourteen he committed a homicide. At eighteen he was sentenced to imprisonment for five years for robbery at Bar-le-Duc. He was only eight days in the House of Correction in that town when he escaped. He was captured and again committed, but he shortly escaped a second time. After his fifth escape from prison in France he was sentenced to twenty years' hard labor, and embarked for Cayenne at the beginning of the year 1864. Five convicts escaped from Cayenne last year, and PERNET was their leader. He assumed the command of the frail boat in which they risked their lives. They had just quitted the land when they were perceived and fired on by the guard on shore, but escaped without injury. After tossing about for fourteen days and nights, nearly starved to death, they reached a British settlement. The inhabitants, mistaking them for shipwrecked seaman, treated them with the greatest kindness. They remained some months in the settlement, when PERNET and one of his comrades, tired of the monotonous life, embarked for Spain, where they committed a robbery, and supplied themselves with a considerable sum of money and a quantity of good wearing-apparel. Pursued by the police, they took refuge in Corsica, where they passed themselves for merchants, having large establishments in Spain. Having money in their pockets and being respectably clad, they acquired some friends, and led for a time a jovial life. Their cash was soon expended, but PERNET, nothing abashed, announced that he had lost a pocket-book containing 100,000 francs in bank-notes and valuable securities, and had it proclaimed by the public crier through the streets of Ajaccio, offering a reward of 10,000 francs for its recovery. The stratagem succeeded; for their acquaintances, taking compassion on the pretended Spaniards, placed their purses at their disposal, of which they availed themselves sparingly. They were shortly afterward accused of a robbery of plate at the hotel where they lodged, and fled. They next appeared in Italy, where PERNET passed for a government engineer, and his companion acted the part of secretary. They were detected, but again contrived to escape. The month of March last found PERNET in London, but British air did not agree with him, and he embarked for France, and arrived at Boulogne on the 15th of that month. He was then completely destitute, but he made the acquaintance of a charitable person in the coach between Boulogne ane Lille, who afforded him some assistance, and would have procured him employment, but he declined the offer. He was arrested at Lille as a vagrant, and sentenced to six months' imprisonment, after which he is to be sent back to Cayenne.
