abstract: -- Judge RUSSEL, yesterday, sentenced two young scoundrels who had been convicted in the Court of Sessions of robbery in the first degree, under very aggravated circumstances, each to twenty years' incarceration at Sing Sing Prison. For this action His Honor deserves the thanks of the community. The offence of highway robbery has been remarkably prevalent of late -- almost as frequent as it was about ten years since. At that time Judge RUSSEL was on the bench, and in spite of the clamor in certain influential political quarters, ostensibly on humane grounds, against the severity of his dealings with "garrotters," he persisted in imposing long sentences upon them -- in one case sending a convict to the State Prison for forty years. The wisdom of this course was soon apparent. The crime of highway robbery suddenly ceased, and the salutary lesson then enforced required the lapse of a decade to efface it from the remembrance of rogues of the foot-pad class. Now, therefore, that the offence has been revived, it seems eminently proper to try the same measures in checking it which formerly were so effective.

abstract: ONE OF THE HAPPY FAMILY. -- The large white cat which everybody remembers as a picture of perfect content, somehow escaped from the happy family's cage, during the great fire, and was captured unhurt and not even singed. Grimalkin may be seen at Mr. STORM's hat store, No. 136 Fulton-street, and Mr. BARNUM can secure the animal by proving property and paying charges of keeping. The latter are not heavy, as the cat would not eat until her food had been saturated with morphine; and in this discovery Mr. STORM thinks that he has obtained the secret of the management of the happy family.
lead_paragraph: ONE OF THE HAPPY FAMILY. -- The large white cat which everybody remembers as a picture of perfect content, somehow escaped from the happy family's cage, during the great fire, and was captured unhurt and not even singed. Grimalkin may be seen at Mr. STORM's hat store, No. 136 Fulton-street, and Mr. BARNUM can secure the animal by proving property and paying charges of keeping. The latter are not heavy, as the cat would not eat until her food had been saturated with morphine; and in this discovery Mr. STORM thinks that he has obtained the secret of the management of the happy family.

abstract: -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Magnetic Telegraph Company, held in this city yesterday, Hon. AMOS KENDALL was elected President in place of ZENUS BARNUM, Esq., deceased, to whose memory and worth as a man, and an officer, appropriate resolutions were offered by WM.M. SWAIN, Esq., and unanimously adopted. JOSEPH SAILER was reelected Secretary, THOS. P. BLADEN Treasurer, and Prof. S.F.B. Morse, Wm.M. Swain, E.S. Sandford, Francis Morris, Wilson G. Hunt, John H. Purdy, C. Livingston, Marshall Lefferts, C.A. Burgees, J. McKesson, and H.O. Alden, directors. The stock of the company was largely represented. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 14.

abstract: A Monument at needed
lead_paragraph: -- It is announced that a large force has been sent from Washington to Andersonville, Ga., with instructions to properly inter the remains of our noble soldiers who died while confined in the prison-house at that place. The party takes with it 15,000 headboards to mark the resting-places of those brave men; and this fact will, doubtless, suggest the thought to every mind, that a movement should at once be inaugurated to erect a monument which shall hand down to future generations the memory of that noble army of martyrs which passed through such privations and suffering to seal with life itself their devotion to the sacred cause of liberty. Bull Run, Antietam and Gettysburgh are to be thus marked. Why should Andersonville be forgotten?
headline: {'main': 'THE RIGHT PLACE FOR A MONUMENT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE RIGHT PLACE FOR A MONUMENT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At Galveston, on the 27th of June, a meeting of the Common Council was held, at which the Mayor stated that the board had been assembled by his order, to take into consideration several matters of interest to the city. One of them was the altered condition of the colored population, which required new regulations for the protection of the citizens. He regretted to see that some citizens were renting houses to those negroes who had left their employers, thus giving facilities for establishing various nuisances and committing depredations upon citizens. He had received many representations of negroes congregating for improper purposes in the houses they occupied, and of many disorders. He had no power to remedy these evils, unless a sufficient police force be furnished. The ordinances against the meeting of slaves, and their renting houses apart from their owners, are now inapplicable. The ordinance against vagrancy could be made available, but requires amendment.

abstract: New-York; Nolen >amp; Steers' Saw Mill; one killed, >amp;c.
snippet: New-York; Nolen >amp; Steers' Saw Mill; one killed, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Between 11 and 12 o'clock yerterday forenoon a steam-boiler exploded in Messrs. NOLEN & STEERS' steam saw-mill, on the northwest corner of Fifty-fourth-street and Second-avenue, and PATRICK COLLINS, the fireman, who was in the engine-room, was buried in the ruins of the shed wherein the boiler stood. It is Supposed that he was instantly killed. OWEN KELTY, of Greene-street, near Broome, and JACOB B. LAKE, of No. 49 North Third-street, Williamsburgh, engineers, were very seriously scalded, cut, and bruised, and Policeman WEITCH, of the Nineteenth Precinct, took them to Bellevue Hospital. JOSEPH PARKER, EDWIN FAY, and PATRICK BARRY, workmen in the mill, were also severely bruised, cut, and scalded, but they required no assistance in getting to their respective homes. Immediately after the explosion a section of the Nineteenth Precinct Police, under command of Sergeant FITZGERALD, hastened to the spot and commenced the work of removing the ruins, and in this they were aided by members of Fire Engine Company No. 37, and a number of civilians who dwell near the scene of disaster; but it was quite 3 o'clock before they reached the body of COLLINS. The corpse was taken to the Nineteenth Ward Police Station, and a Coroner was notified. The police think the explosion resulted from the heedlessness of the engineer in leaving the boiler with an insufficient supply of water. Tho building wherein the boiler stood was completely demolished, and much of Messrs. NOLEN & STEERS' machinery was shattered. It has been ascertained that only one life was lost.

abstract: British Sympathy with his Fall
lead_paragraph: Circumstantial details of the comical scene at Irwinsville, Georgia, on the capture of his late Excellency, J. DAVIS, have been reported in England, and John Bull's comment thereon is that he does not see where the laugh comes in. America, at the North, is flooded with caricatures of the unhappy fugitive. Cork minstrels have vied with the more legitimate branch of the histrionic profession in reproducing the force enacted at Irwinsville before the foot-lights, with such interpolations us a playful fancy suggests. Newsboys have hawked metrical versions of the same ludicrous event about the streets, in their penny-apiece ballads, Press and platform have found matter for many a jest therein; and private wit, satire or hearty good-humor, all over the country, are still busy with the fruitful story. This lighter commentary, however, has not prevented grave accounts, elaborate descriptions, hot discussions, and many official reports and documents from giving importance to the capture. America, at the South, meantime, has been hanging her head over the chief of the chivalry, and feeling very much vexed, if not at the conduct, at least at the unhappy plight into which JEFF's sardonic demon of misfortune has got him. The dignified Ex-President has had all the starch of possible heroism and martyrdom cruelly washed out of him. Instead of his career going out with a glorious closing brilliancy, as when a celestial body disappears, it promises very positively to smoulder away with an unpleasant odor, like a smoking candlewick, when the flame is quenched.

abstract: New-York Fifth Collection District; Names, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The fiscal year ended on the 30th of June in every department of the governmental revenue. It is now near the middle of July, and in a great majority of the collection districts the lists are so far advanced as to render it possible for us to determine the exact result of the year's labor, while in all of them approximate results can be obtained. One would imagine that the rural districts, whose, boundaries are limited, and whose returns are comparatively slim, would be far in advance of the metropolitan districts, where the number of tax-payers is legion, and the variety of interests bewildering; the contrary is the fact Partially this is attributable to the energy and perseverance of the assessors and collectors, but mainly it is due to the mercantile habits of promptness and quickness which characterize our people. In districts where incomes are the main sources of revenue we do not find punctuality so general, but in the sections where licenses and taxes on sales form the principal reservoirs of return, the prompt payment of taxes is notable and satisfactory.

abstract: Securities Abroad
lead_paragraph: A story comes to us from Frankfort, to the purport that the King of Hanover, some time since, ventured no less a sum than half a million dollars of his private wealth in United States 5-20s, by order to his Frankfort bankers, the Messrs. ROTHSCHILDS, to buy $500,000 of these bonds at the going rates. They were surprised by such an order, and, it is said, advised His Hanoverian Majesty, by letter, to review his order, which he promptly did by directing its immediate execution, and informing them that he would hold his bankers responsible for any advance of price that might have occurred in the meanwhile.

abstract: Mrs. CHARLOTTE THOMPSON, of No. 220 Grand-street, made affidavit that on the evening of the 2d of May last, while she was at a theatre, her domestic, JANE DIXON, who is otherwise known as ANTOINETTE VIRGINIA GOLDEN, left her dwelling with three silk dresses, four calico dresses, a white dress, a bonnet, a sun-shade, six pillow-cases and other articles, and that, subsequently, several of these articles were recovered at a pawn-shop. Mrs. THOMSON's search for the girl was fruitless until Friday afternoon, and then, finding her in Grand-street, the complainant turned her over to Officer DEVOY, of the Seventh Ward. The prisoner was committed for examination. She appeared at Mrs. THOMSON's dwelling as a homeless orphan, and Mrs. THOMPSON gave her shelter as a domestic as matter of charity.

abstract: Toads found in Rocks
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting of the Manchester Geological Society, Mr. JOSEPH DICKINSON, one of the inspectors on mines, called attention to a paragraph copied from a Newcastle paper, respecting a living toad which was alleged to have been found embedded in a block of magnesium limestone stratum near Hartlepool. It was said that Mr. TAYLOR, the incumbent of Hartlepool, an eminent local geologist, had pronounced this wonderful toad to be 6,000 years old. This was the second paragraph of the kind that had gone the round of the Manchester papers. The first paragraph was relative to a live toad said to have been found at St. Helena embedded in the coal. Knowing the owners of the colliery where the discovery was said to have been made, he wrote to them for particulars, and they sent over the collier who had discovered the wonderful reptile, which the man brought with him all alive in a piece of cannel coal. He took the man to Mr. PLANT, at the Peel Park Museum, and full particulars were given as to how, when, and where the toad was found. Mr. PLANT examined the specimen, and said there could be no doubt the man had made the hole himself and put the toad into it. The men said such a hole could not be made, but Mr. PLANT said he knew an ivory carver who could make a much better one. Mr. PLANT wanted to break the coal asunder, having, by inserting his finger, distinctly felt the chisel marks, but the collier hastily objected, and also refused to go with his discovery to Dr. ALCOCK, of the Natural History Museum. He (Mr. DICKINSON) quite agreed with Mr. PLANT that the specimen was manufactured. He had never met with a toad underground himself, nor had any of his many friends connected with the mines. Mr. AITKEN produced some photographs of the Hartlepool toad. Mr. PLANT corroborated Mr. DICKINSON's account as to the St. Helens toad, and added that the collier tried every way to prevent him putting his finger into the hole, saying that the toad's bite was poisonous. [Laughter.] He (Mr. PLANT) however had no difficulty whatever in recognizing, both in the St. Helens specimen and in the Hartlepool photograph, our old friend, the British toad, which was to be found under our hedges at any time. It had been stated that the recently-found Hartlepool specimen had no mouth, but that was a remark resulting from ignorance. Toads often breathed with their mouths closed, the air escaping through the pores of the skin. Since the appearance of the paragraph to which Mr. DICKINSON called attention, Rev. Mr. TAYLOR had denied uttering any such nonsense as that the toad was 6,000 years old. Mr. GREENWELL said it was remarkable that no living things but toads were found imbedded in rocks. [Laughter.] The President (Mr. A. KNOWLES) said a learned society in Paris experimented by inclosing toads in a preparation to see how long they could live without air; some of them lived twelve years, but the covering was broken open every six months. The meeting generally received the tale of the toads with amused credulity.

abstract: -- A startling tragedy was enacted at Nashville, Ill., on the Fourth. A German farmer named JACOB MEIER had employed two men named WHITE and MCGREADY to assist him during harvest. The two laborers declined to work on the Fourth and asked for the money due them, which MEIER refused to pay, as he was disappointed by their determination not to work. After this, which occurred in the field, the two men repaired to MEIER's house and ordered his wife to tell them where his money was concealed. Upon her refusing they began torturing her with boiling water from the stove. Upon her persistently refusing to produce the money, one of the men brought in an iron wedge from the yard and beat her on the head until he had killed her. To prevent the murder from becoming known the men then set fire to the house, and securely locking the doors and fastening the windows, went directly into the woods a short distance off. The smoke was soon seen issuing from the house, and one of the neighbors saw the dead body of MEIER's wife on the floor. The atrocious murder caused great excitement, and the people turned out in every direction to seek for the perpetrators. The next day WHITE was caught on his way to St. Louis. He had traveled about twenty-five miles on foot, and had fallen asleep on the side of the road. He was taken back to the village, where he made a confession of all that had occurred. About 6 o'clock the same evening it was determined to lynch him. He was given a few moments to prepare himself for death, when a rope was placed about his neck and he was hung to a tree in view of the ruins of the house where the cruel and brutal murder was committed. At last accounts MCGREADY had not been arrested.
lead_paragraph: -- A startling tragedy was enacted at Nashville, Ill., on the Fourth. A German farmer named JACOB MEIER had employed two men named WHITE and MCGREADY to assist him during harvest. The two laborers declined to work on the Fourth and asked for the money due them, which MEIER refused to pay, as he was disappointed by their determination not to work. After this, which occurred in the field, the two men repaired to MEIER's house and ordered his wife to tell them where his money was concealed. Upon her refusing they began torturing her with boiling water from the stove. Upon her persistently refusing to produce the money, one of the men brought in an iron wedge from the yard and beat her on the head until he had killed her. To prevent the murder from becoming known the men then set fire to the house, and securely locking the doors and fastening the windows, went directly into the woods a short distance off. The smoke was soon seen issuing from the house, and one of the neighbors saw the dead body of MEIER's wife on the floor. The atrocious murder caused great excitement, and the people turned out in every direction to seek for the perpetrators. The next day WHITE was caught on his way to St. Louis. He had traveled about twenty-five miles on foot, and had fallen asleep on the side of the road. He was taken back to the village, where he made a confession of all that had occurred. About 6 o'clock the same evening it was determined to lynch him. He was given a few moments to prepare himself for death, when a rope was placed about his neck and he was hung to a tree in view of the ruins of the house where the cruel and brutal murder was committed. At last accounts MCGREADY had not been arrested.

abstract: -- Yesterday morning, in the United States District Court, the case of ROBERT M. LEE was called up on the writ of habeas corpus, sued out to procure the defendant's release on bail. The case is a peculiar one. While LEE was on trial for defrauding the government, and before the jury rendered a verdict, he fled. The bail was forfeited. Subsequently he was arrested, brought into court and sentenc imposed. President JOHNSON pardoned the defendant. As soon as the pardon was registered, LEE was rearrested and committed to prison for contempt in running away. On an application to have him admitted to bail, Judge CADWALADER suggested a habeas corpus as the proper form, and it was upon this that the case was heard yesterday. Before the argument, Judge CADWALADER suggested that the only question in the case was whether the defendant, having been bailed once and abused the privilege was entitled to enter bail a second time. Mr. HIRST urged at some length that the defendant was before the court as though for the first time and was therefore entitled to bail. He referred to the fact that close confinement affected seriously the health of Mr. LEE, owing to the wound in his leg. Judge CADWALADER said he would hold the case under consideration, and, in the meantime, would appoint a physician to make an examination of the condition of the defendant. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 15.

abstract: Bernard McElhone, a bar-tender, was charged with assaulting Jane McLachlin. Complainant's face was very much bruised and her eyes were still black, although the affray took place on the 3d of July. Witness said: I went into the store to ask what he had to say about my brother; I believe I never spoke to him before I went in there; when I went in I did not see him and I told the man in the store he was a dirty loafer; when he came out I asked him what he had to say about my brother and me, and he said my brother was a thief and he called me out of my name, and he took hold of me put me out of the store, and I shoved him back when he struck me and tore my hat and threw it on the floor, and he beat my head against the floor, and he pulled me by the hair across the store; it wasn't his store; he is bar-tender there; he also kicked me on the breast; he did not order me out until he took a-hold of me and pushed me out.

abstract: -- Some of our cotemporaries, mindful of the fact that in syntax two negatives produce an affirmative, think that by analogy two wrongs ought to make a right in morals. Because such men as FORREST, KIRBY SMITH, &c., broke their oaths as Confederate soldiers, the latter crime is supposed to condone their previous treason to the United States as citizens. According to this, we suppose that proving -- than which nothing is easier -- that these worthies have also been guilty of the most atrocious outrages upon the laws of civilized warfare, by starving or hanging surrendered prisoners, will elevate them to the rank of martyrs. Another set of offences will get them as far as the grade of patriots and so on, to the end of their apotheosis.

abstract: Smith, Gen. G. W. History of
snippet: Smith, Gen. G. W. History of
lead_paragraph: -- In referring to the fact that Gen. G.W. SMITH has applied for pardon, the Boston Traveller gives the following sketch of his life: "He is a graduate of West Point, a citizen of Kentucky, and in the Mexican war was Captain of the company of Sappers and Miners of which Gen. MCCLELLAN was Lieutenant. After that war he recruited a company of Sappers and Miners in Boston, but the command having been given to MCCLELLAN, he left the army in disgust. When the rebellion broke out, he was a prominent New-York politician, and it was expected that he would take command of the Tammany Regiment, but he went to Kentucky, under the pretence of having business there, and was next heard from at the South. He was warmly received at Richmond, and was assigned to an important command in the rebel army, but he proved a failure as a General, and soon left the service. Subsequently he had charge of the extensive iron works at Rome, Ga., where his practical knowledge was of great value to the rebel government."

abstract: -- Judge CATON has shown us a handful of ears taken from a seven-acre field of white Winter wheat near his residence. The ears are seven inches in length, and filled with plump, healthy corns. He is confident of reaping 40 bushels to the acre from the field. The same field had white Winter wheat in it last year, yielding a handsome crop, and although it was plowed and well sown again last September, Judge CATON is satisfied that the wheat now on the ground is not from that he sowed, but from what was left of the old crop and had been plowed in. He gives it as an argument in favor of the plowing in wheat instead of covering with a drag or drill. Mr. WM. POOL, of Serena, has also shown us some rye, seven feet high, taken from a field which he is confident will yield 50 bushels to the acre. Winter wheat around here, of which very little was sown, was generally winter-killed, but Spring wheat looks well, and has no danger to encounter except rot and rust. -- Ottawa (Ill.) Trader.

lead_paragraph: Mr. PITMAN, one of the official reporters, furnishes the Cincinnati Commercial the following statistics of the recent assassination trial at Washington: Number of witnesses subpoenaed for the prosecution, 251; number of witnesses actually examined, 201; number of witnesses subpoenaed for the defence, 236; number of witnesses actually examined, 163; total number of witnesses examined, 371; total number examined, including recalls, 423; total number of witnesses subpoenaed, 491; number of pages of testimony, (legal cap,) 4,300; total number of pages, including arguments of counsel and reply of Judge-Advocate, 5,010, making a pile of manuscript twenty-eight inches high. The vast amount of depositions, &c., taken by three Judge-Advocates, Col. BURNETT, Col. FOSTER and Col. ALCOTT, and reports presented at the War Department prior to the opening of the case, employed five short-hand writers a fortnight, and took two experienced clerks six weeks merely to brief and file away.

abstract: The First New-Hampshire Cavalry arrived yesterday afternoon by the New-Jersey Railroad, landing at foot of Cortlandt-street at about 2 o'clock. Marching quietly down to the Battery Barracks, the men took dinner, and at 4 o'clock the command took special steamer for New-London, as they could not be carried by the boats of the regular route. The First expect to reach Concord, N.H., this evening or tomorrow morning.
lead_paragraph: The First New-Hampshire Cavalry arrived yesterday afternoon by the New-Jersey Railroad, landing at foot of Cortlandt-street at about 2 o'clock. Marching quietly down to the Battery Barracks, the men took dinner, and at 4 o'clock the command took special steamer for New-London, as they could not be carried by the boats of the regular route. The First expect to reach Concord, N.H., this evening or tomorrow morning. While in Baltimore, a private named JAMES RAMSEY, Company I, Fifty-sixth Massachusetts, (which regiment passed through this city on Friday,) attempted to get upon the train, failing in which he was run over and horribly crushed. RAMSEY lived in Thirteenth-street, near Avenue B, in this city. He was thought to be mortally wounded by the officers of the First Cavalry.

abstract: -- We cannot afford to be generous in racing business, but we will endeavor to be just. A great anxiety and considerable doubt appear to hover in the minds of the mass of our countrymen respecting the forward appearance of the French horses, and especially of Gladiateur, as he showed among the three-year-olds at the post. There is so forward a look about the horse that, with no authentic data, men may be excused for having breathed a suspicion that Gladiateur was older than he ought to be. Unhappily, the means of acquiring correct information on these subjects are few and uncertain. We have every reason to believe, from information we have received, that in the present case there is no ground for suspicion at all. But we urge the Jockey Club, and all those connected with the turf, to take every precaution for the proper registration of thoroughbred stock in France. We have already opened the door to a most powerful and successful rival; there is no necessity for taking it off the hinges. The natural advantages which the French enjoy more than compensate for their want of experience, which is rather apparent than real. Their trainers are English, their jockeys are English, and they are no whit behind us in the mechanism and machinery of the turf system. Why, then, should we throw a chance away? We are gravely told that the registration of horses in France is made to the Maire of the commune. "The Maire ought to know when the foal is thrown, if any one does," may be an excellent joke, but it will not satisfy the exigencies of our curiosity. We should like to see a system of registration as severe as our own. We know that even in this country four-year-olds have won the Derby, and honest men -- French-men as well as Englishmen -- would prefer to be above suspicion. -- Fortnightly Review.

abstract: -- The Berlin correspondent of the London Times says in a recent letter: "In many parts of Western and Northern Germany the value of land is from three to five times what it was thirty years ago. House property, too, has risen immensely in towns of any importance and size. A Berlin house which in 1847 would have fetched 20,000 thalers, to-day could not be bought for less than 40,000 to 60,000 thalers. Other prices have gone up in proportion. In 1847, a Berlin family was certainly better off with £250 than to-day with £500 a year. Meat was about half as dear; rent but a third or a fourth of the exorbitant rates exacted now-a-days. Ladies and gentlemen, both from the heightened standard of respectability and the increase in the price of apparel, before the change came on, could cover their outer selves very decently at a third part of the expenditure now incurred as a matter of course. Labor commands double the sum in the market, being at the same time as much in demand as to have created a social revolution in the relations between employer and employe. Domestic servants especially have been pleased to assume the independent manners of 'helps.' Agricultural laborers -- the bite noire of the country -- gradually emerge from their old humility, going off to America by thousands, or casting wistful glances on 'the land of the free,' 'the republic of the plowman.' As regards the peasantry, being all independent, and many of them proprietors to a large extent, they have been diretly and materially benefited by the new state of things. Upon the whole, and in comparison with the straightened circumstances of what now appears the olden time, prosperity is more general, even in the smaller towns and villages, than the homely habits and garb surviving in those places would seem to indicate."

abstract: Party Ruin Wrought by
lead_paragraph: There has seldom, if ever, been so ruinous a defeat of any political organization, in the history of constitutional government, as the rout of the Unconditional Peace Party in 1864. The whole concern was overthrown -- horse, foot and artillery. The Chicago cabal was utterly demolished; and the disjecta membra of their retinue are to-day "lying round loose," no one having the courage or the inclination to gather them together.

abstract: Electric Telegraph in 1787
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent of the Morning Post gives the following remarkable extract from Arthur Young's Travels in France, published in Dublin in 1793: " Paris, Oct 16, 1787. -- In the evening to Monsieur LOMOND, a very ingenious and inventive mechanic, who as made an improvement in the jenny for spinning cotton. * * * In electricity he has made a remarkable discovery. You write two or three words on paper; he takes it with him into a room, and turns a machine inclosed in a cylindrical case, at the top of which is an electrometer, a small, fine pith ball, a wire connects with a cylinder and electrometer in a distant apartment, and his wife by remarking the corresponding motions of the ball, writes down the words they indicate, from which it appears that he has formed an alphabet of motions. As the length of the wire makes no difference in the effect, the correspondence may be carried on to any distance within or without a fortified town, for instance, or for purposes much more worthy. Whatever the use may be, the invention is beautiful."
headline: {'main': 'THE ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH IN 1787.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH IN 1787.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: at Old Point, a correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer says: "An inadvertent joke was perpetrated yesterday at Richmond by the humane and gallant Miss Surgeon WALKER. Among the visitors at the late rebel capital were the officers of the British gunboat Styx. Miss WALKER, M.D., mistaking them for officers of our own navy, invited them to a seat on the platform. The English officers accepted, and when they were comfortably seated. Miss Surgeon WALKER arose, and read, with good emphasis and discretion, 'The Declaration of Independence.' The officers of the Styx acknowledged the corn. They patiently listened to the charges against GEORGE III. They never heard them before in so conspicuous a position enunciated by a fair lady."

abstract: Mrs. CHARLOTTE THOMPSON, of No. 220 Grand-street, made affidavit that on the evening of the 2d of May last, while she was at a theatre, her domestic, JANE DIXON, who is otherwise known as ANTOINETTE VIRGINIA GOLDEN, left her dwelling with three silk dresses, four calico dresses, a white dress, a bonnet, a sun-shade, six pillow-cases and other articles, and that, subsequently, several of these articles were recovered at a pawn-shop. Mrs. THOMSON's search for the girl was fruitless until Friday afternoon, and then, finding her in Grand-street, the complainant turned her over to Officer DEVOY, of the Seventh Ward. The prisoner was committed for examination. She appeared at Mrs. THOMSON's dwelling as a homeless orphan, and Mrs. THOMPSON gave her shelter as a domestic as matter of charity.

abstract: German Singing Festival
lead_paragraph: The great Sangerfest now in progress in this city is altogether beautiful in all its characteristics. It is a beautiful idea that of such a large body of citizens, and such a large number of delegations gathering from the chief cities of the land, not for the purposes of gain or selfishness, not to frame a political platform or secure a party's success, but to celebrate a high festival of music and song, to engage in harmonious contests and strive to excel in the creation and expression of heavenly melody. The concomitants of the festival, such as the hearty fraternization of all concerned in it and the generous hospitality extended by the Singers of this city to their vistors from all the other cities, are also admirable. Then the actual doings, lesser and larger, thus far, such as the great torchlight procession of the societies on Saturday night -- the joyous reception of the delegations from abroad and the magnificent song of welcome with which they were saluted in the City Hall Park at midnight -- the floral decorations at their headquarters and at the chief places of German resort -- these, with the grand sacred concert last night at the Academy of Music, in which over two thousand well-trained singers took part, have been the prominent incidents of the festival up to this time, and all of them have had the profound feeling as well as the superficial impress of the beautiful.
headline: {'main': 'The German Singing Festival.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The German Singing Festival.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Trade Convention
lead_paragraph: -- RECIPROCITY AND ANNEXATION. -- The Detroit Convention came to a unanimous conclusion in favor of the renewal of the Reciprocity Treaty. As the whole question of definitely terminating or reviving the Commercial Convention of 1854 turned upon details, the affirmation of the Detroit Conference, perhaps, amounts to less than the supporters of reciprocity may imagine. But the apparent unanimity at Detroit at least shows that there is a disposition among our commercial men to continue trading with the provincials on something like fair terms. Whether our neighbors will relish these terms, as we interpret them, is a matter not at all apparent just yet. The most elaborate speech delivered at the convention appears to have been that of Hon. JOSEPH HOWE, of Nova Scotia, which we reproduce this morning in other columns. That gentleman's statements and arguments on a variety of incidental questions, such as the fisheries, the frontier smuggling trade, the neutrality of the colonists, and their thorough devotion to the British Crown, will be found entertaining enough, if not instructive.

abstract: THE STEAMER DEAN RICHMOND. -- The new floating palace Dean Richmond, of the People's Line, and sister boat to the St. John, the largest steamboat in the world, was on Saturday taken around to Pier No. 41, North River. She left the yard of JOHN ENGLIS & SON at a few minutes past 1 o'clock and steamed a few miles, just to test her machinery. Her short trip gave general satisfaction to all concerned. She will probably be ready to make her first regular trip on the 20th inst., and from that date she will take her place in the regular line and run regular during the season.

abstract: Textile Fabrics
lead_paragraph: During the opening period of the war, while the prices of all kinds of merchandise and an abundant supply of raw material was on hand, the manufacture of cotton was one of the most prosperous in this country. Until this stock was used up, the mill-owners found an ample demand for every pound of yarn or cloth they could produce, at war prices. At a later period, in consequence of the rise in wages, the scarcity of raw cotton and the excise duties imposed, the business ceased to be prosperous; and at one time a majority of the spindles in the North were standing idle, though coarse cotton yarns sold at from $2 to $2 50 per pound. The scale has once more turned in favor of the cotton interest. With a plentiful supply of the "floculent fibre" coming forward, and a market almost completely bared of certain fabrics, there is now understood to be quite a brisk demand for yarns at from 75 cents per pound upward, according to quality. In the mills of New-England and New-Jersey, we believe no decline in wages has yet taken place, or if any, the reduction is inconsiderable and local. Cotton goods of all kinds have stiffened in price, since the late upward turn in the gold market.

abstract: Merchant; Significant Facts
lead_paragraph: On Saturday there were in this port forty-nine ocean steamers. Of this number thirteen were flying the flag of foreign nations. There were one hundred and eight ships, nineteen were foreigners. Of barks there were one hundred and twenty-nine; seventy-six of them represented seven foreign nationalities. One hundred and twenty brigs lay along our docks; ninety of them were foreigners; and out of the number of seventy schooners we found twenty-eight of them to be of foreign register.

abstract: Public Buildings; Deficiency of
lead_paragraph: It is natural and right that New-Yorkers should be proud of their city; that they should boast of its wealth, of its size and its rapid increase, of its commercial enterprise and importance. These are legitimate objects of pride. There is nothing in the history of new countries more remarkable than the growth of the little dull Dutch settlement of half a dozen houses into the metropolis of the present day -- the largest, wealthiest, most populous and most influential city in the New World. And it possesses features of which any city in the world might be proud. Our Central Park bids fair to equal, if not surpass the most celebrated parks of London and Paris. No European city can boast of finer charitable institutions. What else have we?

abstract: -- The day announced for the sailing of the Great Eastern with her valuable freight was Monday, the 10th inst. She was expected, while paying out the cable at a safe rate, to make an average speed of six miles an hour. The distance from Valentia Harbor in [???]land to Heart's Content Bay in Newfoundland is, in round figures, about eighteen hundred miles. Making one hundred and forty miles every twenty-four hours, the voyage ought to be compassed in about thirteen days. This reckoning would give us the news of the Great Eastern's arrival on the Newfoundland coast on Sunday next. There are too many contingencies to be taken into account to make it safe to speculate on so early a solution of the great problem. But a couple of weeks more, in all probability, will determine the success or failure of the enterprize.
lead_paragraph: -- The day announced for the sailing of the Great Eastern with her valuable freight was Monday, the 10th inst. She was expected, while paying out the cable at a safe rate, to make an average speed of six miles an hour. The distance from Valentia Harbor in [???]land to Heart's Content Bay in Newfoundland is, in round figures, about eighteen hundred miles. Making one hundred and forty miles every twenty-four hours, the voyage ought to be compassed in about thirteen days. This reckoning would give us the news of the Great Eastern's arrival on the Newfoundland coast on Sunday next. There are too many contingencies to be taken into account to make it safe to speculate on so early a solution of the great problem. But a couple of weeks more, in all probability, will determine the success or failure of the enterprize.

abstract: Mr. JULIUS PERRIDEANS, of No. 258 Third-avenue, made oath that on the 5th inst., AMEAL SANTONI, a French coffee-merchant, stabbed him in the right side of the body, inflicting a dangerous wound, which laid him up in Bellevue Hospital until Saturday, and that he gave Mr. SANTONI no provocation whatever. The accused, who is of the French Legion of Honor, and evidently a gentleman of good standing, was apprehended by Patrolman JOHN LA RUE, of the Eighteenth Ward, and Justice DODGE required him to find $1,000 bail.

abstract: CHARLES TRUMPER, of No. 285 Seventh-avenue, made oath that he had been robbed while asleep in KATE SMITH's place in New Chambers-street. It appears that on Saturday evening he requested permission to sleep on hour in KATE SMITH's room, and that she locked him in and put the key in her pocket. Subsequently GEORGE SEITZ, of No. 94 Hester-street, begged to be admitted to change his attire, and the female gave him the key. TRUMPER awoke shortly after SEITZ had been in the room, and ascertained that somebody had stolen $150 from his pantaloons pocket. The Judge committed SEITZ for examination.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES TRUMPER, of No. 285 Seventh-avenue, made oath that he had been robbed while asleep in KATE SMITH's place in New Chambers-street. abstract: At a recent meeting of the Executive Committee of the Institute of Reward for Orphans of Patriots, held at the Free Academy, resolutions were offered appointing a Memorial Committee to cooperate with the officers of the Bureau of Military Records in the collection and preservation of military statistics; also ...
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting of the Executive Committee of the Institute of Reward for Orphans of Patriots, held at the Free Academy, resolutions were offered appointing a Memorial Committee to cooperate with the officers of the Bureau of Military Records in the collection and preservation of military statistics; also instructing said committee to cooperate with the committee already appointed having in charge the petition now before the Common Council, praying the bestowment of a tract of land bounded by Fourth and Fifth avenues and Eighty-first and Eighty-second streets; and also to aid the committee already appointed for petitioning the Common Council to grant said land to the National Academy named in the petition, and for the additional purpose of erecting a home and school for orphans of patriots, and a compensative school for soldiers and sailors maimed in the service of the Union.

abstract: Between 11 and 12 o'clock Saturday forenoon a steam-boiler exploded in Messrs. NOLEN  STEERS' steam saw-mill, on the northwest corner of Fiftyfourth-street and Second-avenue, and PATRICK COLLINS, the fireman, who was in the engine-room was buried in the ruins of the shed wherein the boiler stood. It is supposed that he was instantly killed.
lead_paragraph: Between 11 and 12 o'clock Saturday forenoon a steam-boiler exploded in Messrs. NOLEN & STEERS' steam saw-mill, on the northwest corner of Fiftyfourth-street and Second-avenue, and PATRICK COLLINS, the fireman, who was in the engine-room was buried in the ruins of the shed wherein the boiler stood. It is supposed that he was instantly killed. OWEN KELTY, of Greene-street, near Bro[???], and JACOB B. LAKE, of No. 49 North Third-street, Williamsburgh, engineers, were very seriously seal led, cut, and bruised, and Policeman WEITCH, of the Nineteenth Precinct, took them to Bellevue Hospital. JOSEPH PARKER, EDWIN FAY, and PATRICK BARRY, workmen in the mill, were also severely bruised, cut, and scalded, but they required no assistance in getting to their respective homes. Immediately after the explosion a section of the Nineteenth Precinct Police, under command of Sergeant FITZGERALD, hastened to the spot and commenced the work of removing the ruins, and in this they were aided by members of Fire Engine Company No. 37, and a number of civilians who dwell near the scene of disaster; but it was quite [???] o'clock before they reached the [???]o[???] of COLLINS. The corpse was taken to the Nineteenth Ward Police Station, and a Coroner was [???]. The police think the explosion resulted from the heedlessness of the engineer in [???]ving the boiler with an insufficient supply of water. [???]o building wherein the boiler stood was completely demolished, and much of Messrs. NOLEN & STEERS' machinery was shattered. It has been ascertained that only one life was lost.

abstract: We were very sorry to learn that the Federal soldiers had committed depredations on the plantations on Red River. Gentlemen have informed us that the soldiers left the steamers and entered the premises of Messrs. TEMPLEMAN, HUTCHINSON and  others, and robbed the smoke-house, and were rude to the ladies. These were no petty thefts, but wholesale robberies.

abstract: The Fourth Vermont Regiment left for Burlington Saturday morning. The First NewHampshire Cavalry and Seventh Rhode Island Regiment arrived Saturday afternoon, departing almost immediately for their several destinations. The One Hundred and Fifty-second New-York also arrived and left Saturday night. Yesterday afternoon the Seventeenth New-York, Second Rhode Island, Eleventh and Fifty-eighth Massachusetts and Seventeenth Vermont, arrived in this city from Washington. All of them, except the Seventeenth New-York, left for their respective States last night.

abstract: Hoboken, Bakers' Combination in
lead_paragraph: A perfectly reliable person tells us that when the New-York bakers began to return to making five cent loaves, the Hoboken bakers "came together" and agreed not to make any. It is added that the ten cent loaves in that suburb are a little larger than the old five cent loaves, but not much. We mention this as one of the combinations which ought to be broken up. Of course Hoboken does not possess a baker with smartness enough to return to old prices and handbill the town to announce it.

abstract: -- The large white cat which everybody remembers as a picture of perfect content, somehow escaped from the happy family; cage, during the great fire, and was captured unhurt and not even singed. Grimalkin may be seen at Mr. STORM's hat store, No. 136 Fulton-street, and Mr. BARNUM can secure the animal by proving property and paying charges of keeping. The latter are no heavy, as the cat would not eat until her food had been saturated with morphine; and in this discovery Mr. STORM thinks that he has obtained the secret of the management of the happy family.

abstract: Yesterday a large number of returning regiments arrived and departed, all being received with a degree of enthusiasm and hearty welcome pleasant to witness, and gratifying to record. Among the arrivals yesterday afternoon, were the Seventeenth New-York, Second Rhode Island, Eleventh and Fifty-eighth Massachusetts, and the Seventeenth Vermont, all of which, except the New-York regiment, departed for home. The Rhode Island and Massachusetts troops left in the steamer Continental for New-Haven.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 203, of which 58 were adults, and 145 under 21 years of age. The principal diseases were, cholera infantum 50, consumption 18, marasmus and convulsions 18 each, scarlet fever 1, cholera morbus 3, diarrhoea 8, smallpox 3, typhoid fever 3, whooping-cough 2, measles 1, &c. Under one year of age, 105; natives of United States, 165; Ireland 20; Germany, 10; England, 5; Scotland, British America and unknown, 1 each.

abstract: Excelsior, of Brookly, vs. Union, of Morrisania
snippet: Excelsior, of Brookly, vs. Union, of Morrisania
lead_paragraph: Those who visited Morrisania, on Saturday, to witness the first match this season between these clubs, and the first appearance of the Excelsior nine of 1865 in a match, were not only gratified spectators of a very interesting contest, but also of the most attractive attendance of the fair sex seen at a match this season. In fact, the Union Ground has become quite a noted resort for the fair patrons of the game in Morrisania, every attention being shown them by the gay gallants of the Union Club, and due accommodations are specially provided for their fair guests on these occasions. Their efforts to induce the attendance of ladies at their matches have been the means of enabling them to surpass every other club in the community in this respect. Once upon a time, the Brooklyn clubs took the lead in having the most numerous attendance of the fair sex at their matches, but of late years they have become the most ungallant set in the country, although they have the facilities for excelling every other locality.

abstract: At about 3 o'clock Saturday morning an incendiary fire was discovered in the hall-way under the stairs leading to the second story of No. 74 Bleecker-street, and before the firemen could gain mastery of the flames the upper floor and port of the second story were destroyed. Considerable damage was also done at No. 641 Broadway, adjoining. The losses and insurances are as follows: M.E.E. SHEPHARD, silver-plater, lost $800; insured for $500 by the Continental Company. Mr. CHRISTIAN FLOCKS, cigar-maker, $800, and insured in the Hanover office for $500. Messrs. J.M. GRENNELL & Co. lost $300, and are not insured. Mr. G.W. BURGHER lost $150, and has $200 insurance [???] the Kings County office. Mr. C.N. BROWN [???], and is not insured. Mr. A.E. DELOUEST, [???]er, lost $200, and is insured for $1,500 in the [???]n office of Philadelphia. lead_paragraph: At about 3 o'clock Saturday morning an incendiary fire was discovered in the hall-way under the stairs leading to the second story of No. 74 Bleecker-street, and before the firemen could gain mastery of the flames the upper floor and port of the second story were destroyed. Considerable damage was also done at No. 641 Broadway, adjoining. The losses and insurances are as follows: M.E.E. SHEPHARD, silver-plater, lost $800; insured for $500 by the Continental Company. abstract: Bernard McElhone, a bar-tender, was charged with assaulting Jane McLachlin. Complainant's face was very much bruised and her eyes were still black, although the affray took place on the 3d of July. Witness said: I went into the store to ask what he had to say about my brother; I believe I never spoke to him before I went in there; when I went in I did not see ...
lead_paragraph: Bernard McElhone, a bar-tender, was charged with assaulting Jane McLachlin. Complainant's face was very much bruised and her eyes were still black, although the affray took place on the 3d of July. Witness said: I went into the store to ask what he had to say about my brother; I believe I never spoke to him before I went in there; when I went in I did not see him and I told the man in the store he was a dirty loafer; when he came out I asked him what he had to say about my brother and me, and he said my brother was a thief and he called me out of my name, and ho took hold of me put me out of the store, and I shoved him back, when he struck me and tore my hat and threw it on the floor, and he boat my head against the floor, and he pulled me by the hair across the store; it wasn't his store; he is bar-tender there; he also kicked me on the breast; he did not order me out until he took a-hold of me and pushed me out.

abstract: The fiscal year ended on the 30th of June in every department of the governmental revenue. It is now near the middle of July, and in a great majority of the collection districts the lists are so far advanced as to render it possible for us to determine the exact result of the year's labor, while in all of them approximate results can be obtained. One would imagine
lead_paragraph: The fiscal year ended on the 30th of June in every department of the governmental revenue. It is now near the middle of July, and in a great majority of the collection districts the lists are so far advanced as to render it possible for us to determine the exact result of the year's labor, while in all of them approximate results can be obtained. One would imagine that the rural districts, whose boundaries are limited, and whose returns are comparatively slim, would be far in advance of the metropolitan districts, where the number of tax-payers is legion, and the variety of in terests bewildering; the contrary is the fact. Partially this is attributable to the energy and perseverance of the assessors and collectors, but mainly it is due to the mercantile habits of promptness and quickness which characterize our people. In districts where incomes are the main sources of revenue we do not find punctuality so general, but in the sections where licenses and taxes on sales form the principal reservoirs of return, the prompt payment of taxes is notable and satisfactory.

abstract: German Festival in New-York
lead_paragraph: Sunday, the second day of the grand German Singing Festival might well be termed the first, for as the readers of yesterday's TIMES will remember, the magnificent torchlight procession which initiated the Festival, did not make its first step until the smaller hours of the sacred day were chimed out by the City Hall clock. With a paragraphic resume of the causes of delay, which so nearly upset the plans and defeated the well-made plans of the committees, we will start with the procession at 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, and continue with it and its, until the closing chorus of last night's magnificent concert at the Academy of Music.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon Messrs. C. & R. POILLON launched from their yard, foot of Bridge-street, Brooklyn, the new and splendid screw steamer Leo, 800 tons burden, intended for the Atlantic coasting trade. This vessel is owned by MURRAY & NEPHEW, and is the fourth vessel which they have built for the same service during the past few months. The Leo is 175 feet on deck; beam, 32 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 22 feet; height between decks, 7 feet. She i built in the most superior manner of white oak, hackmetack and locust, and fastened in the most secure manner with copper, iron and locust treenails. Instead of the usual strapping, she is "edge-fastened," which, owing to her length, is considered the best possible means for giving her great strength. Her second deck beams are of genuine Georgia pine, a rarity at the present time in fact; but few if any vessels, except those built by the POILLONS, have used this material in any quantities since the beginning of the war.

abstract: United Service Petroleum Company Case Resumed
snippet: United Service Petroleum Company Case Resumed
lead_paragraph: Messrs. HENRY C. BANKS, WILLIAM BOIES and Assistant District-Attorney GUNNING S. BEDFORD, Jr., for the people; and Ex-Judge SIDNEY H. STUART and Mr. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Jr., for the defendants; Col. WILLIAM D. MANN and DANIEL STRATTON, Jr., founders and managers of the United Service Petroleum and Mining Company, appeared before Justice DODGE, at Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, and Mr. GEORGE D. KELLOGG, late Secretary of the company and complainant against MANN & STRATTON, was examined at length. A comprehensive history of this oil speculation has already been published in the columns of the TIMES. It appears that Col. MANN, who had served in the army and formed an extensive acquaintance among the officers thereof, tiring of the service, resigned and came to this city, where he opened an office for the sale of patent accoutrements, etc., and meeting DANIEL STRATTON, Jr., of Ohio, a person who had some kind of title to certain lands in the petroleum regions, he concocted the scheme of the United Service Petroleum and Mining Company, and used his acquaintance with army officers in introducing the scheme to the public. Precisely how much land MANN and STRATTON owned or purchased, or pretend to own does not as yet appear, the investigation not having yielded this interesting fact; but whether they owned a foot or an acre, or even the six hundred and odd acres which their flaming prospectus advertised, it matters not, since they appear to have been quite as successful in selling stock as though their oil fields had been indeed the diamond gulches of Golconda. They pretended to have $60,000 capital; their working capital was $15,000, and they actually sold shares representing $60,000. Nearly one half of this sum is believed to have been paid in, and is supposed to be in the hands of MANN or his agents at this moment. Hence the suit. The gentlemen who purchased stock in the United Service and Mining Company desire to exchange their certificates for the money which they have disbursed, and they think that if Justice DODGE holds MANN and STRATTON to answer a criminal charge, (the allegation is false pretence,) these persons may restore a portion of the money. In the following testimony the reader may find such facts as were drawn out by the counsel for the defence, yesterday. The counsel for the people will examine this witness on Friday morning next, and then further developments may be expected.

abstract: The City of Washington and the Pennsylvanian arrived at this port yesterday, and the North American at Father Point, bringing news from Europe to the 6th inst. The most important news from Great Britain is the resignation of the Lord Chancellor, in consequence of a vote of censure in the House of Commons, and the appointment of Lord CRANWORTH as his successor. The Fourth of July was celebrated with great enthusiasm at London and Paris. Parliament was prorogued on the 5th. The Queen's speech, which was delivered by commission, touches on American affairs, and expresses much gratification at the termination of the struggle between the North and the South.

abstract: Atlantic Telegraph; Tariff and Traffic Arrangements
snippet: Atlantic Telegraph; Tariff and Traffic Arrangements
lead_paragraph: We publish to-day the official statement of the tariff and traffic arrangements of the Atlantic Telegraph Company. They differ, apparently, in no material respect from those reported previously in abstract, form. In the official statement now, given to the public, the directors, however, take especial care to have it understood that, even at the proposed extravagant rate of charges, they will come under no responsibility whatever for the correct transmission or the safe and prompt delivery of messages intrusted to them. Those who make use of the line at one dollar a letter -- five letters being reckoned a word -- will thus have the cheerful excitement of counting on the chances of the ultimate disposition of their dispatches. Weeks may elapse before they ascertain whether their messages have gone to Jericho or to the bottom of the Atlantic. Or if, in accidental cases, the proper address is discovered without unnecessary delay, and the message is delivered, then will follow the pleasant excitement of speculating on the errors of transmission -- which the directors are candid enough to anticipate, and for which they utterly refuse to be held responsible. Thus, says Mr. Secretary SAWARD, in behalf of the company, "Nor will they (the directors) consent to be liable for any sum whatever, under any circumstances whatever, as damages or otherwise, for loss accruing from errors, mistakes, delays or other causes in respect to any message intrusted to them." We dare say it is all right -- if the company can make this style of doing business pay them. At the rate of one dollar per alphabetical letter, the sender of messages may be presumed to be rather careful as to what he writes -- how his message is worded -- who he sends it to -- where the intended recipient lives -- and what faculty that happy individual may have of interpreting and correcting messages, so as to avoid "loss acruing from errors, mistakes, delays, or outer causes." If those who are to patronize the telegraph have not made up their minds for all this, then they will not be able to blame the Directors for not having forewarned them. The luxury of asking, through the cable, after a relative's health in London or Paris, at the respective rates of twenty pounds sterling, or twenty guineas, may be indulged in -- but with some draw-backs, it may be perceived. For instance, your neighbor Jones may send a message to his London partner to take half a million of Five-Twenties, at the London rate. If that message should go to your relative, in place of an inquiry after his health -- both might suffer some inconvenience. Or Jones and his partner might suffer still more inconvenience, and loss as well. But the company would have incurred no responsibility, beyond applying your two hundred-dollar check to their own account.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, THOMAS SANDERSON, of 227 East Eighteenth-street, went into JOHN EVERT's den, in the Bowery, near Spring-street, and engaged in a dispute with one CATHARINE BREEDY, because she kept a five dollar bank note, and refused to give him $4, which he claimed as change. He said that he had agreed to pay but a dollar for what he had purchased, and uppealed to JOHN NEECK, the barkeeper, but that person, having his employer's interest in view, struck and drove him from the place. SANDERSON then complained to Policeman UHL, and that officer apprehended the female, and took her to court. Presently JOHN NEECK appeared as her friend, and SANDERSON preferred a complaint against him for assault, and, at Justice SHANDLEY's suggestion, a further complaint was preferred against JOHN EBERT, keeper of the place, and Officer LAW arrested him. The gang were committed for examination.

abstract: ISAAC M. VEITCH, Grand Sire of the Grand Lodge I.O. Odd Fellows, has issued his proclamation inviting and exhorting all Grand Lodges and Grand Encampments throughout the United States to send representatives to the Grand Lodge of the United States, to assemble at Baltimore on the third Monday of September next. For four years the Southern Grand Lodges and Grand Encampments have not been represented, and the Most Worthy Grand Sire expresses the hope that the brotherhood may renew its fraternal intercourse, and that "its great heart may ever vibrate in unison with the teachings of charity."
lead_paragraph: ISAAC M. VEITCH, Grand Sire of the Grand Lodge I.O. Odd Fellows, has issued his proclamation inviting and exhorting all Grand Lodges and Grand Encampments throughout the United States to send representatives to the Grand Lodge of the United States, to assemble at Baltimore on the third Monday of September next. For four years the Southern Grand Lodges and Grand Encampments have not been represented, and the Most Worthy Grand Sire expresses the hope that the brotherhood may renew its fraternal intercourse, and that "its great heart may ever vibrate in unison with the teachings of charity."

abstract: We understand that Mr. BARNUM is up and at the world again for contributions of the rare and curious with which to fill the shelves and salons of a new fire-paoof museum, the plans of which are in promotion. An agent was sent by the last steamer to Europe to secure sundry noteworthy matters of which Mr. GREENWOOD reported some time since, and another will follow in the course of a fortnight The sympathy felt for Mr. BARNUM throughout the country develops in many ways. Letters are received from persons all over the country, offering collections of coins, of shells, stuffed birds, revolutionary relics and rebellion record curiosities. Gen. SCOTT has presented Mr. BARNUM with a very unique collection of personal relics, which will be of great interest as years go on. The fact is, that the loss of the Museum was a national calamity. The mineralogical cabinets alone were of inestimable value, and can only be replaced by years of careful enterprise. Yet, if every family will send anything curious which they may have on hand, whether it be minerals, shells, stuffed birds or animals, artificial curiosities, relics of the rebellion or revolutionary war, or anything that is historically curious, Mr. BARNUM will acknowledge its receipt, and the name of the donor will be conspicuously attached to it for all coming time -- for the next museum will be fire-proof, and will probably stand for ages. We learn that one gentleman presented the new museum with one thousand rare and valuable shells on Saturday last, and that quite a number of specimens have already been sent in by various individuals. It is only needful to call their attention to it to induce Captains of vessels sailing to all parts of the world to bring home novelties in natural history to present to Mr. BARNUM; and Americans abroad will be sure to bring or send home their contributions in the shape of something rare and valuable for this new institution. We are assured that the Smithsonian Institute, the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences, and several other public collections in various cities will present such duplicates as they have to Mr. BARNUM. He needs this kind of help, material help in contributions. He has money enough and to spare, but money cannot do everything, and the only way in which these collections can rapidly be made is by the spontaneous action of our people from Maine to California.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 5th, the Lord Chancellor announced his resignation in an appropriate valedictory address. He stated that he had repeatedly expressed his desire to resign in consequence of the unjust charges which had been brought against him, but that Lord PAL, MERSTON and his colleagues had dissuaded him from doing so.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 5th, the Lord Chancellor announced his resignation in an appropriate valedictory address. He stated that he had repeatedly expressed his desire to resign in consequence of the unjust charges which had been brought against him, but that Lord PAL, MERSTON and his colleagues had dissuaded him from doing so. He would say nothing in regard to the vote of the House of Commons further than that he bowed to it, and hoped that in time a more favorable feeling would be entertained toward him. The address was marked by feeling and good taste, and was received with respect and sympathy by the House.

abstract: The United Service Petroleum and Mining Company was again up before Justice DODGE yesterday, Messrs. HENRY C. BANKS, WM. BOIES, and Assistant District-Attorney GUNNING S. BEDFORD, Jr., appearing for the people, and Ex-Judge SIDNEY H. STUART and Mr. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Jr., for the defendants, WILLIAM D. MANN and DANIEL STRATTON, Jr., the actual President, Directors & Co. of this oil company. Mr. GEORGE D. KELLOGG, one of the victims of the fraud, was examined at considerable length, and his testimony corroborated our previously-published accounts of the great petroleum scheme. The further hearing is set down for Friday morning next at 9 o'clock.

abstract: Billings, Benjamin L.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BENJAMIN L. BILLINGS, a well-known lawyer of this city, and a partner of Gen. C.W. SANDFORD, died suddenly on the steamboat Matteawan, while taking his family to Keyport. There was no physician on the boat, but as soon as the landing was made, Dr. J.R. ARROWSMITH was summoned. His services were, however, of no avail, and, in his opinion, Mr. BILLINGS sustained an attack of pure appoplexy causing immediate death. Capt. ARROWSMITH, of the Matteawan rendered every assistance in his power, and hurried up his boat that he might the sooner obtain medical aid. Mr. BILLINGS was a laywer of ability and research; his acquaintance was extended and his practice lucrative. As a man he was genial and true, as a member of the bar he was respected, in his death his family and friends sustain a loss which it is impossible to overestimate.

abstract: Belligerent Rights, Withdrawal; Mr. Seward's Dispatch
snippet: Belligerent Rights, Withdrawal; Mr. Seward's Dispatch
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Secretary SEWARD to Sir FREDERICK BRUCE, which had not been previously given to the public, was laid before the British Parliament on the 3d inst. That dispatch we publish to-day in another column. It cannot be said to present the relations of the two governments in any new or more unfavorable light to the public, on either side of the Atlantic. Mr. SEWARD, it is true, gives addititional point and illustration to the statement of the case which he presented in his letter to the Secretary of the Navy. But no material facts, that can be called new, are presented in the present dispatch. In his letter to Secretary Welles, Mr. SEWARD said:

abstract: New-York, Mr. Cheever, in West Fifteenth-street
snippet: New-York, Mr. Cheever, in West Fifteenth-street
lead_paragraph: Late on Saturday night Mr. MARTIN CHEEVER, of No. 10 West-street was garroted and robbed while he was passing through West Fifteenth-street, by three men, whose names he gives as PATRICK TIGHE, MICHAEL GaFFNEY and THOMAS MCGOVERN. Subsequent to the robbery be informed Policeman MCCONNELL, of the Sixteenth Precinct, of the outrage, and gave him a description of the robbers, and on this information the officer apprehended MCGOVERN and took him to the Sixteenth Precinct Police Station, where he was identified by Mr. CHEEVER. On Sunday morning MCGOVERN was arraigned, but the complainant failed to appear, and Justice DODGE issued a subpoena, sending MCGOVERN, meantime, back to the cells. The complainant obeyed the summons yesterday morning, but declined to prefer a charge, and thereupon the prisoner was released. It was the opinion of bystanders that Mr. CHEEVER had been "seen."

abstract: -The crop of grass was never more luxuriant; the rains have been as frequent and winds violent as usual, yet grass is lodged less even than usual. How is the fact to be accounted for? Is the stubble firmer? and if so, has wet weather a tendency to stiffen and make firmer the stalks of grass? A contrary opinion seems to have prevailed generally among farmers. But this year's experience seems to show that a wet season gives body and strength to the grasses. Whether it gives what the farmers call heart remains to be seen and determined by the manner in which it spends the coming Winter. -- Manchester (N.H.) Mirror.

abstract: In the matter of the admission of the will of James Ross to probate, the following singular fact came out in evidence: Ross, the testator, was a soldier in the Army of the Potomac, and died last Winter in the Hampden Hospital, at Fortress Monroe. Shortly before his decease he made a will, that instrument having been drawn by a Capt. Rose who, in copying the attestation clause, must have done so from the will of one Robert Graham. The clause begins, "I, Robert Graham," instead of "I, James ROSS." The will was duly witnessed by a Surgeon of the hospital and one of his assistants, and in other respects seems to have been regular. The testimony of Capt. Rose not being obtainable, the Surrogate was compelled to refuse the admission of the will to probate. The estate is thought to be worth about $5,000.

abstract: Polygamy, and Prophet Young's Views of
snippet: Polygamy, and Prophet Young's Views of
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that the Republican Chicago Platform of 1856 spoke of "slavery and polygamy as the twin relics of barbarism." So far as slavery is concerned, it is now a relic in the deadest sense, and it seems that polygamy also is preparing itself for death. Speaker COLFAX, and a number of other prominent gentlemen, have recently passed through Utah, and while at Salt Lake City had a conference with the Prophet BRIGHAM YOUNG, in the course of which Mr. COLFAX remonstrated earnestly against the barbarous institution of polygamy. The Prophet said in reply that it was no essential part of Mormonism; that it did not exist in the early days of the Mormon church; that it was not enjoined in the Book of Mormon, and that if the Lord were to give him a revelation that it should be stopped, he would cheerfully enforce the divine injunction. It seemed, from the Prophet's remarks, that he was in expectation of receiving such a revelation. We hope he will get it before next session of Congress, though we hardly know how he will dispose of his three score and ten wives.

abstract: Policeman HILDRETH, of the Twenty-second precinct, apprehended PATRICK SULLIVAN for carelessly handling his pistol and seriously wounding JEFFREY GILFOIL and his sister. It appears that SULLIVAN, while visiting friends on Sunday evening, in Seventh-avenue, near Fifty-fourth-street sought amusement by firing from a window a pistol which was loaded with powder and slugs, and that the youth GILFOIL and his little sister, who were in Fifty-third-street, were severely wounded, a slug having entered GILFOIL's mouth, displaced three teeth, and lodged in the roof of the mouth, and another slug having penetrated Miss GILFOIL's neck. The prisoner was committed for trial before the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: Gen. Meade's Staff
lead_paragraph: By the orders of Gen. MEADE, who has command of the Military Division of the Atlantic, and of Gens. DIX and HOOKER, it will be noticed that sundry important changes have been made in the organization of the United States forces hereabouts. The Department of the East, hitherto independent, is merged in the "Military Division of the Atlantic," and Gen. DIX retires from its command. Gen. DIX ranks every officer in the army, except Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. He was first appointed, and can therefore be second to none. It would be, according to military idea, infra dig for him to serve under Gen. MEADE, and when it was known that that officer was to have command of this division, Gen. DIX, who had intended leaving the service as early as he could without damage to it, sent in his resignation. It has been accepted, and Gen. JOE HOOKER is appointed in his place. It will be seen that Gen. HOOKER, between whom and Gen. DIX the most cordial relations exist, retains the staff of the retiring commander. Every one of them has been brevetted, and the official announcement of their retention in position conveys likewise the information of their brevet.

abstract: THE TREASURY DEPARTMENT AND SOUTHERN CLAIMS. -- Mr. DRAPER, United States Cotton Agent, having received a large number of claims for the proceeds of cotton and other property captured by the military authorities, wrote to Secretary MCCULLOCH for instructions. The answer came yesterday. The Treasury Department has no power to adjudicate claims for the proceeds of property turned over to its agents by the military authorities. Hence the better course would be for parties to withdraw their papers and send them to the Court of Claims, as providvd by law. That tribunal was specially designed for the settlement of all such cases, and an appeal to the Treasury Department can only involve delay and disappointment. Those who desire, can receive these papers by applying at the Cotton Agency, in the New-York Custom-house.

abstract: Speech to Second Mass Regt. at N. Y.
snippet: Speech to Second Mass Regt. at N. Y.
lead_paragraph: The city, during the whole of yesterday, was filled with returning troops, on their homeward way to be finally discharged and paid off. Broadway, from early morning until late in the evening, resounded with the crash and swell of martial music; and as the different regiments passed to and fro from the steamers to the Battery Barracks or the New York State Agency, they were received with marked attention, if not enthusiasm.

abstract: New-York and Newark, at Bedford. 1st day
snippet: New-York and Newark, at Bedford. 1st day
lead_paragraph: NEWARK VS. NEW-YORK. -- The return game between these clubs was commenced at Bedford yesterday at noon, although it was expected that the rain would have necessitated a day's postponement; but by 12 o'clock the grounds were in good condition, and at 1 P.M. the Newark eleven went to the bat, and before they were disposed of they had placed the handsome total of 111 on the telegraph, of which HATTERSLY obtained 25, JEFFERSON 21, BAKER 16, and WARREN 10, all by good cricket. On the New-York side 166 had been scored, with the loss of but six wickets when the stumps were drawn and the game terminated for the day. Of this fine score, BYRON's splendidly obtained 73, not out, was the feature; BOOT's 25, obtained in a very lively style, and SHARP's 18, capitally scored, being the other noteworthy scores. The game will be resumed this morning at 11 o'clock.

abstract: We mentioned the other day that certain old Ohio Hunkers had challenged the nation to discuss the question of slavery with them -- they taking the ground that the institution was right, and consequently that it ought to be resurrected. This is quite as entertaining as the programme recently adopted at a Union meeting in North Carolina, where a resolution was adopted setting forth that, "We (the meeting) would prefer the abolition of slavery to be gradual." Perhaps the institution should have been abolished gradually, and perhaps it should not have been abolished at all; but the fact remains fixed that it has been abolished suddenly, totally, irretrievably and forever; and it is time that everybody, North and South, had heard the news.

abstract: BENJAMIN RICKER, of Bangor, now tarrying at No. 143 Forsyth-street, entered one of the dens in Greenwich-street, near the Battery, and was there robbed of $200 by JENNY WHITE, one of the most depraved and repulsive inmates of the den. Mr. RICKER informed Policeman WALKINSHAW, and the female when first taken into custody, acknowledged her offence, but at the Tombs she professed profound ignorance of the robbery. Mr. RICKER at length recovered $50, and JENNY WHITE was committed for trial....Private JAMES BROWN appeared against ELLEN RICHARDS, keeper, and ANN MURRAY, one of the initiates of a den in Mulberry-street, who had been atrested by Capt. JOURDAN and Sergeant QUINN, of the Sixth Ward. The soldier testified that, having taken lodgings in this brothel, he tied his money, amounting to $140, in a handkerchief, and attached the same to his leg, and that while he was lying in a stupor the prisoners entered the room and forcibly took the money from him. Justice DOWLING committed the prisoners for trial, declining to accept bail. Capt. JOURDAN and his officers describe this den as a resort of the Sixth Ward "Dead Rabbits," and say that eight soldiers and civilians have been robbed therein recently....FREDERICK GROSSMAKER, keeper of a lodging-house at No. 148 Leonard-street, and EDWARD HAMPSON, one of his partners, were arrested by Capt. JOURDAN, and Mr. JOHN LOCHRANE, of No. 108 Seventh-avenue, made affidavit that while he was asleep in the place the prisoners stole $55 from his pockets. HANNAH SULLIVAN, a servant, testified that she saw the accused commit the robbery. The prisoners were committed in default of $2,000 bail.

The soldier testified that, having taken lodgings in this brothel, he tied his money, amounting to $140, in a handkerchief, and attached the same to his leg, and that while he was lying in a stupor the prisoners entered the room and forcibly took the money from him. Justice DOWLING committed the prisoners for trial, declining to accept bail. Capt. JOURDAN and his officers describe this den as a resort of the Sixth Ward "Dead Rabbits," and say that eight soldiers and civilians have been robbed therein recently....FREDERICK GROSSMAKER, keeper of a lodging-house at No. 148 Leonard-street, and EDWARD HAMPSON, one of his partners, were arrested by Capt. JOURDAN, and Mr. JOHN LOCHRANE, of No. 108 Seventh-avenue, made affidavit that while he was asleep in the place the prisoners stole $55 from his pockets. HANNAH SULLIVAN, a servant, testified that she saw the accused commit the robbery. The prisoners were committed in default of $2,000 bail.
