abstract: Fictitious Report of Barnum's Museum Fire
snippet: Fictitious Report of Barnum's Museum Fire
lead_paragraph: The Tribune's graphic and eloquent description of the terrific combats among the lions, tigers, bears and other wild beasts in Barnum's Museum during the fire, is going the rounds of the country press. Our rural neighbors do not suspect for a moment that a city journal of position and character would, in a report of city incidents, substitute fiction for fact. Some doubt is thrown upon the accuracy of our neighbor's statement, however, by the fact that there was not in the Museum at the time of the fire, a single lion, tiger, bear or wild beast of any kind. An enterprising reporter may sometimes see "snakes" where none exist, but the Tribune's scribe must have been very far gone to see so many ferocious animals where actually there were none at all.

abstract: Congressional Elections
lead_paragraph: "Reconstruction" does not consist in the appointment of Provisional Governors, Federal Judges, District Attorneys, Marshals, and other Federal officers, in the Southern-States; nor in the popular election of conventions, and new Legislatures; nor even in the election of Senators and Representatives to Congress. It practically lies in the actual refitting of the vacant chairs in Congress. When Senators and Representatives from the Southern States shall come to the national capitol, with legal and true titles to the deserted seats, and shall be admitted to them, then, and not until then, will the old relations of the Southern States to the Union be practically restored Therefore it behooves these States to see well to it that their new Senators and Representatives come with such titles.

abstract: Returning; Hospitality to
lead_paragraph: The City of New-York, true to her reputation for generosity, has done a good work, during the past six weeks, in making the troops returning home to be mustered out of the service heartily welcome. We had simply, before the beginning of the "homeward march," to call attention in the TIMES to the propriety of raising a fund for the purpose of supplying fruits and luxuries to the faithful men who have been enduring with heroism the hardships and rough fare of the field, when the benevolent and wealthy people of the city promptly opened their purses and contributed handsomely to this object. Col. COLYER, the State Agent, has been the almoner of at least $9,000 in cash, voluntarily offered, which has been used in purchasing berries and watermelons, providing coffee and cigars, and expended in other judicious ways, to cheer the hearts of the brave veterans, and testify in the most emphatic manner the. esteem and good will of the people toward them. Not the smallest item of this expenditure has been the cost of the music, without which the march of the soldiers through the city would have been cheerless as a funeral, and with which every regiment has expressed a delight more enthusiastic even than is drawn out by the liberal supply of the good things which rejoice the inner man of those so long accustomed to hard tack and salt junk. Thus far, during the past few weeks, upward of 25,000 men have been lodged, fed and hospitably entertained at the New-York State Agency, in their transit through the city. No troops bound for any portion of the State have been allowed to pass on their homeward journey without some material testimony of this sort of the high appreciation felt for their services. Not only the rank and file, but the officers have been cared for, which frequently is as much a duty as providing for the men; because the officers very often come home without funds, and fully enjoy a good meal after the long abstinence from decent food, incidental to traveling, and the peculiarities of the military service.

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE impanneled a jury last evening, at the Nineteenth Ward police station, and made inquiry concerning the cause of the boiler explosion at Messrs. NOLEN & STEERS' steam saw mill, in Second-avenue, corner of Fifty-fourth-street, on Saturday morning last, whereat PATRICK CONNER lost his life, and OWEN KELTY, JACOB B. LAKE and others were severely hurt, bruised and scalded. After taking testimony showing that the engineer had omitted to open the steam valves while there was fire under the boilers, and that probably the explosion was occasioned by this omission, the further investigation was adjoured to 8 o'clock on Friday evening next, to enable the engineer to put in his deposition.

abstract: Yesterday, the third in the grand festival, was passed by our German people in pleasant paths of peaceful recreation. That Germans should be merry and quiet and orderly is by no means strange, but that they should nearly monopolize public attention for three days and nights, ringing and speaking in our largest halls, parading the streets with paraphernalia and banners, entertaining friends with liberal hospitality, gathering in groups upon the street and in multitudes at the parks, all without trouble among themselves or with outsiders, is both wonderful to us and creditable to them.

abstract: The Academy of Music was crowded Monday evening with a highly Teutonic audience. It is in some measure...
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music was crowded Monday evening with a highly Teutonic audience. The season, in fact, is unfavorable for any other; and it may be added that the programmes are constructed for Germans alone and possess none of the saliences that Americans expect and are eager for. It is in some measure deemed a privilege to attend these hearty gatherings. There is surely a lesson and an example in these myriad toilers who, rising superior to those "twain-jailors of the soul, low birth and iron fortune," yet contrive on many nights of the year to devote a pleasant period to the cultivation of art, and once in the round of the months to carry with them to other cities -- as now -- the evidence of their devotion. When we remember the sickly condition of our own singing societies and compare them with their German competitors, we see how completely the true feeling and enthusiasm are on the side of the latter. It is hardly worth while, therefore, to question the policy of making the programme too Teutonic Evidently there would be but little advantage in making it more American.

abstract: Sugar, Paper, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the decline which has taken place in the price of sugar, the refineries of this city are actively engaged, and to all appearance, doing a prosperous business. This is partly explained by the fact that during the era of very high prices many of them suspended operations, in view of the irregularity and uncertainty of the market. STUART's establishment was idle from last June to January. When it resumed, the market was tolerably well bared. With a gradual fall, through the rate of exchange, to 50 per cent. on raw sugars, manufacturers could easily stand a reduction of 30, and even 40 per cent. on the price of the refined article. At STUART's they are very active, having nearly their full force (360 hands) employed. The prospects are considered from fair to good. So far, labor has been looking rather upward in price. Business is conducted on the cash principle. No Southern demand of any account as yet. Among those engaged in this pursuit throughout the city a good feeling prevails as to the immediate prospect.

abstract: Jordan, A. L.; Proceedings of the Bar, Funeral, >amp;c.
snippet: Jordan, A. L.; Proceedings of the Bar, Funeral, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: This being vacation time for the members of the Bench and the Bar of this City, there were no Courts in session yesterday, with the exception of the Supreme Court Chambers held by Justice Joseph F. Barnard, and the Chambers and Special Term of the Superior Court. For this reason the death of Ambrose L. Jordan, Esq., was not announced in Court as is usual when the death of an eminent member of the Bar takes place. In the Chambers of the Supreme Court however, after a little routine business had been finished, Mr. Levi S. Chatfield, late Attorney-General of this State, arose and with much emotion announced Mr. Jordan's death. He said substantially, that in making a motion that the Court adjourn, he did it with feelings of the deepest sorrow. An old, honored and respected member of the legal profession was dead. AMBROSE L. JORDAN died on Sunday last, in the 77th year of his age. The speaker had known him well for very nearly half a century. In 1812 Mr. Jordan came to the County of Otsego, where he was actively engaged in the practice of his profession until the year 1823 or 1824, when he removed to the City of Hudson, this State. During ail the years of his professional career in Otsego County, and after his removal further east, he was well known to the speaker. From the beginning of his professional life he had admired his honest simplicity of heart am exhibited in his daily life; his uprightness of purpose, as manifested in his dealings with his clients, and his uniform kindness and urbanity as displayed toward his opponents during the heat of debate and during protracted trials. He was one of "nature's noblemen," a genuine specimen of a man as well as a lawyer. He was the contemporary of such eminent jurists as Kent, Tallcott, Spencer, Thomas J. Oakley, (who died the Chief-Justice of the Superior Court of this city,) of Samuel Stevens, B.F. Butler, George Wood and others, nearly all of whom, are now in their graves. Mr. Chatfield said that the deceased was his immediate predecessor in the office of the Attorney-General of this State. If there was one thing which Mr. Jordan had always avoided, it had been politics. This should be an example to young men just embarked in the legal profession -- let politics alone, follow closely the legitimate business in which you are engaged. Mr. Jordan invariably said this to young lawyers. And no old, experienced lawyer was ever more the friend and counselor of the young man than he.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. -- From the City Inspector's report it appears that 660 deaths occurred in this city during the past week -- 106 men, 100 women, 262 boys and 192 girls -- being an increase of 106 upon the mortality of the previous week, and of 50 upon that of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased 416 were children under five years of age. The mortality of the principal diseases were as follows Cholera infantum, 148; consumption, 59; infantile marasmus, 56; convulsions, 45; diarrhoea, 32; dysentery. 20; croup, 5; bilious fever, 5; typhus fever, 24; scarlet fever, 8; inflammation of the lungs, 32; small-pox, 8.

lead_paragraph: They had a scene in Thompson-street yesterday morning. Mr. ERNST CAMSIER, of No. 143 Thompson-street, sat over his lager in CAROLINE AUSBERGS' saloon, at No. 165 Prince-street, at about 11 o'clock, and one JAMES FOSTER entered into a pleasant chat with him, and after drinking twice or thrice, ascertained that Mr. GAMBIER had $520 in a bag in his pantaloons pocket. FOSTER proposed a wrestle, and GAMBIER assented; but during the scuffle he detected FOSTER's hand in his pocket, and at once missed his money. FOSTER sprang to the sidewalk, but was pursued and captured by GAMBIER, and then ensued a fierce struggle, in which every particle of clothing was torn from FOSTER's person; and he, to insure his escape, kicked GAMBIER in the face, dosing one of his eyes. FOSTER then fled to Thompson-street, and was there seen by Patrolman JAMES FERDON who, after a hot chase up that street, captured the fugitive in a stable. How to get the prisoner to court was now the question which puzzled Officer FERDON; but after passing a few harmless sallies on the fellow's appearance the bystanders loaned a coat and pair of pantaloons, and the captor and captured went off to Jefferson Market amid the jeers of a multitude who had gathered to see the fun. Justice DODGE committed FOSTER to await trial at the Court of General Sessions, declining to accept bail. Mr. GAMBIER has not recovered his money.

abstract: JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- The Jersey City dead-lock Common Council held a meeting at the Council Chamber last evening. Alderman PANGBORN was chosen chairman pro tem. A communication was received from the Board of Chosen Freeholders in reference to the claims of Jersey City for the county war coupon bonds of $400 for each volunteer and substitutes furnished on the two last calls for troops. A resolution was adopted instructing the Special Committee of Enlistment of the old Board, to procure the necessary papers and vouchers in order to obtain the bonds. Three ballots were had for permanent President of the Board, resulting in a tie vote. Alderman EARLE then withdrew his name from the canvass, and the board adjourned to Friday evening.

abstract: Reconstruction in
lead_paragraph: Since we last noticed in these columns the progress of reconstruction in Arkansas, events have conspired favorably for the early rehabilitation of the State in the Union. The Free State Government, organized in March, last year, appears now to be acquiesced in on all sides. Not one outrage has been committed within the last two months, or in other words, since the disbanding of the Trans-Mississippi Confederate forces. Nearly every county is now organized; as are also the judicial districts. Some of the courts have already been in session, and all of them will shortly be regularly holden. Taxes are being as quietly collected as before the War, and civil process can be executed everywhere throughout the State.

abstract: Mudd, >amp;c., Sent to Dry Tortugas
lead_paragraph: The President has changed the place of confinement of Dr. MUDD, SPANGLER, ARNOLD and O'LAUGHLIN from the Albany Penitentiary to the Dry Tortugas, a secure prison on a barren reef a few miles beyond Key West. No visitors can reach their place of confinement except by special permission of the government, and there is absolutely no chance of escape. A more suitable spot for the incarceration of these conspirators could not have been selected, and the change will commend itself to every impartial judgment The solemn roll of the waves of the Gulf; the silent and even ghostly air, or rather want of air, on these lifeless coral reefs; the absence of every living thing save the albatross and the shark, "the blue above and the blue below," in one unvarying monotony, save the infrequent visit of the hurricane, which only adds terror to desolation, all these may faintly picture the far seaward home of those to whom the law and the testimony have denied the boon of death.
headline: {'main': 'TO THE DRY TORTUGAS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'TO THE DRY TORTUGAS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A free press is the bulwark of liberty. A free press is the grand conservator of the rights of the people. A free press may be Thersites or Ulysses -- it may carp and snarl, or advise and direct. Within three months the might of loyal arms has emancipated the press of the South. It is free. We recognize the fact. In all districts beyond military law, it can be as violent virulent, poisonous, malicious, incendiary, ignorant, bigoted and infernal as the chafed and untamed spirits of its tolerated directors may dictate. And what is the result? Simply this: A horde of seedy vagabonds, whose short commons during the war, and whose constricted throttles, firmly grasped by JEFF. DAVIS's strong hand, have not known a free respiration for four years, are now untrammelled. What do they undertake? Most of them return to the course of 1860; they damn the North, they damn its men, its; armies, its politicians, its women, its political course, its commercial faith, its honor, (if any is accorded,) and, with the utter foolishness of folly, they sneer at its strength. All this we must accept as it comes; and we really cannot blame the men who have written curses for so many years that they do not easily learn to bless. But have they no common sense? . Are they still, oblivious of the fact that the war is over? Do they not know that they are defeated -- that their Confederacy is a thing of the past, their slavery a matter of history, themselves the losing party in the grand contest? Yet, indeed, we confess to no small amazement at their hallucination. Such men as JEFF. DAVIS, A.H. STEPHENS, ROBERT E. LEE, ROBT. H. TOOMBS, and a host of lesser lights -- not excepting BEAUREGARD -- accept the decree of fate with some show of dignity; but these blind leaders of the blind still fill their columns with the extinct "nigger," and brawl in extravagant rhetoric about the "abolitionists," and topics equally remote from the vital questions of the day. In consequence of their foolish violence, it may become necessary (as the military power judges, to suppress some of these prints. The fact is to be deplored, although we make no issue with those whose right it is to judge. We only regret that such a strange oblivion seemed to have fallen upon the faculties of so many Southern editors; that they do not more justly appreciate the great changes which have taken place since their own friends suppressed their sweet voices; and that, instead of reviving the ideas of 1860, they have not sufficient patriotism and good sense to recognize and act upon the conditions of 1865 -- that instead of acting the part of guides to the people, and setting before them the real truth, they are concealing the most important facts and leading their deluded followers into courses alike disgraceful to their intelligence and dishonorable to their loyalty.
lead_paragraph: A free press is the bulwark of liberty. A free press is the grand conservator of the rights of the people. A free press may be Thersites or Ulysses -- it may carp and snarl, or advise and direct. Within three months the might of loyal arms has emancipated the press of the South. It is free. We recognize the fact. In all districts beyond military law, it can be as violent virulent, poisonous, malicious, incendiary, ignorant, bigoted and infernal as the chafed and untamed spirits of its tolerated directors may dictate. And what is the result? Simply this: A horde of seedy vagabonds, whose short commons during the war, and whose constricted throttles, firmly grasped by JEFF. DAVIS's strong hand, have not known a free respiration for four years, are now untrammelled. What do they undertake? Most of them return to the course of 1860; they damn the North, they damn its men, its; armies, its politicians, its women, its political course, its commercial faith, its honor, (if any is accorded,) and, with the utter foolishness of folly, they sneer at its strength. All this we must accept as it comes; and we really cannot blame the men who have written curses for so many years that they do not easily learn to bless. But have they no common sense? . Are they still, oblivious of the fact that the war is over? Do they not know that they are defeated -- that their Confederacy is a thing of the past, their slavery a matter of history, themselves the losing party in the grand contest? Yet, indeed, we confess to no small amazement at their hallucination. Such men as JEFF. DAVIS, A.H. STEPHENS, ROBERT E. LEE, ROBT. H. TOOMBS, and a host of lesser lights -- not excepting BEAUREGARD -- accept the decree of fate with some show of dignity; but these blind leaders of the blind still fill their columns with the extinct "nigger," and brawl in extravagant rhetoric about the "abolitionists," and topics equally remote from the vital questions of the day. In consequence of their foolish violence, it may become necessary (as the military power judges, to suppress some of these prints. The fact is to be deplored, although we make no issue with those whose right it is to judge. We only regret that such a strange oblivion seemed to have fallen upon the faculties of so many Southern editors; that they do not more justly appreciate the great changes which have taken place since their own friends suppressed their sweet voices; and that, instead of reviving the ideas of 1860, they have not sufficient patriotism and good sense to recognize and act upon the conditions of 1865 -- that instead of acting the part of guides to the people, and setting before them the real truth, they are concealing the most important facts and leading their deluded followers into courses alike disgraceful to their intelligence and dishonorable to their loyalty.

abstract: Thomas Kinsley, through his counsel, pleaded guilty to assaulting Mary Jane Bishop, but an asking permission to examine witnesses to show mitigation of circumstances, the plea was ordered to be withdrawn and the case went to trial. Witness Well, Sir, on the 2d day of July Mr. Kinsley struck me with his fist; then he kicked me on the side; twice he struck...
lead_paragraph: Thomas Kinsley, through his counsel, pleaded guilty to assaulting Mary Jane Bishop, but an asking permission to examine witnesses to show mitigation of circumstances, the plea was ordered to be withdrawn and the case went to trial. Witness -- Well, Sir, on the 2d day of July Mr. Kinsley struck me with his fist; then he kicked me on the side; twice he struck me, then I fell; then he kicked me, and Mrs. Grudges saw it all. As for Mrs. Callahan, the prisoner's sister, I haven't spoken to her in fourteen long months, but she arrested me this day week. Was I speaking to her that day? No, Sir. Never a word did I speak to her that day. I swear I haven't been in the habit of abusing her. Yes, well, yes I was arrested last Wednesday and taken before Judge Connolly on her complaint, and I think I was twice there before that.

abstract: One of the actors in the latest East Houston-street murder -- WILLIAM  MAHON by name -- was taken into custody, yesterday, by Policeman MULLIGAN, of the Fourteenth Ward, and turned over to Coroner GOVER, by whom he was required to find $1,000 bail to abide the action of the Grand Jury. A Coroner's Jury, sitting ever the body of MORTIMER MAGUIRE, a youth who received mortal injuries in a fight at pidgeon's bar-room, on the north-west corner of East Houston and Crosby streets, on the night of the 29th ult., found a verdict against MAHON; but he kept out of sight until yesterday.

abstract: New-York, Harlem Bridge, Highway, of W. McCormick
snippet: New-York, Harlem Bridge, Highway, of W. McCormick
lead_paragraph: Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning, Mr. WILLIAM MCCORMICK, of Melrose, Westchester County, was attacked by four highwaymen while he was wending his way homeward over the Harlem Bridge. The outlaws, having garroted and beaten him, and stolen his diamond breastpin and other valuables, fled, but WALTER KEECH, who is alleged to have been one of the gang, was subsequently apprehended by Policeman FORBES, and taken to the Fourth District Police Court yesterday morning.

abstract: Poughkeepsie Boat Race
lead_paragraph: The much talked-of aquatic contest between the crews of the celebrated four-oared shell-boats George J. Brown, of New-York, and the Stranger, of Poughkeepsie, came off at the latter place yesterday. The race was over a distance of five measured miles. For some years past the crews of these two boats have been regarded as the finest oarsmen in the United States, and although they have met on various occasions at regattas, they have never, been matched before. Neither party rowed in their old boats yesterday. New and splendid vessels had been constructed for each, the Brown's crew pulling in the Samuel Collyer, the Stranger's crew pulling in the Floyd T.F. Fields, both vessels being named after the principal backers of the contestants. The crew of the Collyer was composed of DENNIS LEARY (stroke) JOHN BEGLIN, JAMES H. BEGLIN, and BERNARD BEGLIN (bow.) As the George J. Brown crew they have made themselves famous by their numerous victories in the regattas at Boston, Worcester, Newburgh, Poughkeepsie, Albany, New-York, Troy and other places. The Foughkeepsie crew is composed of WILLIAM STEPHENS (stroke,) HOMER WOODEN, WILLIAM BERGER and EZEKIEL BENEWAY. They have been undergoing a severe training at Poughkeepsie for some time past, while the New-York crew have taken their "airing" on the Harlem River, at Red House.

abstract: The Irish Legion, composed of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, the One Hundred and Fifty-fifth, the One Hundred and Sixty-fourth and the One Hundred and Seventieth, of this State, Col. J.P. MCIVOR, acting Brigadier-General Commanding, arrived in this city about noon yesterday and was received by Col. COLYER, the State Agent, and escorted to the armory of the Eighth Regiment, where a collation was prepared for the men. The legion was headed by ROBERTSON's brass band, which had been furnished by Col COLYER. The men were warmly greeted along the line of march.

abstract: UNITED STATES COMMISSIONERS' COURT BEFORE COMMISSIONER NEWTON ALLEGED MURDER ON THE HIGH SEAS This court has for some time been engaged in the examination Of HENRY CLARK and JAMES H. FURLONG on charge of the murder of Capt. WILLIAM W.FRENCH, of the ship William Tell, of Boston, Mass. The Captain was found murdered in his cabin, when within twenty-four hours' sail of Pernambuco, on the 19th of March, 1865. The defendants...
lead_paragraph: UNITED STATES COMMISSIONERS' COURT -- BEFORE COMMISSIONER NEWTON -- ALLEGED MURDER ON THE HIGH SEAS. -- This court has for some time been engaged in the examination Of HENRY CLARK and JAMES H. FURLONG on charge of the murder of Capt. WILLIAM W.FRENCH, of the ship William Tell, of Boston, Mass. The Captain was found murdered in his cabin, when within twenty-four hours' sail of Pernambuco, on the 19th of March, 1865. The defendants were seamen, and on arriving in port were given in charge of the United States Consul and sent to the United States for trial. Considerable evidence was taken, and the facts elicited point strongly to the prisoner CLARK as the perpetrator, although there is no direct testimony to that effect. During the examination, it was also shown that the seamen were most inhumanly treated by the officers of the vessel. One of the men, called DANIEL, a Norwegian, was beaten with belaying pins and ropes two or three times a day, till at last, in a fit of despair, he jumped overboard and was drowned. This was about a fortnight before the murder. The examination of the case was finally concluded yesterday morning, and the Commissioner decided to hold CLARK for trial before the United States District Court and to detain FURLONG as a witness.

abstract: Lord Chancellorship, the
lead_paragraph: The advises which brought in the detailed account of Lord Chancellor WESTBURY's resignation, and the Parliamentary censure by which it was ostensibly caused, announce that Lord CRANWORTH again assumes his seat on the Woolsack. The charges of corruption against the former official were singularly indefinite, and rested upon what; might be surmised rather than anything capable of distinct proof. It is probable that with a less exalted personage they would have been unnoticed altogether. Nor need the whole case be considered as one involving much more than a struggle, arising out of the approaching reorganization of political parties in England, and, in some respects, the unpopularity of the Chancellor himself. In this view of the case we think our cotemporaries, who are so eager to improve the occasion of Lord WESTBURY's political disgrace, might spare themselves much needless labor.

abstract: A YOUNG LADY ATTEMPTS TO SHOOT A POLICEMAN, AND IS ARRESTED AND LOCKED Up. A young lady, named CHRISTIANA BUGBY, residing in North Second-street, E. D., was yesterday taken before Judge DALY, on a charge of attempting to shoot Officer THOMAS H. CHICHESTER of the Forty-fifth Precinct, the night previous, while he was patroling his beat in South First-street, near Eighth. The facts of the...
lead_paragraph: A YOUNG LADY ATTEMPTS TO SHOOT A POLICEMAN, AND IS ARRESTED AND LOCKED Up. -- A young lady, named CHRISTIANA BUGBY, residing in North Second-street, E. D., was yesterday taken before Judge DALY, on a charge of attempting to shoot Officer THOMAS H. CHICHESTER of the Forty-fifth Precinct, the night previous, while he was patroling his beat in South First-street, near Eighth. The facts of the case seem to be that CHICHESTER and the young lady kept company together, about nine months since, and an estrangement between them arose in consequence of some scandal, originated by Miss BUGBY's lady friends. The persistent scandal-mongers not only broke up the company of the young people, but also goaded the unhappy girl into the position of an attempted murderess. She acknowledged to the Justice that the officer never harmed her, and expressed the belief that she had been deceived in regard to him. The moral character of Officer CHICHESTER is attested to by all his fellow officers, and that of the young lady is irreproachable. The Justice has reserved his sentence.

abstract: Retrenchment and Economy by Government
lead_paragraph: The time has now about come when the expenditures of the government will necessarily be reduced, when probably less than one-third of the daily expenditure of the last four years will be required. The real cost of the national establishment has, of course, been diminishing daily and greatly for the last ten weeks, or ever since the disbandment of the army, the diminution of the navy, and the breaking up of the Provost-Marshal system was commenced; but for the same reason, the expenditures have been at their highest. We suppose that more than half a million men have been dismissed from the public service since the capture of JEFF. DAVIS, and many of the soldiers had three, six or nine months' pay due, all of which they received before getting their discharge. Many of the large contracts, also, have come to a close, and the accounts been settled by the government. So that though the dismissal of every regiment, the sale of every vessel, and the closing of every contract, reduced expenses permanently, they also enlarged for the moment the outflow of money from the treasury.

abstract: The screw-steamer Nyack, 7 guns, which was built at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, in 1863, will sail in a few hours for the Pacific station, and service in those waters. Once out there, in all probability she will never return to the Atlantic sea-coast. She will touch, en route, at St. Thomas, Bahia, Rio Janeiro, Montevideo, and one or more ports on the west coast of South America.

abstract: The graceful act of the Spanish Government in ordering the surrender of the rebel ram Stonewall, and not less the graceful manner in which that act was performed, will long be remembered by our people with satisfaction. England, under Lord RUSSELL's guidance, might profit by the example of Her Catholic Majesty. CHARLES LAMB's excuse for leaving his desk at an early hour in the afternoon was that he came to it late in the morning. Probably Lord RUSSELL's excuse is as valid for being the lost to desert the Confederate navy, to wit that he was the first to recognize.

abstract: WALLACE'S THEATRE. -- Mr. DAN BRYANT, with the perfume of the shamrock still about him, commenced a season at this establishment on Monday evening. The house was crowded to its greatest capacity, and this too with the "Irish Emigrant" and "Handy Andy." It is needless to speak of the worth of these dramas. They are acceptable to the public, and that suffices. Mr. BRYANT, on whom the interest of the evening centered, was in fine health, and gave to the two leading characters a just and genial interpretation. He was, we need scarcely add, received with enthusiasm.

abstract: The New-Hampshire Superior Court has decided that an express company delivering a parcel marked with the cabalistic "C.O.D." -- collect on delivery -- may allow a person to whom it is consigned reasonable time to open the package and determine whether he will receive it or not. The rule heretofore has been that no examination could take place -- the receiver must take the package and determine whether it contained what he had ordered or not. This decision of the court is both legal and sensible, which latter cannot be said of all legal decisions.

abstract: We modestly suggest that the new contractors ought to study a few favorite dodges of the gentleman who has heretofore cleaned the streets of the great city of Utopia. This able functionary, whose name was Gargantua, (vide RABELAIS,) had two hundred men to sprinkle, two hundred men to sweep, two hundred men to hoe, two hundred men to shovel, two hundred men to drive horses, two hundred men to empty carts, two hundred men to brush out carts, two hundred men to say "whoa" to the horses, two hundred men to hold the cartmen's hats while they dumped their loads, two hundred men to give out checks, (each man giving two tickets for each load, with fifty per cent of the swag in his favor;) two hundred men to see that two hundred drivers, with each a cart (200 carts,) carried each not more than a quarter of a load, and that each duly spilled half of that between the loading place and the dumping-ground; and finally, two hundred political pimps, to take seventy-five per cent of all the wages of these various two hundreds, with which to buy their votes at the next election. If the new contractors are not up to these grand teachings of jolly old RABELAIS, we can only pity their ignorance. Let them live and learn.

abstract: On Monday evening, JOSEPH HUNT, of No. 33 Ridge-street, carman, and Mr. THOMAS TRAINOR, of No. 49 East Forty-ninth-street, quarreled in a political discussion in a saloon at No. 35 Ridge-street; blows ensued and the affair ended in mayhem, Mr. TRAINOR losing his left ear. Officer GRASSEL, of the Tenth Ward, apprehended HUNT, and the prisoner was committed for trial at the Court of General Sessions. When Mr. TRAINOR appeared to make complaint yesterday morning, he took his ear into court in a bottle.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; History of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Every city reader of the TIMES, every man, woman and child in the metropolis is interested in the condition of our streets. A few of the men doubtless-are quite content that they should remain filthy, full of garbage, pressing invitations to pestilence and laden with the dust of months, butt the majority of our citizens are mainly concerned in the approximate cleanliness and consequent health of the place. That our streets and alleys, and courts and highways have been for years past a reproach to us; that the fair fame of our city in this respect has become a by-word and a hissing, we need not state. Everybody here and everybody elsewhere knows it and never expected any change. A fortuitous combination of circumstances has, however, secured a change, the elements being neglect on the part of our authorities, frequene complaint of the people, the interference of the Legislature and the outrageous conduct of politicians whose inhumanity and reckless disregard of public weal have been manifested in part by organized opposition to the new system of cleaning, partly by covert support of the scoundrels who urged the workmen to acts of violence, and partly by the diabolical action of sundry miscreants who develope their deviltry in the cutting of horses' throats, ham-stringing them, setting fire to stables and brutally beating their more deserving fellows.

abstract: The Verdict on Miss Harris
lead_paragraph: The trial of MARY HARRIS for the murder of ANDREW J. BURROUGHS, which has been in progress in Washington for the last twelve days, was concluded yesterday afternoon by her acquittal, after a brief deliberation on the part of the jury. The course of the trial, from its beginning to its close, has been followed with very great interest throughout the country. It was not because the incidents of the crime were of any very extraordinary character; or that the public or social position of either of the parties was eminent; or that the counsel on one side or the other were of marked distinction; or that there was any expectation that any new principle would be settled by it, or that the verdict would be other than what it has been. The popular interest manifested in the case arose mainly, we suppose, from the fact that the times are rather dull, and an episode of this kind furnishes a lively subject of gossip amid the grave public questions now before the country.
headline: {'main': 'The Verdict in the Mary Harris Trial.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Verdict in the Mary Harris Trial.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Work of Time
lead_paragraph: Many men are disappointed in not finding a more rapid transformation of Southern character. They read of a great deal of bitterness yet towards the national government, of a loyalty that is simply submission to the strongest, of continued adherence to the doctrine of State rights, of a disposition to oppress and persecute the freedmen; they conclude that there is but a poor prospect that the South will ever assimilate with the rest of the country, and look forward to an indefinite prolongation of military rule, or to never-ending disorder and wrong. From this state of mind naturally comes an inclination to try rigorous measures and summary expedients.

abstract: AN OFFICIAL ACCOUNT. -- Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD favors the press with the information that the Great Eastern probably sailed from Valentia on the 15th inst. He says that the reason newspaper correspondents were excluded from the vessel was the fear that they might enter into conversation with the engineers and distract the brains of those worthy gentlemen. Will creation please hold its breath while the engineers attend to "their highly important duties?" It may be inconvenient for creation; but only think of the awful consequences of meddling with the engineers! Yet Mr. FIELD graciously announces that as soon as the work is done, the press will be furnished with an "official" account. That is something; but with all respect for the directors, we beg to state that we should prefer the account of our own correspondent, and so, we presume, would every other journal in this country or in Europe. It is not to be assumed that the official account will be intentionally doctored to suit circumstances, or that any important facts will be omitted or glozed over, and yet the people have so long looked to the individual enterprise of their favorite newspapers for information upon topics of importance, that we venture to predict a general disbelief in any account which the directors may furnish until it shall have been confirmed by the reports of writers unconnected with the company.

abstract: EXCURSION OF THE SEVENTY-FIRST REGIMENT N.G.S.N.Y. -- Companies H and B of this command, numbering 150 men, have decided to visit Boston and Providence instead of Albany and Saratoga, as has been stated in our columns. The former places have been selected after a thorough inquiry by the committee regarding every particular pertaining to the pleasure and general satisfaction of the visit. They are promised a cordial reception and a happy time [???]y the "Tigers" and "Fusileers" of Boston. They will leave this city on Tuesday, the 15th of August, by the Sound Line. The regimental (DODWORTH's) full band will accompany them, and every arrangement is being made to insure a grand success. The committee will be in waiting at the armory of Company B, corner of University-place and Thirteenth-street, at 7 o'clock on every Tuesday and Friday evening, after this week, previous to the date of starting, where they will be happy to receive any propositions or communications from those interested. Any communications addressed to Lieut. REMSEN APPLEBY, No. [???]8 Broadway, will also receive attention.

abstract: Police; Over-zealous Arrests by
lead_paragraph: OVER-ZEALOUS POLICEMEN. -- Very frequently, now-a-days, we are informed of arrests, on the part of the police, which are absolutely inexcusable, and which have caused a great deal of misery to the victims of such indiscriminating power. We recall, for example, two instances in which respectable women were the sufferers. In these cases the subjects of the outrage found themselves abroad in the streets, under perfectly legitimate circumstances, at a late hour, without a male protector, and hurrying homeward in great trepidation. They were roughly taken into custody, their explanations were unheeded, and they were subjected to the indignity of a night's detention at the station-house, because, forsooth, an ignorant policeman choose to suspect them of being common bawds. A man of ordinary discernment, in these instances, would have discovered at a glance that such suspicion was groundless. We know that in a body of policemen, numbering at least two thousand, it is quite possible that a few idiots may contrive to receive appointments; but we trust, and have reason to believe, that the Metropolitan Police Commissioners will dismiss at once every patrolman who shall make such flagrant and unhappy mistakes. Now that the soldiers have done their work and are arriving home by thousands, ready for employment there is a good opportunity to select from their ranks as many worthy and discreet men as shall be sufficient to fill the places of the worthless minority who now disgrace the department.

abstract: Two Germans -- AUGUSTUS KLUKE and ADAM MILLER by name -- became involved in a quarrel in a saloon in Forty-fifth-street, near Second-avenue, during which MILLER received a severe stab wound in the head at the hands of his antagonist. Officer KELLY, of the Nineteenth Precinct, arrested KLUKE. and Justice CONNOLLY held him to bail in the sum of $1,000 to answer a charge of felonious assault and battery.

lead_paragraph: Once again the flag-ship Hartford as in commission, and the starry pennant floats from her main truck. She will be ready to sail in a few days to take her place at the head of the East India Squadron, bearing the broad pennant of Acting Rear-Admiral HENRY H. BELL. The following is a list of the officers of the vessel: Commander, R.W. SHUFELDT; Lieutenant-Commander, Charles C. Carpenter; Lieutenants, J.H. Read, F.J. Higginson, E.T. Brown; Paymaster, Washington Irving; Chief-Engineer, Andrew Lawson; First Assistants, Fletcher A. Willson, W.T.E. Mullen; Second Assistants, Charles M. Burchard, Walter D. Smith; Acting Second Assistant, J.A. Crouthiers; Acting Third Assistants, Domingo Custano, George B. Boggs, Phillips Little; Passed Assistant Surgeon, J.N. Penrose; Ensign, A.S. Crowninshield; Midshipmen, D.C. Woodward, F.H. Sheppard, H. Elmer, Wm.M. Folger; Lieutenant Marine Corps, E.C. Ganbadan; Carpenter, R.A. Williamson; Gunner, R.H. Cross; Sailmaker, J.A. Stevens; Boatswain, not reported. The ship was formally put in commission on Monday, the 17th inst., and was hauled out into the stream, where she now lies. Acting Rear-Admiral BELL, will be present, with his staff, to hoist the flag in a few days. He resides at Newburgh, on the Hudson.

abstract: ARREST OF A POLICEMAN's WIFE FOR THREATENING TO SHOOT HER HUSBAND's FRIEND. -- Mrs. NAFEN, wife of the officer of that name, was arrested yesterday by Officer EDWARD BROWN, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, and taken before Judge DAILEY. Officer BROWN alleges that Mrs. NAFEN threatened to shoot him for leading her husband into the company of strange women. Both officers belong to the same precinct, and are fast friends. Mrs. NAFEN and her husband have been separated for some time, in consequence, it is alleged, of her intensely jealous disposition. It is further alleged that she was one of the women mainly instrumental in inducing Miss BUGBY to attempt the life of Officer CHICHESTER. Judge DAILEY gave her permission to find bonds to the amount of $500 to keep the peace, but she has not yet returned with the documents.

abstract: Speech of
lead_paragraph: GOV. PERRY, OF SOUTH CAROLINA -- THE DANGER OF MUCH TALK. -- We publish to-day a speech said to have been delivered by Gov. PERRY, at Greenville, S.C., on the 3d of July. Although there are many exceptionable remarks in that speech -- remarks elicited, doubtless, by the temper of Gov. PERRY's audience, we do not think there is anything to excite a suspicion of the Governor's loyalty, or of the perfect good faith with which he purposes to act in his official capacity. It is rather surprising to hear a South Carolina mountaineer like Mr. PERRY -- to say nothing of the delicate office he holds -- declare that "in all history there is not a more perfect model of a pure and great man, (save WASHINGTON,) than ROBERT E. LEE." One would have supposed that a fitter subject for eulogy might have been found by an official who has gained his present position upon the faith placed by the Executive in Mr. PERRY's solemn disclaimers of any sympathy with secession or its advocates. But allowance will be made for the sort of audience the Provisional Governor had before him. What we are more alarmed at than the apparant bent of Mr. PERRY's sentiments, is his extreme volubility.

abstract: Lowell, of Boston, vs. Resolute, of Brooklyn
snippet: Lowell, of Boston, vs. Resolute, of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The Lowell Club, of Roston, arrived in the city at an early hour yesterday morning, and they were met at the depot by a delegation of the Resolute Club, of Brooklyn, whose guests they were yesterday, and by them escorted to the International Hotel in Broadway, which is to be their headquarters during their stay. At noon the party proceeded to the Union Ball-ground, Brooklyn, and at 2:45 began play in a match with the Resolute Club. The Resolutes, on this occasion, had a majority of their nine out, and played one of their best games, both in the field and at the bat. The display on the part of the Lowell nine was excellent in regard to batting, and their fielding, considering the high wind which prevailed, was, in many respects, praiseworthy. There is evidently first-class material in the club, and the practice they will have during their visit will greatly develope it. All who witnessed their play were impressed with the fact that they are as gentlemanly and intelligent a party of ball-players as ever visited the city. To-day they play with the champion Atlantics, at Bedford, and to-morrow their adversaries will be the noted Excelsiors. At the close of the game, yesterday, the Lowell Club was hospitably entertained at the clubhouse, an hour's social enjoyment ending the afternoon's proceedings. We append the score;

abstract: Yesterday Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body of PATRICK BURKE, who died from the effects of injuries received by having one of his feet crushed by a Hudson River Railroad car. On Monday last BURKE attempted to leap from a train as it was passing Fortieth-street, in Eleventh-avenue, and in doing so fell on the track, receiving mortal injuries. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

abstract: Floods in Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers
snippet: Floods in Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers
lead_paragraph: During Sunday afternoon and evening heavy black clouds were seen to the southwest of the city, and toward night our citizens expected to be visited with a heavy rain-storm; but to the surprise of almost every one there was but a slight sprinkle of rain. The clouds seemed to have passed up the Schuylkill some distance west of the river, and when reaching the upper part of the city, about Chestnut Hill, Roxborough, and through that section of country, the rain came down in a perfect flood, washing roads and swelling small streams into angry torrents, which, on reaching the Schuylkill and Wissahickon, carried away houses, bridges, &c.

abstract: During the fiscal year which ended on 30th ulto., it appears, from the official Customhouse returns which we publish in our Money columns this morning, that the New-York market took for actual home consumption foreign merchandise to the value of one hundred and thirty-five millions. The gross im
lead_paragraph: During the fiscal year which ended on 30th ulto., it appears, from the official Customhouse returns which we publish in our Money columns this morning, that the New-York market took for actual home consumption foreign merchandise to the value of one hundred and thirty-five millions. The gross importations were twenty-five millions in excess of this sum, but owing to the high ruling of gold throughout the first and second, and part of the third quarters of the year, our consumers prudently declined to afford so large a market. The consequence was that eighteen millions were reoxported to other than American markets, and the remainder held over in bond.

abstract: Speech at Greenville on the Rebellion
snippet: Speech at Greenville on the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: MR. CHAIRMAN: This public meeting of the citizens of Greenville is one of deep humiliation and sorrow. A cruel and bloody war has swept over the Southern States. One hundred and fifty thousand of our bravest and most gallant men have fallen on the field of battle. The land is filled with mourning widows and orphans. There is scarcely a house in which there has not been weeping for some loved one lost. Three thousand millions of dollars have been spent by the Southern States in carrying on this war. And now we are called upon to give up four millions of slaves, worth two thousand millions of dollars more. Our country has been ravaged and desolated. Our cities, towns and villages are smouldering ruins. Conquering armies occupy the country. The Confederacy has fallen, and we have been deprived of all civil government and political rights. We have neither law nor order. There is no protection of life, liberty or property. Everywhere there is demoralization, rapine and murder. Hunger and starvation are upon us. And now we meet as a disgraced and subjugated people, to petition the conqueror to restore our lost rights. Such are the bitter fruits of secession!

abstract: MICHAEL KINSLER, a returned soldier, No. 39 Madison-street, entered a complaint of robbery against THOMAS McSHERRY. KINSLER alleges that on the night of the l3th inst. he met McSHERRY in a porter-house at the intersection of King and Varick streets. After drinking together they left...
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL KINSLER, a returned soldier, No. 39 Madison-street, entered a complaint of robbery against THOMAS MCSHERRY. KINSLER alleges that on the night of the l3th inst. he met MCSHERRY in a porter-house at the intersection of King and Varick streets. After drinking together they left the saloon, when MCSHERRY assaulted KINSLER, brutally beating him. Two confederates joined MCSHERRY, and the three robbed the soldier, after rendering him insensible by their violence. On recovering his consciousness, KINSLER found that he had been robbed of $134, the thieves having cut his pocket from his pantaloons. Since the time of his assault, KINSLER has been suffering from his injuries. He gave Officer JAY, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, a description of MCSHERRY, and yesterday that officer arrested him. KINSLER positively identified the prisoner as his assailant. Justice DODGE committed thh accused for trial without bail.

abstract: Atlantic Telegraph; C. W. Field's Information, >amp;c.
snippet: Atlantic Telegraph; C. W. Field's Information, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: POSTPONEMENT OF THE CABLE-LAYING. -- The first announcement of the time for commencing the second attempt to lay the Atlantic Telegraph, fixed the date for the early part of June. Subsequently, it was postponed to the end of the month. Later still, it was put off to the 10th of July. Now, it is further adjourned to the 15th. There is not much satisfaction in this style of taking the public into confidence. Every rational person is prepared to wait until the carrying-ship can be got ready, and everything is put in proper order, even if it takes another year to reach the desired result. What is the use, then, in fixing dates, when everything is thus far uncertain concerning the line except the company's advertised tariff?

abstract: THE CITY RAILROAD TRAFFIC YESTERDAY. -- We will do the "east-side" City Railroad Companies the justice to say that they did, yesterday, all they possibly could, with the means at their disposal, to accommodate the vast, moving throng of passengers attracted up town by the German Singing Festival. But, after doing all they could, the companies -- we speak specially of the Third and Second avenue lines -- were unable to offer even a half decent conveyance to more than half the intending holiday-makers. We must have more and better outlets for the population that crowds northward, to the upper part of the island, in Summer, every day, and at all hours, in search of a breath of free air. The present accommodation -- possibly from no fault of the railroad proprietors -- is fast becoming a mockery.

abstract: Vessels in British Ports
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL LAW. -- The British Government continues to discuss the late American war, and the questions growing out of it with the French Government. The results jointly arrived at, or at least some of them, are communicated to the American Government Earl RUSSELL, it now seems, has authoritatively pronounced the opinion that vessels formerly belonging to the Southern Confederacy, and not lawfully transferred to other owners before the total cessation of hostilities, may be claimed as public property by the United States, if found in any British waters; and any counter claim must be decided in ordinary course of law by the civil tribunals. To the British Minister at Washington Earl RUSSELL writes that an enemy's commissioned ships-of-war cannot, during the continuance of war, be relieved from risk of capture and condemnation by any sale or transfer to a neutral.

abstract: A very interesting submarine experiment, which gives every promise of success, is now being made in the Missippi River, below New-Orleans. Our readers will remember that the United States gunboat Varuna, at the time of the fleet attack apon Forts Jackson and St. Phillip, safely ran the gauntlet of the forts and followed in chase of one of the Confederate gunboats. One mile above Quarantine a ball from the latter struck the Varuna, sinking her almost immediately.

abstract: We had the pleasure this morning of grasping the hand of Major-Gen. FRANK J. HERRON, who arrived in this city on Wednesday night, and is stopping at the St. Charles Hotel. The General, we are happy to say, is in good health, and looks remarkably well. He is accompanied by Surgeon O.M. HUMPHREYS, Lieut. A. RAYBURN, A.A.Q.M., Lieut. WM.H. GLADWIN, A.C.M., and Capt. E.E. SHELTON, C.S., all of his staff. The party left Shreveport on Monday last, and arrived here on Wednesday evening, making the quickest trip on record.

abstract: Since the arrival of the Federal troops, Galveston has been perfectly quiet and orderly. The troops are under strict discipline, and observe, as well as enforce, good order. Neither the officers nor men show, in their manner toward our citizens or the late soldiers of the Confederacy, any of the oppressive airs which are supposed to characterize the conqueror in his demeanor toward the vanquished. The conduct of all the parties are reciprocally respectful.

abstract: New-York vs. Newark
lead_paragraph: A much larger attendance of spectators were present on the Bedford Cricket Grounds yesterday than on the day previous, the rain of Monday morning having deferred a crowd front visiting the grounds. The contest was resumed at 12:50, BRYAN and CASSIDY taking their places at the bat again. As both were in good trim, and in play another fine display at the bat was looked for, but after a few overs had been received from HALLIS and KIDD it was at once seen that the increased liveliness of the ground had proportionally improved the bowling and great care was needed in defence off the wickets. HALLIS especially being well on the spot all the time, and bowling very wickedly. BYRON had played him neatly for a couple of single's, when on facing KIDD he gave a chance to BULLIS at slip which was of course taken, and BYRON retired for the splendid total of 75, the highest made in this country for many years past, HUDSON's 85 being the only one that has excelled it for the past nine years. After he had retired, the other wickets soon followed, the interest in the match being pretty much ended, the last wicket going down for 184. At 1:40 NEWMARK went to the bat for the second time, and 76 had been added to their score when the innings closed, thus requiring New-York to go in again for 4 runs, which they obtained before a wicket bad fallen, the final result being then settled with ten wickets to fall. The full score below gives all other particulars.

abstract: BROADWAY CITY RAILROAD TERMINUS. -- We trust that the suggestion which we made a few days since, to erect a railroad terminus on the site of the late American Museum, will receive the attention which the subject deserves. Such a building would be a great public convenience, and much facilitate the business of the companies themselves. The evils attending the present arrangement are notorious, and will be a positive discredit, unless the present opportunity is embraced. As a source of pecuniary profit to the companies there can be no doubt of the success of the plan, and a great eye-sore in the most crowded part of the city would be removed.

abstract: BUTTER. -- We are reminded that in spite of causes which should make butter exceedingly cheap, the price does not give way. The great supply available is beyond all question, and the only reason for the present rates extorted in the city is that the public submit to them. So luxuriant has been the supply of grass this season, that in many localities cheese-making began two weeks earlier than usual; a fact which speaks volumes on the ability to supply butter as reasonably as four years since. The public must combine against combinations, or, depend upon it, the cost of all kinds of food will be permanently enhanced.

abstract: On Saturday night a ball was given in Brownsville by Federal officers -- whether or not in honor of the staff officers of CORTINA, we don't know -- but such officers were prominently in attendance at the ball. No liquor was allowed at the ball, but all, notwithstanding, got decidedly mellow. One of CORTINA's officers, richly attired, but without his coat, did not like the style of dancing, and undertook to change the "rule and figure work" to something better adapted to his taste. To this end he requested a senorita not to dance with the Yankees. This fact being made known to the officers of negro regiments, one of them drew a pistol, and with it knocked CORTINA's chief staff officer entirely off his pins. A general muss came very near ensuing, but it ended in loud and long-drawn curses, without further demonstration of a knock-down character. Whether the knocking down of CORTINA's chief of staff in the house of his friends will affect certain stealing transactions along the Rio Grande, remains to be seen.

abstract: A fearful hurricane occurred at the Cape of Good Hope on the 17th of May. The English mail steamer Athens, from Mauritius, was totally lost, and seventeen other vessels were wrecked. Seventy lives were lost in Table Bay.

abstract: Sheep for Texas and New-Orleans
lead_paragraph: As good mutton as was ever brought to market was sold yesterday morning at 20 cents per pound. Beef, of as good quality, was sold at 30 cents per pound. Now, as good mutton is usually in as good demand and as much sought after as beef, we were a little surprised at this disparity of prices. We were soon, however, enlighted on the subject by a beef butcher, who informed us that the decline in the price of mutton was due to the fact that large droves were on their way to the city from Texas. This intelligence has already reached us from persons who have recently come from the great grazing State. The practibility of driving sheep such a great distance has been fully proved by experience. Three years ago, large droves of sheep were driven to this city from the Rio Grande, and the sheep arrived here in better condition than when they left. They are driven across a country which, at this season of the year, is one great, rich meadow, with frequent ponds of fresh water and salt lakes and marshes, and thus, by easy marches and careful herding, arrive here in much better condition than the poor, imprisoned, crowded inmates of steamboats and flatboats which get nothing to eat on their voyage but dry hay. What is thus done with sheep, may also be done with beef cattle; and these droves of sheep, at least, will prove the avant courriers of like droves of the fine, fat and deliciously flavored beeves from the musquit pastures of Texas. The disbandment of the armies will throw a great many people into this business, and herding and cattle driving promises to be one of the most flourishing occupations in the Southwest. Its success and increase will produce two effects of great value and importance to our city. The first is the augmentation of the wealth and great development of the resources of a State with whose progress and advancement our city is closely identified; and the second is the assurance that our markets will be well supplied with the great essentials of subsistence, at reasonable prices. These prices ought to be lower than in any other city in the Union, as no other community will have so easy and cheap an access to so great a source of supply. The greatest need now of New-Orleans is cheap subsistence, which will offer temptation to emigration, and encouragement of labor and industry, and prevent that great obstacle to our city's progress in population and wealth, to wit: the expensiveness of living, and the consequent tendency of certain classes of our population to remove to other parts of the country, where, though their labor may not be so remunerative, the cost of living is so much lower.

abstract: The Price of; On Demand and Supply
snippet: The Price of; On Demand and Supply
lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK TIMES is slaughtering the butchers and milkmen, whom it charges with keeping up the price of meat and milk. These people make all the money they can, but they can no more control the prices of the articles they deal in than they can reverse the movements of the tides, or make the trunk of a tree grow into the earth instead of out of it. Prices are permanently controlled by the law of supply and demand, and the Editor of the TIMES would be about as sensibly employed in abusing the chickens for the present scarcity and dearness of eggs, as to berate the milkmen and butchers for the price of milk and meat. One would suppose from reading the TIMES that all the butcher-boys and old women who owned cows had entered into an oath-bound conspiracy to rob the people of this fair realm. It is quite absurd to complain of high prices. The tremendous debt we have incurred in this war settles that question for the present generation. Appeals such as those of the TIMES, to a low order of intelligence and to vulgar prejudices, might do well enough in a rural journal, but are quite out of place in a metropolitan newspaper. -- World.

abstract: The premises of MICHAEL MANTEL, in the rear of No. 77 Forsyth-street, were entered by burglars on Tuesday night, who stole a valise containing clothing and other property. Officer JEPHSON, of the Tenth Precinct, subsequently saw two suspicious-looking men carrying a valise through the Bowery, near Canal-street. The officer asked them what they were carrying, when they started to run away. He seized the one having the valise, when a desperate struggle ensued. The officer knocked the man down twice before he was able to take him to the station-house, where he gave his name as JAMES GORDON. Justice SHANDLEY committed him for examination. From a letter in the valise it was ascertained that the property belonged to MANTEL.

abstract: The steamer Africa arrived yesterday at Halifax, with three days later intelligence from Europe. She brings advice that the Great Eastern was to sail from Valentia Bay on the 19th inst., and would probably arrive on this side about the 1st of August. The cholera was making great ravages in Egypt. A correspondence has taken place between France and England in reference to the cessation of the war between the North and South; and Earl RUSSELL has addressed a note to Sir F. BRUCE, British Minister at Washington, on the subject of the capture and condemnation of insurgent commissioned vessels of war. The political news from the continent is not especially important.

abstract: On Thursday, July 6, about 7 o'clock, a steam boiler at the coal mine of Mr. WILLIAM REEVES, near Reed's Station, on the Belleville and East St. Louis, Mo., Railroad, exploded, causing the death of the engineer, named WILLIAM KENICKER, in the most horrible manner.
lead_paragraph: -- On Thursday, July 6, about 7 o'clock, a steam boiler at the coal mine of Mr. WILLIAM REEVES, near Reed's Station, on the Belleville and East St. Louis, Mo., Railroad, exploded, causing the death of the engineer, named WILLIAM KENICKER, in the most horrible manner. The explosion of the boiler was caused by a defect, and made a fissure about a foot in length by an inch wide, through which the scalding water and steam escaped, rushing full against the engineer, who was sitting about ten feet distant, knocking him into a shaft hole, into which the stream of escaping water and steam from the boiler was pouring. The unfortunate man struggled out of the hole and crawled out of the building, the flesh being torn off his hands and knees in the endeavor. He managed to walk a short distance and sat down on a doorstep, asking a bystander to pull off his boots, after which he walked to his boarding-house, where he received every attention that kindness and medical skill could bestow upon him, but death came to his relief about 3 o'clock.

abstract: Markets and Prices this Week
lead_paragraph: -- There were 5,449 cattle brought to New-York this week, and this number is a very ample supply; in fact, only 3,765 were sold. Prices were, however, about the same. Last week prices rose upon the false pretext that there was a short supply. This week the rise is maintained because, as it would seem, the supply is ample. Of Sheep last week there were 13,215, and this week there are 17,500. In sheep, also, there is a slight rise. Now there are, every one knows, a set of men who intercept the droves and flocks, and thus interpose a speculative price before they can reach the consumer. The system is very bad and ought not to be tolerated. Every butcher says it is the forestallers who keep up prices; but, we submit, the forestallers would have a considerable less inducement to continue their trade if the public refused to be fleeced.

abstract: Retirement and High Reputation of
lead_paragraph: Gen. JOHN A. DIX has closed his labors as commander of this department, and has been succeeded by Gen. HOOKER. During the period of Gen. DIX's semi-military labors here, he has so acted and so borne himself as to command the profound respect of the entire body of our citizens. The appointment, in the first place, was one peculiarly fitting. Gen. DIX not only had a national reputation as a statesman and administrator, but his long public career in the city and State had at once made him widely known to our citizens, and thoroughly familiar with our local affairs. His bearing and action as commander of the department have been singularly free from assumption, from arbitrary and dictatorial conduct and from intemperate measures; and have been characterized by dignity, suavity, and a spirit of moderation and conciliation. There have been many difficult cases and questions to deal with, such as the St. Albans raiders, the Lake pirates, the rebel incendiaries, the drafts and innumerable matters of administration; but Gen. DIX has dealt with them in such a manner as to secure at once popular satisfaction and the approval of the government; and in but one instance (viz: his order to pursue the raiders into Canada) has his course been modified by the President. Prior to administering the affairs of the Department of the East, with his headquarters in this city, Gen. DIX was in command of the Middle Department, with his headquarters at Baltimore; and the energy and wisdom he has displayed here were also of the highest efficiency and value then and there. Prior to that time again, in more strictly military service at Fortress Monroe, he approved himself a true soldier. In short, from the time of his ever-memorable order at the opening of the war, to shoot upon the spot any man who tore down the American flag, until the close of the rebellion, our distinguished fellow-citizen has done himself honor by honoring his country.

abstract: An ancient writer, whose language is even now dead to the common sight of men, once wrote these words: "It is a pleasure to stand upon the shore, and to see ships tossed upon the sea; a pleasure to stand in the window of a castle, and to see a battle, and the adventures thereof, below; but no pleasure is comparable to the standing upon the vantage-ground of truth, and to see the errors, and wanderings, and mists, and tempests, in the vale below." Something of this must be fell by Mr. Jay Cooke, as he sees the comments excited by the publication now before the world, prepared by Samuel Wilkeson, but bearing the great Financier's sanction. It is not often the lot of man to be the first to stand up and declare a truth; nor is it given to the multitude to be able to see truth" when it comes to them. This is beautifully illustrated in our recent history. When Mr. Sumner said, ten years ago, that freedom was national and slavery sectional, all the world but Massachusetts laughed; for slavery sat upon a throne, and gave evidences of power, and declared that her scepter should be borne to Bunker Hill. When Mr. Douglas anticipated universal suffrage by declaring in favor of popular sovereignty, men did not see the truth that was speaking through the lips of the politician, and making itself manifest amid many false surroundings. Truth is not always agreeable to men who have found error pleasant -- but in the end it reigns. We might as well call the dead from the grave and bid them speak to us, as to attempt the reestablishment of slavery in America, or serfdom in Russia, or the reign of Louis XIV. in France, or the Corn Laws in England. And yet, in their day, all those issues were living elements of society.

abstract: On Wednesday, the 12th inst., a pale, neatlyattired young woman, of engaging address and attractive person, applied for board at Mrs. WORCESTER'S private lying-in hospital, in Hudson-street, four doors above Charles. Her appearance being that of an invalid who had long suffered under chronic infirmity, and as she had but a pittance to spare, Mrs. WORCESTER thought it not prudent to admit her; but at ...
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the 12th inst., a pale, neatly-attired young woman, of engaging address and attractive person, applied for board at Mrs. WORCESTER's private lying-in hospital, in Hudson-street, four doors above Charles. Her appearance being that of an invalid who had long suffered under chronic infirmity, and as she had but a pittance to spare, Mrs. WORCESTER thought it not prudent to admit her; but at length she was prevailed upon to take the stranger in, and a room was assigned her under the pseudonym of MARY BROWS. She did not pretend that this was not a fictitious name, but said, in response to every question touching her real name, "You may call me MARY BROWN." Taking a cramped but not unpleasant room on the third-story, the unknown locked herself within, and there, reticent and pensive, sat from dawn until dusk, and admitted only the female physician to whom she had come in her extremity. But even to this woman, to whom she must unavoidably communicate something of her history, she revealed nothing beyond the fact that the man to whom she gave her trust in girlhood bad within eight years frequently placed her in the hands of physicians whose names she declined to disclose, and that this was her seventh errand abroad to seek temporary shelter under a stranger's roof. She had never been guilty of infidelity to the man who ought to have made her a wife, but as he had persistently refused to acknowledge the paternity of her offspring, it had thus often become necessary to destroy the evidence of her imprudence. Who this man is, where he dwells, and what are his pecuniary circumstances and social standing, his faithful, unfortunate victim only knew; but that he is a person of opulence does not seem probable, since the poor woman had only $30 when she first appeared at Mrs. WORCESTER's, and her habit, though rich and fashionable, was yet far from such as the mistress of a man of wealth might be supposed to wear, She had no jewelry, not even a ring.

abstract: About 4 o'clock yesterday morning a serious disturbance occurred at the Williamsburgh ferry. It appears that only one ferry master was on duty, and he was in Williamsburgh; so that passengers from this city might go on the boat, (the Superior,) but were expected to pay on the other side. Four young men who came from New-York refused to pay after crossing over, and attacked the ferry hands, and beat them in a brutal manner before the arrival of the police. After the police arrived, the fight was continued with redoubled energy on the part of the rioters. Pistols and clubs were freely used on both sides, and the rioters received a severe pummelling, two of them being so severely injured that they were sent to the Hospital for treatment. Officers MCFARLAND and CODNER, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, succeeded, after a most desperate struggle, in taking the rioters into custody.

abstract: John Boyle, a very dandily dressed youngman, of about 25 years of age, who describes himself as a bartender, was charged with assaulting Mary Lee. The case was called a week ago, and the complainant did not appear; but the papers showed that a gross ...
lead_paragraph: John Boyle, a very dandily dressed youngman, of about 25 years of age, who describes himself as a bartender, was charged with assaulting Mary Lee. The case was called a week ago, and the complainant did not appear; but the papers showed that a gross outrage had been committed, and an order was made to compel her appearance. As the prisoner stood at the bar with half an ounce of "solace" in his cheek, while at the same time he played with his teeth and a quill, he bowed very gracefully to the court, squirted out about a pint of tobacco-juice; and said "Very well, Sir," when the court decided that the complainant must come into court or withdraw the complaint. When the witness came into court yesterday one eye was still very black.

abstract: Significant Eagerness for; Statistics of from Europe
snippet: Significant Eagerness for; Statistics of from Europe
lead_paragraph: The pressure of rebel Generals, rebel Congressmen, rebel officials of all sorts upon the President for pardon strikingly shows the slight hold their cause had upon their moral convictions. There is such a thing as facing exile or even death itself sooner than renounce principle, or bend the knee to its enemy. History abounds with instances of men who staked their all upon some great revolutionary effort for the good of their country; who did not suffer even the most crushing defeat to shake their devotion, and were proud to testify it by courting any extremity of fate. Such men have gone to the scaffold, or lain immured for years in subterranean dungeons, sooner than recant their principles, and put themselves in the position of suppliants before the power they had combatted. Often, when even no terms whatever were imposed, when a complete unconditional pardon was tendered, all grace has been spurned. Eight years ago the French Emperor proclaimed an absolute amnesty to all the proscribed enemies of his dynasty. He required no oath, attached no condition. Yet there are hundreds who, like VICTOR HUGO and LOUIS BLANC, prefer to live in perpetual exile from the France they love so well, rather than discredit their principles by taking any boon from an imperial hand. From every oppressed nation and nationality in Europe, there are exiles in this country, who are here solely because they consider that fidelity to their principles requires it.

abstract: Mr. CHARLES SUTTON, the well-known Warden of the Tombs, has been removed by the commissioners, and Mr. JAMES E. COULTER is appointed in his place. Mr. SUTTON's experience, judgment, and information were invaluable to the city, and his services, while warden of the prison, were such as fully warranted the high popular reputation which he sustained. Ever kind and considerate to the people confined, he was a strict disciplinarian and a thorough master of the situation. Many a poor devil has thanked him, with tears of gratitude in his eyes, for kind words of encouragement and a little timely assistance; and the opportunities of doing good, which so continually presented themselves, were never allowed to pass unimproved. We understand that Mr. SUTTON's successor is a man of intelligence and shrewd judgment, and we can only express the desire that he will prove as thoroughly fitted for the duties of his sphere as was Mr. SUTTON.

abstract: Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday over the body of MIS. FRANCIS MILLER, the young woman whose throat was out by her husband, at her abode, in Canal-street, in May last. The jury found that she died of "acute peritonitis, dependent upon a perforating ulcer of the ilium intestine." The husband was arrested, recently, and committed by Coroner Gover to the Tombs, to await the result of the wife's injuries, and last week the wife had so far recovered as to be able to make an affidavit against him; but she subsequently suffered a relapse, and died on Wednesday, It now remains to be seen for what MILLER is to be tried, or whether he is to be released under the foregoing verdict. Mrs. MILLER was a native of Germany, 17 years of age.
