abstract: Brooklyn Navy-yard frauds
lead_paragraph: -- HOW WORKMEN ARE EMPLOYED AND WHAT THEY DO. -- An interesting state of facts was developed yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON in relation to operations in the Navy-yard. Some time since JOHN MAXON, JOHN R. MARSDEN, WM. MCDERMOTT and FRANCIS RILEY were arrested on the charge of defrauding the government by carrying off several thousand dollars worth of manufactured material. They all occupy prominent positions in the mechanical departments of the yard. JOSEPH ANDERSON, of No. 137 South First-street, E.D., was the only witness examined. His testimony shows that he was employed in the pattern shop under MCDERMOTT and MARSDEN in 1861, and continued until 1864 or 1865, (he is not certain what year,) when he was discharged. When he commenced work MCDERMOTT was master boiler-maker, and MAXON master pattern-maker. MARSDEN came there in 1861, in place of MCDERMOTT. Witness was employed in making patterns for machinery, and also in making four book-cases and three tool-chests. He commenced this work in the Fall of 1863, and they were finished in the Summer of 1864. The material used in their manufacture was mahogany and black walnut. The book-cases were gothic finished, sash-doors, carved and otherwise ornamented. Each case had four sections which, when put together, made a case 8 feet high, 5 feet wide and 20 inches deep. They were manufactured in the top loft of the pattern-shop, in a room on one end of the building which had been partitioned off before the cases were commenced. The room was 14 by 12 feet in extent. Previous to this time the room had been accessible to all the workmen, but after the work on the drawers was commenced it was kept locked by direction of Mr. MCDERMOTT. The time employed in manufacturing the book-cases was about two years, several men being occupied on them. The actual time occupied was about one year. MARSDEN and MCDERMOTT were in the habit of visiting the rooms, and the latter gave directions every time he came. The materials for the cases came from the lumber-room attached to the pattern shop. It was of the best quality. The screws were procured from the office of the pattern shop. No nails were used. Two of the cases were of mahogany, and two of black walnut. During the time witness and another man, named NOYES, were working on the cases the door was kept locked. Access was gained by knocking three times on the door. While witness was working in the room nothing else but the cases were made there. Received $2 50 per day from the government. Beside witness, two men, named HARRIS and SEYMOUR, or SEAMAN, worked on the cases. HARRIS did the carving, at which ho was engaged six months, and SEYMOUR put the locks on and did other work on the drawers. Three tool chests were made at the time the cases were made. They were of black walnut. Some three weeks were spent in their manufacture. They were worth $75 each, without the tools, and were afterwards fitted up with tools such as mechanics seldom use, because they are so costly. Witness saw two of the chests in MARSDEN's office, and one was taken down stairs. The book-cases cost from $500 to $600 each. They could have been made outside for from $300 to $400. All work costs more in the yard than outside. Sometimes a man gets a hint (the witness testified) not to do more than he can help. On his cross-examination, witness acknowledged having also made a tool-chest and small work-chest for himself. The three tool-chests were made for Messrs. MARSDEN, MAXON and MCDERMOTT. The above is the substance of Mr. ALEXANDER's testimony. The examination was then adjourned until this morning.

abstract: Building in New-York
lead_paragraph: The Commercial Chronicle takes up the subject of house-building, and the great want of houses in New-York for business people of small incomes, and mechanics and others with limited wages, upon which we have frequently written of late. We think, however, it makes a great mistake in arguing that what are needed most are small houses, to be occupied by single families. Houses of such a character are perfectly adapted to small towns, or to the suburbs of large cities, where there is room for unlimited expansion. But in a great city like this, located on a small island -- in a place where land is of such great value -- in a community where time is of so much importance -- in a society where there is such a great proportion of industrious but poorly-paid workers -- it would neither be convenient nor profitable to have large spaces covered by small, "self-contained" cottages. The population of our island is now over a million, and by 1880 it will almost certainly be three times as great; and to accommodate this vast mass of human beings decently and economically, we must have blocks of compact yet commodious houses, of from three to five stories in height. Those who are worst off for accommodations now are small traders and mechanics and others, whose earnings are from twelve to twenty dollars a week. Even at the cheapest rates possible for rents on this island, considering the price of real estate, the cost of labor and material, and the value of capital, those people, in single families, could not afford to rent even small cottages; and yet we see no reason why there should not be provided for their use commodious, ample, wholesome apartments, in which families could be reared in health, virtue and intelligence.

abstract: Free Academy Alumni Meeting
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the Alumni of the New-York Free Academy took place in the large hall of the Academy building, last evening. The President of the Alumni Association, Mr. E.P. WHEELER, being absent in Europe, Prof. RODNEY G. KIMBALL, of the State Normal School, was, on motion, appointed to preside. Mr. JAMES KNOX acted as Secretary. The minutes of the last annual Alumni meeting were read and approved. The Constitution of the Alumni Association was then read and signed by such of the class of the present year as desired to join the association. Reports from the committees appointed last year were then read. The first was from the Executive Committee of 1864-5, who reported in favor of erecting tablets in the Academy to such of the graduates as had fallen in battle during the late war.

lead_paragraph: OF THIS CITY -- HEARING UPON A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS IN BOSTON. -- It will be recollected that some weeks since two men, named JOSEPH LUCAS and CHARLES T. DODGE, were arrested in the town of Haverhill by Constable J. BURNHAM of that town, upon suspicion of having stolen government bonds from parties then unknown. Six 7-30 bonds of the denomination of $1,000, which they had attempted to sell, were found upon them. After their arrest, the officer learned that VERMILYE & CO., No. 44 Wall-street, New-York, the day before their arrest, had been robbed of eight $500 7-30 bonds and six $1,000 bonds, and that those found upon the arrested men corresponded with the stolen ones. Constable BURNHAM then complained of the men, charging them with the robbery, and they were taken to Lawrence for examination.

abstract: Lord BROUGHAM recently said in Parliament that he wished to correct a misapprehension which some of his friends from the United States had told him might have an unfortunate result in lessening the influence, such as it might be, of that earnest remonstrance which he had addressed to the United States, imploring them to exercise moderation and mercy in the hour of their great victory.
lead_paragraph: -- Lord BROUGHAM recently said in Parliament that he wished to correct a misapprehension which some of his friends from the United States had told him might have an unfortunate result in lessening the influence, such as it might be, of that earnest remonstrance which he had addressed to the United States, imploring them to exercise moderation and mercy in the hour of their great victory. It would be utterly absurd to charge him who thirty years ago abandoned the gift of a large plantation in Barbados, and an estate in the county of Durham, because he would not forsake the cause of emancipation, and his fellow laborers in that cause, with taking the part of the slavemongers of the South. While he accorded every praise to the North for their conduct in reference to the abolition of the slave-trade, and for granting to all nations the right of search, he did not believe, as many good men did both in this country and on the other side of the Atlantic, that the emancipation of the slaves was pronounced for the benefit of the slaves themselves, but as a measure intended to harass the South. His remarks, however, at the Social Science Congress at York last Autumn to this effect, had been cited, without also quoting what he had stated on the same occasion, that the South were partly fighting for the maintenance of their detestable institution. He could not help feeling that any one who kept aloof in affairs of this kind, and treated matters as they were, was exposed to the misrepresentations of both sides.

abstract: Mr. JAMES MCKENNA, of No. 148 Sullivan-street, entered Mr. A. DETTMER's grocery, at No. 233 Thompson-street, yesterday morning, and there fell asleep, only the proprietor's son, AUGUSTUS G. DETTMER, and an unknown man, being in the store at the time. After awhile Mr. JAMES S. WILLIAMS, brother-in-law of young DETTMER, entered and woke Mr. MCKENNA, telling him that that was not a place wherein he might sleep, and bidding him go home. Mr. MCKENNA inquired where young DETTMER had gone, and on searching his pockets, missed his wallet, containing $85, and when he made known his loss, the unknown man departed. Mr. MCKENNA at once called in Patrolman JOHN S. JONES, and caused the arrest of young DETTMER, and that person, upon Mr. KENNA's complaint, was committed for examination. Mr. DETTMER, Sr., is a man of wealth and high standing, and the prisoner, whose unimpeached character ought to shield him, had no temptation that could have induced him to commit an offence of the kind alleged.

abstract: The old proverb of "Circumstances after cases," had a spicy illustration the other day at a Boston hotel, and two parties, one from the city, and the other of Boston, participated therein. A young man, who is the least bit feminine in his appearance, parting his hair in the middle, etc., went to Boston, and while in that city, taken with a severe fit of colie. Stopping at a hotel, he put himself to bed, and sent for a physician. The doctor came, felt of his patriot's pulse, examined his stomach and inquired solemnly if his habits were "regular;" to which the young man, somewhat surprised, answered in the affirmative. The Doctor then cautiously and politely informed his patient that his symptoms manifested some probabilities of an increase of the census in a short time. The surprise of the colic-stricken young man at this singular announcement was only equaled by that of the Doctor when he discovered the true sex of his patient. "Circumstances after cases," always. -- Springfield Union.

abstract: Degree of LL. D. Conferred on
snippet: Degree of LL. D. Conferred on
lead_paragraph: -- Harvard has conferred the degree of LL.D. upon Maj.-Gen. MEADE, and those journals which a short time since ridiculed other institutions of learning for bestowing similar honors on other Generals, will now probably bring their batteries to bear on Harvard. If any one, however, deserves the title, Gen. MEADE is the man. The rebels at least will class him with GRANT, SHERMAN and SHERIDAN, as having "doctored the laws" pretty effectually, so far as they are concerned during the last four years.

abstract: Right Rev. ALONZO POTTER, D.D., LL.D., Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Pennsylvania, and brother of Bishop POTTER, of the Episcopal Diocese of New-York, died in San Francisco, Cal., on the 4th inst., in the sixty-fifth year of his age. Bishop POTTER was born in Dutchess County, in this State, July 10, 1800. He graduated at Union College in 1818, became tutor in 1819, and was elected Professor of Mathematics and natural philosophy in 1821. Studying for the ministry, he was ordained deacon in 1821, and priest in 1824. In 1825 he was elected President of the College at Geneva, but declined the post. In 1826 he become rector of St. Paul's, in Boston, where he remained until 1831, when he was elected Vice-President and Professor of moral Philosophy in Union College. His degrees of D.D. he received at Harvard and Gambier, and that of LL.D. at Union. He was consecrated Bishop of Pennsylvania in September, 1845. Bishop POTTER married a daughter of President NOTT for his first wife. She died some years ago. Just prior to his departure for California, a few weeks since, the Bishop was married again. Bishop POTTER was the author of several books, one of which, A Hand-book for Readers and Students, had a wide circulation and great popularity among young men engaged in study. He was a vigorous writer and an eloquent speaker, and was justly held in high esteem in the large church of which he was so conspicuosly a prelate, and by the scholars and thinking men of the country. Three of Bishop POTTER's sons, Gen. ROBERT B. POTTER, CLARKSON A. POTTER, Esq., HOWARD POTTER, of the firm of BROWN BROS., are conspicuous in professional and commercial life in this city.

abstract: -- FREDERICK ZELLER was taken to the New-York Hospital, having fallen through a hatchway on the fifth story of No. 4 Howard-street. Dr. JOHNSON attended him, and ascertained that the frontal bone of the skull and the left arm had been fractured....On Wednesday afternoon, a press broke down at Messrs. BEARD & CUMMINGS' warehouse, No. 279 Front-street, and MICHAEL LYNCH'S left leg was crushed. Policeman GEORGE F. DUNBAR took him to the New-York Hospital, and amputation of the limb was recommended, but the mother would not consent, and the boy lingered until yesterday morning, when Dr. BUCK took the limb off, that being the only chance of saving life....A most unskilful Surgeon thrust compressed sponge into a gunshot wound in RICHARD FENTON's knee on the 4th instant, FENTON having been accidentally wounded at Bayonne, N.J. This distended the knee-joint to its utmost capacity and threatened the limb. FENTON therefore went to the New-York Hospital, and the sponge was removed yesterday by Dr. JOHNSON.

abstract: The Fifth New-York Cavalry, (Ira Harris,) 517 men, Col. A. WHITE, commanding, arrived at the Battery Barracks yesterday morning, from Winchester, Va, and proceeded to Hart's Island, where they will be paid off. The Fifth was recruited in this city in the Summer of 1861, and was encamped on Staten Island for several weeks, where the men were thoroughly drilled.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth New-York Cavalry, (Ira Harris,) 517 men, Col. A. WHITE, commanding, arrived at the Battery Barracks yesterday morning, from Winchester, Va, and proceeded to Hart's Island, where they will be paid off. The Fifth was recruited in this city in the Summer of 1861, and was encamped on Staten Island for several weeks, where the men were thoroughly drilled. On taking the field the regiment was one of the best equipped and best disciplined in the army, and has always done efficient service.

abstract: JAMES DALY, of the United States steamer Alabama, with an old shipmate, accompanied LEWIS and FANNY LIGHT to their saloon, in Allen-street, yesterday afternoon, and having drank their compounds, styled brandy, wine, and cordial, fell asleep, and was robbed of $181. The keepers of the place, when he awoke and demanded his money, professed profound ignorance of any robbery, and he thereupon called in Policeman RICHARD S. KING and had them taken to court. They were committed for examination.

abstract: The Montreal papers publish the resignation of O.S. WOOD, Manager of the Montreal Telegraph, whose letter to United States Consul POTTER, regarding the Reciprocity Treaty, caused such a sensation in Canada. Addressing the president and directors, he says: "I believe you are fully aware that during my long connection with the Montreal Telegraph Company I have scrupulously abstained from all participation in political affairs, and I can only now express my deep regret that I should have departed from that course on the present occasion. With this frank explanation which my own self-respect, no less than my duty to you, impels me to offer, I beg to place my resignation at your disposal.

abstract: Mutual vs. Empire
lead_paragraph: The return game of the match between these two New-York Clubs, was played at Hoboken yesterday, resulting in a victory for the Mutuals, by a score of 26 to 15, in a full game of about three hours duration, which gives the match to the Mutuals. Both clubs had their first nines out, placed in the same position as in their previous game, but neither played up to their usual high mark. This was particularly the case with the Mutuals, MCSWEENEY's fine pitching not being supported well enough to make it effective. BROWN led the score on the side of the Mutuals, marking his first bat by a home run. MARTIN's slow twisters bothered the Mutuals a little at first, and WESTERVELT took several fly balls in his usual manner. The game was witnessed by from three to five thousand spectators -- a goodly number of ladies being present. The following is the score:

abstract: New-York, Pearl-street, No. 264; ribbons, $1,700
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night Mr. WILLIAM G. TOMPKINS' dry-goods store, at No. 546 Pearl-street, was entered by three burglars, who forced a rear window and stole black silk-velvet ribbons of the value of $1,700, with which they escaped. Mrs. MARY MCCREA, whose abode is opposite Mr. TOMPKINS' store, saw the three burglars go thence with the goods, and described the fellows with minuteness, and, acting upon the information thus obtained, Capt. JOURDAN arrested four persons, one of whom -- HENRY DIBET, of No. 138 Sixth-avenue, a returned soldier -- was identified by Mrs. MCCREA, as having been of the party that committed the burglary. DIBET was committed for trial at the Court of General Sessions, and the other prisoners were held for examination. Capt. JOURDAN has been unable, thus far, to find the ribbons.

abstract: A decision has recently been rendered by Judge DENIO, of the Court of Appeals, to the effect that this city is not liable for damages to property caused by the elements in districts where sewers have not been constructed by the authorities. The leading case bearing upon this subject was brought before the Kings County Circuit Court some three years since. The plaintiffs were JOHN H. MILLS and ISAAC DEAN, who brought an action against the City of Brooklyn, to recover $2,500 for damages to building owned by them on the corner of Franklin and Putnam avenues. The trial took place before Judge SCRUGHAM and a jury. It appears that the building was Hooded on the occasion of several violent rain storms in the Fall of 1861, and was considerably injured. It not being practicable to carry out the permanent plan of sewerage in the vicinity, a temporary sewer was built in April, 1851, which proved insufficient to carry off the immense volume of surface water that flows down Franklin-avenue after a heavy rain. The plaintiffs based their claim upon the negligence and improvidence of the city authorities in not providing a sufficient sewer, an act of the Legislature empowering the Water Commissioners to frame and fill a general system or plan of sewerage for the whole city, which should be the "permanent plan" of such sewerage, and according to which the whole work should be done. A verdict in favor of plaintiffs was rendered. The case was carried to the General Term of the Supreme Court, and the judgment of the Circuit Court was affirmed, the opinion being given by Judge LOTT. An appeal was then made to the Court of Appeals, and the judgment of the lower courts was reversed, the Chief Justice giving an elaborate opinion, in which, after reviewing all the points in the case, he declares that the city is not responsible for the want of judgment upon which the system of sewerage was devised, or for the insufficiency of sewers laid.

abstract: Potter, Mr. Consul, on Annexation
lead_paragraph: -- It will be seen that the provincials continue to be exercised over Mr. Consul POTTER and his views upon the question of annexing Canada to the United States. At a meeting held in Detroit, in connection with the recent convention, it will be remembered, Mr. POTTER laid himself open to a charge of excessive candor, by declaring that if the Reciprocity Treaty were not renewed, the colonists would soon begin to perceive the advantages of annexation. Nothing could be truer than Mr. POTTER's observation. But, although that observation was accompanied with many kind words and apologies for the Canadians, it has excited so much consternation in political circles that petitions are being sent round for signature in Montreal, demanding a government inquest into Mr. POTTER's conduct. The whole thing, nevertheless, looks very much like a tempest in a teapot.

abstract: -- Yesterday morning four men, evidently very drunk and mischievous, undertook to force their way over the Roosevelt-street Ferry without paying. The ticket-man objected, whereupon the four rascals pitched upon him and his assistants, and beat them severely. Help arrived very soon, and the four ruffians enjoyed about as terrible a whaling as they could hear and live. It is painful to record such facts; but if rowdyism will have it so, there is at least some consolation in knowing that the peaceable citizens whom they abuse, and the police who are necessarily parties, have the courage and the power to administer exemplary punishment. Rowdies care little for law; the chances of escape with very slight or no punishment are greatly in their favor; but when it comes to a summary thrashing, when they find that blows given will be promptly returned, that pistols may be used both ways and knives are two-edged, they will be likely to hesitate before running a-muck. It is not for us to advise violence, even against violence; yet we cannot feel otherwise than gratified when the ruffianly insolence of our seminative rowdies meets its punishment on the instant -- when we hear that the broken head is on the right side.

abstract: Regular passenger trians commenced running from knoxville to Jonesboro, 98 miles above, on Wednesday last. Special trains convoy passengers and freight to Carter's Depot, twelve miles further, which is the present terminus of the road. This leaves only twenty miles of the road to be finished to Bristol, and there are only two bridges to repair to complete the whole. The Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, from Bristol to Lynchburgh, and the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, from Lynchburgh to Alexandria, opposite Washington, are nearly completed. A continuous line of railroad will connect us again soon with the Eastern and seaboard cities by the route through Virginia. This will shorten the line of communication and travel by which intercourse is had with the great outside world by East Tennessee -- and will enable our people to repair their losses in property, household goods. &c., at less expense for transportation. -- Chattanooga Gazette, July 11.

abstract: The Union Convention to nominate candidates for State Officers was held yesterday. The attendance was large, and the proceedings appear to have been entirely harmonious, notwithstanding a degree of exuberance, foreign to the rather phlegmatic politicians of that State. The competition for Governor had been narrowed down to ALEX. G. CATTELL and MARCUS WARD; but just on the moment of balloting, some one proposed Gen. KILPATRICK, and the gallant soldier came within an ace of being rushed through by acclamation. The cooler heads, however, managed to keep the lead, and after four ballots the choice fell upon MARCUS L. WARD, a gentleman well known and well qualified to uphold the Union banner. The friends of Mr. CATTELL and Gen. KILPATRICK gracefully acquiesced in making the nomination unanimous, and all went off smoothly. If the canvass continues with the spirit in which it opens, the result can hardly be doubtful. One of the resolutions of this convention declares that the constitutional amendment must and shall prevail in New-Jersey, and we are inclined to think that the boys mean just what they say. Thus far the Democracy make no sign; but of course the forlorn hope must come to the scratch; for if "the party" shows its back in the Jerseys, where shall we look for its face?

abstract: Coroner HESLEWOOD yesterday held an inquest at the ferry landing at Sailors' Snug Harbor, S.I., upon the body of a returned soldier, which was found floating in the river near that place. Upon his person was found a letter addressed to BENJ. F. ARNOLD, Company B, Seventh Regiment Rhode Island Volunteers, First Brigade, Second Division, Ninth Army Corps, Washington, D.C., dated June 30, 1865, purporting to be from his father, and signed J.B.A., Lafayette, North Kingston. Also, a letter from his sister, signed HATTIE, together with some likenesses and some few other small articles. He was dressed in soldier's uniform. Any further information required can be had by applying to ROBERT HESLEWOOD, Coroner, Tompkinsville, Quarantine Landing, S.I.

abstract: Lowell, of Boston, vs. Atlantic
lead_paragraph: The match between these clubs, which took place at Bedford yesterday, on the Capitoline ball grounds, resulted in the defeat of the Lowell Club, but by a much less score than expected, the totals being 45 to 17, the Lowells making more runs off the Atlantics than they did in the Resolute match. A very large crowd of spectators were present, the ladies being more numerous than on any previous occasion this season. The game opened favorably for the Atlantics, who had it all their own way in the first three innings. Afterwards, however, the Lowells played a very superior game to their display of the day previous, their out-fielding especially being an improvement, their in-fielding this time being the weak point. In the first five innings the totals stood 34 to 8 in favor of the Atlantics, but in the last four innings the Atlantics only added 11 runs to their score, while the Lowells scored 9. The Bostonians had the honor of making the most fly-catches in the match, besides scoring the only home run of the game. The contest throughout was marked by the utmost good feeling, the Atlantics paying their guests every attention. The Bostonians received their defeat with the best grace imaginable. In fact, they congratulated themselves on their success in making such a good fight of it with their powerful adversaries. At the close of the match the club-room became the scene of a gay and festive gathering of the members of the two clubs, the hospitality of the champions being as familiar to visiting clubs as their fine play. We append the score of the match:

abstract: This veteran regiment arrived at a late hour on Thursday night, with 468 men and 30 officers, Col. P.P. BIXBY commanding. After remaining at the Battery Barracks all night and the better part of yesterday, the Sixth left for home at 3 o'clock. While marching up Broadway, the regiment met Gen. BURNSIDE, (their old corps commander,) and the Colonel halted his regiment, when the boys gave three thundering cheers for the man who had led them through so many perils and in so many different campaigns. The General was somewhat taken aback at the sudden recognition, but gracefully submitted to the call of his gallant followers. Shaking off all appeals for a speech, Gen. BURNSIDE contented himself with passing down the line, shaking hands with all, and addressing a few pleasant words to each. With three more hearty cheers, the New-Hampshire boys shouldered their muskets and resumed their march for the good old Granite State, from which they had been absent so long.
lead_paragraph: This veteran regiment arrived at a late hour on Thursday night, with 468 men and 30 officers, Col. P.P. BIXBY commanding. After remaining at the Battery Barracks all night and the better part of yesterday, the Sixth left for home at 3 o'clock. While marching up Broadway, the regiment met Gen. The General was somewhat taken aback at the sudden recognition, but gracefully submitted to the call of his gallant followers. Shaking off all appeals for a speech, Gen. BURNSIDE contented himself with passing down the line, shaking hands with all, and addressing a few pleasant words to each. With three more hearty cheers, the New-Hampshire boys shouldered their muskets and resumed their march for the good old Granite State, from which they had been absent so long.

abstract: This beautiful steamer, which has been kindly placed by its owner, Mr. L.W. JEROME, at the service of Mr. EVERETT, Engineer of the New-York and Newfoundland Telegraph Company, will sail to-morrow (Saturday) for Aspy Bay. The yacht is about 160 tons burden, and is a staunch sea-boat. Owing to the large number of assistants required for the peculiar business of repairing and relaying the cable across the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and the quantity of machinery necessary, with other appliances essential to the successful prosecution of the present expedition, the extent of the accommodations are exceedingly circumscribed, and, notwithstanding several of the crew have been dispensed with, to accommodate Engineer EVERETT's force, many of the latter will be obliged to find quarters on board entirely outside of the berths and small cabins of the craft.

abstract: United States District-Attorney DICKINSON received information on Thursday last that the Portugese bark Dahomey, lying in the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, was fitting out as a slaver. It was alleged that the vessel had sailed from Cuba with a cargo for NewYork; on her arrival part of her cargo was sold, but the balance, consisting of timber, rice, rum, and other articles used by slavers, was kept in the vessel.
lead_paragraph: United States District-Attorney DICKINSON received information on Thursday last that the Portugese bark Dahomey, lying in the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, was fitting out as a slaver. It was alleged that the vessel had sailed from Cuba with a cargo for NewYork; on her arrival part of her cargo was sold, but the balance, consisting of timber, rice, rum, and other articles used by slavers, was kept in the vessel. Acting District-Attorney COURTNEY immediate filed a libel, and the process was given to the Marshal, who proceeded to Brooklyn and seized the vessel. The bark was sailing under Portugese colors, and had her captain and regular crew on board. The consignees in this city are Messrs. SANTOS & Co. The cargo of the vessel will be examined in a day or two.

abstract: Yesterday was another exceedingly pleasant day, the sun shone brightly and a welcome breeze cooled the atmosphere. Every train swelled the volume of visitors, and the hotels begin to swarm with pleasure-seekers. Of course, in such fine weather, as may well be imagined, everybody was out doors as much as possible, and there was to be seen a constant stream of pedestrians in the different promenades, and a goodly display of teams on the "rides."

abstract: United Service Petroleum Company Case Continued
snippet: United Service Petroleum Company Case Continued
lead_paragraph: The United Service Petroleum and Mining Company appeared, yesterday morning at 9, and, for a wonder, introduced itself without unnecessary sparring between counsel. Mr. GEORGE D. KELLOGG, having been put on the stand to complete his testimony, was, for a time, permitted to make reply to nearly every question that counsel on either side chose to propound; but at length a skirmish between counsel sealed his lips and finished the proceedings of the day. It was supposed that this day's proceedings would yield information which the reporters know to be somewhere in existence, and which may be interesting to many gentlemen who have invested their surplus means in the unctuous region of Titusville; but, unhappily, the wrangle in which counsel indulged consumed the time of the Court, and an adjournment was demanded just when everybody expected to hear from Col. HILLYER, a witness who is said to be well informed.

abstract: Over two hundred soldiers and sailors honorably discharged from the United States service, have agreed to become members of the United States Soldiers' and Sailors' Protective Society, having for its object the amelioration of their welfare, and the benefit of the country. They will meet at Pythagoras Hall, No. 136 Canal-street, on the 19th of August, at 7 o'clock P.M., to organize definitely the society, to appoint its officers, and take all necessary measures to insure its success. The society is under the patronage of the Metropolitan Employment Agency for Soldiers and Sailors, managed by J.B. HERMAN.
lead_paragraph: Over two hundred soldiers and sailors honorably discharged from the United States service, have agreed to become members of the United States Soldiers' and Sailors' Protective Society, having for its object the amelioration of their welfare, and the benefit of the country. abstract: New-York Corcoran Legion, Reception of; New-York, 5th Heavy Artillery, Reception in Brooklyn
snippet: New-York Corcoran Legion, Reception of; New-York, 5th Heavy Artillery, Reception in Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The returning tide of discharged troops continues to flow on its homeward way, and each day sees our streets thronged with veterans about to throw off the uniform of the soldiers for the habiliments of the citizens. Amid all the noise and confusion of Broadway, the bronzed and hardy boys who have formed the grand army of the Union march as unconcerned as they did to the sound of cannon or bursting of shell. Proudly they go on their way, conscious of earnest duty bravely performed, and relying upon the records of the past for their future renown.

abstract: North Carolina is making active exertions to secure emigration to her territory. Col. J.M. HECK and KEMP P. BATTLE are at the St. Nicholas Hotel, for the purpose of opening offices in the North to furnish information and encourage emigration. They say the people of North Carolina are anxious to have the State filled with Northern settlers, and desire to have their resources fully developed. The feeling is very strong in favor of the new system of labor, and a large majority express gladness at the abolition of slavery. They offer for sale or lease large quantities of land, gold, iron and lead mines, and water-power, and offer liberal inducements to emigration. This is the first step of the kind taken by any State.

abstract: The examination into the alleged Navy-yard Frauds was continued before Commissioner NEWTON yesterday. Three witnesses were examined, namely, Mr. THOMAS E. SCHERMERHORN, JAMES HARRISON, and SAMUEL MORRELL. Their testimony was mainly corroborative of the evidence given the day previous as to the manufacture of two mahogany and two black walnut book-cases, tool chests, &c. Mr. HARRISON testified to doing the carving work on the cases, and being employed on the tool chests about six months. The examination was further adjourned until Monday.
lead_paragraph: The examination into the alleged Navy-yard Frauds was continued before Commissioner NEWTON yesterday. Three witnesses were examined, namely, Mr. THOMAS E. abstract: Excelsior vs. Lowell, at Bedford; Last Day
snippet: Excelsior vs. Lowell, at Bedford; Last Day
lead_paragraph: The last of the series of games played by the Lowell Club, of Boston, took place at Bedford yesterday, their adversaries on the occasion being the Excelsior. We had occasion last week to speak in terms of warm praise of the Excelsior for the skill they displayed in their match with the Unions. This time, however, their performances were very different, so much so that we could scarcely credit it was the same club playing. The Lowells, on the contrary, showed a marked improvement in their play, it being their best display of the three games. They were properly entertained after the game terminated. We append the score:

abstract: Union Commission, Agent's Report
lead_paragraph: We are permitted to lay before our readers this morning a very interesting report of the doings of the General Agent of the commission at the barracks during the past three months. abstract: Yesterday afternoon MARY WAGNER, wife of GEORGE WAGNER, was murdered by her husband, at their abode, at No. 516 Broome-street. It appears that WAGNER, having been abroad drinking, reached home intoxicated, and quarreled with his wife on the stoop in the rear of their abode, and that Mrs. WAGNER having used language which exasperated him, he brained her with an axe, lodging the weapon deep in the head. Death was instantaneous. The axe remained in the woman's head until removed by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, Jr., of the Coroner's office. WAGNER, who is a German of about 39 years, was apprehended by Policeman BARKER, and committed to the Eighth Ward Police Station, where he was held last night. Mrs. WAGNER was a native of France, aged about 30 years. The couple had been married about twelve years.

abstract: Muller vs. Orskay, Seduction
lead_paragraph: Frederick A. Muller vs. Eugene Orskay. -- Mr. Muller, a musician attached to the Ravel troupe, having married a danseuse of the troupe, one of the Zanfrettas, discovered that she had formed an attachment for a Hungarian Count rather derogatory to his marital rights. After some discussion the matter was settled, and the young Anetta returned to her husband. Subsequently the guilty wife and her lover met in Chicago, and again she strayed from the path of virtue, and again the husband pardoned her. The third time, in New-York, the Count persuaded the lady to leave her husband, who has again received his wife back, but, desiring to punish the seducer, has commenced an action against him, laying his damages at $20,000. The Count was committed to jail, in default of $3,000 bail, and he now moves to reduce the amount of bail, on an affidavit not denying the seduction, but alleging in substance that the plaintiff compromised with him for the seduction at Davenport, Iowa, for $200, which was paid by the defendant, and that Anetta had been compelled by the cruelty of her husband to apply to him for money, and that he, out of his old affection for her, had occasionally supplied her with small sums of money, and that this had been made the ground of attempts to extort money by suits from him.

abstract: Infiltrated Meat, Report of Quality, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: We received, a few days since, from Dr. ATWOOD, a specimen of meat which had been subjected to MORGAN's preserving process. Having tried it both by boiling and broiling, we are able to report that it is excellent, both in tenderness and retention of flavor and juiciness. We presume that Dr. ATWOOD, whose office is at No. 9 Broad-street, in this city, is in communication with persons who intend using the process. The importance of any means of cheapening food is our reason for departing from our custom of not recommending articles of trade in our columns. The sooner infiltrated beef becomes an article of general use, the better for the public, and the worse for the greedy speculators in meat.

abstract: On Tuesday evening, Detective Officer GEORGE W. ELDER apprehended one JAMES THOMSON for picking a gentleman's pocket at the box-office at Niblo's. THOMSON, who is otherwise known as ROGERS, was taken to Police Headquarters and searched, and in his possession was found a card that had manifestly been torn from a trunk, inscribed, "Mrs. JOSEPH BRITTON, Baldwin House, Lake Mahopac, N.Y. This card was, it appears, precisely what the detective officer required to aid him in another direction; for on Monday Mrs. JOSEPH BRITTON and daughters, of No. 31 Ninth-street, having started for Lake Mahopac, lost their luggage at the Harlem Railroad Company's depot, in Twenty-sixth-street, and had made their loss known at Police Headquarters. The prisoner was questioned concerning this card, but he held his peace, and Detective ELDER was forced to seek information in another quarter: but this, happily, he soon obtained from a gentleman who had seen THOMSON riding out with two females that seemed suddenly to have donned new dresses of the latest fashion. Having obtained this clue, the detective officer visited one LIZZIE DIXON, in Thompson-street, and one IDA CLARK, in Wooster-street, and found in their rooms the contents of Mrs. BRITTON's trunks, and the females confessed that the same had been given them by THOMSON. They had pawned many articles belonging to Mrs. BRITTON, and these were redeemed by the Detective Police. THOMSON, who is a native of England, is well known by our own and the London police. Justice DOWLING, declining to accept bail, committed him.

abstract: Those sensible people who stay away from butcher shops to-day, are referred to the encouraging announcement concerning milk, which we print. They will see that to buy no meat is the true and only policy. It will be all the better for the butchers themselves in the end -- they know as well as we do, the source of the evils complained of -- and they are equally aware that there is no remedy other than that which we are urged incessantly to advocate.

abstract: Deputy Coroner JOSEPH G. SHAW went to Bellevue Hospital, yesterday, to take the depositions of OWEN KELTY and JACOB B. LAKE, the two persons who were most seriously injured by the explosion of a boiler in Messrs. NOLAN & STEERS' steam saw-mill, Second-avenue and Fifty-four-street, on Saturday last. KELTY, the engineer, was found yet unable to give testimony, and LAKE was delirious at the time of the doctor's visit. It was believed that these men could not live; and there being no testimony but theirs that had not been taken, the inquest was adjourned indefinitely.

abstract: the Magnitude of the
lead_paragraph: The revolution in the South involves a prodigious change, and it will require, at the very least, a generation to complete it. We never expect to see the South entirely clear of the old theories of the subordination of the races, and of the doctrines of State sovereignty, until those who are now upon the stage give place to those born in the new era. Meantime there will be, as in every transitional period, a great deal of irregularity. The new relations of the white and black races of the South will not adjust themselves without much rough collision, and not a little hardship to the weaker race. We may lament this. We may and should do our utmost to avert and to check it. Yet to some extent it will be inevitable, and altogether beyond our control. It will come from impulses of human nature which it is quite beyond the power of any government perfectly to restrain or regulate. We ought to regard it as the price we must pay for the new promises of the future, and like wise, practical men, make the best of it.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment in
lead_paragraph: The position now taken by the public men of Kentucky and the altered tone of public sentiment in that State, give good assurance that the Constitutional Amendment will be adopted there when next it comes before the Legislature. In all the States further South to which Provisional Governors have been appointed, there is no doubt of its adoption, as it has been adopted in Louisiana, for the simple reason that everybody there knows that, as an actual fact, slavery is dead anyhow, and that there would be great advantages in having this settled and established by constitutional law. Even in South Carolina the leading men are in favor of the measure, and Gov. PERRY expects it will be enacted by the State Legislature before the coming Winter is over.

abstract: Freedmen; Success of Government Policy on
snippet: Freedmen; Success of Government Policy on
lead_paragraph: It is gratifying to know that the Freedman's Bureau in Washington, under the management of Major-Gen. HOWARD, and the officers of the army detailed as superintendents in the various States, is fast overcoming all difficulties and achieving a most decided success. The colored people, under its direct charge, are adapting themselves with great cheerfulness to its regulations, and are cultivating the new crops with steadiness and general good behavior. They have come to an understanding that freedom does not mean idleness, and that their future well-being must depend mainly upon their own exertions; and they show little or no disposition to abuse the mild policy of the Government. The experiment is already far enough advanced to make it quite certain that all these freedmen will soon be brought to a self-supporting condition, and will be quite as well able to take care of themselves in all respects as the white population about them.

abstract: In February last, Miss LEO HUDSON, the equestrian actress, accidentally fell from her steed in the Nashville Theatre, and during the excitement that ensued, a small satchel, which contained Treasury notes and jewelry of the value of $3,185, was stolen. Several persons who were connected with the theatre were examined, but nothing satisfactory was learned until recently, when FRANCIS J. SHARPE, who was in Miss HUDSON's employ as a servant at the time of the accident, ostentatiously exhibited jewelry, and made lavish expenditure of money while intoxicated, in the neighborhood of the New Bowery Theatre, where both himself and Miss HUDSON are well known, and Miss HUDSON's jewels were recognized. Information was given Miss HUDSON, and she came to this city, but SHARPE had fled to the interior, and when found by Detectives SLOWEY and MCCLOUD, had married and settled down with his young wife in the beautiful interior city of Schenectady. He was not, however, captured there, but in Albany, the city of the Blest. He was taken before Justice SHANDLEY, yesterday, and committed in default of $5,000 bail, his young wife insisting upon sharing his captivity and entering the prison with him. Miss HUDSON's money, amounting to more than $1,000, SHARPS had spent, and her jewelry he had pawned -- some of it at GEORGE A. MEIER's pawn-shop, No. 51 Avenue B. The detectives went to MEIER's place, yesterday, and seized Miss HUDSON's watch and chain, three diamond rings and other jewelry, and also took MEIER into custody. MEIER was taken to Essex Market and required to find $1,500 bail, and this was given by his father, Mr, GEORGE MEIER, of No. 283 Avenue A.

abstract: Annexation Question; The
lead_paragraph: We beg the people of Canada not to get unduly excited about the subject of annexation -- or, rather, about our desire to annex their territory to the Union. We do not know anybody on this side of the lines who gives a thought to the matter; and we are sure there is not an American who, under any circumstances, desires to force them to become a part of the United States. It seems that Mr. POTTER's speech at the Detroit Commercial Convention has given them an undue idea of their importance to us, and an undue estimate of our anxiety to woo and win them. They are protesting, through their papers and otherwise, that they don't desire annexation; that they won't be annexed; that they are loyal to the Queen, and satisfied with their institutions; that they dread democratic rule, and are appalled at our national debt; that they are happy as clams with the present condition of things, and would be wretched as roasting clams under any other condition. All we have to say is, "all right." Be not excited. We will not and would not annex you. We should not, in fact, know that such a thing was ever thought of by anybody, if we did not from time to time learn of it from the Canadian papers.

abstract: THE MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY. -- In another column the Mutual Life Insurance Company repeat the main facts, which they presented a few days since. An idea of the immensity of the business transacted by this company is exhibited by the report of the Massachusetts Insurance Commissioners for 1864. Number of policies outstanding, 17,370; amount insured, $59,650,764 46. It will be noted from this advertisement that the dividends on "Ten-Year Plan" in the Mutual Life, after premiums have ceased, are an absolute cash income to policy-holders for remainder of life. Thus, before a person, aged 35, attains his "table-rate" of expectation of life he will probably have received in cash, from the company, all that he has previously paid in; and his policy of $10,000, drawing a large annual cash dividend for balance of life, will have cost him only the interest on his premiums while they were retained by the company.

lead_paragraph: OUTRAGE ANE MOB LAW AT GREENPORT, L.I. -- The usual quiet of Greenport, L.I., has been considerably disturbed during the past week, growing out of an alleged attempt by a colored barber to outrage the person of a respectable married white lady residing next door to him. The facts are thus stated: The barber is a man of some property, and has heretofore borne a good character in the town; but, early one morning last week, he so far forgot himself as to seize the lady alluded to in the rear of his house, where she had gone for a pitcher of water, and endeavored to make her submit to his embraces. He did not succeed in his effort, however, and the lady immediately stated the circumstance to her husband. He then advised with his neighbors as to what course to pursue in the matter; but before they came to any conclusion, news of the transaction spread throughout the town, and some eighteen or twenty young men visited the barber's shop and carried him to the outskirts of the town. After some little delay a pail of tar and a bag of feathers were procured, when the offender was divested of his clothing and completely covered with that garment of lawless fame known as "a coat of tar and feathers." It is believed that the man received no further injury. A gentleman in the town, sympathizing with the barber, offered $100 for the apprehension of the young men, but he has been threatened with a like visit, it is said, for his interference.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon and evening the company and attaches of Barnum's Museum, sufferers by the late fire, took a benefit at the Academy of Music. The programme included several vaudevilles, which were well put upon the stage, and a variety of minor attractions. Mr. BARNUM made an amusing speech on each occasion, which was frequently interrupted by applause. Crowded audiences were present, and it was stated at an early hour in the afternoon that 7,000 fifty cent tickets had already been disposed of.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon and evening the company and attaches of Barnum's Museum, sufferers by the late fire, took a benefit at the Academy of Music. abstract: I have the best authority for saying that JEFFERSON DAVIS is in good health, even better than when he arrived at this place. His eyesight is not impaired, and his appetite is remarkably good. There are many rumors afloat regarding JEFF., but no alteration has taken place in his health or condition. No one is allowed to see him except Surgeon CRAVEN and the guard.

abstract: A terrible affair occurred at Cape May on Sunday afternoon between a white man, named MICHAEL SULLIVAN, a Philadelphian, and a colored man named CHARLES WILSON, in which the former was killed. It seems that WILSON, who was a cook at one of the hotels, was standing on the pavement, which is rather narrow, between the United States Hotel and BARRETT's saloon. He was talking with a friend, when SULLIVAN approached in an inebriate condition, which drew a taunting remark from WILSON. SULLIVAN thereupon made a violent assault upon him, and WILSON, picking up a brickbat, struck him in the head with it, following it by striking him several times with a fence paling, fracturing his skull in several places and battering his face, disfiguring him in a terrible manner. The wounded man died almost instantly. WILSON was arrested. Mr. SULLIVAN had been tending bar at Cold Spring, about four miles from the Cape. -- Trenton, N.J., Gazette, July 20.

abstract: Dunderberg, Iron-Clad; Launch of
lead_paragraph: For months past a formidable-looking craft, of extraordinary dimensions and strange model, has been growing on the stocks in the ship-yard of W.H. WEBB, Esq., at the foot of Sixth-street, East River, which has excited no little wonder in naval circles, as well as in the minds of people generally. When first projected, it was supposed and hoped that it would be completed in season to take part in the capture of Charleston or Mobile, or teach those mysterious Richmond rams, which were always going to do such great things, a salutary lesson in naval warfare. With his usual sense of the fitness of things, the projector and builder christened her the Dunderberg -- a name at once expressive of her formidable qualities, and sonorous, national and historical. Dunderberg, as our readers probably know, is the name of the mountain near West Point, at the foot of which Capt. KIDD is popularly supposed to have sunk his piratical craft, laden with gold and rigged with "curses dark," and where, in later years, a massive iron cable was stretched across the Hudson to prevent the ascent of British ships-of-war. That gold, by the way, has often been the object of enthusiastic but fruitless search; and several links of the chain were melted down when Barnum's Museum fell a prey to the flames.

abstract: Social Condition of, by Mrs. De N., No.1
snippet: Social Condition of, by Mrs. De N., No.1
lead_paragraph: [The following is the first of a series of letters written by Mrs. MARIA A.K. DE N., a lady who has resided for more than ten years in Mexico. The results of the observations of one who has had such opportunities for acquiring information will possess peculiar interest, now that the affairs of that country are attracting so much attention. -- ED. abstract: Reduction to 50,000 Expedient
lead_paragraph: It is now stated in official quarters that it is the intention of the government to reduce the army to 100,000, and perhaps to 50,000 men. We see no reason why the latter mark may not be adopted without injury or risk. All accounts represent that an absolute submission to the National Government prevails everywhere throughout the South. There is not the least guerrilla warfare among the whites, nor the fear of any; and not the slightest sign of a violent disposition has yet appeared among the blacks. There is, indeed, great disturbance of industry, and a certain extent of civil and social disorganization, but nothing that calls for military interposition. It is really remarkable how quietly all the rulings of the Provost-Marshals and other government officials are acquiesced in, from the Atlantic to the Rio Grande. There seems to be no difference in this respect between these regions which are largely garrisoned with national troops and those which have few or none. The universal feeling is on the side of a complete submission to the National Government, and the speediest restoration possible of law, order, industry and prosperity.

abstract: -- Every day since the close of the war brings to light some now devilish device of the Southern traitors. Among the ammunition, &c., captured at Richmond, (large quantities of which are constantly arriving at the arsenals in West Troy,) are eighteen large shells, from fifteen to eighteen inches in diameter. The shells were filled with benzine, wads of oakum, and pieces of small sized tarred rope. It is supposed by the officers at the arsenal that these shells were prepared specially to fire at our wooden ships, or perhaps from a gunboat into our cities. Benzine, as our readers are aware, is highly inflammable, and ignites as quickly as powder, so that the blaze from one of the wads would be sufficiently prolonged to fire any wooden object with which it might come in contact. The screws of the plugs are finely made, and fit beautifully, in order to retain, without leakage, the benzine. The benzine has been poured out of the shells, and a friend has sent us a piece of one of the oakum wads, which he personally fished out of the shell. The smell is pretty strong proof of its genuineness. -- Troy Whig.

abstract: -- In addition to the number of daily newspapers which are now printed in this city, there has recently been started three new weeklies, representing as many of our Christian denominations, viz.: the Christian Observer, New School Presbyterian, edited by Rev. Dr. CONVERSE; the Central Presbyterian, Old School, edited by Rev. Dr. BROWN, and the Episcopal Methodist, edited by Rev. Drs. DOGGETT and JOHN E. EDWARDS. They are all neatly printed and ably and piously edited, and devoted to the interests of their respective denominations. The two former are resumptions of old issues; but the latter is an entirely new enterprise. We hope and believe that they will receive that prosperous support which the extensive denominations whose interests they represent are so fully able to extend to them, -- Richmond Bulletin.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO DEPUTY SHERIFF WESTERVELT.--On Friday last the friends of Deputy Sheriff JOHN J.V. WESTERVELT presented him with a magnificient gold watch, as a mark of their esteem.
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATION TO DEPUTY SHERIFF WESTERVELT. -- On Friday last the friends of Deputy Sheriff JOHN J.V. WESTERVELT presented him with a magnificient gold watch, as a mark of their esteem. Mr. WESTERVELT had been unfortunate enough to loose his time-piece while looking at the fire at Barnum's Museum, and his friends availed themselves of the occasion to make the presentation. The affair took place at the Merchants' Exchange, Mr. KENNELLY, real-estate auctioneer, making the presentation speech. Mr. WESTERVELT responded in a happy manner. Amongst those present were Ex-Sheriff LYNCH, Deputies STEVENS, MOORE and REILLY, Capts. GOODWIN and MCGUIRE

abstract: Montgomery's Air Line Railroad
lead_paragraph: We do not know that the plan of air-line railroads for the accommodation of city travel, has all the merit claimed for it by its author, Mr. RICHARD MONTGOMERY. But the apparent simplicity, cheapness and facility of construction, invite at least examination. This we invite the practical engineers of the city to give it, that we may know if the scheme can be made available. Our own view, at the first blush, is, that such an elevated viaduct -- light as the structure is -- would be objectionable on Broadway. But if the feasibility of the enterprise were made otherwise certain, there would be means of finding right-of-way on less thronged and important thoroughfares. It is claimed by the author of the present device, that a road such as he proposes -- extending from Madison-square to Bowling-green -- can be built in four months, and built without disturbing the traffic on any portion of the streets through which the line passes. It is also claimed that the construction will cost not more than $13,000 a mile. Even if it cost double this amount, and were made durable and thoroughly safe, it would be a mere bagatelle.

abstract: There have been received at Fortress Monroe during the past two weeks, one hundred and eighty iron guns, late the property of the rebels, and mounted on the approaches of Petersburgh and Richmond. These guns are all of large calibre, ranging from seven to ten-inch. The ten-inch guns were taken from Fort Darling.
lead_paragraph: There have been received at Fortress Monroe during the past two weeks, one hundred and eighty iron guns, late the property of the rebels, and mounted on the approaches of Petersburgh and Richmond. These guns are all of large calibre, ranging from seven to ten-inch. The ten-inch guns were taken from Fort Darling. They are of rebel manufacture, and nearly new, having been cast in 1864. They are said, by competent Judges, to be excellent specimens of serviceable ordinance. They bear a strong resemblance to the Armstrong gun, being reinforced at the breech by concentric bands. All were cast at Richmond. Nearly every one of them are effectually spiked. These guns were never finished at the foundries where they were east, and they bear the roughness peculiar to castings when first taken from the sand in which they were molded.

abstract: -- While we think the greatest possible latitude should be allowed to youngsters who come out of the lower wards to enjoy themselves in the City Hall Park, we think there ought to be a stop put to the nuisance of juvenile street-sweeping beggars, with which the Park is infested. Scores of ragged girls parade the square with brooms, and shout at every passer-by for pennies with merciless persistence. The mendicant elders are doubtless more or less gratified lookers-on at some convenient distance. The young beggars perform no sort of service with their brooms beyond that of sprinkling the passing pedestrian with mud. All this goes on daily and hourly under the eyes of the police. Yet they fail to see it, and the public suffer enduringly.

abstract: The best estimate of the growing cotton crop is 500,000 bales. The derangement of labor and the necessity of raising at once the wherewith to keep the wolf from the door have caused much less land to be planted with the great staple than was at first supposed.
lead_paragraph: The best estimate of the growing cotton crop is 500,000 bales. The derangement of labor and the necessity of raising at once the wherewith to keep the wolf from the door have caused much less land to be planted with the great staple than was at first supposed. Well-informed gentlemen, who have recently traversed the cotton region, some of them skilled in such estimates, say there was never so little cotton planted before, not even in the midst of this war. In many districts, formerly devoted entirely to it, scarcely a stalk or boll is to be seen. The falling of prices, both actual and prospective, is doubtless one reason; but the principal one is to be found in the labor and food questions.

abstract: Bigelow, Minister, Speech on Fourth of July in Paris
snippet: Bigelow, Minister, Speech on Fourth of July in Paris
lead_paragraph: A fete champetre, given by the United States Minister, Mr. BIGELOW, in commemoration of the Declaration of Independence of the 4th of July, 1776, took place on Tuesday in the soacious grounds of the Pre-Catalan, and will be long remembered with gratification by every one present. With the exception of the French Minister and the Diplomatic body, the company present consisted solely of Americans, or foreigners connected with America by marriage; in all between 600 and 700 persons were present, including about 100 children, who formed a most interesting feature in the day's proceedings. The visitors, in fact, formed the largest body of Americans that has ever assembled on the continent.

abstract: DISPOSITION OF THE SOUTH SEVENTH-STREET RIOTERS. -- WILLIAM LANE, TIMOTHY O'CONNOR, and DAVID O'CONNOR, were yesterday afternoon brought before Justice DAILEY, charged with being engaged in the murderous assault on the ferry hands and police on Thursday morning last. The testimony was very voluminous. MICHAEL HAMBURY, one of the injured parties, was placed upon the stand, and his evidence was positive against the prisoners. Several other witnesses were sworn, but nothing beyond what was previously published was elicited. After a summing up by CHARLES BRIGGS for the defendants, and RICHARD H. HUNTLEY for the prosecution, Judge DAILEY held WILLIAM LANE and TIMOTHY O'CONNOR in bonds to appear before the Grand Jury. DAVID O'CONNOR was discharged. JOHN LANE is still in the hospital.

abstract: Among the arrivals on Saturday was that of the Fifth Connecticut, numbering 390 men, under command of Col. HENRY W. DABOLL. The regiment came by the Amboy route at 4 P.M., and after remaining at the Battery Barracks until yesterday afternoon, the command took passage by the Hartford steamer for that city. During its stay at the barracks, the Fifth enjoyed a great treat at the hands of Col. ALMY, in the shape of a bountiful supply of ripe and luscious peaches, eighteen baskets of which delicious fruit were placed at their disposal.

abstract: Tennyson's Poems
lead_paragraph: These two elegant volumes -- perfect in style and typographical execution -- present us with the entire title-deeds to immortality of one whom the Anglo-Saxon speaking world has consented to receive as the representative poet of the intellectual era. His writings, including the latest published volume, Enoch Arden, and several fugitive pieces, have never previously been collected in one series. As such, the edition before us has superior claims to popular favor than any other. We have only one objection to make to it. The author's portrait, when compared with the last English likeness, engraved from a recent photograph, is far too heavy and coarse in execution, making the poet look more like a "border ruffian" than the accomplished gentleman that he is.

abstract: A most astounding and diabolical transaction was brought to light yesterday morning at the storeroom of a first class druggist in this city. As yet, for obvious reasons, the full particulars, (or at least so much thereof as has been brought to light by the energy of Capt. G. WILLEKENS, acting Provost-Marshal of the Sixth District,) must be withheld. The high character and standing of the druggist referred to, would seem to place him beyond all suspicion of guilt in the matter, either as principal or accessory, and we should dislike to publish anything which might sully his fair name. This much by way of preface. We are permitted to make public the following:

abstract: Arnold's Essays on Criticism
lead_paragraph: The essays, forming the main portion of this volume, have already appeared in the Cornhill Magazine and other English periodicals. To them the publishers have joined the author's "Lectures on Translating Homer," making it a complete collection of his miscellaneous writings. Mr. ARNOLD is the eldest son of Dr. THOMAS ARNOLD, of Rugby, and bids fair to become as celebrated a man as his father. As a critic he stands alone amid writers of the day, and brings to his task a delicacy of discrimination, vigor of thought, and fascination of style without a parallel in cotemporary literature. He is one of the severest denouncers of the provincial spirit dominant in English writers, as well as in the social life of the nation, and hesitates not to shock its dearest prejudices, while inculcating greater breadth of view and catholicity of treatment. As a volume for Summer reading -- weighty in actual substance, but light and sparkling in manner, sufficiently attractive to enchain the most ordinary reader, and solemn enough to afford subjects for the meditation of the most cultivated -- we know no recent work that can compete with it.

abstract: COTTON Sales of week 4,500 bales, including 7,500 to speculators and 10,500 to importers. The market has been dull, with a decline of  d. on American and Surats; other descriptions were irregular. Sales, to-day, (Friday,) 8,000 bales; market closing firmer at unchanged rates. The authorized quotations are: Middling Upland, 19d.; Middling Upland. Orleans, 19 d.; Middling Upland. Texas, 19d. The stock of Cotton in port amounts to 361,000 bales, including 29,500 bales of American.

abstract: Camp, Major H. W., Biography of by Chaplain Trumbull
snippet: Camp, Major H. W., Biography of by Chaplain Trumbull
lead_paragraph: In preparing this worthy record of a noble career, Chaplain TRUMBULL has performed a good and acceptable service, not only to the family and friends of Major CAMP, but to all who can feel their natures inspirited and exalted by the contemplation of the memorial of a life sacrificed unhesitatingly at the call of duty -- a life that offers a model of the civic and Christian virtue, reduced to action in the career of its hero. The illustrations, including a fine portrait of Major CAMP, add much to the beauty of this book, which is in every respect creditable to its publishers and those concerned in getting it out.

abstract: A CHANCE FOR A LEGAL SQUABBLE. -- Upon the recent disbandment of Engine No. 8, the members of the company sold by auction the furniture and decorations of their house. Among the pictures was a life-size portrait of Ex-Engineer R.H. HARDING, which was knocked down to the clerk of the Fire Commissioners for &66, in payment for which he gave his check. It is alleged now that when the check was presented for payment it was found that it had been stopped by the clerk. The company then sent to Judge DAILEY for a search-warrant to get possession of the picture, which was granted, and on Saturday night it was found by the court officer and taken to the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house. Its ownership is now claimed by Mr. HARDING himself, who alleges that the company donated it to him. This the company deny, and state that the ownership still rests in them, in consequence of the purchaser's check being stopped. The affair will be judicially investigated.

abstract: Dexter, Henry M., Congregationalism
lead_paragraph: This handsome and well printed octavo is devoted to the defence and explanation of the system of church polity dominant in New-England. In assuming to explain "why it is better than any other form of church government," the champions of rival denominations will probably accuse the author of "begging the question," but all will praise his able and uncompromising argument for what he supposes to be the truth.

abstract: TIRED OF LIFE. -- PATRICK HENNESSY, while laboring under the effects of liquor, attempted to kill himself on Friday night by suspending himself to a lamp post on Third-avenue. He was discovered by the Police of the Forty-eighth Precinct and taken to the station house. He had previously stabbed himself, but not seriously. HENNESSEY stated as a reason for his strange actions that he had lost $1,500 in gambling and could not survive it. He took another view of the subject when he became perfectly sober, and now desires to live some time longer, notwithstanding his losses.

abstract: Smith's Alex., Alfred Hogarth's Household
lead_paragraph: This is, we believe, the first prose work of an author whose volume of poetry, a few years since, took the world by surprise and made him suddenly famous. It is a domestic story of Scotch life, showing strong descriptive power and a poetical insight into the springs of character, but -- perhaps partaking of the stern and serious tone of the society it delineates -- the general effect is too gloomy and unrelieved, imparting anything but a genial impression to the mind of the reader. This is a defect that we look to see remedied in Mr. SMITH's next story. His acknowledged talent must always draw attention to everything he writes.

abstract: Baxley's West Coast of South and North America
snippet: Baxley's West Coast of South and North America
lead_paragraph: In his capacity as Special Commissioner of the United States, Dr. BAXLEY visited during the years 1860-62, the portions of the West Coast of South America, and the Hawaiian Islands that have afforded materials for the composition of this handsome volume. It also contains a full description of his visit to California, en route, which does justice to the wonders of the Yo-Semite Valley and the other marvels of nature, in which that country is so prolific. Dr. BAXLEY has seen much, and has, accordingly, much to tell. His style, however, has a certain official ponderosity about it that is not attractive. We are not aware what part of the country he comes from, but his opinions, freely expressed, in rather a sermonising style, have a smack of the old Southern flavor about them, that now seems, to say the least, out of date. We hear much of Puritan persecution and intolerance, and bitter denunciation of the missionary proceedings in the Sandwich Islands. A labored defence of negro slavery in tropical countries is also undertaken by the author. His professional pursuits give special value to many of his remarks and observations on hygiene, medical geography, &c. The book is got up in superior style, with numerous embellishments apparently from original drawings. It is a valuable addition to our knowledge of a region daily advancing in importance to the rest of the world.

lead_paragraph: In this compact and handsome volume Messrs. TILTON & Co. have been the first to produce in an enduring form the records of the great act of national justice, recently completed at Washington, by meting out to the guilty the punishment they had so richly deserved. As a volume for easy and handy reference, it will rank high among the books indispensable for all who would form a correct estimate of the evils we have just escaped from. It is got up in handsome style, and is certain to meet with a very large sale.

abstract: Commercial Policy of America
lead_paragraph: The United States owe much to their commercial men. Theirs were among the most influential of the signatures to the Declaration of Independence; theirs the policy which controlled the earliest Congresses. While the policy of the country was dictated by its commercial interests, it grew and prospered. It is with peculiar satisfaction, then, that every patriot should view the endeavor recently made at Detroit, by our commercial men assembled in general convention, to assume the position to which their wealth and numbers, no less than their intelligence and devotion to their country entitle them.

abstract: Thomas, Miss Annie, Novels
lead_paragraph: Miss THOMAS is rapidly advancing in the favor of the public, with the successive appearance of her novels from Messrs. HARPERS' press. They have all been received with so much eagerness and admiration abroad, that it is remarkable they should have remained so long unknown here. The best English critics do not hesitate to rank her alongside of Miss BRADDON, Mrs. HENRY WOOD, and the most successful writers of the present century. The charming character of Theo Leigh is one of the most life-like and winning female portraits ever delineated.

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool July 13, via Greencastle July 14, arrived at Father Point yesterday. The news is four days later than previous advices. Additional correspondence on American affairs has been published, which shows that England and France acted in concert and that the concession to Confederate vessels, allowing them to be disarmed and sold in neutral parts, originated with DROUYN DE LHUYS. Earl RUSSELL replies to Mr. SEWARD's note on the cessation of belligerent rights, and expresses regret that his explanations were not not acceptable to the United States. It is stated that the steamer Beatrice, late the Rappahannock, was overhauled by the Sacramento before reaching Liverpool, but permitted to proceed. Political news from England is interesting. The elections were proceeding quietly; at last accounts the Liberals had gained seven members. The rumored negotiations for a European Congress still lack continuation. Spain has recognized the Kingdom of Italy, and notified the Pope of its action. A private telegram from Rome announces that the Pope has excommunicated MAXIMILIAN. The ship Mercury, at Havre, from New-York, reports having picked up forty-three passengers from the wreck of the ill-fated ship William Nelson.

abstract: ARD S. FAY died at Liverpool on the day of the departure of the steamer Africa. It is reported that he was on the way to the steamer, and dropped dead in the street. The deceased was about sixty years old, and a graduate of Harvard College. He was formerly a lawyer, but of late years had been engaged in trade and manufactures. He married a daughter of DUDLEY PICKMAN, Esq., Salem, and was quite wealthy.

abstract: Hackmen and their Charges; Letter from Capt. Brackett
snippet: Hackmen and their Charges; Letter from Capt. Brackett
lead_paragraph: We publish elsewhere a communication from Capt. CHARLES N. BRACKETT, "Captain Twenty-sixth Precinct," respecting hackmen's charges. We know all about the law, which Capt. BRACKETT is so industrious as to quote for our instruction. What we have had to complain of is not the law, but the practice. This we mentioned in previously referring to the subject. The law is, that you may be carried a mile for two shillings, York money; and for that sum you may take a moderate-sized trunk along with you. The practice is, you can't ride any distance at all under a dollar. The hackman's first inquiry has reference to your destination; the second bears upon the money consideration. If either answer disagrees with his inclination, he refuses to serve you. This was precisely the case with the gentleman who asked, on Sunday, the 16th, to have his trunk taken from the corner of Spring-street and Broadway to the Hudson River Railroad station. One hackman after another demanded the same fare -- $3 -- for the service. The intending traveler had no means of compelling them to go on the errand for less. No law that we know of would empower even Capt. BRACKETT himself to make the hackman do the required service. Where, then, is the practical benefit of the tariff which is supposed to regulate the charges of these cabmen? Everyone knows that not one traveler in ten thousand can find cab and conveyance for a mile at the reasonable charge of 50 cents. And no one, surely, knows this better than the members of the police force.

abstract: A gentleman who has just returned from a trip of eighty miles up the country reports the crops suffering greatly from the drouth and intensity of the heat. Fine fields of corn are absolutely wilting up, and but few of the agriculturists entertain hopes of making a full crop. It is not a little singular that while we have been favored with such heavy rains within the past month, the parts through which he traveled have not been visited with so much as a shower. Notwithstanding this manifest deterioration in the agricultural interests of the country, however, we trust that the complaints of the formers may soon be silenced by "falling weather," inasmuch as the corn has certainly not been so injured as to be beyond the benefits that would be derived therefrom.

abstract: New-York, Broadway, No. 440; $5,000 in goods
lead_paragraph: FREDERICK A. HOWE, a resident of Meadville, Crawford County, Penn., who had been arrested by Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, on a charge of having, by false and fraudulent representations, defrauded Mr. NATHANIEL SHELDON, of this city, out of $5,500, was arraigned before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs Police Court, on Saturday afternoon. It seems that the defendant induced Mr. SHELDON to invest money in a tract of land which he represented was located in Forest County, Penn., and that it abounded in valuable timber and minerals, besides containing three oil wells. Mr. SHELDON, in his complaint, a copy of which will be found below, charges that the representations of HOWE in regard to the property were untrue:
