abstract: Pauperism; Reform Needed
lead_paragraph: We spoke the other day of the great reductions in expenses that are now being made by several departments of the government and in various branches of the public service. There is one matter concerning which it is quite time that we had some efficient action. We refer to the system that has sprung up since the war, of issuing government rations to destitute or needy persons of both sexes, and of all colors, throughout the cities and States of the South. The system grew in magnitude as our armies made conquest of larger and larger spaces of the Southern territory, and since the close of the war it has assumed absolutely appalling proportions. Its operation begins with Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac river, with the cities of Norfolk and Alexandria, in the East, and extends to the uttermost bounds of the republic in the Southwest. In the Mississippi Valley it commences, on a large scale, we believe, somewhere about the latitude of Knoxville, Nashville, Memphis and Little Rock, and reaches across the cotton States to the coast. There are large cities like Mobile, where, incredible as it may seem, three-fourths of the white population and one-fourth of the blacks, live from day to day upon the rations issued to them from the government storehouses. It is true, that owing to the late great fire, the number in that city is exceptionally large; but there are many Southern localities in which we are supporting from a fourth to a half of the entire people, and, judging by the statements in our Southern exchanges, we should think there were not less than one hundred towns and cities in the South, in each of which from two to ten thousand individuals are fed on public rations. As soon as a military post is established in any locality, the needy applicants for relief present themselves, and the poverty-stricken country folks also rush into the towns as beggars, whenever they hear the news. The bulk of the recipients fancy they have a perfect right to this bounty; and we have heard of cases in which they watched the weighing scales and scanned the bushel measured, with a sharpness that could not be surpassed -- delivering maledictions upon the heads of the functionaries if they failed to give satisfactory weight or measure.

abstract: For months past a formidable-looking craft, of extraordinary dimensions and strange model, has been growing on the stocks in the ship-yard of W.H. WEBB, Esq., at the foot of Sixth-street, East River, which has excited no little wonder in naval circles, as well as in the minds of people generally. When first projected, it was supposed and hoped that it would be completed in season to take part in the capture of Charleston or Mobile, or teach those mysterious Richmond rams, which were always going to do such great things, a salutary lesson in naval warfare. With his usual sense of the fitness of things, the projector and builder christened her the Dunderberg -- a name at once expressive of her formidable qualities, and sonorous, national and historical.

abstract: Merivale's Conversion of the Roman Empire
snippet: Merivale's Conversion of the Roman Empire
lead_paragraph: This is the work of what Lord BACON calls "a full man;" one who has studied his subject in every possible view, and submitted it to the analysis of a mind amply furnished by learning and natural ability with power to do it justice. It is a necessary and indispensable companion to the author's larger work, and promotes the true "philosophy of history," the essence remaining after the distillation of the mere facts, whose presence makes them chiefly valuable. A comparison with the famous chapters of GIBBON on the same subject is full of instruction, and gives results highly favorable to the honesty and erudition of the living author. It is a book that should be read by every thinking man.

abstract: A dispatch from Nashville says that Gen. FISK, Assistant Commissioner of the Bureau of Refugee Freedmen and Abandoned Lands, has directed that no more refugees from Georgia or Alabama be transported southward from Louisville, except upon special authority from him. Refugees from Georgia and Alabama now in Tennessee desiring to return to their homes, will not be transported South unless they can show, by the best evidence, that upon their return they will not become a charge upon the government for their subsistence. This action is made necessary by the return to Nashville of large numbers who have but recently been furnished transportation to their homes, and who were unable to procure food sufficient to prevent starvation.

abstract: Mr. BARNUM's company appeared for the first time at the Winter Garden on Saturday afternoon -- the "Green Monster" having been placed on the stage in a rapid but effective manner. In the evening the same piece was repeated, and the "Green Monster" stands on the bill for twice a day during the present week. Mr. BARNUM's patrons will unhesitatingly follow him to his new quarters. The benefit in aid of the attaches of the late Museum, came off on Friday at the Academy of Music. It was a pecuniary success.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; Is the Contract a Farce?
snippet: Street-Cleaning; Is the Contract a Farce?
lead_paragraph: We have made a tour through the streets of the city. Considering the fact that the workmen have been at them but a week, they are in good condition so far as mere cleanliness is concerned, while in many places the great holes of which we wrote months ago are yet unfilled, in others the cobble-stones are sunk for yards below the level of the street, while block after block is as yet unpaved. The outward opposition to the new commission has ceased; no longer are men beaten in the streets, horses slashed in their stables, or barns burned at night; the full force of men and carts and horses is at work, and, if the contractors will it, the city will be cleaner this year than ever before.

lead_paragraph: -In our Washington dispatches will be found an explanation of the circumstances under which Gov. PERRY, of South Carolina, delivered his Greenville speech, At the time the speech was delivered Mr. PERRY was unaware of his nomination to the office of Governor. abstract: Yesterday, Coroner WILDEY, held an inquest at the house of Mrs. WORCESTER, at No. 539 Hudson-street, over the remains of an unknown woman who died there last Wednesday afternoon, from the alleged effects of an abortion. Dr. WO[???]STER BEACH made a post-mortem examination, and [???]pned that death had ensued from disease of the heart and not from the effects of an abortion, as was first supposed, and the jury rendered a verdict in accordance with these facts. The remains have not yet been identified.

abstract: N.C. -- A late copy of the Salisbury Banner says: "Miss TEMPLE NEELY, the young lady accused of killing the negro woman near Mocksville, is at the residence of Mr. T.J. FOSTER, in this city, under guard. We learn that the act was perfectly justifiable, as all who are acquainted with Miss NEELY will very readily believe. The negro woman had assaulted her mother, and was beating her, when, alarmed by her cries, Miss NEELY ran to her rescue, and shot the negro through the heart with a revolver, of the kind known as a lady's pocket pistol. Her friends and those conversant with the circumstances have no doubt that in the coming investigation, the propriety of her conduct will be made clear. A preliminary investigation simply was held yesterday before Col. FARLEIGH."
lead_paragraph: N.C. -- A late copy of the Salisbury Banner says: "Miss TEMPLE NEELY, the young lady accused of killing the negro woman near Mocksville, is at the residence of Mr. T.J. abstract: Mary, the Handmaid of our Lord
snippet: Mary, the Handmaid of our Lord
lead_paragraph: The great success of this beautifully-printed volume, the first edition of which was sold off in a few days, shows that Mrs. CHARLES does not need to rely on the attractions of fictitious narrative for securing the sympathies of her readers. Novelty of incident of course is not the charm of this beautiful book. It is the reverent and thoughtful tone of mind that the authoress brings to the contemplation of one of the most deeply interesting characters of sacred writ, one too, that from the natural reaction against the erroneous views and practices of another religious body, is often less considered by Protestants than its important place in the plan of the world's redemption should command.

abstract: The steam-yacht Clara Clarita, which has been so kindly tendered to Mr. WILLIAM E. EVERETT, for the purpose of repairing the submarine cable at Aspy Bay, so necessary to make the connection complete between the great Atlantic Telegraph Cable, when it shall arrive on our shores, and this city, sailed yesterday morning. She left the dock at the Novelty Iron Works and proceeded up the Sound in fine style. The Clara Clarita is owned by LEONARD W. JEROME, Esq., and he is entitled to much praise for so generously tendering his beautiful yacht for such important and arduous service. She will, no doubt, receive some rough usage before she will have completed her service. Mr. EVERETT, who was for a long time if our naval service, will take as good care of her as possible.

abstract: The Ninety-fourth New-York, Ninth Maine, Fifth Connecticut and Fifth United States Veteran Volunteer regiments arrived during Saturday afternoon and night. Yesterday the One Hundred and Forty-third New-York and Second Massachusetts Cavalry also arrived. On Saturday the Ninth Maine and Fifth United States Veterans left for Augusta and Hartford. The Fifth Connecticut, Second Massachusetts and Ninety-fourth New-York left for their respective rendezvous, at Hartford, Readville and Albany, last evening. The Corcoran Legion, Ninety-ninth New-York and Sixty-fifth New-York, have goneto Hart's Island. The One Hundred and Forty-third New-York will probably go to the island to-day.

abstract: Perry, Gov., the Speech of
lead_paragraph: -The news by the steamer Peruvian, published in yesterday's TIMES, showed that half or nearly half the elections are already over. Thus far the Whigs, under Lord PALMERSTON, have apparently gained nothing. The Tories have lost six seats, but these cannot be counted as absolute Whig gains. JOHN STUART MILL, for example, can hardly be regarded as a Ministerial accession. And it is doubtful even whether THOMAS HUGHES ("Tom Brown") can be ranked in the Ministerial lists. The governing party, moreover, (they are called Liberals by courtesy,) have had some of their underlings rejected, and most righteously, we believe. Among others of the small official tribe rejected, we note the name of Lord BURY, Treasurer of the Queen's Household -- a young man, known here as an official in the neighboring provinces, and son-in-law of the late Sir ALLAN MCNAB, of rebellion notoriety. One of the PAGETS, too -- whether CLARENCE or ALFRED, it is not stated -- figures among the rejected. CLARENCE is Secretary of the Admiralty, and a good-tempered placeman. ALFRED is an officer of the Queen's hoosehold, and is chiefly known by having made one laughable speech, in connection with the arrival of the Princess ALEXANDRA in England, and of having broken down in attempting to make a second. Col. WHITE, who is likewise one of the rejected Whig officials, was member for Kidderminster. And as for Mr. FREDERICK PEEL, he is an Under Secretary, and the son of his father. No one ever supposed he was fit to be anything but a Whig placeman, and it seems the electors of the burgh of Bury think he is not even fit for that. They have, therefore, cast him out.

abstract: Eureka vs. Keystone, at Newark; Atlantic vs. Union
snippet: Eureka vs. Keystone, at Newark; Atlantic vs. Union
lead_paragraph: The keystone Club, which left Philadelphia yesterday at 8 A.M., arrived at the Market-street deot, Newark, at 11:45, where they were welcomed by a large crowd of the Eureka Club and escorted to DITTLER JAHN'S restaurant in Market-street, where the Philadelphians were duly refreshed outwardly and inwardly, the whole party sitting down to a truly palatable collation provided by the hospitable Eurekas, after which the visitors were taken through the suburbs of the city in a six-horse stage, by way of passing away time until the hour for commencing play. While en route to the club rooms the party stopped at Clinton Gardens to try some fine Newark lager, during the discussion of which the Mozart Glee Club, composed of members of the Keystone Club, favored the company with a beautiful glee in their best style. After returning to the city they proceeded to the club rooms adjoining the Eureka grounds on Ferry and Adams streets, and at 3:45 the contesting nines of the two clubs began play together in the presence of a large crowd of spectators, attracted to witness the first performances of the Keystones in Newark.

abstract: About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a serious affray occured at the Corner of East Broadway and...
lead_paragraph: About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a serious affray occured at the Corner of East Broadway and Market-street. BRYAN REILLY, a member of Engine Company No. 2, was dangerously shot, and Officer WILLIAM L. WALLACE, of the Seventh Precinct, while endeavoring to quell the disturbance and disperse the mob, was brutally beaten, and will probably be unfit for duty for a long time. It is alleged that THOMAS SHIELDS, proprietor of a saloon in the neighborhood of the affray, who was drunk and disorderly at the time, instigated the affray. He was arrested after a desperate struggle, and taken to the station-house. The officers were compelled to use their locusts freely to conquer him. Capt. JAMEISON, of the Seventh Precinct, made a report to Inspector CARPENTER, from which it appears that Officer WALLACE was the first to reach the scene of disturbance, when he was instantly surrounded by a mob, and was compelled to fight his way out, or run the risk of losing his life. During the melee a pistol was discharged, the ball from which took effect in the right side of REGAN REILLY. The latter was taken to the New-York Hospital for treatment yesterday morning. SHIELDS was arraigned at the Essex Market Police Court on a charge of assaulting and beating Officer WALLACE. A commitment was made out for the accused, and while Officer WALLACE was taking SHIELDS to the cell, the latter turned and struck the officer in open court, and afterward kicked him while lying helpless on the floor. The magistrate required SHIELDS to give additional bail in the sum of $500 for the second assault. RICHARD WALTERS, of No. 27 East Broadway, became bondsman for SHIELDS. It being found that REILLY could not live, Coroner COLLIN yesterday went to the Hospital and took his deposition, as follows:

abstract: The One Hundred and Sixty-ninth New-York and Seventeenth Connecticut Regiments arrived yesterday, the first from City Point, via Baltimore, and the other from Hilton Head. The New-York boys took dinner at the State Agency, and left during the afternoon for Troy by the John Brooks. The Connecticut regiment departed for Hartford. The One Hundred and Forty-third New-York and the Fifth New-York Artillery left yesterday for Hart's Island, to be paid off. Gen. HOOKER received the compliment of a salute and hearty greeting at the hands of the One Hundred and Forty-third, making a few complimentary remarks in return.

abstract: The homeward march of the gallant boys in blue will soon come to an end. Very few regiments belonging to New-York or the Eastern States now remain in the field. In all probability, the 1st of August will see the glorious and triumphant march toward home and a peaceful lite, come to a close, and thus will cease all semblance of a great war that has cost so large an expenditure of life and treasure. Yesterday only two regiments arrived on their way to be finally mustered out.

abstract: Mr. JOHN MCGOWAN, of No. 101 Norfolk-street, has recently suspected his wife ELEANOR of unfaithfulness; his suspicions were directed against JOHN GANNON, a cousin of Mrs. MCGOWAN; on Sunday night he found his wife and her cousin in an improper position, when he ordered GANNON from the house. To hasten GANNON's departure MCGOWAN hurled a spittoon at his head, when an exciting scene followed. While Mrs. MCGOWAN was standing near the head of the stairs her husband accidentally ran against her and knocked her down, when she fell to the landing. She was taken up insensible and died a few hours afterward. MCGOWAN surrendered himself to the Tenth Precinct Police. Yesterday Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body. Dr. ROBINSON testified that in his opinion death was caused by indulgence in liquor and undue excitement, and the jury rendered a verdict to that effect. Mr. MCGOWAN was discharged from custody.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN MCGOWAN, of No. 101 Norfolk-street, has recently suspected his wife ELEANOR of unfaithfulness; his suspicions were directed against JOHN GANNON, a cousin of Mrs. MCGOWAN; on Sunday night he found his wife and her cousin in an improper position, when he ordered GANNON from the house. While Mrs. MCGOWAN was standing near the head of the stairs her husband accidentally ran against her and knocked her down, when she fell to the landing. She was taken up insensible and died a few hours afterward. MCGOWAN surrendered himself to the Tenth Precinct Police. Yesterday Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body. Dr. ROBINSON testified that in his opinion death was caused by indulgence in liquor and undue excitement, and the jury rendered a verdict to that effect. Mr. MCGOWAN was discharged from custody.

abstract: At every meeting of the Police Commissioners for the trial of police cases, complaints are made by parties who have been arrested without cause and even on the most frivolous pretexts. These arrests, are, of course, made by officers who are insufficiently acquainted with their duty, but they are none the less annoying to the parties arrested. A case occurred a few days ago, in which the stupidity of a policeman was sufficiently exemplified. An intoxicated soldier entered CROOK & DUFF's dining-saloon, in Park-row,and becoming very noisy was politely requested by the Superintendent, Mr. NASH, to be quiet. Shortly afterward the man produced some clams from his pocket and taking up a plated ivory-handled table-knife proceeded therewith to extricate the bivalve. Mr. NASH seeing that the man would not listen to reason, took hold of him by the shoulders and put him out on the sidewalk, the man still retaining his hold of the knife. Mr. NASH then grasped his hand and endeavored to take the knife from him, and in so doing the man fell on the sidewalk. A policeman, THOMAS MURRAY, of the Second Precinct, at once came up, declared that the soldier was badly hurt, and that Mr. NASH must accompany him to the station-house. Mr. NASH accordingly went to the station-house and related the whole affair to Sergeant LATTY, who ordered the officer to take the case to court. In this the Sergeant only did his duty, as he had no power to release an arrested person without an order from a Police Magistrate. On the case being brought before Justice DOWLING, he merely inquired whether the man was drunk, and on being assured by Mr. NASH that he was, he at once ordered him to be locked up, and told Mr. NASH that he was at liberty to return to his duties.

abstract: Intelligencer; On Public Debt and High Prices
snippet: Intelligencer; On Public Debt and High Prices
lead_paragraph: "We shall have at the close of the month a statement from the Treasury of the amount of the public debt. It will not vary much from the statement of the 1st of June, except so far as it may have been increased by the issue of certificates of indebtedness, and by the last series of the seven-thirty loan. The amount of the debt on the 1st of August may, perhaps, be twenty-eight hundred millions, or a little more. The authority for borrowing money on long loans will be exhausted with the last series of seven-thirties. There remains of this loan to-day, untaken, forty millions or less. At the close of the loan it is probable that the whole remainder will be taken up in large sums, as heretofore. There will be no new loan till Congress shall authorize one, and, meanwhile, it is supposed that the Treasury can meet all demands upon it by the current revenue, and without calling too rapidly upon the national banks for the public deposits. Some have apprehended, from this source, great stringency in the money market, which would have the evil effect of raising prices of living -- prices which are now almost intolerable, and apparently unreasonable." -- National Intelligencer.

abstract: The Otawa (C.W.) Citizen says: "The theatrical wardrobe of the late JOHN WILKES BOOTH, recovered about a month ago from the wreck of the schooner Maria Victoria, at Bic, last Fall, was disposed of by decree of the Vice-Admiralty Court, by public auction, at Quebec, by Messrs. CASEY & Co., auctioneers at the Champlain Market Hall. Among the wardrobe, which unfortunately had been injured by salt water, there was a splendid collection of theatrical clothes, in fine silk velvets, silks, satin, ermine, crimson clothing, hats, caps, plumes, boots and buskins, shoes, &c. In swords and pistols, there was a case or trunk packed with a large variety of some very beautifully mounted ones among them. The competition, on the whole, was very spirited, and several articles were sold at exceedingly high prices. The amount realized for the wardrobe, in its damaged state, was about $500. The original cost cannot have been less than $1,500."

abstract: Era of Past
lead_paragraph: One great lesson taught by all wars or national struggles, is the relation between the true and the false, the real and the unreal, in human progress or advancement. The contest now happily closed, was one of the great educators of the nation. It brought with it a recognition of many truths heretofore unlearned or disregarded. It sets before us as a people the faithful reflex of what we are, and left us to draw the conclusion as to what we may become.

abstract: Capt. JOURDAN and Officer WOOLDRIDGE, of the Sixth Precinct, arrested Louis and JACOB BALLENBERG, brothers, doing business at No. 168 Canal-street, on a charge of receiving $1,900 worth of silk and velvet trimmings which had been stolen from No. 546 Pearl-street, GEORGE W. PEARSON, who is said to be one of the burglars, confessed to Capt. JOURDAN that he assisted in removing the goods from the store. PEARSON says that all of the goods were taken to BALLENBERG's store, and the entire lot sold for $180. Justice DOWLING committed the aroused for examination. It is supposed that the stolen goods will be recovered.

abstract: SAD CASE OF DESTITUTION. A family consisting of a mother and four children, named OULD, residing corner of Graham-avenue and Powers-street, Eastern Division, were yesterday discovered by Officer COLGAN of the Forty-sixth Precinct, suffering the horrors of famine and disease. The father of the family, a German named JOSEPH OULD, was some time since in business for himself, but failed.
lead_paragraph: SAD CASE OF DESTITUTION. -- A family consisting of a mother and four children, named OULD, residing corner of Graham-avenue and Powers-street, Eastern Division, were yesterday discovered by Officer COLGAN of the Forty-sixth Precinct, suffering the horrors of famine and disease. The father of the family, a German named JOSEPH OULD, was some time since in business for himself, but failed. At the time of his failure he had some thirty or forty dollars, but his wife taking sick the physician who attended her claimed and received the whole amount. Since that time they have been living upon such garbage as the children found in the gutters. The father, in a fit of desperation, started off somewhere in search of employment, and has not since returned. Superintendent FITZGERALD hearing of this sad case has given relief to the sufferers.

abstract: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- That quaint old specimen of dramatic artifice called the "Soldier's Daughter," was played here last night for the purpose of introducing Mr. SEDLEY SMITH to the audience. The gentleman is a favorite with our Boston friends, and enjoys the metropolitan distinction of being the father of one of our most charming comediennes -- Mrs SEDLEY BROWN. In the stormy part of Governor Heartall, Mr. SMITH appeared only to moderate advantage, but with sufficient emphasis and discretion to demonstrate the value of his addition to the company. Such characters, in truth, are no longer attractive on the stage, and in real life they never existed. "You lie, you scoundrel," is a vigorous form of speech, reminding one of the editorial columns of a contemporary, but its too frequent repetition is aggravating. There is hardly anything else to fall back upon. The inevitable nephew was played carefully but somewhat tamely by Mr. G.D. CHAPLIN, and the wearisome poor gentleman, ("the dear friend of my dead brother," guggle, guggle, et seq.,) with the thin breeches and thick skull, who, it is plain to everyone, could be more easily touched with a kick than an idea, this vaporous creature was personated by Mr. HAMBLIN -- a gentleman who is struggling bravely and conscientiously with the difficulties of his profession. Miss KATE REIGNOLDS was a good Wiaow Cheerly. She is, indeed, excellent in all that she undertakes, but shines particularly in comedy; even in this sort of comedy, with its intense verbosity and artificial plumping of silly sentences. Miss REIGNOLDS' archness is sometimes a little overwhelming, but as a rule she is discreet and charming. To-night she appears in the "Youthful Days of Richelieu," in which she was quite successful last week.

abstract: A SKIRMISH IN BROADWAY. On Sunday afternoon a disturbance occurred in Broadway, which, but for the interference of citizens, would undoubtedly have had a serious result. An infantry regiment was moving up Broadway, followed upon the sidewalk by a number of stragglers. The regiment had passed Cortlandt-street, when a party of fifteen or twenty cavalrymen, dismounted, turned the corner of Broadway and mingled with the stragglers.
lead_paragraph: A SKIRMISH IN BROADWAY. -- On Sunday afternoon a disturbance occurred in Broadway, which, but for the interference of citizens, would undoubtedly have had a serious result. An infantry regiment was moving up Broadway, followed upon the sidewalk by a number of stragglers. The regiment had passed Cortlandt-street, when a party of fifteen or twenty cavalrymen, dismounted, turned the corner of Broadway and mingled with the stragglers. One of the former jostled against one of the infantry, and upon being remonstrated with, assaulted him. Upon this, the assaulted soldier, using his musket as a club, knocked the cavalryman down. His companions immediately drew their sabres for a charge, while the friends of the insulted soldier rallied to his support. The troopers kept off their intended assailants with their swords, but the latter prepared to resort to a long range fight, fixed their bayonets, loaded their muskets and would probably have resorted to extreme measures but for the interference of citizens, who persuaded them to be quiet and not disgrace their uniforms. The officers of returning regiments should prevent their men from straggling in the streets.

abstract: -- There will be a special commemoration and celebration at Yale College on Wednesday of this week, in honor of about seven hundred students from the university who have taken part in the military and naval service of the nation during the recent war. A large attendance is anticipated. At 11:30 o'clock of that day, Rev. HORACE BUSHNELL, D.D., will deliver the oration in the North Church, the procession leaving the college at 11 o'clock. The church gallery will be open to ladies at 10:30. The main attraction of the day, however, will be the great dinner to the Veteran Alumni, at Music Hall, at 2 o'clock. WM.M. EVARTS, Esq., of New-York will preside, and the occasion is expected to be one of rare interest. Guests specially invited are requested to call and receive cards of admission at the room under the Trumbull gallery, next to the Treasurer's office, on Tuesday afternoon from 3 to 8 o'clock, and on Wednesday morning from 8 to 11, and no person will be admitted to the hall without a ticket. Graduates and officers of the college in any department may obtain tickets on the payment of $3 each by applying at the same time and place, and a limited number of tickets, admitting to reserved seats in the galleries, may be procured at $1 each.

abstract: -- There appears to be a remarkable disagreement between the Holy See and the secular governments both in the Eastern and Western hemispheres. Spain, whose sovereign enjoys the distinction of a Most Catholic monarch, has proceeded to recognize the Kingdom of Italy at the very crisis of the negotiations between VICTOR EMANUEL and the Vatican on the subject of temporal supremacy. And, as if this were not aggravating enough to the Head of the Church, MAXIMILIAN's Envoy at the Court of Rome has so misconducted himself that his mission is to be closed. Along with this comes the alarming rumor that Prince MAXIMILIAN himself is to be excommunicated. This is a beautiful condition of things, and shows how far our modern systems of government, liberal and illiberal, have departed and are daily departing from the Roman apostolic standard.

abstract: Fire Department and the Comptroller
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors, at their meeting last week, directed the Comptroller to prepare an ordinance making the necessary appropriations for the Metropolitan Fire Department. At the meeting of the board yesterday, a communication was received from the Comptroller stating that, according to the provisions of the law, the expenditures of the Metropolitan Fire Department are city and not county charges, and that, consequently, the appropriations must be made by the Common Council. As one of the boards of the Common Council has adjourned to September, and as it is well known that a large majority of the members are opposed to a Paid Fire Department, it will probably be some months before the Fire Commissioners obtain the appropriations necessary for carrying on the operations of the department.

abstract: Williamsburgh, Highway, Third-street in Afternoon
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- Yesterday afternoon a man aged 70 years, was walking along Fourth-avenue, near Third-street, Gowanus, when he was met by two young fellows, who accosted him and asked what time it was. While the old man was getting his watch out -- the process being rather slow -- one of the fellows "turned him over," and the other took his watch, a silver one, for which he had paid 10 sterling, in London. His pockets were rifled, and only five cents and a bunch of keys were found. The money was appropriated, but the thieves were magnaminous enough to let him retain the keys. Sergeant MATHEWS and Officer SCOTT, of the Fiftieth Precinct Police, being informed of the occurrence, pursued the fellows, and officer SCOTT nabbed one of them, who is known by the name of Butcher MORSE. The other escaped over Carroll-street bridge, and had not been arrested up to a late hour last night; but as he is known he will doubtless be taken into custody some time. The old man was badly injured. His face was covered with blood. The police attended to him as best they could, and called in a physician, who dressed his wounds. He was detained at the station-house until able to go to his home.

abstract: England and France; Joint Action on American Affairs
snippet: England and France; Joint Action on American Affairs
lead_paragraph: The concert of action between tho government of England and the government of France, as to the policy to be pursued toward the North and South during the war, continued until the close of the rebellion. Tha latest official publications we have upon the subject are certain dispatches that passed between Earl RUSSELL and the British representatives at the French Court, in May and June last. Earl RUSSELL, under date of May 30, says to Earl COWLEY: "Your Excellency will have been enabled by my telegram of this morning to prepare M. DROUYN DE LHUYS for the communication of the views of Her Majesty's government as to the course which, in the present posture of affairs in the United States, may properly be adopted by the governments of England and France." Further on, in the same dispatch, he says: "The government of the Emperor will probably view the matter in the same light; and, under this impression, Her Majesty's government desire your Excellency to propose that the two governments should agree at once to adopt the following measures," &c.

abstract: Hutchins, John, of Williamsburgh
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF AN OLD STEAMBOAT PILOT. -- Mr. JOHN HUTCHINS, a well-known resident of Williamsburgh, died, yesterday morning, of disease of the heart, at his residence in South Second-street, between Fifth and Sixth streets, at the age of 83 years. The deceased was born in Newcastle, Westchester County, in the year 1783, and at the age of 13 years he had the honor of acting as steersman for the first steamboat ever made in the United States, which was constructed by JOHN FITCH, and sailed on "Collect Pond," the site of what is now occupied by the Tombs, in New-York. Mr. HUTCHINS for the past fifty years had been connected with the Methodist church, and was also chaplain of Hyatt Lodge of Freemasons, and was supposed to be the oldest Freemason in the United States.

abstract: -- The question whether the East or North River presents the greater advantages for country residences, remains undecided. If the test be the price to be paid to gratify a preference, the Hudson carries the day. Those who prefer a limitless water-view, yachting, bathing, fishing, may gratify their choice at a sale on the premises, on Saturday next, by P.C. BULKLEY, of the Clark Estate, at Rye, extending to and fronting on Rye Beach. Judge BRADFORD has already purchased one of the sites.

abstract: If there had been newspapers in the eighth century, when the wandering pirates of the Northern seas first ravaged the shores of the Green Isle, we should be able to ascertain when it was that Ireland began to organize societies to liberate herself, for doubtless even in those chaotic days there were demagogues and self-seeking leaders who were ready to traffic in national humiliation, and rise upon any wave of popular emotion that promised to hoist them into power or notoriety.

abstract: Trial of Rebel Torturers of
lead_paragraph: The assassins of the President disposed of, the government will next take in hand the ruffians who tortured to death thousands of Union prisoners. The laws of civilized warfare must be vindicated; and some expiation must be exacted for the most infernal crime of the century. The guilt is of that character which it is impossible to cover by any legal perversion, or by any denial of the evidence. The laws of war, which require that prisoners should not be put to death, and shall be spared all needless suffering, are as distinctly set forth by all the standard authorities on the subject, and as universally recognized by Christian nations as any principles of public law. The fact that the prisoners in the hands of the rebels were subjected to unnecessary cruelties, which, in thousands of instances, resulted in death, rests upon proofs that exclude all possibility of doubt. Even if, in the spirit of extremest charity, it be allowed that the meagreness of the rebel commissary stores was such that the prisoner depots could barely be furnished with a sufficiency of wholesome food, there were other deadly cruelties than starvation, for which it is impossible to plead any such necessity. Nothing can be said in mitigation of the stripping of our prisoners of the apparel required for their warmth, of refusing them fire, of withholding pure water, of selecting miasmatic sites for places of confinement, of making those places mere pens, without roofs or any shelter whatever from the scorching suns of Summer, and the pelting storms of Winter; or any of the other hundred forms of maltreatment, all calculated to kill by inches. Give the rebels the benefit of every possible excuse in connection with their straitened means, and other peculiar circumstances, and yet the fact stands that thousands of Northern soldiers are buried under Southern soil who to-day would be rejoicing at home had they received, we will not say such treatment as did the rebel prisoners in our hands, but the treatment the rebels could have given, had they been disposed, even had their disadvantages been ten times greater than they were.

abstract: Celebration in New-York
lead_paragraph: We are becoming a Nation of Pic-Nickians. Sunday schools, churches, target companies, brothers of every name and degree, Germans, Irishmen, Frenchmen, and colored persons, one and all, spread themselves and their table cloths regularly once a year in the open air, where, to the merry music of blatant brass and deafening drum they dance and celebrate their souls. We had passed safely and serenly through an entire week of Teutonic feest, and were about settled in dull routine when huge pieces of pasteboard, gilded and grand, requested the honor of our presence at another monster festival, an Irish celebration, a Fenian demonstration, at that Schildknechtian Paradise, Jones Woods.

abstract: LARGE FIRE NEAR BERGEN TUNNEL.-About 12 o'clock on Monday night a fire was discovered in the extensive cattle pens, formerly occupied also for slaughtering purposes, belonging to the Erie Railroad Company, and situated near the western debouchment of the Bergen Tunnel, at a place called West End.
lead_paragraph: LARGE FIRE NEAR BERGEN TUNNEL. -- About 12 o'clock on Monday night a fire was discovered in the extensive cattle pens, formerly occupied also for slaughtering purposes, belonging to the Erie Railroad Company, and situated near the western debouchment of the Bergen Tunnel, at a place called West End. The area covered by the sheds was very large, and sufficient to accommodate temporarily a considerable number of cattle, prior to their transfer to the cattle-yards on Bergen Hill and other depots. About the centre of the area was a very extensive building, which also sheltered cattle, and which was formerly used as the main slaughter-house. Owing to the combustible character of the buildings -- the wood-work being, in some instances, almost saturated with grease -- the flames spread with great rapidity, and soon enveloped the entire property. The fire caused a brilliant light and attracted the attention of the fire companies of Union Hill, West Hoboken and Jersey City, who hastened to the assistance of their Hudson City brethren. All efforts to subdue the flames, however, were unavailing until some adjoining buildings were torn down, when the progress of the fire toward the neighboring dwellings was stayed. The fire occurred on the identical spot made notorious as the scene of the tunnel riots four years ago, and the rioters were addressed by the Priest and Mayor from the platform upon which cattle were landed preparatory to being sent to the pens. The loss is estimated at from $15,000 to $20,000, on which there is no insurance.

abstract: There was a large gathering of the "crack shots" from the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, &c., yesterday, at the Centreville Course, L.I., to witness the two matches between Messrs. HARTSHORNE and SIMPSON, at double and single birds. The matches were made for $200 a side, each event, at 25 double birds each, 21 yards rise, 60 yards bounds, 1 1/2 ounce shot, find and trap for each other, pull for themselves. The second match was made on the same conditions, at 50 single birds. Each match to be shot off on the 25th July. In the first match, Mr. HARTSHORNE felled 27 birds out of 23 pairs; Mr. SIMPSON counted 22 out of the 23 pair, he shooting 7 pair double birds, while HARTSHORNE brought down 5 pair. Several private matches were shot off in the interval of the first and second matches.

abstract: Keystone, of Philadelphia, vs. Mutual, of New-York
snippet: Keystone, of Philadelphia, vs. Mutual, of New-York
lead_paragraph: The second match of the series in which the Keystone Club have been engaged in this week, took place at Hoboken yesterday, in the presence of an assemblage of spectators numbering over three thousand, considerable curiosity being evinced to see whether the Mutuals would defeat the Keystones more than the Eurekas had done. As in all the games played by the Mutuals since their first and best game with the Empires, in June last, they played without HARRIS, MCSWEENEY, their swift pitcher, being in his place, and, as in the two previous games, the contest turned out to be a tedious one, in comparison to the lively play which characterized the first Empire match.

abstract: -- The son of a well-known Federal official in Brooklyn (19th Ward) became so frantic on Monday last, inconsequence of being discarded by the lady to whom he was paying attentions, that he swallowed a large dose of laudanum for the purpose of committing suicide. His mother was soon after informed of the rash act and sent for the family physician, who, by the forcible application of antidotes, saved the young man's life. The only recognition the physician received for his services was a torrent of foul invectives -- the would-be suicide declaring that no man had a right to prevent him taking his own life when the lady whom he loved called him a goose.

abstract: Honors to the Brave at
lead_paragraph: The celebrations that are being held by some of our great colleges, in commemoration of those of their graduates who fell during the war, and in honor of those who have done service and survived it, deserve commendation, and their example ought to be followed by all the institutions of learning in the land. That at Harvard last week, of which the TIMES yesterday contained a full and admirable account, was altogether the most imposing that has yet taken place. It showed, so far as it went, and we know that the record in every other case would be essentially the same, how noble has been the patriotic attitude and practical action of the scholarship and intellect of the republic during its late crisis. It disposes of the wicked statement of the Copperheads that those who were learned and well-to-do contented themselves with urging others to rush to the battle-field, while they devoted themselves to selfish ease. The simple facts that out of 2,400 living graduates of Harvard (including the aged, sick, absent and all,) over five hundred voluntarily entered the service of the country, and one hundred of them fell in it, (not counting the wounded and sick,) furnish a sufficient answer to all the falsehoods and sneers about the matter. Ten fell at Gettysburgh, said Gov. ANDREW; seven fell at Antietam; five at Fredericksburgh, five at Cedar Mountain, five in this struggle, and as many more in that; and every arm of the service, military and naval, was represented; every rank, from Major-General to private, from Gen. WADSWORTH, who fell in the Wilderness, to private EMERSON, who fell at Chancellorsville. At this commemoration alone there were present twelve distinguished General officers who had graduated at Harvard, and, in the true democracy of New-England, they shared the honors of the day with those of their fellow-graduates who had done service as privates in the ranks. "God knows," exclaimed RALPH WALDO EMERSON, "God knows these scholars and idealists had no fury for killing their old friends and countrymen;" but "they exchanged the black coat for the blue," because of their all-dominating devotion to their country.

abstract: Peter Murphy and Joseph Flynn, two rather rough-looking, knocked-about characters, were charged with robbing Edward Kelly, a seaman, of only seventy-five cents. That was all they took, and all they had the chance to take, as an officer made his appearance before they could complete the robbery which they had commenced. The sailor, having been on a spree, fell asleep on the door-step, and only knew he had been robbed when he was aroused by the officers, and when he did look up, there were the thieves in custody.
lead_paragraph: Peter Murphy and Joseph Flynn, two rather rough-looking, knocked-about characters, were charged with robbing Edward Kelly, a seaman, of only seventy-five cents. abstract: One of the most animated sights at the great horse show is the exhibition of the roadster sires every afternoon, about 5 o'clock. The predominant color of those round, stout, active horses is roan. There are also amongst them some good browns and blacks. Quicksilver, the winner of the first prize, is a bright red roan, of surpassing courage and action. As soon as the roadsters have retired. Shepherd Knapp, a chestnut trotting stallion from New-York, with a white blaze down his face, makes his appearance in a light match-cart, and is driven round the arena at a pace which shows that, speedy as the Norfolk horses are, there are none of them that could hold their own with their American cousin. He is lighter and more highly bred than they are, and his hind-leg action is tremendously powerful and true. The spacious area at the Agricultural Hall is far too limited to allow his driver to exhibit Shepherd Knapp's full speed; the perfect temper with which the astonishing animal, guided and controlled by a smooth snaffle, allows himself to be suddenly and easily pulled up when going at the rate of twenty miles an hour, daily elicits thunders of applause from the admiring spectators. Their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of WALES visited the hall yesterday about 6 o'clock, and seemed much struck by the performance of the American horse. --Pall Mall Gazette, July 11.

abstract: A NOVEL SHIPMENT. -- The steamer De Molay will leave this city in the early part of August with three hundred women bound for Washington Territory. These women will be selected by Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, from the cotton operatives of that State. The enterprise is under the auspices of the Governor and Hon. Mr. MERCER, a member of the Executive Council of Washington Territory; the latter desiring to supply the unmarried men of the Territory with wives, there being a scarcity of women in that vicinity. The De Molay has been placed at the disposal of the proprietors of the scheme by the government, under the sanction of Gen. GRANT. She will take her living and lovely freight to the Isthmus, whence they will be sent to Aspinwall, and thence at the expense of Washington Territory, to their destination. If this novel enterprise should be successful we may expect to see it repeated.
lead_paragraph: A NOVEL SHIPMENT. -- The steamer De Molay will leave this city in the early part of August with three hundred women bound for Washington Territory. These women will be selected by Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, from the cotton operatives of that State. The enterprise is under the auspices of the Governor and Hon. Mr. MERCER, a member of the Executive Council of Washington Territory; the latter desiring to supply the unmarried men of the Territory with wives, there being a scarcity of women in that vicinity. The De Molay has been placed at the disposal of the proprietors of the scheme by the government, under the sanction of Gen. GRANT. She will take her living and lovely freight to the Isthmus, whence they will be sent to Aspinwall, and thence at the expense of Washington Territory, to their destination. If this novel enterprise should be successful we may expect to see it repeated.

abstract: The One Hundred and Second New-York Regiment was the only command arriving yesterday. The regiment numbered 625 men, under the command of Col. H.S. CHATFIELD. It was the intention of the friends of the One Hundred and Second to give it a formal reception to-day, but the regiment left during the afternoon for Hart's Island, thus defeating their amiable intentions. The One Hundred and Second halted in front of the Astor House and saluted Gen. HOOKER with three cheers and a tiger. In reply the General made a short speech.

abstract: New-York, Greene-street,Highway; Mr. Sherman
lead_paragraph: Officer MULLEN, of the Fourth Precinct, yesterday arrested MARGARET LYNCH, alias SULLIVAN, a domestic, on a charge of stealing a gold watch and chain from JACOB P. THURSTON, living at No. 49 Cherry-street. It appears that the complainant accompanied the girl to a disreputable house in New Bowery, a few nights ago, where the theft is alleged to have been committed. The prisoner confessed her guilt after her arrest, and told where the stolen property could be found. Justice HOGAN committed her for trial. It is said that this is the second time Mr. THURSTON's watch has been stolen.

abstract: THE ALLEGED NAVY-YARD FRAUDS. -- The examination in the case of JOHM MAXON, JOHN R. MARSDEN, WM. MCDERMOTT and FRANCIS RILEY, charged with manufacturing articles for their own personal use in the Navy-yard, was continued before the United States Commissioner yesterday. EDWIN S. DELUCE, the Chief-Engineer of the yard, testified to the knowledge of a bookcase which was concealed in the pattern-shop. It was detained in witness' private office for some time, when it was given to the Master Cooper, for whom it was made, and was now in his office. JOHN VAN DORN, draughtsman, testified that an order for a mahogany bookcase was given for his office, and it was now there. After this witness' testimony, the case was adjourned till this morning.

abstract: Speeches
lead_paragraph: It is pleasant to hear a soldier tell of his battles and a victor recount his triumphs. But we fear that the friends of Gen. SHERMAN, in the West, will not add to his fame by compelling him to deliver public speeches at the rate of two or three a week. We have published a number of these speeches, and yesterday we gave quite a lengthy one, which he delivered at St. Louis a few days ago. As is natural, they relate mainly to his own exploits in the war. During its progress he was bitterly averse to the correspondents who attempted to follow him and chronicle his deeds; and we judge now the reason was that he considered them ignorant as to the real part he played in the conduct of affairs. That part, it would seem, has been much greater than ever was heretofore supposed. Even in the earliest stages of the war, before GRANT had achieved a single victory, Gen. SHERMAN told HALLECK privately that the "perpendicular" of the rebel line in the southwest was the Tennessee River, and that it would have to be broken "physically by a perpendicular force." And so he goes on, narrating circumstances of the subsequent great campaigns in the Mississippi Valley, showing, at every step, how little these people know who attributed their success to the genius of GRANT.

abstract: The great issue before the voters of Kentucky, to be decided at the election of Aug. 7, is the constitutional amendment. In view of this election, an energetic canvass of the State is now going forward. The Unionists are sanguine that a sufficient number of pro-amendment men will be elected to the coming Legislature to insure the success of an enactment that shall make Kentucky, by her own emphatic verdict, henceforth and forever free.

abstract: Capital and Labor; their Meeting
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the workmen at different trades and handicrafts are meeting together extensively to discuss their interests, and are taking council one with another. The question of wages, the question of hours of work, the question of apprenticeship, the question of the relations of labor and capital, and other questions, temporary and permanent, will all be helped to a satisfactory solution by wise discussion, and by a comparison of views and notes on the part of all concerned. We think it would be well if those Societies and Unions which are composed mainly of the working craftsmen, would secure the attendance at their meetings of those who are employers, "bosses" and capitalists. Many misunderstandings would thus be prevented, many mistakes corrected, many theories tested at both ends. It seems from the proceedings of some of these societies that many of their members cannot get out of their heads the notion that capital is everlastingly and necessarily at war with labor, that employers are the natural enemies of the employed, and that it is the duty of one to organize for perpetual resistance to the other. It is curious enough that such opinions should exist in this country; but that they do, it needs but that one should attend any of these trade meetings to be satisfied. Freedom of discussion, however, if it be permitted, and a comparison of views between employers and employed, if it could be had, would soon rectify all such damaging errors.

abstract: Mrs. ELLEN HEFFERNAN, at a late hour on Monday night, went into a liquor-store at the corner of Avenue C and Tenth-street. While there she exhibited $25 in treasury notes. On returning to her home, No. 175 Avenue A, she was followed by three or four men. In the entry-way they seized her. She called for help, and her husband ran down stairs to the aid of his wife. At the bottom of the stairs HEFFERNAN was seized and held until the thieves had obtained his wife's money. Officer JOHNSON, of the Eleventh Precinct, came up just at that moment, and arrested two of the ruffians -- FRANK MCGINNISS and JOHN MURRAY by name. The money was not recovered. Justice SHANDLEY committed the accused for examination.

abstract: We are informed that the Morris and Essex Railroad Company have ordered their engine-drivers to suspend the amusement of trying speed with the New-Jersey engines on the meadow between the Hackensack and the Passaic Rivers. It is now ordered, by both companies, we believe, that the train nearest to the 1,500-feet signal-posts, as they approach either river, shall push ahead, and the one in the rear shall follow at such rate as to avoid even the appearance of racing. The railroads have done a simple act of justice to themselves and the public it is well.

abstract: Grinnell, M. J., of Williamsburgh
lead_paragraph: SUDDEN DEATH OF MR. MOSES J. GRINNELL. -- Mr. MOSES J. GRINNELL, residing at No. 234 South Second-street, E.D., and doing business in New-York, was found in a dying condition near the Hunter's Point Bridge, on Tuesday night, by Officer DISSOSWAY, of the Forty-seventh Precinct. After being taken to the Station-house, he was sent to the City Hospital, where he shortly afterward expired. Early on Tuesday morning deceased, whose mind had been disturbed for some few days, attempted to commit suicide by hanging in the kitchen of his residence, but was rescued by his friends, and sent to the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house, for safe-keeping. In the forenoon of the day he was taken before Judge DAILEY, but no complaint being made against him he was discharged. Shortly after his discharge he visited the Station-house, and seemed to be in a rational state of mind, and nothing was further heard of him until he was found as above stated. There was a wound in his neck at the time of his death, and the theory is that he succeeded in committing suicide; his friends, however, assert that apoplexy was the cause. Deceased was a nephew of MOSES H. GRIFNELL, Esq., of New-York, and aged about 30 years. Coroner BARRETT will hold an inquest on the body at 89 Grand-street, this morning.

abstract: Agricultural Bureau on
lead_paragraph: The Agricultural Bureau, at Washington, reports that the whole breadth of the North will be favored this year with excellent crops. While our thoughts have been occupied with the great events which have attended and followed the closing up of the rebellion, we have paid little heed to the alternations of vivifying sunshine and refreshing rain; and yet these hardly noted movements of nature were fraught with the most tremendous influences upon the same great concern for which battles were fought and amnesties granted -- the restoration of the broad republic.

abstract: Birkenhead and Election of Blockade-Runners
lead_paragraph: BRITISH ELECTIONS. -- The great Liverpool suburb of Birkenhead has shown its anti-American proclivities by returning the notorious ram-builder LAIRD by a vastly increased majority over the liberal candidate. LAIRD probably purchases his seat. But the fact need not be forgotten on this side of the Atlantic, that a constituency, the most dependent upon the American trade of any in England, sends to the British House of Commons as its representative, a characterless speculator in the national troubles of the American people. We do not know that LAIRD, the ram-builder, can do the world much good or much evil, sitting in Lord DERBY's livery in the British Parliament. But when we think, with satisfaction, of the return of such representatives of British Liberalism as JOHN STUART MILL, to the House of Commons, we may as well emphasize the contrast presented by the return of this Birkenhead fellow "of the baser sort."

abstract: -An Eastern Democratic paper is exceedingly wrathy, because in some telegram sent over the wires by the Associated Press agents, a mark of interrogation was put after the word patriotism. Instead of the manifest fact that the copyist merely wished to call attention to the accuracy or propriety of the word, the editor assumes that the crooked little mark was a slur upon a Democrat, and reads the telegraph agents a solemn lesson about their duties. The sensitiveness of the editor is natural enough; he knows right well how, but a few years ago, it was the rule rather than the exception to give a partisan bias to news dispatches; but then the bias was almost invariably in favor of the Democratic party. The matter became so bare-faced that it was necessary to check it by stringent rules. We do not remember that our now sensitive editor grumbled at all in those days.

abstract: The Petersburgh (Va.) Index says: "We have been informed that JEFFERSON DAVIS has made several requests to be relieved of the perpetual tramp of the sentinels up and down his room, but on this point no relaxation could be granted, and he is suffering from the nervous excitement and resulting prostration which these perpetual footfalls induce. This is the reason of his failing sight, his eyes having suffered for many years from a disorder which is greatly increased by any nervous irritation."

abstract: Jersey City, Westervelt's Oil Factory; Incendiary; $6,000
snippet: Jersey City, Westervelt's Oil Factory; Incendiary; $6,000
lead_paragraph: The large oil factory belonging to WESTERVELT & CO., situated on me Meadows, between Jersey City and Lafayette, near the plank-road, was damaged by fire on Tuesday night. Firemen from Jersey City, Bergen, and Hudson City, were soon on the ground, and speedily got the flames under, not, however, until the building was nearly destroyed. Loss about $6,000. Fully insured. The fire is supposed to be the work of an incendiary.

abstract: London Letter, July 15
lead_paragraph: I date my letter from London from force of habit -- my own and the reader's -- but, in point of fact, I write "these few lines" from one of the breezy marine suburbs of the great metropolis, at St. Leonard's-on-Sea, which itself is only a long shore extension of Hastings, once a little fishing village, overlooked by a Saxon castle, now a fashionable watering-place. The difference between this and St. John's Woods, or Chelsea, or Camberwell, is that we get down in two hours by rail, instead of an hour by omnibus, and that we get the Times at 10 o'clock instead of at 8. In all other matters we might as well be in London, but for the sea.

abstract: New-York, Scott >amp; Baldwin, Broadway
lead_paragraph: The closing exercises of Grammar School No. 8, in Grand-street, near Wooster, SYLVESTER G.PENFIELD, Esq., Principal, took place yesterday morning, and were witnessed by a large concourse of people. JOHN R. RUSSELL, Esq., President of the Eighth Ward Board of Education, presided, and was assisted by Messrs Clark, Aitken, Everett and Fleet, Trustees of the Ward. On the platform were School Commissioner Adams, Dupignac and Tuthill, Drs. J. Llias Whitehead and Wm. B. Eager, Jr., Prof. Frank Gilder, James McCreery, Esq., Rev. Wm.D. Ares, and many other prominent citizens of the ward. The exercises consisted of miliiary drilling, dialogues, declamations, solos, choruses, and the reading of essays. The military drill was especially fine, and elicited rounds of applause. Master John Kuehike, a leading voice in Prof. Gilder's choir, sang three solos with excellent effect. A solo by Master E. Mackey was also executed with great sweetness and power.

abstract: Fast Suggested
lead_paragraph: -- A MEAT FAST FROM AUG. 5. -- If any answer were needed to the apologist for high prices, it will be found in the letter we printed yesterday about milk. Two and a half cents a quart to the farmer and ten cents a quart paid by the consumer is the state of things disclosed by that letter. We have abundance of information to the same effect. Last July the milkmen "had a meeting" -that is the whole story. The "natural law of supply and demand," which some persons so glibly prate about, was interfered with then, as it is now. The action of the Twenty-second and Twenty-third streets citizens was the right step, and measurably succeeded. We assure our readers that if the example is followed in other directions, it will be equally successful.

abstract: Mr. BENNETT, proprietor of the Herald, yesterday bought BARNUM's unexpired lease of the ground recently occupied by the Museum, paying therefor $200,000. At the same time Mr. BENNETT purchased the fee of the lot, 56 by 100 feet, for $450,000 -- the largest price ever paid in America for a lot of equal size. Of course the Herald will soon be located there. BARNUM at once invested all that he received in 7-30s.

abstract: TWO MEN SERIOUSLY INJURED. -- One of the walls of the building recently occupied by KNOX, the hatter, at the corner of Broadway and Fulton-street, and which was partially burned at the Museum fire, fell yesterday morning, with a loud crash. Two men, who were engaged in demolishing the building, were severely injured. Sergt. BLAIR, of the Second Precinct, and a section of men, was soon on hand, and rescued the men, named JOHN HARRINGTON and _____ MULLERY. The former was taken to the New-York Hospital, and the latter to his home.

abstract: A serious accident occurred in the cartridge factory of Messrs. FITCH & VAN VECHTEN, at the foot of Fifty-first-street, North River, on Tuesday morning. Several of the girls employed in the establishment were engaged in charging cartridges, when one of the missils exploded, seriously injuring JENNIE SMITH, JOHANNA BURK, and AMEY REYNOLDS. Miss SMITH was conveyed to St. Luke's Hospital, and the others were taken to their homes. The accident occurred through carelessness.

abstract: MICHAEL BERRIGAN and JOHN SULLIVAN, both of whom claim to be discharged soldiers, were arraigned before Justice DODGE, yesterday, on a charge of robbing GEORGE RENCHEY, living at No. 497 Eighth-street. The complainant alleges that at a late hour on Tuesday night be met the accused in a saloon corner of Eighth-avenue and Forty-second-street. While conversing with them his attention was attracted by a remark made by BERRIGAN, when, he alleges, SULLIVAN stole a gold watch and $130 in money from the complainant's pockets, with which he escaped. RENCHEY immediately discovered his loss and raised an alarm. Officers IRVING and SMITH of the Twentieth Precinct, arrested BERRIGAN, and the latter restored the stolen money to RENCHEY. Subsequently, SULLIVAN was also arrested, and gave information which will lead to the recovery of the watch. Both of the prisoners confessed their guilt, but said they were in, toxicated at the time. Justice DODGE committed them for trial without bail.

abstract: A foreign cotemporary says: It is not many months since one of the most eminent of living microscopists expressed his conviction that in the production of object glasses with one twenty-fifth of an inch focus, the microscope had reached its utmost attainable limit of perfection. He added that "It appears impossible to separate or define lines more numerous than ninety thousand in an inch, on account of the decomposition of light, or some other cause. It therefore seems beyond our power even to discover more of the ultimate composition of bodies by means of the microscope." It is always foolish to use such "thus far and no farther" language in reference to any department of scientific research, but it is not often that its fallaciousness has been demonstrated within so short a period as in the present case. The above extract is taken from a journal dated Dec. 16, 17, 1864, and yet already the one thing which microscopists are now talking about is an object glass with one-fiftieth of a focus, recently made by Messrs. POWELL & LEALAND, which was described to the Royal Society by Dr. LIONEL BEALE the other day, and was exhibited at the annual conversazione of that society a short time since. This object glass possesses double the power of the one which we were so lately told and by so great an authority, was the most powerful we must ever expect to possess, and defines with wonderful distinctness particles which the latter cannot render visible at all. It magnifies three thousand diameters with the low eye-piece, or with a number five eye-piece, fifteen thousand diameters -- that is to say, in popular parlance, one thousand five hundred and seventy-five millions of times. It must immensely increase our knowledge of the lower organisms, and may even aid our researches into the ultimate constitution of matter. And who shall say that even its power may not be exceeded in time.
lead_paragraph: A foreign cotemporary says: It is not many months since one of the most eminent of living microscopists expressed his conviction that in the production of object glasses with one twenty-fifth of an inch focus, the microscope had reached its utmost attainable limit of perfection. He added that "It appears impossible to separate or define lines more numerous than ninety thousand in an inch, on account of the decomposition of light, or some other cause. It therefore seems beyond our power even to discover more of the ultimate composition of bodies by means of the microscope." It is always foolish to use such "thus far and no farther" language in reference to any department of scientific research, but it is not often that its fallaciousness has been demonstrated within so short a period as in the present case. The above extract is taken from a journal dated Dec. 16, 17, 1864, and yet already the one thing which microscopists are now talking about is an object glass with one-fiftieth of a focus, recently made by Messrs. POWELL & LEALAND, which was described to the Royal Society by Dr. LIONEL BEALE the other day, and was exhibited at the annual conversazione of that society a short time since. This object glass possesses double the power of the one which we were so lately told and by so great an authority, was the most powerful we must ever expect to possess, and defines with wonderful distinctness particles which the latter cannot render visible at all. It magnifies three thousand diameters with the low eye-piece, or with a number five eye-piece, fifteen thousand diameters -- that is to say, in popular parlance, one thousand five hundred and seventy-five millions of times. It must immensely increase our knowledge of the lower organisms, and may even aid our researches into the ultimate constitution of matter. And who shall say that even its power may not be exceeded in time.

abstract: The steamship Scotia, from Liverpool July 15 and Queenstown July 16, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with three days later news. An Antwerp paper states that that port is to become a permanent station for American ships-of-war. All attention in Great Britain was concentrated in the elections. Up to the evening of the 14th the number of contests completed was 421. Of these the Liberals had 263 seats and the Conservatives 153. The net gain to the Liberals was nine. There were still 233 seats to be filled, mainly by the counties, and the elections would extend over another week. The final preparations for laying the Atlantic cable had been made, and the Great Eastern was to sail from Valentia Bay about the 19th. The cable appeared to be in perfect working order, and messages were sent through the entire length at the rate of four words per minute. It was confidently expected that an increased rate could be obtained by using improved instruments. The cholera was rapidly abating in Egypt.

abstract: The splendid new steam fire-engine, " Metropolitan No. 1," which arrived a few days since from the Amoskeag Works, Manchester, N. H., for the Metropolitan Fire Department of this city, was tried for the first time yesterday afternoon at the Corporation Pipe-yard, foot of East Twenty-fourth-street. The trial embraced a se
lead_paragraph: The splendid new steam fire-engine, "Metropolitan No. 1," which arrived a few days since from the Amoskeag Works, Manchester, N. H., for the Metropolitan Fire Department of this city, was tried for the first time yesterday afternoon at the Corporation Pipe-yard, foot of East Twenty-fourth-street. The trial embraced a series of one, two, three and four streams through various lengths of hose. The grand trial of one stream through one thousand feet of hose, over a building seventy-five feet high, was completely successful. The entire series proved the capacity of the steamer to be fully up to her great reputation.

abstract: Keystone, of Philadelphia, vs. Eckford
lead_paragraph: Truly is base ball an uncertain game, and seldom has there been a more striking illustration of the fact than was afforded in the contest between the above clubs, which took place on the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday, the result being the success of the Keystones by a score of 18 to 16, the game being one of the best contested, and most exciting matches of the season. Both clubs had fine teams to represent them, and both appeared to be in excellent condition for play, the Eckfords opening play in brilliant style at the bat, obtaining no less than thirteen runs in their first innings. This done, the spectators seemed to consider the defeat of the Philadelphians, and knowing, as we did, how difficult it is to beat a club like the Eckfords, with such an advantageous lead to start with, it ready did seem as if the Keystone were fated to meet with defeat in every game. But in base ball, no game, however bad it looks, can be considered lost until the last innings has been played and the result declared, and apparently the Keystones entertained the idea that this was so, for they pluckily went to work, and played one of the best up-hill games we have seen for a long time past. The game was not so much lost by the Eckfords as it was won by the Keystones. If there was any weak point of play on the Eckford side, it was in the very inaccurate pitching, which, but for the fine catching, would have led to a worse defeat. On the Keystone side these two positions were admirably attended to, the fielding at second base being a feature of the game, three splendid catches marking the Keystone play in this position. Take it al3ogether it was a very interesting contest, and that not from the display of fielding or batting, so much as in the up-hill play of the Philadelphians, for in the early part of the match the inaccurate and unfair pitching, we may say, rendered the game tedious. As soon as the match was over an adjournment was had to the club rooms, where the Keystones were hospitably entertained, and afterwards they were escorted to their hotel by the Eckfords. We give the score below:

abstract: The three days' sports of the Germans of this city were concluded at HANFT's Myrtle-avenue Park last evening. There was an immense number of persons present. The double-headed eagle was riddled, and the winner was crowned by a number of girls dressed in white. Dancing, running races in sacks, &c., added to the attractions. All passed off in a peacrable manner and to the apparent enjoyment of all who participated.

abstract: The battle-fields of Napoleon I. were scarcely more numerous than the confests of the Wheeler & Wilson's Sewing Machine. Paris in 1861, London in 1862, Linz and Koenigsburg, 1863, Dantzic, Agram, and Krems, 1864, and Stettin, Cologne and Wismar, 1865, bear testimony to the superiority of this machine, and its appreciation abroad. At all these International Exhibitions the best fruits of foreign genius were arrayed against it, backed by national amour propre; but there, as here, the star of its destiny is always in the ascendant. -- Commercial Advertiser.

abstract: Atlantic Cable; Carrying Power of
lead_paragraph: BLE. -- A correspondent of one of the London papers, writing on board the Great Eastern, gives the statement that the power of transmission through the cable will not exceed four words per minute. Even at this rate, the company, should the line be found at all workable -- will be able, at $5 a word, to realize a gross income of $10,000,000 a year. All the leading London journals have representatives on board the Great Eastern, so that the recent order of the directors excluding the press, and promising an official report of their own, was aimed at the New-York press. In spite of this, the directors will find that the New-York journals will pay more for the transmission of news over their line -- if it ever gets agoing -- in one week than the whole press of Europe (England included) will pay in a month. The cable concern is now in the hands of snobs. It will either be popularized by a new management in three months, or it will come to ruin.

abstract: Algonquin, the, and Mr. E. N. Dickerson
snippet: Algonquin, the, and Mr. E. N. Dickerson
lead_paragraph: We publish elsewhere a letter from E.N. DICKERSON, Esq., concerning the "double-ender" Algonquin, which has just been completed, under his direction, by P.S. FORBES, Esq., in pursuance of a contract with the Navy Department. It seems that, by the contract, the Algonquin was to prove, in her performance, equal in power and economy of fuel to any of the other double-enders constructed by the department, the machinery of which is, in some respects, of a different kind.

abstract: A new railroad to Long Branch, Highlands, Pleasure Bay and Atlanticville, will be open to the public on Monday next. This line is shorter than any other, and, as the name indicates, runs along the beach, affording a fine view of the ocean and the benefit of the sea breeze. The running time from New-York to Long Branch is only one hour and three-quarters. Passengers take steamer from the foot of Barclay-street at 10:30 A.M. and 4:15 P.M. The truck has been laid for some time, but owing to the fact that it passed over a small space of government land, its use was forbidden by the Secretary of War. The order has now been rescinded.

abstract: The City Mission held a meeting on Tuesday evening, in the Baptist Church, Forty-second-street, Rev. Dr. WESCOTT's. Mr. WETMORE in the chair. Several of the missionaries briefly addressed the meeting. One told of a man who had kept a brothel, and of another, who had a policy shop, who had been convinced of the evil of their ways and who voluntarily relinquished their iniquitous practices. Another spoke of a family sick with typhoid fever, deserted by their terrified friends, who were nursed and cared for, by those who go about to do good. And another related facts showing the influence of the truth upon the minds of Germans and other strangers, and how they may be insensibly, yet surely molded into American life. Among the figures given of the month's operatives, we note the following: 5,959 missionary visits; 291 meetings; 534 persons to church; 220 children to Sabbath and day schools; 106 bibles and testaments given, and 68,143 tracts distributed.

abstract: -- Mr. W.H. RUSSELL's account of the condition of the Great Eastern, with her full freight and supply of coals on board, is not flattering. The entire load is full twenty-five thousand tons, and with that she is alarmingly deep in the water, besides presenting the appearance of sagging amidships. We do not know that these symptoms are mitigated by the repeated delays in starting. By the Scotia, yesterday, whose news comes down to the 16th inst., we have no assurance that, up to that date, the Great Eastern had even left the Nore. Before she could make Valentia Bay, and get the cable spliced, we fear the end of the month will be found rapidly approaching. And in spite of the opinion of those who do the special touting for the enterprise, we incline to the opinion that August is not the best month for a North Atlantic voyage, in which there shall be a general absence of anything approaching to a storm. With her present enormous load, the Great Eastern would probably be found as hard to manage as she has been on other occasions. These facts may as well be borne in mind by those who are sanguine of the immediate success of the work.

abstract: New-York, Smith, James, Returning from Fenian Pic-nic
snippet: New-York, Smith, James, Returning from Fenian Pic-nic
lead_paragraph: JAMES SMITH, a young man who lived in Thirty-second-street, near Second-avenue, was brutally murdered about 9 o'clock on Tuesday evening, at the foot of Fifty-fifth-street, East River. From the evidence thus far elicited, it appears that the deceased, in company with Mr. ROBITAELLE, living in Thirty-first-street, near Second-avenue, another man and two young women had been to the Fenian Pic-nic at Jones' Woods. They returned in a small boat, and landed at Allen's Point, foot of Fifty-fifth-street, and entered the public house, where they partook of refreshments. Another boat-load of men from Jones' Wood soon entered the place, one of whom accused SMITH and his companions with stealing a pair of oars. Without awaiting an explanation, a murderous assault was begun on SMITH and his male companions by the new-comers. One of his assailants knocked SMITH down, and drawing a knife or other sharp instrument, inflicted three terrible wounds on the back of his neck, a severe gash across his throat, besides several less serious wounds. SMITH sprang to his feet, with the blood gushing from his wounds, and ran about one hundred and fifty feet, when he fell to the ground and expired. The murderer then attempted to take the life of POBETAILLE with the same weapon. The latter received one dangerous wound on the right side of the neck. Officers CLARK and HEILMAN, of the Nineteenth Precinct, succeeded in arresting two men, PETER CARLEY and FREDERICK HOOKER, the former a boiler-maker, and the latter a boatman, on suspicion of having committed the murder. HOOKER made a desperate resistance, and could not be arrested until Officer HIELMAN had discharged his revolver at him. The prisoners were taken to the station-house and locked up. Yesterday afternoon, Coroner COLLINS began an investigation on the body of the deceased, which was not concluded last evening. It will be resumed at 1 P.M. to-day, at the Nineteenth Precinct Station-house in Fifty-ninth-street.
