abstract: Dr. VON EISENBERG has made for himself a reputation in the medical world that falls to the lot of few men in a lifetime. His specialty has been the treatment of diseases of the eye and ear, and it is but justice to this distinguished practitioner to say that he has already performed some of the most wonderful and miraculous cures on record. Many of those cases were supposed to be incurable. Dr. VON EISENBERG has also performed many wonderful cures of a variety of diseases even outside of his immediate specialty. -- New-York Dispatch.

abstract: The Twelfth New-York Cavalry, Col. SAVAGE, commanding, arrived from Raleigh, via City Point and Baltimore, yesterday afternoon. As the regiment was rather late, in arriving, it was deemed inadvisable for the command to proceed up town to the New-York State Agency. After dinner at the Battery Barracks, the Twelfth took passage by the regular boat for Hart's Island. The regiment has been with SHERMAN's army, under command of Gens. HEATH and KILPATRICK.

abstract: N. J., Ky., Del. and the Con. Amend
snippet: N. J., Ky., Del. and the Con. Amend
lead_paragraph: It is a striking fact that the only States in the Union which now oppose the constitutional amendment abolishing slavery are the three loyal States of New-Jersey, Kentucky and Delaware. Not one of the late rebel States, so-called, nor any party in any one of them, makes the least remonstrance against this change of the fundamental law. Even South Carolina itself, as Gov. PERRY has assured the President, will ratify the amendment at the first opportunity. There is not in the entire South a solitary newspaper, so far as we know, which raises the slightest objection to the amendment. There are many which find much fault with this or that particular measure of the government; but so far as respects the perpetual extinction of slavery, no question is made. All recognize that the war has killed it, and none deny that it is just and expedient that its spirit should be laid forever by an everlasting interdict.

abstract: Westchester County, Highway, of M ssrs. Horton >amp; Wilson
snippet: Westchester County, Highway, of M ssrs. Horton >amp; Wilson
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORKERS ASSAULTED AND ROBBED. -- Mr. GEORGE VAN HOUTON, living at No. 459 Eighth-avenue, and ARTHUR R. WILSON, of No. 445 West Twenty-third-street, while driving above McComb's Dam, on the read leading to Woodlawn cemetery, about 6 o'clock on yesterday morning, were assaulted by three men who lay in ambush. The horses were seized, and one of the villians placed a loaded pistol at Mr. VAN HOUTON's head and threatened to shoot him if he and his friend did not deliver up their valuables. Mr. VAN HOUTEN declined to comply with the demand, and applied the whip to his horses, also administering several vigorous blows to the villain holding the pistol. The man clung to the horses, and the pistol was discharged, the ball striking the breast of Mr. VAN HOUTON's coat and bounding off. The powder burned his neck and face. Regarding further resistance as extremely hazardous, Mr. VAN HOUTEN gave the highwaymen his gold watch, and Mr. WILSON gave them $25. No clue has yet been obtained of the thieves, who escaped with their plunder.

abstract: Debats on Commerce and Close of American War
snippet: Debats on Commerce and Close of American War
lead_paragraph: The Paris Debats has a long article on the probable consequences of the return of peace in the United States, as affecting French commerce. The only States that could possibly gain by a continuation of hostilities were those which supplied to the Confederates gun-powder, arms and contraband of war; but as France deals only in honest merchandise, she rejoices at the cessation of the conflict not only in a general sense but as far as she is herself individually concerned. The war in America gave a grievous blow to many branches of French commerce, and both Lyons and Rouen suffered severely:

abstract: We publish to-day an  account of a series of outrages committed in open day in the City of Hudson. The City of Hudson is but a few miles this side the capital of the State. It is itself a place of such
lead_paragraph: We publish to-day an account of a series of outrages committed in open day in the City of Hudson. The City of Hudson is but a few miles this side the capital of the State. It is itself a place of such considerable size and importance that we should suppose it has an organized police force. It is on the great northern highway -one of the principal thoroughfares for half a continent -- where twenty or thirty trains a day make more or less of a halt in passing. It was this place that on Monday, as the telegram has it, "was visited by a gang of roughs." "The scoundrels spread all over the city, knocking down citizens to their hearts' content," amusing themselves by firing loaded guns and revolvers at people's heads, seizing whatever moveable property suited them in liquor stores and elsewhere, beating one poor remonstrating police officer (seventy years of age) into a jelly, and maiming and wounding citizens generally.

abstract: -- Officers HARVEY  and WELSH, of the Harbor Police, arrested, on Wednesday night, three desperadoes, named PATRICK CONREY, WM., JONES and WILLIAM WARD, who were prowling about the river in a boat. When searched, although there was no property found, yet they had the tools to operate with. There was found an iron jimmy, a saw, some files and a razor blade with a long wooden handle -- a murderous looking weapon. The boat they were in was stolen, and, a complaint being made by the owner, they were locked up by the Justice to await the action of the Grand Jury.
lead_paragraph: -- Officers HARVEY and WELSH, of the Harbor Police, arrested, on Wednesday night, three desperadoes, named PATRICK CONREY, WM., JONES and WILLIAM WARD, who were prowling about the river in a boat. When searched, although there was no property found, yet they had the tools to operate with. There was found an iron jimmy, a saw, some files and a razor blade with a long wooden handle -- a murderous looking weapon. The boat they were in was stolen, and, a complaint being made by the owner, they were locked up by the Justice to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The funeral of Rev. EDWIN R. COOK, the rector of the Wainwright Memorial Church, corner of Waverley-place and Hammond-street, took place at the church yesterday at 2 P.M., and was attended by a large concourse of people, among them a large representation of the clergy. Rev. Dr. MUGHLENBURG, Rev. SAMUEL HOLLINS SWORTH, of Portchester, and Rev. WM.C. WINSLOW, of this city, were the officiating clergymen. Dr. MUHLENBURG made a few appropriate and touching remarks, and the solemn service of the Episcopal Church lent its effect to the occasion. Many hundreds passed around the coffin to take a farewell look of a faithful and successful minister of the gospel. The remains were taken to Trinity Cemetery, where they were interred after a brief service by Rev. Mr. WINSLOW. On Sunday forenoan a discourse appropriate to the occasion, will be delivered by Rev. Mr. WINSLOW, and it is hoped that Rev. Dr. VINTON will hereafter furnish a funeral discourse on the lamented dead.

abstract: The rebel pirate Shenandoah has been definitely heard from by the whaling bark Milo, which brings to San Francisco several crews of vessels destroyed last month. It seems that the pirate Captain was fully informed of LEE's surrender, but affected not to believe it. He was also informed of the assassination of President LINCOLN, and that he believed readily because he expected it. The Arctic whaling fleet of about 60 vessels will probably be entirely destroyed. The pirate is said to have sailed last from Melbourne, and is manned by English and Irish cut-throats.

abstract: Securities; Renewed Activity in
lead_paragraph: -The apprehensions of impending stringency in the money market, so prevalent a week ago, having completely subsided, because of the unyielding confidence of the people in the solvency and uprightness of their government -- which practically means confidence in the energy, enterprise and honesty of the people themselves -- national securities have recovered from the depression with which last week closed so gloomily. Prices of all the gold-bearing bonds have rallied materially under a marked improvement in the demand on both home and foreign account. The Scotia, at this port early on Wednesday, brought liberal fresh orders for the national six per cents, especially the 5-20s, together with advices that all the large shipments of the bonds from this side, made prior to the first of the current month, had been speedily absorbed by the investment demand in London and Frankfort at generally firm and buoyant prices. The latest London quotations for the 5-20s by the Scotia, were (in specie) 71 1/2@72, which, with gold at 145, are equivalent to 115 7/8@116 [???]/8 in the New-York market. The purchases of this special class of bonds on foreign account within the past three days, exceed three million dollars, including a snug lump of one million dollars taken for Germany on Wednesday. The renewed foreign demand for our government bonds promises to keep down the adverse balances of our foreign trade, which, on last week's imports into this port, as against the exports from the port, were against New-York to the tune of over five million dollars in currency value. The shipments of the bonds on a liberal scale will prevent any material outflow of specie, and tend to check the inflation of the premium on gold coin, which an influential clique of operators are indefatigably laboring to stimulate -- using, for this nefarious purpose, mounds of borrowed money, gross misrepresentations of the wants and resources of the National Treasury, and an extensive assortment of similar false pretences.

abstract: Mowing Machines, Trial at West Mt. Vernon
snippet: Mowing Machines, Trial at West Mt. Vernon
lead_paragraph: This great trial came off, according to arrangement, on Tuesday afternoon, but, owing to the various severe tests, it was not concluded until Wednesday afternoon. The trial has been the most interesting of any that has over taken place in this country. The great mechanical improvements in all the first-class machines rendered it necessary to make the trial a severe one, and the work laid out by the committee was of a character never attempted before in any country. The ground selected was at West Mount Vernon, on the Harlem Road. Twenty acres of the bottom-land along the banks of the Bronx River was held in reserve for the trial. The first trial was in a piece of seven acres. The grass was very heavy, mostly blue grass and red top. This piece had been several times overflowed within the last month, and it would have been with great difficulty that a man with the old-fashioned scythe could make much headway in the grass. The machines, in their order of numbers, were set at work at 2:30 o'clock, going entirely around this plot. No. 1, the Clipper machine, made the first round. The ground moved over was very undulating and rough. The machine frequently settled in mudsloughs and water, so as to hide one-half of the machine; but still it worked on. In cutting around, it was required to stop and start, without backing, in the heaviest and worst tangled grass, and in every instance it performed its work. All the machines that followed were required to do the same work. They were the Buckeye, Monitor, Union, Two-in-one, Harvester, Hubbard, and a one-horse Clipper. Two or three of these machines failed to accomplish all that was required by the committee. This experiment occupied the afternoon, and was witnessed by nearly 2,000 persons. Further tests of the machines were postponed to 8 o'clock Wednesday morning.

abstract: Absurd and Wicked News of
lead_paragraph: The warlike news we have to-day from the Rio Grande is of a style we have not been favored with since the earlier days of the late rebellion. Its main characteristics are sensationalism, looseness and baselessness. It comes from an indefinite source, in a zig-zag way, through many places, by numerous hands. It gives no reliable authority, no intelligible details, no dates, and is utterly incoherent. It is flung among us like a bombshell, screaming and sudden, and, being unexpected, is, of course, startling.

abstract: Mutual Respect Between
lead_paragraph: It is a noteworthy fact that there has not been a time in this generation when the language of the North and the South toward each other has been so respectful and considerate as since the close of the war. We mean the language used by the public speakers and the public writers of the two sections. It would be difficult to recall a single instance, either here or there, since the advent of peace, of the employment of the old style of sectional abuse by any man of the least personal responsibility. All the old sort of denouncing, depreciating, sneering, flouting and reviling has quite passed away. A thousand contumelious phrases, which used to be the stock in trade of every village politician in the two parts of the country, have become obsolete; they have literally dropped from the language. There is no longer a Northern political dialect, in distinction from a Southern political dialect.

abstract: Several notices have recently appeared in the newspapers about a young man employed in Fulton Market rescuing persons who have fallen into the ferry slips, on the Brooklyn side, from certain death, at the peril of his own life; and some of the local reporters have attempted to immortalize him.
lead_paragraph: -- Several notices have recently appeared in the newspapers about a young man employed in Fulton Market rescuing persons who have fallen into the ferry slips, on the Brooklyn side, from certain death, at the peril of his own life; and some of the local reporters have attempted to immortalize him. The amount of this young man's heroism may be thus stated: He is an expert swimmer, and has a rival, with whom he has frequently quarreled on the question of expertness. Both recently agreed to turn their skill to some account, and consummated a bargain, by which one should achieve a reputation, and the other (who is of a mercenary disposition) money. The agreement was that both should travel frequently on the East River ferry-boats, and when a good opportunity presented itself, one was to "accidentally" fall overboard, while the other was to heroically plunge in and rescue him. This bargain has been carried out to the letter on five different occasions; the rescuer paying the rescued $5 for every time his name appears in the papers.

abstract: Seven-Thirty Loan; The Close of
lead_paragraph: All of the great Seven-Thirty has now been marketed. The three series of notes into which the Loan was divided were as follows: The first series, of $300,000,000, bearing date Aug. 15, 1864, and now quoted at par and interest; the second series, also of $300,000,000, bearing date June 15, 1865, and now selling in this market at 99 3/4 a 99 7/8, adding interest; and the third and final series of $230,000,000, bearing date July 15, 1865, and just closed out at par and interest. These three series of notes make a grand aggregate of $830,000,000, all disposed of within a single year, in the home market, exclusively, and at par. Under the direct supervision of the Treasury Department, between the beginning of August, 1864, and the 1st of February, 1865, a period of six months, the sales of the first series of the loan reached $130,000,000, or a weekly average of $5,000,000. Late in January, 1865, Hon. WM.P. FESSENDEN, then Secretary of the Treasury, reappointed Mr. JAY COOKE general Loan Subscription Agent of the department, the duties of which position he had demonstrated his eminent fitness to discharge during the process of marketing over five hundred millions of the Five-Twenty Loan, the popular precursor of the emphatically more popular Seven-Thirties. Mr. COOKE formally assumed charge of the Seven-Thirty Loan on the 1st of February, and promptly revived the admirable sub-agency system, which he had organized during his first official connection with the national finances. Between the 1st of February and the 26th of the current month of July, Mr. COOKE's agent, acting under his personal supervision, sold $700,000,000 worth of Seven-Thirties, thus running up the daily average rate of sale to within a traction of $5,000,000, or equal to the weekly rate of distribution, under the Treasury management. Never, in the history of nations, was such an enormous amount of money raised for public use, with such extraordinary rapidity and success, as in the instance of the great Seven-Thirty Loan, which is now all in the bands of the loyal people, and deemed by them the most desirable security ever issued by the government. The notes of the loan have been more widely distributed than any previous issues of the Treasury Department, with the solitary exception of the famous greenbacks. And, it is safe to say, that wherever, in the remotest section of the country, any spare greenbacks awaited on opportunity for reliable and profitable investment, the Seven-Thirties found them out, drew them forth, and swallowed them up, to the advantage, present and prospective, of all interested parties.

abstract: The prospect of Mr. GLADSTONE'S defeat at Oxford ought to be an encouragement to British reformers rather than otherwise. His party supporters will find him a seat in the Liberal constituency of South Lancashire. He will thus be severed from his quasi-Conservative connection altogether. He will have less constraint in taking decided ground in Parliament on the great "open" questions of church rates and test-oaths. He will be drawn by his new representatives affinities into more intimate alliance with the advanced Reformers of England. And he will have the important stimulus of a Liberal constituency to support, instead of condemn him in the advocacy of popular rights. Ever since Mr. GLADSTONE'S great appeal for the liberty and unity of Italy, in the Aberdeen letters, the breach between him and his original party allies has been widening. If this Oxford contest should make that breach irreparable, the cause of Reform in England will be greatly the gainer.

abstract: Davis, Jeff.; Praised by Tory Press
snippet: Davis, Jeff.; Praised by Tory Press
lead_paragraph: The panegyrics lavished by a part of the Tory press pf England upon the leader of the Southern rebellion, have not entirely ceased. Those journals still find space for extravagant laudation of the Confederate ex-President, in their bitter commentaries upon American affairs. Were the eulogium inspired only by that peculiar sentimentality which espouses the cause of the conquered because it is conquered, without reflection on the question of justice and of right, it might be pardonable. But it is invariably accompanied by the fiercest invectives, the most unscrupulous calumnies against the loyal and patriotic chieftains of the Union. By way of contrast with the immaculate integrity of DAVIS, they reproach the martyred LINCOLN with weakness, style President JOHNSON a tyrant, and accuse Secretary STANTON of all the crimes known to the Decalogue, adding thereto all those which can be committed against the Constitution of the Confederate States.

abstract: A sincere tribute of praise is due to the guardians, or "Commissioners" -- if such is their title -- of the City Hall Park for the luxury of seats they have provided. The denizens of the lower wards are profoundly grateful for the privilege of a seat in the only park available to their means and opportunities. Every seat is occupied by some contemplative admirer of nature. And art, too, finds its worshippers abroad in greater numbers than before the luxurious era of seats. We need not refer to the Statue. The Statue, we believe, has been referred to on one or more previous occasions. But the seats! The seats are a new source of satisfaction and delight. And the guardians of the Park may consider themselves the possessors of the daily benisons of a pleased and gratified community.

lead_paragraph: COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED. -- On Wednesday night an effort was made to pass a large number of counterfeit $10 bills on the Thompson Bank of Thompson, Conn. The police soon learned the fact, and gave storekeepers notice, and the villains were foiled in the attempt. The bills are welt executed and calculated to deceive good judges of money in the evening. SALOMON P. STODDARD, a lawyer, was arrested by Officer KELLY, of the Twentieth Precint; LOUIS L. ANGEL, a clerk, 32 years of age, was arrested by Officer DANIEL, of the Eighth Precinct, and THOS. GOLDEN, an expressman, was arrested by Officer HENDERSON, of the Eighth Precinct, for passing the bills.

abstract: Memoir of
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Col. WILLIAM JAY, of Bedford, N.Y., late of the headquarters staff of the Army of the Potomac, resigned his position after the closing review at Washington. Col. JAY, who, at the outbreak of the rebellion, was about completing his studies in the law school of Columbia College, was in April, 1861 appointed by Maj.-Gen. JOHN E. WOOL a volunteer aid. In August of the same year he was commissioned by President LINCOLN under the act of Congress authorizing "aid-de-camps," and was the first officer of that corps with the rank of Captain -- the next appointed, in September, having been Capt. LOUIS PHILIPPE D'ORLEANS, Comte de Paris, and Capt. ROBERT D'ORLEANS, Duc de Chartres, whose gallant services under Gen. MCCLELLAN have an historic significance. Capt. JAY was assigned successively by the War Department to the staffs of Major-Gens. WOOL, GEORGE W. MORRELL, and GEORGE G. MEADE, and served under the last named commander, then in charge of the Fifth Corps, at Chancellorsville. When Gen. MEADE became Commander-in-Chief of the Army of the Potomac, Capt. JAY was temporarily assigned to the staff of Major-Gen. GEORGE SYKES, at the request of that officer, who succeeded to tue command of the Fifth Corps, then famous for its force of regulars, and served with him at Gettysburgh and other battles to the close of the Mine Run campaign. Recalled to the staff of the Commanding General in April, 1864, he continued with Gen. MEADE throughout the memorable campaign that commenced with the crossing of the Rapidan and ended with the surrender of LEE. The conferring of brevets having been authorized by Congress in 1864, Capt. JAY was in that year breveted Major by President LINCOLN for his conduct in the field; and again, on the 15th June, 1865, by President JOHNSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, to rank from the 9th of April, "for gallant and meritorious services during the recent operations resulting in the fall of Richmond and the surrender of the insurgent army under Gen. ROBERT E. LEE." Maj.-Gen. MEADE, in addressing the War Department on the 25th May, 1865, after approving of Col. JAY's resignation, added: "I deem it due to this officer's distinguished services to express officially my approbation of his gallantry and zeal, and the intelligence he has ever displayed since being under my command." Col. JAY is a son of JOHN JAY, Esq., of New-York, and a grandson and namesake of the late Judge WILLIAM JAY. -- Army and Navy Journal.

abstract: Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in the frame building No. 262 Fifty-first-street, occupied as a shoddy factory by FRANCIS WINTER. The building and contents were completely destroyed, and some of the adjoining buildings seriously damaged. The loss on the stock and machinery of the building will amount to $15,000. Insured for $7,875 on machinery in the following companies: Relief, $2,000; Atlantic, $1,250; Tradesmans, $1,500; Brevoort, $1,625; Albany  City, $1,500. There was an insurance of $5,200 on stock in the following companies: Jersey City, $1,500; Thames, (Norwich,) $1,500; Hampden, $1,100; Norwich, $1,100. The building was owned by GARRETT MOTT; loss, $3,000; insurance not known. The frame building in the rear of No. 657 Ninth-avenue was destroyed. It was owned by Mr. SMALL. Loss about $600. It was occupied by three families, who lost about $100 each in furniture. The frame building in the rear of the pottery of Mr. JOHN FISH, Nos. 257 and 259 West Fiftieth-street, was damaged to the amount of $2,000; insured for $1,500 in the Kings County and St. Nicholas Companies. The dwelling of Mrs. SHARP was damaged to the amount of $600, and the stables of CLANSMAN to the amount of $200. The dwelling of Mr. WINTER, in Fifty-first-street, was damaged to the amount of $250; insured for $1,000 in the Manhattan Company. The origin of the fire is at present unknown.

lead_paragraph: At the session of the Board of Fire Commissioners, the investigation into the charges made by Mr. ROBINSON, Superintendent of Telegraphs, against the operators in the telegraph office, in the city, took place. Mr. ROBINSON declining to furnish specifications to the several charges made by him, Messrs. DAILEY and SEIXAS were interrogated regarding the conduct of their office, and also on the several charges. It is understood that the matter will not be again taken up. Hose Company No. 11 having reported the expulsion of five members for neglect of duty and other causes, the board sustained such action.

abstract: JAMES SULLY MONTGOMERY, aged 20 yean and 3 months, son of James Montgomery, Jr., of Hudson City. N.J., died of typhoid fever July 9, 1865, at Tarboro, N., C., where his regiment was stationed. He was a young man of rare natural abilities, improved by the study of standard works: generous, high-toned, refined in all his tastes, full of noble impulses, and of great purity of character. Actuated solely by patriotic impulses, leaving behind him all those surroundings which make home a paradise and life a charm, he joined the army of his country, and on the eve of returning to the fond embrace of doting parents, death claimed him for his own. Although bitter tears are shed at his loss; although the heart's cords may be almost rent asunder, still there should be great consolation in the reflection that his pure spirit, untainted by the vices of this world, will soar to that blessed immortality which our Heavenly Father has promised to those who love Him.
lead_paragraph: JAMES SULLY MONTGOMERY, aged 20 yean and 3 months, son of James Montgomery, Jr., of Hudson City. abstract: There were no returning regiments arriving during yesterday, but several are expected during the present and early part of next week. Among the early arrivals will be the Sixth and Seventh Connecticut Regiments. The Seventh left Goldsboro, N.C., on Saturday last, and the Sixth the day previous. On Wednesday evening the Sixth had left Fortress Monroe for this city in the transport Eastern State.
lead_paragraph: There were no returning regiments arriving during yesterday, but several are expected during the present and early part of next week. Among the early arrivals will be the Sixth and Seventh Connecticut Regiments. The Seventh left Goldsboro, N.C., on Saturday last, and the Sixth the day previous. On Wednesday evening the Sixth had left Fortress Monroe for this city in the transport Eastern State. The telegraphic information of Col. ALMY stated that the transport Gen. Meigs had also started the same evening with Connecticut troops, and he believes that the Seventh Regiment is en route by that vessel.

abstract: JOSEPH BENEDICT AND THOMAS McCUE were arraigned before Justice DODGE yesterday, on a charge of stealing a diamond breastpin and fifty-five shares of the capital stock of the Delaware Gold and Silver Mining Company, valued at $5,500, from WILLIAM P. ELLSWORTH, on the 18th inst. The mining stock belonged to Messrs. WOLFE  Co., No. 20 Exchange- ...
lead_paragraph: JOSEPH BENEDICT AND THOMAS MCCUE were arraigned before Justice DODGE yesterday, on a charge of stealing a diamond breastpin and fifty-five shares of the capital stock of the Delaware Gold and Silver Mining Company, valued at $5,500, from WILLIAM P. ELLSWORTH, on the 18th inst. The mining stock belonged to Messrs. WOLFE & CO., No. 20 Exchange place, by whom ELLSWORTH was employed. It appears that the complainant entered a ladies' car at the Thirtieth-street depot of the Hudson River Railroad Company. He was ordered out by BENEDICT, a brakeman. He refused to go, when, as BENEDICT asserted, MCCUE ejected him. During the struggle it is alleged that the diamond pin and bonds were stolen. Officer IRVING subsequently learned that MCCUE had endeavored to negotiate the bonds. MCCUE and BENEEICT were arrested, and yesterday Justice DODGE committed them for examination. The bonds were returned to the owners by a man who claimed and received a reward of $500, which had been offered for their recovery.

abstract: SINGULAR CASE OF ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. A man named EDWARD DEADAN was discovered in Washington Park about 3 o'clock yesterday morning lying on the grass and laboring under great pain. His groans had attracted the attention of some citizens in the neighborhood who went to his relief. They found him bleeding profusely and soon ascertained that he had been stabbed.
lead_paragraph: SINGULAR CASE OF ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. -- A man named EDWARD DEADAN was discovered in Washington Park about 3 o'clock yesterday morning lying on the grass and laboring under great pain. His groans had attracted the attention of some citizens in the neighborhood who went to his relief. They found him bleeding profusely and soon ascertained that he had been stabbed. Officers GRIFFIN, BOONE and WHEATON, of the Forty-fourth Precinct Police, came up some time thereafter, and the injured man was conveyed to the City Hospital. The physicians found that he had been stabbed nine times in the left breast, all the punctures being within a space of about three inches in circumference. DEADAN who was perfectly conscious stated that He was a native of Philadelphia, and 30 years of age; that he came to this city for the purpose of procuring employment but had not succeeded; he had only $150, and desiring to save that, concluded to sleep in the Park instead of procuring lodgings at a hotel. While lying on a bench two men came up; one struck him and the other inflicted the stabs, when they robbed him of his money. He described the men very particularly, their height, dress and color of hair. Capt. WADDY made arrangements to arrest certain parties who had been seen in the Park during the night, but before he could accomplish his object he paid a visit, on invitation, to the injured man. His wounds had been probed, and it was ascertained that they were of so serious a character that his death might be expected any time. The physicians could give him no hopes whatever. Being fearful that he had not long to live he made a statement altogether different from that made but a few hours previous, and which was to the effect that he had been a soldier, and, having no home nor relations, did not know what to do with himself, and so resolved to commit suicide; that he had not been assaulted or robbed by any one, but that he inflicted the stabs with his own hand. The knife with which he cut himself was found in his pocket. It was very bloody. There appears to be no doubt but that the last statement is the correct one. He was in a very precarious condition last evening.

abstract: -The Liberal borough of Leeds, in rejecting the aspiring son of the present Foreign Minister of England, have done something more than cast a blight upon the political hopes of an ambitious young man; they have thrust sorely at a cherished Whig tradition -- that political virtue goes by inheritance. The lad (twenty-two years of age,) rejected by the cloth-weavers of Leeds, has been on the "stump" for more than a year, promising much more than his father used to promise -- "civil and religious liberty all over the world;" promising, in fact, to overturn the House of Lords, and remove one of the grandest bulwarks of the British Constitution. The youth seems to have undertaken too much. He has, therefore, been sent back to his parents by the sturdy factory men of Leeds.
lead_paragraph: -The Liberal borough of Leeds, in rejecting the aspiring son of the present Foreign Minister of England, have done something more than cast a blight upon the political hopes of an ambitious young man; they have thrust sorely at a cherished Whig tradition -- that political virtue goes by inheritance. The youth seems to have undertaken too much. He has, therefore, been sent back to his parents by the sturdy factory men of Leeds.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Coroner COLLIN held an inquest at No. 197 West Twentieth-street, on the body of WM. WALKER, a lunatic, who committed suicide by taking Paris green. It is said that deceased has been deranged for over a year, and that during the past nine months he has been an inmate of a lunatic asylum. He was granted a leave of absence and returned to his home. On Tuesday night, during the absence of his relatives, WALKER discovered some poison in a closet, which had been purchased for the purpose of killing roaches. The lunatic swallowed a portion of the poison, and was seized with severe vomiting. He afterward confessed to his sister that he had taken the poison, but said that the people were after him, and compelled him to take it, or they would cut him in pieces. Mr. WALKER died on Wednesday morning. The jury found that the deceased came to his death "by the effects of poisoning by Paris green, taken while deranged."
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner COLLIN held an inquest at No. 197 West Twentieth-street, on the body of WM. WALKER, a lunatic, who committed suicide by taking Paris green. abstract: AN ESCAPED CONVICT RETURNED TO BLACKWELL'S ISLAND. On Monday evening the Eighteenth Ward Police arrested PATRICK BURNS, alias "Piper" BURNS, on suspicion of having killed JAMES SMITH, at the foot of East Fifty-fifth-street, on Tuesday evening. Yesterday Coroner COLLINS discharged BURNS, the prisoner having proved his innocence of that charge. He was immediately re-arrested, however, the police having learned that he was an escaped convict.
lead_paragraph: AN ESCAPED CONVICT RETURNED TO BLACKWELL's ISLAND. -- On Monday evening the Eighteenth Ward Police arrested PATRICK BURNS, alias "Piper" BURNS, on suspicion of having killed JAMES SMITH, at the foot of East Fifty-fifth-street, on Tuesday evening. Yesterday Coroner COLLINS discharged BURNS, the prisoner having proved his innocence of that charge. He was immediately re-arrested, however, the police having learned that he was an escaped convict. BURNS had been convicted of beating a German, and was sentenced to the penitentiary for several months. He subsequently escaped, and eluded the officers until arrested on suspicion of having killed SMITH. He was returned to his old quarters yesterday to serve out the unexpired term of his sentence.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a man named RICHARD O'BRIEN, while under the influence of liquor jumped into the river at the Paterson Dock, Jersey City, with a view of drowning himself. A private watchman gave the alarm and O'BRIEN was rescued much exhausted. He was conveyed to the Station-house, and is still under the care of a physician.

abstract: Northern Offers to Supply--Curious Disclosures
lead_paragraph: We print below, extracts from a report made to the rebel Congress of the workings of the rebel commissary department. These extracts make some remarkable disclosures of the operations of men on our side of the lines, and show that eventually regular contracts were made by Northern men with the rebel government, to supply its armies with food, and that LEE's army was fed in that way to a great extent in 1863. The following are the extracts:

abstract: Gov. HOLDEN has recovered from his recent illness, and is at his post again.  The large landholders in this city and county, who comprise the aristocracy and leading rebel sympathisers, made a strong effort, through Gov. HOLDEN, to have the government tax suspended, but failed, and are now promptly paying their taxes to save their property.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, Monday, July 24.

abstract: We hear from various points on the Mississippi River, as New-Orleans, Vicksburgh, Memphis and Cairo, of the great activity in steamboating and general commerce that now exists there. The busy times before the war are revived on the great river. Steamboats are plenty as ever, and equally fast, and somewhat less explosive.
lead_paragraph: -- We hear from various points on the Mississippi River, as New-Orleans, Vicksburgh, Memphis and Cairo, of the great activity in steamboating and general commerce that now exists there. The busy times before the war are revived on the great river. Steamboats are plenty as ever, and equally fast, and somewhat less explosive. They not only abound on the Mississippi, but penetrate as of yore all its affluents, carrying up supplies, bringing out cotton, and bearing passengers from point to point. The regions all along the river and along its tributaries, are very rapidly recovering from the effects of the war. It has already had two years in which to improve; for it may be said that the war in the great valley ceased with the fall of Vicksburgh in July, 1863; but, in fact, until four months ago, or until the rebel surrender, progress was slow, for the reason that the operations of guerrillas made travel and traffic dangerous.
headline: {'main': 'LIVELY TIMES IN THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LIVELY TIMES IN THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Magazines for August
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly, (Boston: TICKNOR and FIELDS,) opens with an interesting paper, by Miss PRESCOTT, "Among the Honey Makers," on the instincts and habits of bees. "Strategy at the Fireside," by EPES SARGENT, is a story of domestic life turning upon the putting down of the "Secesh" element in; Maryland. "Around Mull, Part II," continues the tale of Miss CUMMINS' Scottish experiences. "Dr. Johns" advances a step further, and promises some new developments of the story. The most ambitious poem is "Countess Laura," by GEORGE H. BOKER. In the reviews a butterfly (the author of "The Gentle Life") is elaborately broken on the wheel of criticism. A little of the like wholesome severity might well be extended to other offenders of the same kind as "The Country Parson," &c.

abstract: Shenandoah in Arctic Seas
lead_paragraph: Lord RUSSELL will have an early opportunity of putting in practice his considerate purpose of hospitality toward one at least of the pirates still afloat. The latest report of the Shenandoah comes to us by way of San Francisco, where a whaling vessel (the Milo) arrived on the 20th instant, with the crews of some ten of our whalers, destroyed by the pirate in the Arctic seas during the month of June. At the date of the Milo's parting with the Shenandoah, that enterprising craft had the prospect of a healthy business before her. There were some sixty of our whaling fleet within reach of her; and the total destruction of the whole of them was a matter more of certainty than speculation. After that job shall have been fairly completed, and if nothing further of a promising character turns up in the same quarter, the pirate can return to a British port at Hong Kong or Vancouver's Island, laden with her stealings. At any of these ports -- being those of the only nation which still extends hospitality to the pirates -- the Shenandoah may take one of two different courses with perfect safety. She may, according to Lord RUSSELL's dispatch, be disarmed and sold for the benefit of her enterprising owners, or she may get her supplies as she would have done before the war closed, and then, for the last time -- Lord RUSSELL is liberal enough to determine -- she may sail out under the twenty-four hours rule, should any United States vessel be in the some port at the time of her departure. Lord RUSSELL's words in his explanatory dispatch to Sir FREDERICK BRUCE, of July 6, are these:

abstract: The beautiful steam-yacht Clara Clarita, from New-York for Aspy Bay, with Engineer EVERETT'S party on board, arrived here yesterday. The company are under great obligations to Mr. JEROME for kindly placing her at their disposal for this important expedition.

abstract: The Oneida Dispatch states that on Monday of last week, ABRAM MCGUIRE, who resides a short distance northeast of Canestota, was cutting grass with his machine, a few rods from his house, when he suddenly came upon his little daughter, between three and four years of age, who had hid herself and gone to sleep in the grass, and, before he could stop the machine, it completelysevered one of her legs a little above the ankle joint, and inflicted a bad wound upon the thigh of the other leg. Drs. MASON and JARVIS amputated the leg and dressed her wound, and she is now doing well. The agony of the father, upon beholding what he had done, can be better imagined than described.

abstract: Johnson, J. H., Advocate of High Price; an Advocate for High
snippet: Johnson, J. H., Advocate of High Price; an Advocate for High
lead_paragraph: -- We are favored to-day with a communication from a gentleman who is an advocate of high prices. He undertakes to show us that neither the milk speculators in the city, nor the dairymen in the country, are overpaid. Ten cents a quart he considers a reasonable price, and so forth. This outspoken advocate of extortion is fitly answered by two correspondents, whose letters we place side by side with his. If ten cents for a short-measure quart is a reasonable price, how comes it that a number of the wealthiest families in New-York, residing in the best parts of Twenty-first, Twenty-second and Twenty-third-streets, have been able by combining together to get the best Orange County milk supplied to them for eight cents, or twenty per cent. less than they paid before the agitation was commenced in these columns? Then again, what has the advocate of high prices to say to the fact stated by another correspondent that the milkmen buy from the farmers by the "dry measure" quart and sell by the wine measure, making nearly a pint extra on every quart? Is it doing an injury to our producing friends to expose these facts?
headline: {'main': 'AN ADVOCATE OF HIGH PRICES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'AN ADVOCATE OF HIGH PRICES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The match between those clubs yesterday, which was played on the Capitoline Grounds, Bedford, resulted in the success of the Star nine, by a score of 37 to 34, in a game occupying over three hour and a half, it being an uninteresting match, as far as the display of fielding was concerned, and one not quite as creditable to the victors as it might have been. In the last innings the contest was rather exciting -- a brilliant rally for the lead, made by the Keystones, very nearly resulting successfully for their side. The wild throwing of the Stars was about as bad a display of the kind an we have seen this season, and the Keystones followed suit to a certain extent. In other respects the contest was not so bad, the batting in some of the innings being very good. Neither party, however, played up to their mark, the Keystones being tired out and entirely out of trim for play, while the Stars threw away all the advantages of good stops by their wild throws. No less than 40 wild throws were made in this match, of which the Stars are chargeable with 27. The umpire impartially discharged his duties throughout; and at the close of the game the Keystones were hospitably entertained. To-day at noon they play the Atlantics, and at 4 P.M. take the cars for Coney Island, there to partake of a grand supper at the Ocean Hotel.

abstract: In the case of the murder of JAMES TAYLOR, who was assaulted and mortally wounded while returning from the Fenian picnic in Jones' Wood on Tuesday evening, the Coroner's Jury yesterday rendered a verdict that he came to his death by wounds received at the hands of JOHN BURNS, FREDERICK HOOKER boing an accessory before the fact. BURNS has not yet been arrested.

abstract: A highly interesting and very important case  of slander was before a Pittsburgh court recently. A gentleman had charged a lady with calling him a "bastard," and she had, accordingly, been arrested. The lady averred that the charge was false, as she only said he was a "dastard." The two words are so similar in sound that the Judge decided that he could not tell which was used. The lady was therefore discharged.

abstract: Distress in
lead_paragraph: We hear of a deeper and more general distress and poverty in Central South Carolina than in any other section of the South. The destruction performed by SHERMAN'S army there was far greater than by any of our other armies anywhere. The suffering, as we are assured by credible witnesses from Columbia, is appalling. Cultivated and refined people are reduced to beggary, and do actually subsist by it. We have heard authentic stories of individual cases of suffering that surpass anything known in American history, and equal the accounts of famines in the Old World. The people are dejected as well as distressed, subjugated in spirit as well as in the field.

abstract: Newbern, Supply Ship, Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States supply-steamer Newbern, Capt. ROBERT Y. HOLLY commanding, arrived at this port yesterday from New-Orleans 14th inst., touching at Key West, Pensacola and Charleston, S.C. She brings a large cargo of stores, together with forty sick officers and men from the hospital at Pensacola, Fla. The Newbern left New-York June 17, with mails and supplies for the East Gulf Squadron, touching at Hampton Roads and Port Royal to deliver stores; arrived at Key West on the 26th ult., proceeded from thence to Pensacola, Mobile Bay and New-Orleans, arriving at the latter port July 6, loaded with stores, and sailed on the 13th for New-York. She supplied twenty-one vessels, and delivered a large cargo of stores. The health of all the above-named ports was excellent. The Fort Morgan arrived at Key West on the 18th, and the Massachusatts at Charleston on the 24th, both bound to the southward. Off Key West, July 20, spoke ship Glad Tidings, 37 days from Portland, for New-Orleans. The Newbern brings home among her passengers, A. G. BUTTERFIELD, Esq., H.B.M. Consul at Key West. This vessel went in commission at New-York, Aug. 5, 1863, has rounded Hatteras 56 times, most of the time with supplies for the North Atlantic Blockading squadron, and has carried for distribution to vessels of that fleet 350,000 pounds of fresh beef, 9,000 pounds vegetables, together with a large quantity of stores of every description, including medicines, with which she kept the fleet supplied; has transported to and from the squadron 2,950 passes, including numerous blockade-runners. She is a fast and comfortable vessel, and very useful as a supply ship.

abstract: The only regiments arriving yesterday were the Fifty-first New-York, and the Sixth and Seventh Connecticut regiments. The Fifty-first is now at the rooms of the New-York State Agency, where they will remain until Monday, as a grand reception, review, and dinner will be accorded them by their numerous friends. The Sixth Connecticut passed through the city hurriedly on their way to New-Haven yesterday morning. The Seventh is now at the Battery Barracks, and will leave during the day for New-Haven. Col. ALMY provided a large quantity of peaches for the Connecticut regiments, and Col. COLYER made a most appetizing spread for the New-York boys. We subjoin a history of the regiment:

abstract: AWARDING CONTRACTS THROUGH [FAVORITISM. -- The Special Committee of the Kings County Board of Supervisors have for some time past been engaged in the investigation of charges made by the flour and grocery firm of S. and J.C. BURLING, against the Superintendents of the Poor, alleging that they were the lowest bidders on the 15th inst. for supplying goods to the almshouse, and that they have been unfairly deprived of the contract for supplying said goods, namely: 3,170 barrels of flour, by the said Superintendents. The contract was awarded to Mr. JAMES CORBOY, notwithstanding that his bids were higher than those of the BURLINGS. Several witnesses have been examined.

abstract: -There is a silent reproof for that most persistent of individuals -- the patriotic bore -- in the fact that men of the fame and public standing of Gen. GRANT hardly any longer dare to pass through the larger cities by daylight. They come and go, as a rule, at night, when the patriotic bore and most other bores are asleep. The people -- the masses, so to speak -- the famous sojourner might stand, but the inevitable mover of resolutions is too much for gods or men -- in July weather, at least.

abstract: Revenues, The National
lead_paragraph: With the disbandment of our gigantic military and naval force, on the one hand, and the immense increase in public revenues from internal taxation and import duties, on the other hand, it is now definitely seen that the day of great expenditures has passed away, and the day of great revenues has fairly begun. The war was nearly over before an adequate system of taxation was adjusted and put in operation; and even yet it is by no means effectively applied throughout the country, for the simple reason that it takes time to get the great machinery in working order. Yet the results thus far are beyond all previous calculation, and promise to be far better every week in the future. The receipts from taxation are now about a million of dollars a day; and the Internal Revenue Bureau at Washington estimate that they will fully equal this figure for the next three months. Judging by the returns being made in this city, we should think that a much higher estimate for the whole country might be made. The receipts from import duties also are very heavy, being at this port alone, at this time, at the weekly average of two millions four hundred thousand dollars. It is true that this very fact is taken advantage of to damage the public credit, but for this the law provides a very simple and effective remedy. So satisfactory is the working of these two great engines of national revenue, that it was semi-officially announced from Washington yesterday that "the Secretary of the Treasury is of the opinion that, owing to the continued reduction of the expenditures of the government, the Treasury can be kept in an easy condition by receipts from the usual source of revenue, and meet all requisitions which can be properly made upon it until the meeting of Congress."

abstract: JAMES EVELAND was arraigned before Justice DODGE yesterday on a charge of stealing" $500 worth of carpets, bedding, and other property, belonging to Mrs. CATHARINE ALLEN, wife of THEODORE ALLEN, living at No. 809 Greenwich-street The complainant alleges that on the 29th of April last she stored a quantity of furniture in charge of the accused at No. 89 Mercer-street On examining the goods on the 27th inst. she found that the above articles were missing. EVELAND could not account for their disappearance, and Mrs. ALLEN caused his arrest. Justice DODGE committed the accused for examination.

abstract: -Gen. BROWN, the commander of our troops at Brownsville, Texas, (on the Rio Grande, opposite Matamoras,) is said to have had an interview very recently with JUAREZ, and to have promised the Mexican President the assistance of his forces; and it is further stated that he (Gen. BROWN) had ordered the Fourth Indiana to cross the Rio Grande into Mexico. These facts, so goes our authority, coming to the ears of Maj.-Gen. STEELE, commander of the Department of Texas, that officer made all haste to stop the wicked folly of his subordinate. We give the stories as they reach us, but it seems incredible that they can be strictly correct. Whether so or not, however, they will doubtless add to the nervous feeling concerning affairs in that quarter, which now, to a great extent, pervades our people.

abstract: At a meeting of the Committee of the Metropolitan Employment Agency for soldiers and sailors honorably discharged, held on the 20th of July, 1865, at No. 136 Canal-street, a report was received from the manager, Mr. J.B. HERMAN, stating that during the month there have been 436 applications for employment, and that 207 situations have been procured for the applicants.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Committee of the Metropolitan Employment Agency for soldiers and sailors honorably discharged, held on the 20th of July, 1865, at No. 136 Canal-street, a report was received from the manager, Mr. J.B. HERMAN, stating that during the month there have been 436 applications for employment, and that 207 situations have been procured for the applicants. The wages paid to the men who have been procured employment vary from $1 50 per day, (the lowest figure for laborers generally,) to $3 per day for workingmen, mechanics, gardeners, coachmen, &c., and clerks. Of these 207 men, 85 have got situations in the country and abroad, the others have been employed in this city and Brooklyn.

abstract: The steamer New-York passed Cape Race on Thursday, with four days later news from Europe. The Parliamentary elections still absorb public attention in England. Mr. GLADSTONE had been defeated in Oxford and was presented for South Lancashire. The Great Eastern was at Valentia Bay on the 19th inst., but the report does not indicate whether she was to sail immediately.

abstract: A dispatch was received in this city yesterday from Worcester, Otsego County, N.Y., stating that Mrs. H.W. ROBINSON, of this city, had been instantly killed while riding with her husband and child. It appears that the horses became frightened and ran away, throwing the occupants of the carriage upon the ground. Mr. ROBINSON and son were injured, but not fatally. Mr. ROBINSON is a lawyer of this city.

abstract: Paris Exhibition of 1867, Report of Com.
snippet: Paris Exhibition of 1867, Report of Com.
lead_paragraph: The Moniteur publishes a report from M. DUMAS, President of the Municipal Council, to the Imperial Commission of the Universal Exhibition, in the name of the Committee of Construction. The document gives an historical sketch of public exhibitions in France from the commencement of the century, and then proceeds to inquire what space should be assigned to the building destined to receive the objects to be exhibited in 1867. The London Exhibition of 1851, received 14,000 exhibitors, and 96,000 square metres of space; that of Paris in 1856,24,000 and 112,000 respectively; the second of London, 27,000 and 120,000; and the coming exhibition will propably receive the articles of 30,000 persons and require 140,000 square metres of superficies. The report examines the several plans proposed for the building to be erected in the Champ-de-Mars, and states that the one decided on will consist of a ground floor only, with an exceedingly large space all around for approaches and other accommodation. The two exhibitions of industrial objects and of the fine arts will take place in the same building, all the foreign members of the commission being unanimous on the advantage of that course. A Paris letter in the Independance of Brussels gives the following particulars respecting the proposed exhibition: "This immense edifice will be about 500 metres in length, and 400 in width. The form proposed is elliptical, or rather that of a parallelogram, with a semi-circle added to each end. The arrangement will allow all the industrial and artistic productions of the different countries to be distributed in lines, resembling those of a spider's web. Besides two great passages, one from the Pont d'Iena, the other facing the Ecole Militaire, a number of sectors, or raddii, cross the concentric galleries, the largest of which, nearest the circumference, is devoted to machinery, and the one nearest the centre, to the fine arts. In the midst is to be a garden, which will permit the visitors to go into the open air without leaving the precincts of the building. After the gallery of fine arts, which may be said to terminate inside the construction devoted to the exhibition, comes an annexed space, leading immediately to the garden, and presenting the history of human ingenuity of all ages and nations, by means of specimens of the different instruments man has invented to facilitate labor. The passage leading from the middle of the palace toward the Pont d'Iena will, moreover, have a peculiar interest; being preceded by a sumptuous vestibule, which forms the interior of the facade, it will be nothing less than a gallery devoted to the plastic history of the earth, as well by geological sections as by landscapes, completing this instructive exhibition. The palace will be connected with the Seine by a cutting through the quay at the Pont d'Iena; visitors will pass under a light bridge made expressly to lead to the salon. The river itself will be utilized, and will become an aquatic hall of the exposition, at the same time as a means for arrivals by water. Buoys, anchors and naval apparatus of all kinds will here be exhibited in their proper element. Such, I believe, are the arrangements already decided. There is also what may be called the fancy part of the project, which is not definitely fixed, and may be modified or even abandoned. The Palace of Industry only occupying about one-third of the Champ-de-Mars, it has been suggested to transform the rest into a kind of park, in which the public would not only find cafes, restaurants, &c., but also cabinets intended for correspondence, an electric telegraph, a small theatre for plays in all languages, a conversation-room, a model farm, a specimen of a camp, and even an observatory. In this part, and close to the outer walls of the palace, will be placed the boilers of the steam engines for working the machines in the great gallery at the end, as it is not thought prudent to have the boilers inside the building.

abstract: Within the past twelve months several lines of stages have been suspended, owing to the competition of the new lines of city railroads. Thus the Houstonstreet, Bleecker-street, Sixth-avenue and Eighth and Ninth streets, Amity-street, Fourteenth-street, Broadway and Wall-street and Broadway and South Ferry lines have ceased to run; while the Fifth-avenue and Fulton-street, Madison-avenue and Wall-street, Fourthavenue and South Ferry, Twenty-third-street and South Ferry, and Broadway and Cortlandt-street lines are still in operation.

abstract: Edward Kaupe vs. Henry W. Eastman, U.S. Assessor. -- This was a bill filed against the United States Assessor of the First Collection District of the State of New-York, to restrain him from inserting in his tax list for tax on incomes for the year 1864, the sum of $4,346 60, which sum was the tax upon the complainant's portion of the profits of the special partnership of F.O. Matthiessen & Wiechers, ending the year 1864, and which the assessor insisted should be deemed part of the complainant's income. The complaint rested upon the following provisions of the articles of special partnership: "Each general or special partner shall be entitled to interest at the rate of seven per cent. per annum on all capital standing to his credit, to be paid annually, provided that the payment of such interest shall not reduce the original amount of the special capital of the firm."

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Mr. JOSEPH VAN DOREN, a city weigher, doing business at No. 40 Beaver-street, was shot and instantly killed by Mr. JAMES F. ORAM, also a city weigher. So far as the facts can be ascertained it appears that the two men quarrelled, and that a scuffle ensued, during which Mr. VAN DOREN was shot by ORAM. The deceased resided in Jersey City, and leaves a widow and several children. ORAM, who is now under arrest, is a resident of this city and unmarried.

abstract: -Mr. ELON A. GALUSHA, a respectable citizen of Rochester, was discovered lying in one of the upper dams surrounding the Central Railroad bridge in that city, Thursday morning last. The supposition is that while on his way home the night before, while crossing the bridge in the darkness, he made a mis-step and fell through between the timbers to the bed of the river, a distance of twelve or fifteen feet below. The head had two bruises upon it, not sufficient to fracture the skull, but sufficient, in the opinion of the examining surgeons, to stun and cause a suspension of consciousness. His watch and valuables were found upon his person, indicating that there had been no attempt at robbery, and that his death came from the above-named cause.
lead_paragraph: -Mr. ELON A. GALUSHA, a respectable citizen of Rochester, was discovered lying in one of the upper dams surrounding the Central Railroad bridge in that city, Thursday morning last. abstract: SUSPICIONS OF FOUL PLAY. On Wednesday morning last, about 4 o'clock, Capt. JAMES PEABODY, of Chelsea, a watchman in the Navy-yard, left the gate near the Chelsea bridge to go to his home. Since then nothing has been heard of him. Capt. PEABODY is an old and highly respected citizen of Chelsea, very regular and domestic in his habits and it is feared he has met with foul play.
lead_paragraph: -- SUSPICIONS OF FOUL PLAY. -- On Wednesday morning last, about 4 o'clock, Capt. JAMES PEABODY, of Chelsea, a watchman in the Navy-yard, left the gate near the Chelsea bridge to go to his home. Since then nothing has been heard of him. Capt. PEABODY is an old and highly respected citizen of Chelsea, very regular and domestic in his habits and it is feared he has met with foul play. A kossuth hat which is known to be the one he had on when he left the yard, has since been found floating in the water near the draw of the Chelsea bridge. Parties are engaged in grappling for the body. There was a rumor that the remains of Capt. PEABODY had been found, with the pockets in his coat and pants turned inside out, but up to 11 o'clock this morning such was not the case. He was 64 years of age, middling height, blue eyes, and a wart on one cheek. -- Boston Traveller, July 28.

abstract: Fort Jackson, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Fort Jackson, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Rhode Island arrived here Friday evening, from the West India special convoy service. This ship went into commission on the 29th of July, 1861, has been four years in service, and has not been laid up for repairs during all that time. She was one of the first vessels purchased by the government, and has proved herself one of the fastest as well as best of her class. She was the pioneer of the supply steamers, but government finding her so fast and better adapted for other duty, she was converted into a heavily armed cruiser, and ordered to the North Atlantic Squadron. The Alabama and Florida making their appearance off our coast at this time, she was at once ordered to the special West India Squadron to cruise after those vessels; it then becoming necessary to convoy the California steamers through the West India passages, she was among the first ordered on the convoy service, and the last one to leave it. Has been attached to the North and South Atlantic Squadrons, and took an active part in both bombardments and capture of Fort Fisher, since which time she has been employed on special and active service.

snippet: Foreign Trade and Customs Duties; Articles on. No. 1, Wants of the Government
lead_paragraph: With the war gloriously ended, we can begin to form some tolerable approximation as an estimate of the amount which will henceforth be required to supply all departments of the national kitchen, and meet the requirements of our vast national debt. Already we have become accustomed to figures so much greater than before the rebellion, that the change from war to peace will agreeably surprise many, even though the total expenditures should be four or five times as great as they were in 1860.

abstract: One of the phenomena of great wars is the proof they afford of the immense latent force and capacity for exertion in the human character. Hedged round by social ties, governed by a host of conventionalisms, the human animal is usually of orderly and peace-loving proclivities content to pass from the schoolhouse and the play-ground to the countingroom, the store, the manufactory or the farm.
lead_paragraph: One of the phenomena of great wars is the proof they afford of the immense latent force and capacity for exertion in the human character. Hedged round by social ties, governed by a host of conventionalisms, the human animal is usually of orderly and peace-loving proclivities -- content to pass from the schoolhouse and the play-ground to the countingroom, the store, the manufactory or the farm. He is born, he dies. He labors for a lifetime and leaves no sign. He floats upon the ocean of life his appointed time, and at last sinks beneath the surface, with hardly a ripple to mark the place of his going down.

abstract: Freedom of Speech and the Rebel Leaders
snippet: Freedom of Speech and the Rebel Leaders
lead_paragraph: Freedom of speech upon public affairs is a privilege we Americans appreciate too highly to suffer it to be tampered with. Unfortunately, however, some people do not know the difference in this respect between liberty and license. Among these undiscriminating persons are not a few of the subdued rebels -- we cannot say repenting rebels, for, according to their story, they have done nothing to repent of. These worthies illustrate the familiar experience that those whose position and record should make them most careful to observe the rules of decorum, are the quickest to leap its bounds.

abstract: -- It has been repeatedly stated, and generally believed, though never officially announced, that Gen. LEE and other officers of the late Confederate Army were indicted at the last term of the United States Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, held, at Norfolk. At the next term of this court, to be held in Norfolk in October, it is said these indictments will be called up; but it is understood in Washington that these cases will not be prosecuted, but the President will direct nolle prosequis to be entered, and dispose of each defendant as he proposes to dispose of other leading Southerners who have been active participants in the war, namely, by putting them on long probation, and then, as a condition precedent to pardon, imposing such penalties and restrictions as may be justified by the circumstances. -- Richmond Bulletin.

abstract: To-morrow the Fifty-first and Forty-sixth Regiments, which arrived late Friday night, will receive the honor of a formal reception, and each command will be entertained by Col. COLYER with collations, out of the funds accumulating in his hands for that purpose.
lead_paragraph: To-morrow the Fifty-first and Forty-sixth Regiments, which arrived late Friday night, will receive the honor of a formal reception, and each command will be entertained by Col. COLYER with collations, out of the funds accumulating in his hands for that purpose. The Union Loyal League Club are also interested in the proper reception of these regiments and will entertain the men at their club-house, Union-square. The dinner to the Forty-sixth will take place at noon, and that for the Fifty-first at 6 P.M. Speeches, a dainty spread, and harmonious music will be the order of the day and evening. The military escort to the Fifty-first will consist of the Seventh New-York and Fourteenth Brooklyn regiments. The Forty-sixth will be escorted by the Eighth, (it is expected,) or some other city regiment. We should suppose that our genial German friends, who wear the State uniform, will also turn out, and we trust to see them do so.

Wallace, $51,482; G.H. Studwell, $33,452; Wm. Hustice, $26,201; Israel Shedon, $40,446. Gen. McClellan, who is a resident of Orange, returns an income of $1,449.

abstract: The Salut Public of Lyons gives the subjoined account of a terrible accident on the Marseilles Railway: "On the day the Indian mail going to Marseilles was announced, the agent appointed to serve as pilot or director had gone to await it at one of the stations above Rognac, when the train from Marscilles arrived at the station.
lead_paragraph: The Salut Public of Lyons gives the subjoined account of a terrible accident on the Marseilles Railway: "On the day the Indian mail going to Marseilles was announced, the agent appointed to serve as pilot or director had gone to await it at one of the stations above Rognac, when the train from Marscilles arrived at the station. This train ought to have waited until the Indian express had passed, but the station-master allowed it to proceed, thinking it would have time to pass over the portion of the railway with a single line before the other reached that point. The contrary, however, occurred, and the two trains -- one proceeding at the rate of 25 and the other nearly 50 miles an hour -- came into collision with a terrible crash. The first carriages of the Marseilles train were smashed to pieces and heaped on each other, and the driver of the Indian mail train was killed. The catastrophe took place in the open country, and at a distance from any town, and the wounded persons lay for three hours before any surgical assistance could be obtained. The scene was most horrible; the fragments of the carriages, exposed to the burning rays of the sun; the greater part had their legs or thighs crushed. One unfortunate young woman about to become a mother had both her legs broken, and with her last breath gave birth to a child. The agent who was accompanying one of the trains had both his legs cut off and died on the spot. At the latest moment we learn that the total number of killed is six, and the wounded thirty-eight."

abstract: The parish of St. John's, Clifton, Staten Island, has resolved to build a new church. The proposed edifice will be of stone, and have a handsome bell-tower and spire overlooking the Narrows. The sittings will number 700, and the cost will amount to nearly $40,000, and when finished will be entirely free from debt. The ladies have promised to provide the furniture and organ. They held a fair last week, which continued through four days, at which the receipts were over $7,500.

abstract: The Capitol mentions a couple of large coffee kettles which have been presented to the Wisconsin State Historical Society by Company A, Sixteenth Wisconsin Volunteer Infantry. These kettles traveled "from Atlanta to the sea," and so around to Washington, making, on an average, forty gallons per day, and leaving many a black spot on the sacred soil of Georgia and the Carolinas.

abstract: -We have a new dog story to relate: A little Euclid-avenue friend of ours possesses, among other pets, a fine pointed dog, and a couple of little chickens, that have been deserted by their mother -- a very unprincipled and, unnatural hen, by the way. The other day he fell asleep while playing with the chickens. As he lay upon the floor, with his long, golden curls streaming out upon the carpet, the chickens nestled beneath them, as they would have nestled beneath their run-away mother. The pointer dog was near, and, for some time, had watched the proceedings with evident interest. Finally be approached the sleeper, poked the little chickens from beneath the curls, took them gently in his mouth, and carried them to his kennel. Their juvenile owner was much alarmed upon awakening and finding that they "were not." Alarm was changed, first to surprise and then to pleasure, upon discovering their whereabouts, and the gentle manner in which they were being cared for. The dog seemed perfectly carried away with fond affection for his charge. He would gently caress them and look upon them with eyes beaming with tenderness. For three or four days the little chicks thus resided with their canine friend. At night they would repose beneath the hair of his paws, and during the day he was their constant companion -- attending to their every want with a human care and solicitude. Finally, this unnatural mode of existence seemed to disagree with them, and the chickens were taken from their strange protector -- much to the latter's sorrow. -- Cleveland Herald.

abstract: DEARLY BELOVED IN THE LORD. -- God has removed from us by death our revered and beloved Diocesan, Rt. Rev. Bishop ALONZO POTTER. While we cannot but mourn our irreparable loss, it becomes us to bow with submission to this bereaving stroke, which takes from the Diocese its faithful and venerable head. This is not the place to declare his many and noble qualities of mind and heart, or to recite the manifold blessings which have resulted to this Diocese through his indefatigable labors.

abstract: The British provincial authorities and the "Tenant Union League," in Prince Edward Island, have come into collision on account of attempts to distrain for rents due the colony for lands occupied. A deputy sheriff was captured at one place, but after his release retaliated by carrying off one CLOW and locking him up. Afterward, elsewhere, the deputy with three assistants seized a horse and wagon, was assailed, beaten, and the property recovered, though he made a prisoner of the ringleader, CHARLES DICKIESON, after a sharp fight. This is only the beginning of troubles, it is said.
lead_paragraph: The British provincial authorities and the "Tenant Union League," in Prince Edward Island, have come into collision on account of attempts to distrain for rents due the colony for lands occupied. A deputy sheriff was captured at one place, but after his release retaliated by carrying off one CLOW and locking him up. Afterward, elsewhere, the deputy with three assistants seized a horse and wagon, was assailed, beaten, and the property recovered, though he made a prisoner of the ringleader, CHARLES DICKIESON, after a sharp fight. This is only the beginning of troubles, it is said.

abstract: Yesterday morning the Bishop Wainright Memorial Church, corner of Waverley-place and Hammond-street, was crowded by a large audience, assembled on the first Sunday after the death of the rector, to listen to a discourse from Rev. WILLIAM C. WINSLOW. After the usual services in the Episcopal form, and the singing of the hymn, "There is a Land of Pure Delight," the preacher discoursed from the text, "God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes, and there shall be no more death," &c. After an eloquent exposition of this portion of Scripture, and agraphic description of the condition of the redeemed in Heaven, Mr. WINSLOW spoke of our Saviour as being the chief and greatest attraction of Heaven. "The Lamb is the light thereof," was quoted and vividly represented. The speaker passed to the presence of our friends in Heaven as being among the heavenly attractions, "they make Heaven richer and earth poorer." Said the reverend preacher: "Brethren, what a spectacle is this! But yesterday we beheld our beloved friend, moving, conversing, and acting his part with us. The lustre of life was on his cheek, the fire of reason was in his eye, the warm current coursed his veins, the hopes, the fears, the loves of a common humanity beat in his bosom. He was one of us. As in a moment, he is one of us no longer. * * * * Mr. WINSLOW then passed to some analysis of the character and some account of the labors of the deceased. Most touchingly he spoke of his relation to the children of the Sunday-school, and his labors of love to hundreds. "He lived for others," said the preacher; "a nobler epitaph could not be written." The discourse closed with a brief exhortation to the Church to go on with the work of the sainted dead, and invoked the blessings of Heaven upon the Church. The discourse was listened to with the deepest attention, and evidently made a profound impression on the hearts of all present.

abstract: -- At About 2 1/2 o'clock on Sunday morning, as Officer STRAN was conveying to the station house JAMES TALLENT, whom he detected acting in a rather suspicious manner, he was set upon in West Nineteenth-street by a crowd of the prisoner's friends, who attempted to rescue the offender. During the struggle which ensued several shots were fired at the officer, none of them, however, taking effect. At length assistance came, and the crowd was dispersed, TALLENT being taken to the station-house, and thence before Justice DODGE, who sent him for six months to the Penitentiary, in default of bail for future good behavior.
lead_paragraph: -- At About 2 1/2 o'clock on Sunday morning, as Officer STRAN was conveying to the station house JAMES TALLENT, whom he detected acting in a rather suspicious manner, he was set upon in West Nineteenth-street by a crowd of the prisoner's friends, who attempted to rescue the offender. During the struggle which ensued several shots were fired at the officer, none of them, however, taking effect. abstract: PETER LYNCH, a youth of 26 years, evidently put in full time from Saturday night until yesterday morning, at which time he went home rather out of humor, and from some unexplained cause, made an indiscriminate smash-up of his father's furniture. Officers MCNAMARA and MANNING, of the Jersey City police, called in and quelled the young man by conducting him to the City Prison, where he waslo ckedup on a charge of being drunk and disorderly, and smashing his father's furniture, at No. 11, Newark Avenue.

abstract: -- A case was reported yesterday of the arrest of the keeper of a disorderly house by a policeman, whose story, as a witness, went further to convict himself than to bring home guilt to the prisoner. The officer in question, moreover, has been confronted with a counter charge in which he is made to figure as the recipient of hush-money from the class whose misconduct it is his business to report No doubt the Commissioners will promptly and righteously deal with this case. But what we wish to say is, that there is a very strong impression abroad that there are not a few similar delinquents in the force -- admirable as it is in its general character and discipline.

abstract: Bright, John--Speeches of
lead_paragraph: The speeches contained in this volume have enjoyed the advantage of Mr. BRIGHT's revision, and are here presented to Americans in an elegant and permanent shape. It is well known that they display and illustrate some of the highest qualities of popular oratory. Every one who remembers the warm-hearted devotion of their author to the cause of freedom, and his undeviating support of the side of law and justice in the late rebellion, should hasten to become possessed of it. The volume is elegantly gotten up, and contains a fine steel portrait of Mr. BRIGHT, engraved by RITCHIE.
