abstract: -- Yesterday, MINA SOLBACK, a German woman, keeping a disreputable house at No. 48 Hudson-street, was arrested and charged with having stolen from JOHN THORNE; an Illinois soldier, the sum of $225 in Treasury notes. It is alleged that the defendant took the money from the complainant, saying she would return it, and then only handed over $53, which she clandestinely slipped in his pocket. THORNE was evidently under the influence of liquor at the time, and was intoxicated three entire days. Justice HOGAN committed MINA for examination.
lead_paragraph: -- Yesterday, MINA SOLBACK, a German woman, keeping a disreputable house at No. 48 Hudson-street, was arrested and charged with having stolen from JOHN THORNE; an Illinois soldier, the sum of $225 in Treasury notes. abstract: Tax-Payers Paying the Piper
lead_paragraph: Just before the people of this city indulged in the luxury of making FERNANDO WOOD their Mayor, the entire taxation for all purposes -- City, County and State -- figured up $4,845,386. This was in 1854. About that time, mainly in order to secure the election of the aforesaid Mayor and certain of his henchmen as Aldermen, there was formed the infamous secret society, since known as "The Ring." This society, following the illustrious example of the Mozart Napoleon, jobbed out the laws and franchises of the city to the highest bidders, and sold their votes for and against affairs of public concern with equal facility to political friend or foe, except in cases of great party moment. That Ring is as perfect to-day as ever. It seems to be the veritable serpent with his tail in his mouth by which the ancients symbolized eternity. The Mogul is in a foreign land, but his "moral effect" still guides and controls the oath-bound gang of thieves who prey upon the long-suffering tax-payers and tax-earners of this city.

abstract: Government; Powers and Duties of
lead_paragraph: Most of our citizens know that we have a municipal government, but very few, with the exception of those specially interested, have ever taken the trouble to ascertain what are the duties and responsibilities of the various departments and bureaus. They know well enough that a great deal of money is spent every year, but not through whose hands it passes. They know that our streets are duty, that in many of them the pavements are in a bad condition, that not a few are insufficiently lighted, that our wharves and piers are a disgrace to a large commercial city; but they do not know who is directly responsible for this condition of things. The powers of the Common Council, though still extensive, are gradually becoming more circumscribed. Within a few years past the Legislature has taken out of their hands the care of emigrants and paupers, the control of the police force and the Fire Department, and now the cleaning of our streets is superintended by a commission. In the following article a brief synopsis is given of the powers and duties of each department of the city government, which may not prove uninteresting, in view of the fact that it is the general opinion among local politicians that at the next meeting of the Legislature some radical and sweeping changes will be effected.

abstract: The parish of St. John's, Clifton, Staten Island, has resolved to build a new church. The proposed edifice will be of stone, and have a handsome bell-tower and spire overlooking the Narrows. The sittings will number 700, and the cost will amount to nearly $40,000, and when finished will be entirely free from debt. The ladies have promised to provide the furniture and organ. They held a fair last week, which continued through four days, at which the receipts were over $7,500.

abstract: On Saturday evening Mrs. ALBERT SAGE, residing corner of South First and Fourth-streets, E.D., who has been in the habit of taking morphine, came near her death in consequence of an overdose of that powerful drug. Dr. BRADY, assisted by other physicians, finally succeeded in saving the lady's life. The street report, intimating attempted suicide in this case, is denied by the lady's friends.

abstract: Parsons, Gen. Lewis B.
lead_paragraph: -- The enormous capability of the United States for war was forcibly set forth at a meeting of the Alumni of Yale College a few days since, by the abovenamed officer, in the statement that since the surrender of Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON the War Department has mustered out of the service and sent home over seven hundred thousand men. It was added, and the declaration was doubtless a surprise to the country, that at the close of hostilities by the event above named the Union army amounted to very nearly one million of men. No statement in brief could have so impressively made known to the nations the true significance of the battle that had been waged on this continent between the democratic principles and the representatives of the oligarchy of the earth. While the one was shattered, trodden out and extinguished, the other had millions of veteran champions fresh and eager for still further conflicts, if they had been offered.

abstract: We are all suffering here with intense heat of the weather. But, notwithstanding it is July, business appears to be quite active. As yet there are no signs of yellow fever, and the impression prevails that we shall escape that scourge this season. Passengers from the North report that it has circulated in NewYork that cases of yellow fever had already occurred.

abstract: -The remains of MICHAEL MARTIN, who was buried in the ruins of No. 93 Furman-street on Wednesday morning last, were recovered yesterday morning. The body was dreadfully bruised. In the pockets were found, carefully wrapped up in paper, a gold sovereign, fifteen shillings in foreign silver coin, $46 in bills, and $45 in postal currency, of which seventy-five cents was counterfeit. MARTIN, who was a laborer, always carried his money about his person. The deceased leaves a wife and two children, residing at No. 46 Baxter-street, New York. The remains were taken to the dead house. An investigation will be commenced this afternoon by Coroner LYNCH.

abstract: Edward Kaupe vs. Henry W. Eastman, U.S. Assessor. -- This was a bill filed against the United States Assessor of the First Collection District of the State of New-York, to restrain him from inserting in his tax list for tax on incomes for the year 1864, the sum of $4,346 60, which sum was the tax upon the complainant's portion of the profits of the special partnership of F.O. Matthiessen & Wiechers, ending the year 1864, and which the assessor insisted should be deemed part of the complainant's income. The complaint rested upon the following provisions of the articles of special partnership: "Each general or special partner shall be entitled to interest at the rate of seven per cent. per annum on all capital standing to his credit, to be paid annually, provided that the payment of such interest shall not reduce the original amount of the special capital of the firm."
lead_paragraph: Edward Kaupe vs. Henry W. abstract: Belial, a Novel
lead_paragraph: We are here introduced, not to the actual Prince of Darkness, but to his representative --" a devilish gentlemanly fellow," who, by the unrestrained indulgence of his selfish propensities, embroils every one in the snarl, does all he can to wreck the happiness of the lovers, and is finally led to commit murder, when hopelessly entangled in plots of his own contriving. He scarcely meets with his deserts, at the end, being washed off the deck of a blockade-runner just in time to escape the avenging arm of the law. The book is anonymous, and though evidently of English origin, we do not remember to have met with any notice or review of it. Its selection for reprint does credit to the discernment of the publishers.

abstract: The steamship City of New York passed Cape Race on Thursday, with four days' later news from Europe. The Parliamentary elections still occupied public attention in England. Up to the 20th inst. the Liberals had gained eighteen seats, securing control of the next Parliament. Mr. GLADSTONE had been defeated at Oxford by a majority of eighteen, but immediately accepted the nomination for South Lancashire, where he "will undoubtedly be elected. The Great Eastern, with the Atlantic Telegraph cable on board, arrived at Valentia Bay on the 19th, whence she was to sail as soon as the necessary preparations were made. From Egypt we learn that the cholera is sensibly abating in that country. The young Prince Imperial of France has been very pick, of what disease we are not informed, but is now recovering. American securities have experienced a slight improvement.

abstract: -- On Saturday, the dwelling-house of Mr. STREET, at No. 9 Lamartine place, was broken into by thieves during the absence of the family. The burglars packed up a large quantity of clothing, &c., with which they were about to escape, when a domestic living on the opposite side of the street gave the alarm and they fled in dismay. No arrests were made.

abstract: -- On Saturday night a woman named SMITH, residing in a building known as "Kelly's House," in Bergen-street, Jersey City, became angry with her husband, and rushing out of the house, ran down to the canal and plunged in, with the avowed purpose of shortening her precious existence. Mr. SMITH, not wishing to be deprived of so sweet a dispositioned helpmate, and not knowing exactly where he could get another like her, followed close in her wake, and, with the assistance of two or three citizens, succeeded in landing her on terra firma, and Mrs. SMITH is now alive and as well as she ought to be.

abstract: The Forty-sixth New-York, One Hundred and Thirty-first New-York and Sixth New-Hampshire Regiments arrived yesterday and Saturday, as also a battery from the Third Rhode Island Heavy Artillery. The Forty-sixth, Fifty-first and One Hundred and Thirty-first New-York Regiments will have a grand reception accorded them to-day. The Eighth Regiment turns out in honor of the Forty-sixth; the Fourteenth Brooklyn Regiment, a company of the Eighty-fourth and the Third company of the Seventh Regiment will parade with the Fifty-first, and a battalion of the Metropolitan Police, 600 men, will form the escort of the One Hundred and Thirty-first or First Metropolitan Regiment. The Sixth New-Hampshire and the Rhode Island battery left immediately for home.

abstract: Santa Anna's Reappearance
lead_paragraph: Old SANTA ANNA is out again with a revolutionary manifesto to the Mexicans. Whenever his native land is in an extremity of misfortune, or whenever its fortunes begin to brighten, he springs to the front, sword in hand, and rushes, as the case may be, upon those whom he considers the authors of its ruin, or upon those who are attempting to rescue it from destruction. It seems to make comparatively little odds to him. He belongs constitutionally to the remarkable order of men who have dominated Mexico for the last forty years -- ambitious, revolutionary, scheming and selfish, ever proclaiming liberty and always trampling it under foot, ever, as he claims, attempting to rescue his country, and always plunging it into profounder and more hopeless anarchy. For the last ten years SANTA ANNA has been an exile, and during that period he has seen the government of Mexico upset half-a-dozen times. He has seen the Liberal party give way to the Priest party, Republicanism give place to Imperialism; but through all the changes, there has been no cessation in the war and bloodshed which had been continuous during the thirty-five years of his previous public life in Mexico.

abstract: Skilled Labor, the Market for
lead_paragraph: -- A suicide by an intelligent mechanic (reported yesterday in our news columns) was committed near Greenwood on Saturday. The unfortunate man, it appears, left letters behind him, giving as a reason for his act, the difficulty or impossibility of finding employment. It is just possible that this declaration -- made under such fearful circumstances -- may create an unwarrantable impression among those who live at a distance. There may be peculiar crafts in which the supply of skilled labor is, at this moment, superabundant. But as a rule, no industrious, steady and honest mechanic need go long in search of employment -- least of all one who, like this unfortunate man, had lived a long while in the city. The high price of provisions, the scarcity of dwellings, and the terrible rate at which municipal taxation increases, make it a harder job than it ought to be for working-men to make both ends meet. But we believe we are correct in saying that skilled labor is now in as good demand, not only here, but throughout the country, as it has been in average seasons in the era of peace.

abstract: -- The Great Eastern, it seems, succeeded in reaching Valentia Harbor, Ireland, with the cable, on the 19th inst. If the twenty miles of shore end was spliced to the main cable in anything like the time promised by the managers, the Great Eastern and her consorts ought to have started on their voyage by the 20th. In that case, We might reckon upon hearing of them in Heart's Content Bay, Newfoundland, on Wednesday. We cannot say that we are sanguine in our expectation of such a result. The vessel that had charge of the shore end of the line must have broken down on the way, for she was due at Valentia on the 13th of July, and the report we published yesterday makes it appear that she was towed in on the 19th by the Great Eastern. The weather, for the past ten days -- unless it was very different on the other side of the Atlantic from what we have experienced here -- must have been altogether propitious for the laying of the cable.

abstract: The advices by the City of New-York, received via Cape Race, show that the Ministeral party has a strong hold on the confidence of the country. Up to the 20th inst. the Liberals had gained eighteen members, and their control of the next Parliament, by a decided majority, is no longer a matter of doubt. With all their shortcomings, the Whigs have included in their ranks our only friends, in England, and we are satisfied to see them continued in power, to the exclusion of open partizans of the rebellion.

abstract: Mott Haven, Gunpowder Stored in Shed
snippet: Mott Haven, Gunpowder Stored in Shed
lead_paragraph: A shed opposite the depot at Mott-Haven, in which was stored three kegs of gunpowder, one barrel of sulphur, and a considerable quantity of pyrotechnics, suddenly exploded yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock. The explosion was the cause of injuring several persons who were standing near. Among the sufferers were a Mr. FABER, residing in Jamaica, L.I, and his neice, both of whom were severely burned; two other gentlemen were considerably bruised by the effects of the concussion.

abstract: -- The defeat of Mr. GLADSTONE, at Oxford, would be a source of regret, if there were danger of its depriving the Liberals of his powerful support in the next Parliament; but as soon as his defeat was known, he accepted the nomination for South Lancashire, where he cannot fail of being elected. As member for a thoroughly liberal constituency, Mr. GLADSTONE will be able to take a much bolder stand in support of the principles and measures of the advanced Liberal party, than would have been consistent in the representative of the reactionary and conservative University. We are not sorry, therefore, to hear of his defeat at Oxford.
lead_paragraph: -- The defeat of Mr. GLADSTONE, at Oxford, would be a source of regret, if there were danger of its depriving the Liberals of his powerful support in the next Parliament; but as soon as his defeat was known, he accepted the nomination for South Lancashire, where he cannot fail of being elected. As member for a thoroughly liberal constituency, Mr. GLADSTONE will be able to take a much bolder stand in support of the principles and measures of the advanced Liberal party, than would have been consistent in the representative of the reactionary and conservative University. We are not sorry, therefore, to hear of his defeat at Oxford.

abstract: Civil and Ecclesiastical Conflict in
lead_paragraph: The official report of the negotiations between home and the Italian Government has been published, and unlike official reports in general, it is a terse, straightforward document, and gives us some valuable information, and furnishes us with sufficient data on which to form a judgment. To begin with, it sets the question at rest as to whether the King or the Pope made the first overtures. On this point LA MARMORA, in whose name the report is drawn up, says, addressing his sovereign: "As soon as your Majesty condescended to communicate to me the autograph letter addressed to you by His Holiness the Pope, on the 6th March, 1865, we, &c." The Cabinet deemed it right and politic to second the Pope's overtures.

abstract: Enterprise vs. Active, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: On Saturday the Keystone Club of Philadelphia, played their sixth and last match of the series, in which they were engaged with the leading organization of the Metropolis and its vicinity; their opponants on the occasion being the champion nine of the Atlantic Club, the result of course, being the success of the champions, but not by the large score the Philadelphians anticipated; the good batting of the Keystones, leading to a score of 13 runs in the same, the champions obtaining 33. But 5 innings were played, the time having arrived -- at the close of the fifth innings -- for the excursion party to start on their visit to Coney Island, that being a feature of the day's proceedings, the winding up of the week's play, being a grand supper at the Ocean House, Coney Island.

abstract: -- The Prime Minister of Canada, Sir. E.P. TACHE, is reported so dangerously ill, that it is taken for granted a new minister will have to be named to fill his place. As the existing government is made up of a coalition of parties, it is considered extremely doubtful whether a new composite administration could be formed under any other available leadership. If this difficulty should arise, the old geographical division of parties would return -- the Anglo-Canadian of the West against the Gallo-Canadian of the East. Less than two years' revived experience of that peculiar antagonism of sections would place confederation and annexation in an entirely different light before three-fourths of the people of the provinces.
lead_paragraph: -- The Prime Minister of Canada, Sir. E.P. TACHE, is reported so dangerously ill, that it is taken for granted a new minister will have to be named to fill his place. Less than two years' revived experience of that peculiar antagonism of sections would place confederation and annexation in an entirely different light before three-fourths of the people of the provinces.

abstract: About 2:30 o'clock yesterdaymorning, a discussion arose between ROBERT MCMENEE and JOHN MCGEE, when the former drew a revolver, discharging one barrel at his opponent, the ball taking effect in MCGEE's under jaw, and inflicting a very serious wound in the back part of the mouth. The wounded man was conveyed to the New-York Hospital. MCMENEE contrived to effect his escape, and has not yet been found.

abstract: The sales of Cotton for three days were 41,000 bales. The market opened buoyant with an advance of 1/4d.@1/2d. lb., but subsequently gave way, and closed with a downward tendency, quotations being hardly maintained.
lead_paragraph: The sales of Cotton for three days were 41,000 bales. The market opened buoyant with an advance of 1/4d.@1/2d. lb., but subsequently gave way, and closed with a downward tendency, quotations being hardly maintained.

abstract: Shortly after midnight on Saturday, officer MCFARLAND, of the 45th Precinct, found an intelligent-looking young woman at the foot of South Seventh street, E.D., in a stupified state. On taking her to the station house, a half-ounce phial, labeled "JULIUS HUPFEED, druggist and chemist, 94, South Seventh street -- laudanum -- poison" was found upon her person. It being evident that the young girl had attempted self-destruction, Dr. NORTH was sent for, the officers meanwhile using every effort to keepher awake. When the Dr. arrived be gaveher emetics, and used his skill successfully in restoring her to consciousness. During then ight the officers of the precinct were unremitting in their attentions to the unfortunate girl, and her life is now probably out of danger. Her name is HENRIETTA FTRNGN, and her parents reside in Lorimer street, near Devoe. Since the age of fifteen she has been a source of trouble le to her father on account of her irregular life, but she now promises to be good, if allowed the protection of her family, which it is understood she will get.
